column2: D'Brickashaw Ferguson Articles, Photos, and Videos
column3:
Ashley Sims remembers returning to his hometown of Rochester, N.Y. during one of his breaks from the University of Maryland football team, going to his old hangout spot at the neighborhood basketball courts and instantly getting mesmerized by the youngster tearing up the competition.

He vividly remembers turning to one of his buddies and asking "who is this fat kid dribbling down the basketball court like a point guard?"

"The kid is taking it coast-to-coast, dribbling through his legs. He's going hard!" Sims recalls. "Then they tell me 'Yo, that's your little brother.' "

Sims couldn't believe the chubby 10-year-old putting on a showcase...

column2: Tom Brady
column3:
Before New England played the AFC Championship Game against Jacksonville, the question was if Tom Brady could play with an injured hand. St. Thomas Aquinas legend George Smith texted his former player, Patriots running back James White.

“If Brady can’t go … Wild White.”

“LOL,” White texted back.

In 2009, when the Dolphins were running the Wildcat, St. Thomas had a backfield of future NFL running backs in White and Giovanni Bernard. But Bernard got hurt. One of the schemes Smith played with was to run White as the “Wildcat.’’ The Wild White, they called it.

It wasn’t needed that game. The St. Thomas alums – and near-alum, in defensive coordinator Matt Patricia’s...

column2: Tom Brady
column3:
Tom Brady labeled the Miami Dolphins “bad guys forever” in the latest episode of his Facebook documentary, “Tom vs. Time.”

Brady, the New England Patriots’ five-time Super Bowl winning quarterback, was at home talking to his five-year-old daughter, Vivian, in what appears to be a family room shortly before she goes to bed.

She’s wearing pajamas and a Santa Claus hat. And the way it’s presented in the episode it could be the night of Nov. 26, hours after New England’s 35-17 victory over the Dolphins at Gillette Stadium.

“Sometimes the Dolphins win,” Vivian says while standing in front of her father as he sits in a chair, “sometimes Patriots win.”

“Uh, huh,” Brady...

column2: Tom Brady
column3:
About 30 minutes before kickoff of Super Bowl LII, former Philadelphia Eagles running back Brian Westbrook appeared on the U.S. Bank Stadium big screen and led the team’s boisterous faithful in a thunderous version of “Fly, Eagles, Fly.”

Before the New England Patriots got the ball for the first time, “Gonna Fly Now,” the theme from the movie “Rocky” blared.

And when the game ended Sunday, the Eagles, their fans and the city of Philadelphia were soaring.

Nick Foles, who began the season as a backup, passed for 373 yards and three touchdowns – and also caught a touchdown pass -- as the Eagles defeated the Patriots, 41-33, before a crowd of 67,612.

Foles, who stepped...

column2: Tom Brady
column3:
There was this, dare I say, touching scene in ESPN’s bill-umentary this week on coaching legends Bill Parcells and Bill Belichick that divulged the high stakes of Sunday’s Super Bowl.

Belichick, who coaches his record eighth Super Bowl on Sunday, surveys his old New York Giants work space and does something remarkable for someone so shrewd and ruthless. He tears up. He actually — sniff — pauses and wipes his eye.

“I’m sorry, a lot of memories in here,” he said.

There also was, dare I double-say, another touching moment this past week...

column2: The massacre that quashed a settlement
column3:
In January 1836, William Cooley and his family were among the 60 or 70 pioneers who lived in what was called the New River Settlement.

Historians place Cooley's farm along the river about where Southwest Seventh Avenue in Fort Lauderdale runs today. Besides a farmer, he was also a justice of the peace.

When a group of settlers murdered a Creek Indian chief, he had them arrested and sent to Key West, the county seat, for trial. But the court dropped charges.

The Indians believed Cooley withheld evidence that could have convicted the killer. When Cooley and others were salvaging a shipwreck on the coast, about 20 Creeks raided his home. They killed his wife, three children and the children's tutor.

The remaining pioneers quickly abandoned the settlement. Three years later, Army Maj. William Lauderdale arrived with troops. But it would be 50 years before any settlers returned to the New River.

Danish Siddiqui, REUTERS School girls offer prayer after a performance of Bharatnatyam, an Indian classical dance, on the occasion of Mahashivratri festival in Thiruvananthapuram, capital of the southern Indian state of Kerala February 20, 2012. column2: Away down south . . . on Old Dixie Highway
column3:
Before the infuriating slowness that is U.S. 1, before the madness that is Interstate 95, there was Dixie Highway. Or "Old" Dixie Highway as it was known in some parts.

In 1915, when it was completed, it was the only "real" highway in Broward County. Actually, it was a network of existing and newly-constructed roads paid for by private subscriptions and some government assistance.

Parts were paved with brick; other sections were made of crushed rock or shell. In the mid-'20s, government funds helped pave some portions with asphalt. The route was identified by signs bearing the red letters "DH" painted on utility poles.

Dixie Highway typically followed the coastal ridge, and hewed close to the Florida East Coast Railway — though it sometimes "jumped the track."

And even into the 1940s, it was said, you could still play marbles in the middle of the road.

Broward historian Susan Gillis contributed to this report

rnolin@tribune.com or 954-356-4525

column2: Right on, Debbie Wasserman Schultz
column3:
Authors of recent letters to the editor just don't seem to get it regarding Debbie Wasserman Schultz and Hobby Lobby.

An employer should never have the right, by virtue of religious belief, to dictate what part of his employee's health coverage he is willing to cover. However, that does put Wasserman Schultz, a sizable number of Americans and me at odds with the John Roberts-led Supreme Court.

This is the court that believes the Founding Fathers intended for corporations to have the rights of individual citizens under the constitution. But once a corporation injects its religious or political beliefs into the workplace, customers have the right to take their business elsewhere. Go, Debbie, go.

J. Raymond Pedersen, Plantation

column2: Barbara Sharief, member, Broward County Commission
Gangsters also enjoyed Broward's sunny climate
column3:
Lots of people wanted to escape the cold of New York, Chicago and Detroit, so why should mobsters be any different?

During the 1930s and continuing past World War II, Meyer Lansky and his brother Jake ran posh gambling houses in Hallandale Beach and Hollywood.

When Teamsters boss Jimmy Hoffa disappeared in 1975, Anthony Provenzano, an alleged capo in the Genovese crime family, held an impromptu news conference outside his home in Hallandale Beach's Golden Isles neighborhood to deny having anything to do with it. Philadelphia boss Nicodemo Scarfo kept a four-bedroom, waterfront home in Fort Lauderdale, where he tied up his 40-foot yacht Casablanca.

At Fort Lauderdale's Galt Ocean Mile in the 1970s and 80s, FBI agents conducted surveillance on the comings and goings of Gus Alex, a high-ranking member of the Chicago mob. When the FBI arrested Chicago mob boss Sam Carlisi in 1992, he was about to board a plane to return to his home in Weston.

When the FBI arrested Nicholas Corozzo, then-head of the Gambino family, in 1996, they charged him with supervising a loan-sharking operation out of a check-cashing store in Deerfield Beach.

column2: People on the Move
column3:
Promotions, hires and recognition at South Florida employers.

Culinary

Angel León was appointed executive chef of Modern Garden, a hot stone and crudo lounge, in Miami, owned by Carlos and Maryam Miranda. In addition, Chef León will oversee their other venue, Seasalt and Pepper, a seafood brasserie that opened in Miami about a year ago.

Finance

George Bermudez has been named business banking market executive for Bank of America Merrill Lynch for Miami-Dade County. Most recently, he was senior vice president and head of corporate, commercial Lending at U.S. Century Bank.

Gregory Santín was appointed vice president, relationship manager, specializing in commercial real estate lending in South Florida, for BankUnited in Miami Lakes. He most recently was vice president, credit risk officer with BNY Mellon in Miami. Additionally LeeAnn Robinson was named affordable housing lending manager for BankUnited in Miami Lakes, joining from Neighborhood Housing Services of South Florida, where she was chief operating officer of the nonprofit organization.

Construction

Guy Gruenberg has joined All County Paving as chief opertaing officer. The family-owned business recently moved to new headquarters in Delray Beach and announced additional hires. They include Tony Grout, vice president of project management; sales staff Mike Ridgway, Nick Kahn, Jeff Eagle, Daniel Leavitt, Erick Mendoza; Luis Mendez, project manager; Kristy Blonsky, marketing specialist; Shannon Scalpi, production assistant; Tammy Lytle, project coordinator; Matt Barron, production scheduler; and Diane Weber, human resources, office manager.

Sun Sentinel Handout photo provided by: Michele Merrell/Courtesy ID: Michele Merrell slug: fl-people-on-the-move-1207 Michele Merrell is the recipient of the Florida Achievement Award from the Florida Commission on the Status of Women. Michele is the vice president of global marketing and communications for Modcomp Systems & Solutions in Deerfield Beach, and is also the president of her own consulting company, Merrell Consulting Group.The award recognizes meritorious women and men who have improved the lives of Florida women, as well as those who have served as positive role models for women and girls in their community. Michele was recognized at the annual National Commission on the Status of Women meeting held in Sarasota, Florida. Handout photo provided by: Michele Merrell/Courtesy ID: Michele Merrell slug: fl-people-on-the-move-1207 Michele Merrell is the recipient of the Florida Achievement Award from the Florida Commission on the Status of Women. Michele is the vice president of global marketing and communications for Modcomp Systems & Solutions in Deerfield Beach, and is also the president of her own consulting company, Merrell Consulting Group.The award recognizes meritorious women and men who have improved the lives of Florida women, as well as those who have served as positive role models for women and girls in their community. Michele was recognized at the annual National Commission on the Status of Women meeting held in Sarasota, Florida. (Sun Sentinel)

Engineering

Nancy Ziegler, a former FDOT District 4 official, has joined Marlin Engineering Inc. as senior vice president and chief operating officer.

Law

Stuart Z. Grossman, Grossman Roth P.A., was a recent recipient of the Florida Justice Association's 2014 Perry Nichols Award, presented to an individual who has fought valiantly for justice throughout their lives.Grossman is a Miami resident working at the firm he co-founded, with offices in Boca Raton. In addition, Grossman is involved withMargaux's Miracle Foundation at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, United Cerebral Palsy and United Way.

Automotive

Ryan Masonwas promoted to general manager at Manheim Fort Lauderdale, a wholesale auto auction in Davie. Headquartered in Atlanta, Manheim has more than 20,000 employees in 121 worldwide sites. Mason joined Manheim in 1998 as a management trainee at Manheim Lakeland and has worked as assistant general manager, factory manager, vehicle inspection manager and vehicle registration supervisor at Manheim Atlanta.Mason comes to Fort Lauderdale from Manheim Darlington, where he has been general manager since 2011.

Nonprofits

Barbara Barlarge was appointed to the Schoolhouse Children's Museum's board of directors. She was also named chairwoman of the Reunion Bash, a fundraiser to benefit the Museum.

Trudy Crowetz was appointed senior vice president of finance of operations for the United Way of Palm Beach County. Most recently she was the chief financial officer of the Boys & Girls Clubs of Palm Beach County.

Jeremy Lurie joined Ruth & Norman Rales Jewish Family Services as director of communications.Most recently, Lurie was marketing director for Boca Cosmetics Group.

Recognition

Julie Ruffolo, managing partner of ADEPT Strategy & Public Relations, was honored with the 2014 Rosa Parks Diversity Leadership Award by the South Florida chapter of Advancing Women in Transportation.The WTS Diversity Leadership Award recognizes astute organizations, companies and innovative individuals that are broadening their multicultural initiatives, changing corporate cultures and philosophies.Ruffolo is a member of Broward League of Cities, the Advancing Women in Transportation, the National Association of Professional Women, the Riverwalk Trust, Envision Uptown Inc., the Historic Stranahan House Museum and the Fort Lauderdale Chamber of Commerce. In addition, Diana Alarcon,director of the ciity of Fort Lauderdale's Transportation and Mobility Department,accepted the WTS2014 Employer of the Year Award on behalf of the city of Fort Lauderdale, an award honoring businesses or agenciesfor their support of the goals and purpose of WTS. NataliaT. Lercari, associate, project manager and traffic section leaderwith McMahon Associates Inc., was honored with the WTS 2014 Member of the Year Award. Robyn Chiarelli, executive director of the Downtown Fort Lauderdale Transportation Management Association, was awarded WTS 2014 Woman of the Year.

Kim Stone, Miami Heat's American Airlines Arena executive vice president and general manager, was recently inducted into the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill School of Journalism and Mass Communication's Halls of Fame for Journalism, Advertising and Public Relations. An alumnus, Stone was recognized for her work in public relations, developing and implementing sound business strategies and management practices, including making the American Airlines Arena the first existing arena in the United States to earn the prestigious LEED certification from the US Green Building Council. Before joining the Heat, Stone was the sports publicity director for the University of Texas women's athletics department from 1992-94. Stone is a board member of Miami Downtown Development Authority, UM's Alumni Association, the Beacon Council's Executive Committee, Save Dade, and is the secretary/treasurer of the Florida Facility Managers Association.

Kaye Chong, Caribbean travel industry veteran, and Paul Brock, communications leader, received the 2014 Caribbean Media Exchange Leadership Awards at the second annual Evenings of Excellence series, sponsored by Wells Fargo Home Mortgage, at Christian Cultural Center in Brooklyn, in New York City, in recognition of their commitment to the development and promotion of tourism in the Caribbean region. Originally from Jamaica, the South Florida-based Chong is an account executive with Caribbean Airlines. Brock, founding executive director of the National Association of Black Journalists, launched his broadcast career in the Virgin Islands.

column2: Oscar nominations 2014: Laying odds on the six major races
column3:
We won't have to wait long to see what kind of final decisions Oscar voters will be making out of Thursday's Oscar nominations. This weekend brings the Screen Actors Guild and Producers Guild awards, with the Directors Guild following on Jan. 25. Those awards will give us plenty of concrete clues about where the most contentious contests -- picture, actor, supporting actress, director -- might be headed.

Meanwhile, Cate Blanchett and Jared Leto can likely work on some new material for their anticipated acceptance speeches. And that screenwriter who recently told "The Wolf of Wall Street" director Martin Scorsese that he should be ashamed of himself ... well, he's probably not all that happy right about now.

Here's an early peek at how the major Oscar races look for the long haul this morning:

PICTURE

"American Hustle," 2-1

"12 Years a Slave," 4-1

"Gravity," 9-2

"The Wolf of Wall Street," 15-1

"Nebraska," 15-1

"Dallas Buyers Club," 25-1

"Her," 30-1

"Captain Phillips," 40-1

"Philomena," 50-1

Analysis: This race might be over and done when the Producers Guild hands out its trophies Sunday. The PGA winner has matched the academy's pick six years running, largely because the guild uses the same preferential ballot (with voters ranking their choices) that the academy employs. If "American Hustle" wins the PGA, it will confirm what many have suspected for the last several weeks: A fizzy throwback trumps a harrowing history lesson, simply because it has a broader appeal. More voters are likely to place "Hustle" higher on their ballots than "12 Years a Slave." Entertainment over art.

Fox Searchlight can certainly counter this by appealing to voters' consciences, highlighting the way that "12 Years" tackled an important subject in an uncompromising fashion. The film's three acting nominations indicate support among the academy's biggest branch; a SAG ensemble win Saturday would help hammer that point home.

"Gravity," with 10 nominations, remains a viable alternative, though one suspects the film will be rewarded much in the same way "Life of Pi" was last year. "Gravity" will likely win the two sound categories, visual effects, original score and cinematography. And director Alfonso Cuaron stands as the front-runner for director. Five Oscars would be a satisfying haul.

ACTOR

Matthew McConaughey, "Dallas Buyers Club," 2-1

Chiwetel Ejiofor, "12 Years a Slave," 4-1

Bruce Dern, "Nebraska," 6-1

Leonardo DiCaprio, "The Wolf of Wall Street," 8-1

Christian Bale, "American Hustle," 20-1

Analysis: The year's most competitive category has started to tilt toward McConaughey, particularly as it has become increasingly apparent that "Dallas Buyers Club" has strong support throughout the academy, not just the actors branch. McConaughey's profile has also been helped by his fantastic, five-minute supporting turn as DiCaprio's mentor in "The Wolf of Wall Street," a performance that really sets the tone for the three hours to follow. (Money chant!) Add to that "True Detective," the smart, subtle HBO mystery miniseries that pairs McConaughey and Woody Harrelson, and the McConaissance is complete and unassailable. It feels like his moment and then some.

ACTRESS

Cate Blanchett, "Blue Jasmine," 2-1

Sandra Bullock, "Gravity," 10-1

Amy Adams, "American Hustle," 20-1

Judi Dench, "Philomena," 25-1

column2: Orlando hotel occupancy highest since June 2005
column3:
Orlando's hotel industry has been having a strong year as evidenced by solid occupancy rates and average daily room rates that are generally higher than last year's.

But Visit Orlando, the region's chief tourism-marketing agency, points out that June's average occupancy rate of 75.4 percent was the best for that month in almost a decade.

The last time June occupancy was above 75.4 percent was 2005, when the average occupancy rate was 76.5 percent.

Those were some fat times. Unemployment in Metro Orlando was 3.7 percent, and the median home value was $218,000, compared with today's $165,000. People were feeling pretty good.

So far this year, occupancy rates have averaged almost 77 percent, up 4 percentage points from the first half of 2013, according to Visit Orlando. The agency said recent data also suggests that advance bookings for the back half of the year are running almost 5 percent ahead of this time last year.

Metro Orlando has about 450 hotel properties, according to Visit Orlando, and about 118,000 rooms.

Haunted Mansion shop to open

A new Haunted Mansion-themed shop will open this fall at Walt Disney World's Magic Kingdom. It will open at the site of the Yankee Trader shop, which closed last month.

Disney is introducing about 100 products based on the attraction. The items will include striped shirts resembling the ones that ride employees wear. Men's shirts will cost $24.95 and women's will cost $32.95. The store also will sell $39.95 bookends and $29.95 cake toppers. The Disney Parks online store will sell some of the items this fall as well.

It will be the first time Disney has created a Haunted Mansion-themed shop for visitors, though it has sold some items in a kiosk and merchandise cart near the ride.

Earnings reports on the way

Walt Disney Co. will report earnings Tuesday, followed by Orlando-based SeaWorld Entertainment Inc. the following week.

Disney will announce results for its third quarter a little after 4 p.m. Tuesday.

Comcast Corp., which announced earnings last month, has set a high bar. Higher attendance and per-capita spending at Universal Orlando and Comcast Corp.'s other theme parks drove a 12.8 percent year-over-year jump in revenue for the properties.

2 eateries ready at I-Drive 360

Two new restaurants are ready to go at the I-Drive 360 complex under construction on International Drive.

Carrabba's Italian Grill and Outback Steakhouse are scheduled to open today at 11 a.m.

The new Carrabba's is 7,800 square feet and features a design that mixes traditional and contemporary touches. It includes an open kitchen, a bar and patio seating.

The restaurant says it has hired almost 120 local residents. It will donate 50 percent of its opening-day sales — up to $5,000 — to the nearby YMCA Aquatic Center.

Outback is donating half of its opening-day sales — also up to $5,000 — to Give Kids the World, the Kissimmee-based nonprofit organization that hosts seriously ill children and their families when they vacation in Central Florida.

Carrabba's and Outback join the Yard House restaurant, which opened in April.

I-Drive 360, a $200 million project, will be anchored by the Orlando Eye, a 400-foot-tall observation wheel under construction. The complex also will include an aquarium and Madame Tussauds wax museum.

The Eye is expected to open in the spring of 2015.

Euro Disney gets new president

Tom Wolber, senior vice president of Walt Disney World resort and transportation operations, has been named president of Euro Disney S.A.S., the management company of Disneyland Paris.

Wolber oversaw all of the 28 resort hotels at Walt Disney World and the property's extensive transportation network. He had been in that position only a few months. He was appointed in March as part of a shakeup of the hotel and transportation divisions.

Wolber also has overseen a number of complex expansion projects, including the launch of the Disney Dream and Disney Fantasy cruise ships.

He was instrumental in the Disney Springs master plan and the continued growth of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts' sports business.

Wolber helped open Disneyland Paris in 1992.

The appointment is effective in September. He is replacing Philippe Gas, who is moving to become general manager of Shanghai Disney Resort.

"One of our greatest assets is the global strength of our teams," said Tom Staggs, chairman of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts, in a statement. "Both Philippe and Tom are seasoned Disney veterans with a tremendous combination of leadership skills, business acumen, and international experience that will help ensure that we carry on our legacy of creating unforgettable experiences for our guests. They bring an incredible depth of operational experience to their respective roles and are well positioned to contribute to the future success of Shanghai Disney Resort and Disneyland Paris."

jstratton@tribune.com or 407-420-5379; spedicini@tribune.com or 407-420-5240

column2: Comités Olímpicos europeos reciben amenazas terroristas antes de Sochi
column3:
LIUBLIANA/BERLIN/ROMA, 22 ene (Reuters) - Los comités olímpicos de Eslovenia, Hungría, Alemania e Italia recibieron amenazas terroristas por carta y vía correo electrónico relacionadas con los próximos Juegos Olímpicos de Invierno en Sochi, dijeron el miércoles autoridades.

El Comité Olímpico Italiano dijo el miércoles en un comunicado que recibió un correo electrónico con "amenazas terroristas" sobre el evento que se llevará a cabo el mes que viene en la ciudad rusa y que envió su contenido a las autoridades a cargo de la seguridad.

Por su parte, el Comité Olímpico Alemán manifestó que también recibió un correo electrónico con amenazas y que fue enviado a las autoridades germanas.

"Estamos en cercano contacto con las autoridades alemanas relevantes", dijo el portavoz del comité germano Christian Klaue a Reuters en un correo electrónico.

Horas antes, el Comité Olímpico Esloveno informó que había recibido una carta con una amenaza terrorista sobre los Juegos en Sochi.

"El comité ha recibido una carta con una amenaza terrorista escrita en ruso. La hemos traducido y entregado a la policía", dijo a Reuters el portavoz de la entidad eslovena Brane Dmitrovic.

En tanto, el Comité Olímpico Húngaro también notificó que había recibido una carta, pero luego dijo que la amenaza contra sus atletas fue analizada y declarada no peligrosa.

El director de Relaciones Internacionales del comité, Zsigmond Nagy, dijo a Reuters en una entrevista que la carta fue enviada al Comité Olímpico Internacional (COI) y a los organizadores de los Juegos, que la analizaron.

"Tanto el COI como el comité organizador de Sochi (…) declararon oficialmente tras el análisis de la carta que esta amenaza no es real, y que esta persona ha enviado todo tipo de mensajes a varios miembros de la familia olímpica", dijo Nagy.

column2: Putin, vestido de esquiador, inicia inspecciones para Sochi 2014
column3:
MOSCU, 3 ene (Reuters) - El presidente de Rusia, Vladimir Putin, comenzó a inspeccionar el viernes los recintos donde se realizarán los Juegos Olímpicos de Invierno en el centro turístico de Sochi, cinco semanas antes del inicio de un evento que ha sido criticado por grupos de derechos humanos y que ha generado preocupaciones de seguridad.

En imágenes difundidas por el canal de televisión estatal Rossiya-24, Putin, de 61 años, fue mostrado esquiando con lentes oscuros y casco.

En el lugar, el mandatario y el primer ministro Dmitry Medvedev se reunieron con sorprendidos atletas e inspeccionaron hoteles.

Un portavoz afirmó que Putin inspeccionará todos los recintos olímpicos "en detalle" durante los próximos días y que observará un ensayo de la ceremonia de apertura.

El éxito o fracaso de los Juegos será gran parte del legado de Putin, quien se ha identificado estrechamente con el proyecto de 50.000 millones de dólares desde que viajó a Guatemala en el 2007 para persuadir a los dirigentes olímpicos a otorgar a Sochi la organización de los Juegos de Invierno.

Los preparativos para el evento han estado marcados por problemas recientes. Dos atentados con bomba acabaron con la vida de 34 personas esta semana en Volgogrado, a unos 700 kilómetros al noreste de Sochi, destacando la amenaza de insurgentes islamistas que han prometido interrumpir los Juegos.

El Comité Olímpico Internacional (COI) ha dicho que no le cabe dudas de que las autoridades rusas podrán entregar seguridad.

Moscú ha recibido fuertes críticas por su historial de derechos humanos y por una ley que prohíbe la difusión de "propaganda homosexual" entre menores, algo que activistas y gobiernos occidentales afirman que viola las libertades básicas.

En una medida para mitigar las críticas antes de los Juegos, Putin dejó en libertad el mes pasado a través de una amnistía a varios de los presos más conocidos del país: el ex magnate petrolero Mikhail Khodorkovsky y a dos miembros del grupo punk femenino Pussy Riot. (Reporte de Vladimir Soldatkin. Traducido por Patricio Abusleme)

column2: John Lurie re-emerges with 'Invention of Animals'
column3:
Looking back from the fragmented media landscape of 2014, it's hard to imagine someone like John Lurie was ever possible.

An immediately recognizable character actor who appeared in landmark indie films including Jim Jarmusch's "Down by Law" and "Stranger Than Paradise," Lurie was also a brilliant saxophonist who helped push the boundaries of jazz in the '80s and '90s with his band, the Lounge Lizards.

But Lurie was forced to give up music and acting after being stricken with advanced Lyme disease and has since switched to painting (his work has been exhibited numerous times and was collected in a 2007 book, "A Fine Example of Art").

PHOTOS: Best jazz albums of 2013 | Chris Barton

Lurie's low profile in recent years is also because of significant trouble with a stalker — a situation that was examined in a 2010 New Yorker profile (the facts of which Lurie has vigorously disputed).

Still, he recently ventured back into the public eye with "The Invention of Animals," a new set of live tracks and rarities by the John Lurie National Orchestra, his trio with drummers Calvin Weston and Billy Martin of Medeski Martin and Wood. Here, The Times catches up with Lurie with an email exchange.

You were diagnosed with advanced Lyme disease in 2004 and have fought health problems relating to it as far back as 2000. How's your health these days?

My health is pretty good these days, but then out of nowhere I get whacked with it from time to time. For an hour or a day or for three weeks. But I am so much better than I was. When it comes back, I am astonished at how hideous it is and that I lived with it for years. There is always something going on with it, and it is nuts because the symptoms migrate, but I am pretty adept at living with it now.

I swim and paint every day, which I never thought would be possible 10 years ago.

PHOTOS: Faces to watch 2014 | Pop music & jazz

Does it still prevent you from playing any music at all? Is there any chance of improvement?

I can play the guitar. I can play the harmonica. But I don't so much. All of my creative energy goes to painting now.

If I play, I start to get ideas. Then I want to actualize the ideas. But then I would need to ... [do] all that other unpleasant stuff that goes around making a musical idea into something people can listen to — this I am not prepared to deal with. So ideas have to be stopped at all costs.

Given the breadth of your recordings, this trio is an interesting choice to revisit with "The Invention of Animals." What inspired you to come back to that project?

My hero assistant Nesrin wanted to hear music of mine she hadn't heard yet. I remembered that trio concert in Thessaloniki [Greece] to be something special and I put on the tape for her. I was shocked by the power of it. It was like standing inside a waterfall. So when Billy wanted to rerelease the "Men With Sticks" record on his label, I thought — no, let's put this other stuff out instead.

INTERACTIVE: Times music staff best of 2013 list

I read where Billy Martin talked about an idea you guys shared that this music is like "a field recording from a lost civilization." I hear a lot of African and tribal-sounding rhythms there — was this band put together to delve deeper into that style?

I don't hear this as so African sounding. To me it seems to fall somewhere between Ravi Shankar and Coltrane. And please, I don't need 9,000 angry bloggers saying, "John Lurie thinks he is Coltrane" — I am just saying stylistically that is the terrain that it falls in for me. Though that wasn't the intention when we did it, I am just hearing that now on revisiting it.

It seems strange now, but a lot of pains were taken by some in the '80s and '90s to place your music outside jazz (the terms "punk-jazz," "no-wave" and whatnot). Did that bother you? Or did you appreciate that divide?

You know, partly I think it was the humor. And partly it was that I was in movies. And we did start out as a punk jazz band and, almost unfortunately, we got a lot of attention. As the music became more serious and more elegant, more beautiful, I think those people you speak of refused to look at it. They thought they already knew what it was and it was no good. At the time, it did bother me because it would have opened some doors for us.

CRITICS' PICKS: What to watch, where to go, what to eat

Being a percussion and saxophone trio, this project is a real showcase for your playing, which to me still sounds like nobody else. As you guys were coming together, was there a sense of finding something new here?

It allowed me to play and concentrate on the playing without all the headaches that go with running a nine-piece band. ("What do you mean you forgot your passport?")

Is there an archive of material from the Lounge Lizards or Marvin Pontiac that could also see release?

Yes, that is possible.

GRAPHIC: Faces to watch 2014 | Entertainment

To broach an uncomfortable subject, your safety seemed very much in doubt years ago. Given you're a bit more in the public eye of late, has that situation improved?

The situation is in no way resolved. It still is altering my life. I am kind of used to it at this point.

You — and many who know you —- were very vocal about being misrepresented in that New Yorker piece, to the point where I'm a bit surprised you're willing to do any press at all. Is there anything you've never gotten a chance to clarify from that time that you'd like to now?

I would very much like to address the horrors of that New Yorker article and the incredible damage that it needlessly did to my life but can't imagine you have room for that here.

What one would hope is that the beauty in the music and in the paintings can somehow transcend and invalidate the kind of sickness that led to the article being written as it was and the kind of irresponsibility that allowed it to be published.

column2: Construction workers in growing demand
column3:
As South Florida's construction business rebounds after years on its knees, Delray Beach-based Meisner Electric is looking to beef up its workforce. Currently it employs 200 electricians – average age is 40 -- and with new projects on the horizon, more will be needed.

That's easier said than done, according to Doug Hutchison, the company's chief financial officer. Turns out there just aren't that many young people who want to be electricians, or carpenters, or concrete finishers, or heavy equipment operators.

"Young people would rather run a mouse than a backhoe," Hutchison said. "Construction is dirty, demanding and dangerous. They're going to sweat and it's demanding because we work on deadlines and schedules."

A growing shortage of young construction workers is occurring as new projects gain steam.

To ensure they'll have the manpower, contractors and trade associations are creating new training and apprenticeship programs and expanding existing ones.

"Right now the supply is falling short of demand," said Andy Allen, project director in South Florida for Skanska USA, one of the state's largest building and heavy civil construction firms.

Skanska is paying 10 percent more than last year for skilled tradesmen, especially plumbers, electricians, carpenters and sheet-metal workers, Allen said.

Construction employment in Broward rose by 2.3 percent to 35,400 and in Palm Beach County by 9.5 percent to 30,000 in September over a year ago. Miami-Dade County, with its boom in condominium construction, increased by 12.8 percent to about 39,600 construction jobs in September.

And the construction sector is expected to be the South Florida metro region's fastest-growing industry, with employment expanding an average of 10 percent annually, according to University of Central Florida economist Sean Snaith.

In a survey released in October by The Associated General Contractors, 46 percent of Florida contractors said they were having difficulty filling skilled trade positions and more than 80 percent rated the pipeline for training available as "poor" or "below average."

Allen said his firm often has to hire two workers instead of one to complete a job, such as installing electric conduits, on schedule.

"A lot of people who are coming into [the industry] just don't have that base of experience or training," Allen said.

Many construction workers left South Florida because work dwindled during the recession and housing crisis. Some took jobs in the oil industry while others drifted into other fields altogether.

And as demand shriveled, so did the training and apprenticeship programs that employers depended upon to turn out new generations of workers.

The Associated General Contractors Florida East Coast Chapter shut down its training program during the housing bust because so many skilled trade workers were thrown out of work and weren't available to serve as mentors, said Michelle Anaya DePotter, the chapter's executive director. Apprentices need hands-on work, and there just wasn't enough available.

But recently, the AGC chapter partnered with Florida Training Services to bring back Palm Beach County's apprenticeship program. Florida Training Services offers training in iron work, painting, glazing, sheet-metal work and other trades.

Ernesto Jurarez knows the value of training programs. In 2010, Jurarez enrolled at ABC Institute, the training arm of Associated Builders and Contractors in Coconut Creek, and learned advanced skills in heating, ventilation and air conditioning.

Today, Juarez runs his own business, Innovative Cooling Technologies in Fort Lauderdale, and teaches part-time at ABC Institute. When he needs new workers for his own company, he hires his best students. After all, he's well-acquainted with their teacher.

"I teach them what needs to be done, the right way," Juarez said.

The institute currently is training 370 people for construction jobs. That's up from 280 a year ago but still well below the 1,528 enrolled at the height of the construction boom a decade ago, said Ruth Tirado, vice president of training and education.

Some companies are investing in their employees by covering tuition for training programs and paying them to log on-the-job training.

Meisner Electric in Delray Beach sponsors 21 apprentices at the institute and at Florida Electrical Apprenticeship Association in West Palm Beach, said Doug Hutchison, Meisner Electric's chief financial officer.

Meisner had scaled back to about 200 electricians when business fell off in 2010. But with new projects in the pipeline, it needs more qualified workers.

Meisner's apprentices go to night school for four years while working for Meisner during the day. Then they are required to pass a state test to obtain their journeyman's license.

"They want a really good career and a good-paying job," Hutchison said.

Once licensed, an electrical journeyman's average wage is $20 to $25 an hour, he said. Those workers can advance into supervisory positions, which can further increase their pay.

For those who like to work with their hands, it can be "engaging and exciting work," he said.

mpounds@sunsentinel.com or 561-243-6650

column2: Retail Notebook: Apura coffeehouse opens in Boca Raton
column3:
A roundup of the week's retail news.

Apura Juicery & Coffeehouse is now open in Boca Raton.

The new healthy-eating restaurant is at 22191 Powerline Road, Suite 20B and serves cold-pressed juices, cold-brewed coffee and whole, plant-based food.

Menu items are prepared using natural ingredients, free of dairy, GMOs, soy and gluten, and with "little to no processing or preservatives," Apura says. Food options include chia pudding, specialty salads, crispy nachos and guacamole.

Bottled juices are made from fruits, sweet roots and vegetables.

The restaurant follows the "made with intention" philosophy of its founder, with drinks and food prepared by hand daily in house.

John Gilmore/Courtesy John Gilmore/Courtesy

"I want people to understand the link between what they eat and how they feel," said Apura's founder, Susan Mussaffi.

Greek restaurant opens in Boca Raton

Gyroroom, serving Mediterranean cuisine, has opened at 20449 State Road 7 in Boca Raton.

The menu includes pita bread wraps, gyro platters and side dishes such as grape leaves. Beef, lamb, fish and vegetable dishes are also available. Gyroroom says it uses local and imported Greek products.

Stein Mart/Courtesy Stein Mart/Courtesy

The eatery will celebrate its grand opening Dec. 11 with complimentary hors d'oeuvres, gift certificate giveaways, half off wine and beer.

Retailer opens in Delray Beach

Discount retailer Stein Mart has a new store in Delray Beach.

Stein Mart sells brand name apparel, shoes and accessories for men and women at up to 60 percent below department store prices. The retailer also stocks home décor, linens and pet care products.

The new 33,000-square-foot store will open at Delray Place, a new shopping at the southeast corner of Federal Highway and Linton Boulevard. The new shopping plaza is also home to a Trader Joe's grocery store.

The Jacksonville-based retailer says the Delray Beach shop is part of the company's largest store expansion since 2007. In May, another Stein Mart opened in Aventura in Miami-Dade County at a space vacated by fashion retailer Loehmann's.

The South Florida locations were chosen as part of a national growth strategy to increase store counts in key markets, Stein Mart said.

The Delray Beach store is the retailer's ninth store in South Florida.

Restaurant opening in Plantation

Brio Tuscan Grille is opening a restaurant Thursday at Westfield Broward Mall in Plantation.

Brio's menu offers options such as gorgonzola crusted beef medallions, lobster and shrimp fettuccine, strawberry balsamic chicken salad and flatbreads.

The restaurant is at 499 S. University Dr.

Burger restaurant opens in Jupiter

BurgerFi has opened a new eatery in Jupiter at Harbourside Place.

The burger joint offers made-to-order, all natural, hormone-free Angus burgers, hot dogs, fries, frozen custard and craft beer.

The Jupiter restaurant is the 63rd in the nation for the chain that started in Fort Lauderdale in 2011. The new eatery is near the outdoor amphitheater at Harbourside Place, a new development of retail, restaurants, entertainment, office and hotel space.

Send updates of retail and restaurant openings and closings to mvalverde@sunsentinel.com, 954-356-4526 or Twitter @MiriamValverde

column2: Florida Bar warns attorneys of hotel scam
column3:
Here’s a ‘man bites dog’ item: The Florida Bar, the state’s professional organization for lawyers, says attorneys are the target of a scam.

I’ve written a lot about lawyers in Florida over the years, and usually it’s the lawyers warning consumers about scams.

This time the bar says there’s a “booking scam” for attorneys who are attending their 2014 Annual Convention on June 25-28. The convention is at the Gaylord Palms Resort near Kissimmee, and apparently someone is contacting attorneys about booking them into the resort.

“It has come to The Florida Bar's attention that housing companies going by the names National Travel Associates, Exhibition Housing Management, Exhibition Housing Services, (and) Global Travel Partners (USA) are claiming to have a relationship with Gaylord Palms Resort and are offering hotel reservation services for The Florida Bar's 2014 Annual Convention,” the Bar said. “These companies, and others like them, are NOT in any way affiliated with The Florida Bar or the Gaylord Palms and should NOT be used to make hotel reservations.”

According to the Bar, the only official agent for rooms at the resort is the Gaylord Palms itself, which does not make phone calls to exhibitors or attendees encouraging them to book with them.

Atttorneys are encouraged to book rooms through a special website set up by the Bar and the resort.

column2: Gardening: July plant of the month is beautyberry
column3:
July's plant of the month is Callicarpa americana, known as beautyberry. It is an all-you-can-eat buffet for butterflies and birds.

This Florida native shrub produces delicate lilac blooms that attract butterflies through August. In the fall, it's a feast for birds, as pea-sized, magenta-colored berries ripen in dense clusters along the length of weeping branches.

Beautyberry is a rambler with an informal look. Spring and summer green foliage has ovate leaves with serrated edges growing 4 to 8 inches. In fall, leaves turn yellow. The plant is deciduous, dropping its leaves in winter.

Give this shrub some space. It grows 3 to 8 feet tall and as wide. For a more compact presentation, prune hard in spring before it flowers.

Callicarpa americana

Origin: Native

Family: Verbeneceae

Foliage: Ovate with serrated edges

Growth rate: Moderate

Nutritional requirements: Grows well in poor soil

Soil requirements: Well-drained

Salt tolerance: Poor

Drought tolerance: Moderate

Light requirements: Full sun, part shade

Propagation: Seed

Pests: None

More info: SunSentinel.com/Beautyberry

Find it: At native-friendly garden centers (find locations at SunSentinel.com/natives) or online at SeedSource.com

July Garden Checklist

Gardening in July is not for the faint of heart. In fact, if you do garden in July, you might faint in the choking heat. Instead, pour yourself a tall glass of iced tea and read up on creating a more Florida-friendly landscape that will attract butterflies and birds, with help from the state and the Florida Wildflower Foundation.

Download it: “The Florida Yards & Neighborhoods Handbook,” a free, downloadable 50-page guide from the University of Florida/IFAS Extension Service and the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, explains the environmental benefits of using plants suited to our zone 10 conditions. It has a chapter devoted to plant and tree selection and offers useful information on watering, fertilizing, mulching and attracting wildlife. Info: Download it at SunSentinel.com/FloridaYards.

Identify it: If you don't know a zebra longwing from a cloudless sulphur, then take a look at the online brochure identifying some of our state's most common butterflies and native plants from the nonprofit Florida Wildflower Foundation (FlaWildflowers.org). The downloadable PDF explains the four life stages of native butterflies and identifies almost 100 species and native plants. Info: SunSentinel.com/FloridaButterflies.

Water it: Don't. We're in the thick of rainy season. If it's 3 p.m., it's likely storming outside. Give your irrigation system a well-earned rest and turn the timer off. Use the sprinklers if it doesn't rain for a few days, around November.

Mulch it: Further conserve water by applying several inches of mulch around plants to keep moisture in and choke out weeds. Keep it 1 to 2 inches from plant stems and leaves.

column2: August: Seaside goldenrod
column3:
August's plant of the month is a native perennial that produces yellow feathery blooms through October.

Solidago sempervirens, known as seaside goldenrod, makes a terrific addition to ornamental flower beds and butterfly gardens.

This low-maintenance plant likes full sun and is often used in coastal dune restoration projects. That means it is highly salt-tolerant, thriving on oceanside balconies. Seaside goldenrod is somewhat drought-tolerant after it is established.

Give this cheerful bloomer room to grow. In the ground, plants can reach 6 feet tall.

In the fall, it is a food source for migrating Monarch butterflies.

— Doreen Christensen

Solidago sempervirens

Origin: Florida

Family: Asteraceae

Foliage: Smooth, dark green

Growth rate: Moderate to fast

Nutritional requirements: Low

Soil requirements: Sandy, well drained

Salt tolerance: High

Drought tolerance: High once established

Light requirements: Full sun

Propagation: Cuttings, division

Pest problems: None

Find it: Jesse Durko's Nursery, 5151 SW 70th Ave. (Viele Road), Davie, 954-792-2297; Delray Garden Center, 3827 W. Atlantic Ave., Delray Beach, 561-243-6869. Or buy seeds at FloridaWildflowers.com.

More info: Plants.usda.gov/factsheet/pdf/fs_sose.pdf

column2: May: Powerpuff mimosa
column3:
If you're wondering what to plant as our weather warms, think pink with Mimosa strigillosa, May's plant of the month.

This native groundcover keeps a low profile, going by the aliases powderpuff or sunshine mimosa. It's ideal for South Florida gardens because it thrives in the sun — producing cute, cotton ball-sized blooms that emerge from a fast-growing dense carpet of fern-like leaves.

Powderpuff mimosa may be pink, but it's no pansy.

This sun-lover thrives on neglect, is drought-tolerant, attracts butterflies, withstands light foot traffic and can even be mowed. The Florida Nursery, Growers and Landscape Association named it a "plant of the year" in 2008.

These attributes make it a terrific replacement for St. Augustine turf because it can be planted in stubborn areas where grass just refuses to grow.

Mimosa's most interesting characteristic: its delicate-looking leaves, which are sensitive to touch. They fold up when handled.

Find it

At your favorite garden center.

Mimosa strigillosa

Origin: Native

Family: Fabaceae

Foliage: Bipinnate leaf

Growth rate: Rapid but easy to control

Nutritional requirements: None

Soil requirements: Well drained

Salt tolerance: Moderate

Drought tolerance: Excellent

Light requirements: Full sun, part shade

Propagation: Seeds or rooted cuttings

Pests: None

More info: SunSentinel.com/Mimosa

May garden checklist

National Hurricane Preparedness Week starts May 25. Trimming trees is No. 1 on the list of May gardening chores.

Trim it

Dense canopies catch and hold wind like an umbrella. Trimming helps protect surrounding houses and cars from damage, and can help keep a tree from being uprooted. With hurricane season starting June 1, take the time to inspect for damaged or weak branches. Only trim one-third of a tree at one time, or hire an ISA (International Society of Arboriculture) certified arborist.

Another important tip: Always look up before you trim. Florida Power & Light Co. recommends you "never attempt to trim any vegetation growing near power lines." Info: FPL.com/Trees, 800-226-3545

Grow it

It may be hot out, but you can still grow edibles. Consider planting an herb garden. Herbs thrive year-round here in Zone 10b and do especially well in containers. Basil, oregano, rosemary and chives are especially easy to grow from seeds.

Download a six-page guide to growing herbs in South Florida from the University of Florida's Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences Extension. Info: SunSentinel.com/Herbs.

Water it

May is a critical watering month before the rainy season gets underway in June. New growth and pests put stress on plants, so be sure your irrigation system is in top working order.

Download it

Speaking of watering, the free "WaterWise: South Florida Landscapes" from the South Florida Water Management District is an indispensable guide on conservation and native plants. The booklet explains how to save time and money by adopting environmentally friendly landscape practices. Info: SunSentinel.com/waterwise

column2: Gardening: September plant of the month is firebush
column3:
It's hot as blazes out, so September's plant of the month is the appropriately named firebush, also known as Hamelia patens.

This semi-showy shrub blooms all year long, producing tubular, orange-red flowers beloved by butterflies and hummingbirds as a nectar source. The plant's edible oval fruit, which continuously ripens from green to yellow to red and finally black, is relished by birds.

Firebush thrives in full sun or part shade, with red woody stems and evergreen leaves that grow 4 to 8 inches long, turning red in the fall.

Use the shrub as a background plant as it can grow to 12 feet and likes to spread 5 to 8 feet.

Hamelia patens

Origin: Native

Family: Rubiaceae

Foliage: Large, oval, pointed, green leaves

Growth rate: Fast

Nutritional requirements: Low

Soil requirements: Wide range of soil types

Salt tolerance: Poor

Drought tolerance: Moderate

Light requirements: Full sun, part shade

Pests: Aphids

More info: SunSentinel.com/Firebush

Find it: Firebush is available at most South Florida garden centers.

September garden checklist

September is still blistering hot, but relief is on the horizon. October will bring cooler temperatures and that long-awaited start to South Florida's growing season. Start planning winter gardens now.

Pests: Lawn pests like chinch bug, sod webworms and armyworm are munching away on turf, causing large brown patches. Responsibly manage the bugs with tips from "The Florida Yards & Neighborhoods Handbook," a free guide from the University of Florida/IFAS Extension Service and the Florida Department of Environmental Protection. Download it at SunSentinel.com/FloridaYards.

Seeds: Start vegetable and herb seeds now so you'll be ready to plant your veggie garden as soon as the weather cools.

Remembering McLean: Make a reservation for Cooper City's 22nd annual Tree & Plant Care Workshop, from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday in the City Hall auditorium, 9090 SW 50th Place. The event will honor the late David McLean, a native plant expert and longtime Broward College teacher who operated the Trinity Churchside Garden nursery in Fort Lauderdale. McLean, who died June 4, was a frequent speaker at the event. Info: 954-434-2300, CooperCityfl.org.

Going native: Learn about "Gardening With Ornamental Native Wildflowers" at 10:30 a.m. Sept. 28 at Mounts Botanical Garden, 531 N. Military Trail, West Palm Beach. The event will feature Rufino Osorio, author of "A Gardener's Guide to Florida's Native Plants," who will offer tips on using wildflowers in beds, as perennial borders and ground covers. Cost: $25 for members, $35 for nonmembers (includes garden admission). Info: 561-233-1757, Mounts.org.

column2: March: Salvia coccinea
column3:
The March plant of the month is Salvia coccinea

Known as Scarlet sage, this is drought-tolerant and attracts butterflies and hummingbirds.

Up North, salvia is an annual. But here in zone 10b, it behaves as a perennial, sending up whorls of bright red flowers from February to December. It's not fussy, growing from 2 to 4 feet in full sun or shade.

"Native salvias are great because they keep blooming and re-seed, so you'll never have to replant them," says Ryan Leavengood, president of the Palm Beach County chapter of the Florida Native Plant Society. "They are amazingly drought-tolerant."

Blue-blooming natives include Salvia azurea (Blue sage) and Salvia lyrata. They mimic the look of English lavender, Leavengood says.

Find it: Native Choice Nursery, 7401 Tropical World Way, Boynton Bleach, 561-756-4370, nativechoicenursery.com; Jesse Durko’s Nursery, 5151 SW 70th Ave. (Viele Road), Davie, 954-873-4563, JesseDurko.com

Salvia coccinea

Origin: Native

Family: Labiatae

Foliage: Green, ovate, serrated leaves

Growth rate: Rapid

Nutritional requirements: None

Soil requirements: Well drained

Salt tolerance: Moderate

Drought tolerance: Good

Light requirements: Sun or shade

Propagation: Self-seeder

Pests: None

More info: FNPS.org/plants/plant/salvia-coccinea

March garden checklist

Spring has sprung early in South Florida, as usual. And there's much you could be doing out in the garden. So put these chores on your March to-do list.

Feed it: Fertilize palms, trees, shrubs and lawns. Get help in choosing the appropriate fertilizer at your local garden center.

Prune it: Give ornamental grasses and frost-damaged plants a trim. Prune trees and shrubs when new growth begins.

Kill it: Aphids, spider mites, thrips, scale, mealy bugs and spiral whitefly may be feasting on tender new growth. Try nonchemical control first by blasting undersides of leaves and stems with a garden hose. Or, try a homemade mixture of 2 tablespoons each of liquid dishwashing detergent and vegetable oil mixed into a gallon of water. Add to a spray bottle and thoroughly saturate infested plants. Reapply as needed.

Plant it: Start warm-season crops like corn, watermelon, cucumber and peppers now.

Source: University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences Extension

dchristensen@sunsentinel.com

column2: June: Gaillardia pulchella
column3:
June's plant of the month is Gaillardia pulchella.

Like most Florida natives, this hardy bloomer worships the sun and likes to party on the beach. Gaillardia, also known as the blanket flower, is often spotted growing wild on sand dunes along the coast.

Its cheerful, orange-red and yellow daisylike flowers are extremely drought- and salt-tolerant. This also makes it an excellent showy container plant for condo balconies, especially those near the ocean.

This flower is not picky, thriving in loam, acidic, alkaline and sandy soils. It doesn't appreciate wet feet, so don't overwater.

Plants reach heights of 12 to 24 inches. Other cultivars include "Yellow Sun" and the fluffy, deep "Red Plume."

Planted en masse, gaillardia adds fiery bursts of color to the summer landscape and also makes for excellent cut flowers.

Gaillardia pulchella

Origin: Native

Family: Compositae

Foliage: Oblanceolate, spatulate

Growth rate: Moderate

Nutritional requirements: None

Soil requirements: Well drained; don't overwater

Salt tolerance: High

Drought tolerance: High

Light requirements: Full sun

Propagation: Reseeds from flower heads

Pests: None

Find it: Grow from seed, or find it at your favorite garden center.

More info: SunSentinel.com/Blanketflower

June garden checklist

Gardening will be a challenge for the next few months. Beat the heat and get outside early in the morning or late in the day or you'll risk turning into a pillar of salt in the SoFla sun. Here's this month's list of gardening chores.

PRUNE IT: Lightly trim oleander, hibiscus, ixora and other flowering bushes to encourage summer blooms.

WATER IT: Rain can be spotty this month. Be sure your irrigation system is in top working order, and that there are no broken or misdirected sprinkler heads.

DOWNLOAD IT: Learn the principles of native gardening and protect our natural resources with "The Florida-Friendly Landscaping Guide to Plant Selection & Landscape Design," available for free online. The 104-page manual offers landscape plans, as well as ideas to attract wildlife. The extensive list of native trees, plants and shrubs is most helpful.

Info: SunSentinel.com/LandscapeGuide

Source: University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences Extension

column2: Orioles' Steve Lombardozzi, Pat McCoy outrighted to Triple-A Norfolk
column3:
The Orioles announced Monday that three players have been removed from their 40-man roster, leaving them at 37 during the first official day of the winter meetings.

Left­-hander Scott Barnes, who was acquired by the Orioles last month from the Cleveland Indians for cash, was claimed off waivers by the Texas Rangers, while infielder Steve Lombardozzi (Atholton) and left-hander Pat McCoy cleared waivers and were outrighted to Triple-A Norfolk.

Barnes and McCoy had both been added to the Orioles’ 40-man roster this offseason to improve depth in the bullpen.

Barnes, 27, was acquired two weeks ago after he was designated for assignment by Cleveland. He didn't pitch in the major leagues in 2014, going 3­-2 with a 3.69 ERA in 31 2/3 innings with Triple-A Columbus.

Barnes held right-handed hitters to a .194 average and lefties to a .191 clip. He pitched 27 2/3 total innings for the Indians in 2012 and 2013, with a 5.20 ERA.

Lombardozzi, 26, played in 20 games for the Orioles and 78 at Norfolk this past season. The club acquired him from the Detroit Tigers in March for veteran infielder Alex Gonzalez.

Lombardozzi batted .270 with 30 RBIs and only 10 extra-base hits for the Tides in 2014. He hit .288 with two RBIs in 73 at-bats in the major leagues.

McCoy, 26, was claimed off waivers by the Orioles on Oct. 31. He split the 2014 season between the major leagues, Triple-A Toledo and Double-A Erie.

In 14 games for the Tigers, he had a 3.86 ERA with 11 strikeouts and 13 walks in 14 innings. McCoy was 1-0 with a 3.95 ERA in nine appearances for Erie, and he was 2-0 with a 2.59 ERA in 21 games for Toledo.

The Orioles needed to clear at least one spot on their 40-man roster during the winter meetings because they plan to make a selection in Thursday's Rule 5 draft.

eencina@baltsun.com

twitter.com/EddieInTheYard

column2: November: Coreopsis leavenworthii
column3:
Go wild for coreopsis leavenworthii, also known as leavenworth's tickseed.

November's plant of the month also is Florida's official wildflower.

This sunny-faced bloomer produces abundant 1-inch yellow blooms with chocolate centers. As with most natives, it attracts butterflies, requires low maintenance and gives garden beds an informal, natural look.

It's easy to grow from seed (there are more than 100 varieties) and great for cut-flower bouquets. Plants reseed yearly, lasting several seasons.

Coreopsis is an annual, but happily blooms all year in South Florida. It thrives in moist soil (not wet) in sunny spots.

Plants are popping up in nurseries, so grab them while you can. Or, start seeds now for economical plantings that will give months of cheery color in the new year.

Coreopsis leavenworthii

Origin: Florida native

Family: Asteraceae

Foliage: Pinnately to bipinnately compound leaves

Growth rate: Moderate

Nutritional requirements: Low; use slow-release fertilizer

Soil requirements: Well-drained acidic to slightly alkaline

Salt tolerance: Probably low

Drought tolerance: Medium once established; doesn't like it too dry

Light requirements: Full sun

Pest problems: None known

Propagation: Seeds or by division

Find it: In native plant nurseries and commercial garden centers; buy seeds at FloridaWildflowers.com

More info: SunSentinel.com/Coreopsis

November garden checklist

Here’s a look at your gardening tasks for November.

Plant it: It’s time to get annuals and veggies such as tomatoes in the ground.

Treat it: The dry season brings mites, slugs, snails, mealy bug and scale. Beetles and weevils, which lay eggs in the soil now, can be treated with beneficial nematodes. Other organic controls include Neem Oil sprayed on leaf undersides. Bayer Advanced Tree & Shrub Protect & Feed will offer protection for about eight months but should only be used in extreme situations. Do not use near water.

Water it: It’s time to turn on the sprinkler system again. Inspect heads and pipes for good coverage.

Buy it: The Fort Lauderdale Garden Club’s plant sale will be from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Nov. 8-9 at the club’s headquarters inside Birch State Park, 3109 E. Sunrise Blvd. Also, the club is having its general meeting at 10 a.m. Nov. 14, with a presentation on honey bees. Info: FLGC.org, 954-561-8475.

dchristensen@tribpub.com

column2: Keep burning nettle under control — carefully
column3:
Question: I have weeds in my yard with small leaves and scalloped edges that are causing me a lot of pain. If I brush up against them, I feel like I am on fire. What are they and how can they be controlled?

Answer: Going barefoot is not going to be fun when your lawn is full of burning nettle that's becoming a common cool-season weed in local landscapes. The leaves and stems have toxic sap that causes the burning sensation when it touches the skin. A soothing cream helps most gardeners, but it would still be good to eliminate this weed.

Broadleaf weed killers made for your lawn type usually give good control following label instructions. It's best if the weeds are treated when small to eliminate them before they become a hazard. Since this is a cool-season weed, remember to check next fall for signs of the seedlings and make the needed treatments. The weeds can also be dug or pulled from the lawn but only when wearing protective gloves and clothing.

Q: Our banana plants grew to 15 feet tall and even though we did not have a freeze, the leaves are brown back to the trunk that still has some green. How far back do I cut them back?

A: Here is some good news for your devastated plants. They could recover to produce a crop of bananas this year. As you noted, banana plants do not like the cold and any temperature below 40 degrees seems to turn them yellow to brown.

Cut the old leaves back to the trunk. Yes, this is going to leave a rocket-looking plant but just maybe the bud inside the trunk can produce a bunch of new leaves before sending out a flower bud. If this occurs by early summer, you are going to get a crop. Keep the soil moist and feed lightly but monthly March through November with a general garden fertilizer.

Q. Our muhly grass turns pink in the fall and has whitish portions the rest of the year. When should it be pruned and what about feedings?

A. Pruning time for all ornamental grass is during February or early March. Since muhly grass is one of the shorter-growing types, it can be pruned to within 6 inches of the ground. Taller grasses are often left a foot or so higher.

Muhly grass does have the attractive pink-to-purple flowers during the fall that are followed by the whitish stem portions. It is best to remove these portions during pruning. After pruning, give the plantings a light feeding with a general landscape or turf fertilizer. Feedings can be repeated in May and August.

Q. I have a St. Augustine lawn and would like to change it to a ground cover without a lot of digging. The area is a shady spot. What should I do?

A. Consider Asiatic jasmine for this spot, as this ground cover can grow in the shade to full-sun locations. It is low-growing, drought-tolerant once established and competes well with tree roots. Perhaps the easiest way to establish the ground cover is to use Roundup or a similar product that allows planting a week or so after use to control the existing vegetation. Then when the unwanted greenery declines, mow the area to within an inch or two of the ground and plant the ground cover. A very light mulch can be added. Keep the new plantings moist and apply a light feeding every other month until established.

Q. I have been told oak leaves falling on our lawn are causing the soil pH to become acid. Will putting lime on the grass help?

A. It's true decomposing oak leaves over time could make the soil more acid. This change does not occur quickly and depends on the type of soil in your yard. Some soils resist pH changes and the leaves may have little effect. Perhaps it's best to have your soil tested at your local garden center or University of Florida Extension Office to determine the pH. Then, if it's becoming too acid, lime could be applied to make recommended adjustments.

Q. A lot of moss is growing on the bushes around our house. Is there a product that removes it without harming the plants?

A. Controlling the moss is easy but trying to find out why it's flourishing could be a bit harder. Moss is a term many gardeners use when referring to lichens, algae, Spanish moss and ball moss that usually do not harm plants but makes good growth when the trees and shrubs are declining due to other causes.

A copper fungicide can be applied as instructed on the label for your plant type and the moss usually declines over time. Regretfully the plants you are trying to grow may not make better growth. If moss is growing better than the plants, look for other pests or cultural problems that may be causing the decline.

column2: White powder points to mealy bugs as culprits for hibiscus' lost leaves
column3:
Question: Our hibiscus has white powder-like stuff on the stems and leaves. An insecticidal soap spray helped but it is back and leaves are dropping. What should we do?

Answer: One of the most common insect pests of hibiscus is mealy bugs. They are hidden in a white coating that may also have a cottony look. Mealy bugs cover the stems, get into the leaf clusters and encase the new buds. These insects suck juices from the plants and reduce their vigor, and that can lead to leaf drop.

Insecticidal soap is one good control but you have to hit the insects, and repeat applications are usually needed each time the mealy bugs appear. Horticultural oil sprays also give control and are used in a similar manner. Perhaps the best and longest-lasting control is a systemic insecticide applied as a spray or to the soil. Several brands are available at local garden centers and should be applied following label instructions.

Q: Fall has arrived and I am wondering what I should do about my poinsettias, gardenias and azaleas. Do they need a feeding at this time?

A: One thing for sure, pruning time is over for all these plants if you want seasonal blooms. Cutting them back now would interfere with their flowering process. But, it is time for a good feeding.

Fall is the last time to make a fertilizer application for this year. Use any general landscape fertilizer. It would be good to pick one with slow-release properties that can feed the plants for several months. Keep the soil moist and maintain mulches to help control weeds and stretch the time between waterings.

Q: Over the years my Floratam St. Augustinegrass has grown runners over each other and the lawn is so high it is scalped by the mower. Is there a machine to reduce the thickness of the grass?

A: Thick and usually spongy lawns have many causes but those most common includes improper soil acidity, use of preemergence herbicides, too much water and excessive fertilizer. Start by having the soil acidity tested and adjust if needed. Preemergence herbicides often used to control crabgrass can keep the runners from rooting down. If this is the case, you might skip their use or try another product.

By far the most common cause of spongy turf is too good a care that promotes excessive growth. Check to make sure the lawn is being watered only when the turf starts to dry. Also, limit feedings to two to three times a year. The only control for an overgrown lawn is sanding to fill in the voids between the runners or installing new sod. There is no mechanical way to help the overgrown turf that wouldn't devastate your lawn.

Q: My lawn has chinch bugs and I have used several of the common sprays to obtain control. I have switched between the products but they have stopped working. Are these pesticide-resistant chinch bugs?

A: It's likely, as many residents and pest control companies are discovering pesticide-resistant chinch bugs in St. Augustine lawns. These pests have become resistant to the generally available pyrethroid-containing insecticides. Products offering a different type of insecticide to control chinch bugs include the Green Light Chinch Bug Killer with Arena and the Bayer 24 hour Grub Killer Plus. Not all garden centers carry these products so you may have to check with several retailers to find what you need. When using either of these products follow the label carefully for chinch bug control.

Q: I have a large sago that is covering the ground with foliage. Can I cut the bottom leaves off without damaging the plant?

A: Many gardeners like to keep the area under their sagos free of foliage to expose portions of their trunks. Most of these lower leaves are older and are shaded by other foliage higher up on the trunks. Also, leaves hidden within the plant often harbor mealybugs and scale insects. Removing several layers of foliage allows better air drainage that seems to help prevent pests.

Q: The tips of the leaves on my indoor corn plant turn brown. What can I do to correct the problem?

A: Brown tips at the ends of plant foliage often indicate a cultural problem. Check for adequate light and water. The corn plant, a type of dracaena, prefers bright light but no direct sun. Also keep the soil moist by watering when the surface becomes dry to the touch. Avoid areas directly in front of air vents to prevent rapid drying. Feed every other month with house or container plant fertilizer. If the brown tips continue, make sure the plant has a large enough container.

column2: Waterfront Partnership of Baltimore Inc. Articles, Photos, and Videos
column3:
Baltimore is approaching a disgusting milestone: By early next year, Waterfront Partnership will pull its one millionth expanded polystyrene foam food container from the harbor.

At nearly 22,000 containers per month, more than 700,000 of these containers have already been collected from the harbor since May of 2014 — more than enough for every resident of Baltimore to use one for lunch tomorrow. And by the end of the decade there will be enough for lunch and dinner. For every container pulled out of the harbor, there are countless more that line our streets, poison our waterways and fill our incinerators, unleashing known cancer-causing chemicals into the air. But despite our...

column2: Waterfront Partnership of Baltimore Inc. Articles, Photos, and Videos
column3:
The parents of a Vermont man who fell into the Inner Harbor and died this month came to Baltimore on Wednesday to implore city officials to install protective rails and more lights around the water’s edge.

Ryan Schroeder, 26, was visiting Baltimore for a business conference when he fell into the frigid waters near the Barnes & Noble bookstore during the early morning hours Feb. 1. Two passersby called 911, but he struggled in the water for roughly 40 minutes before rescue workers pulled him out and rushed him to Shock Trauma. He was pronounced dead at the hospital that morning.

Jim and Anne Schroeder of Duxbury, Mass., visited the spot where their son fell on Wednesday....

column3:
Krish Vignarajah, a former policy director for First Lady Michelle Obama, is the latest Democrat to join Maryland’s gubernatorial race.

Vignarajah said Wednesday she’ll kick off her campaign in September. She is the first woman to announce a run for governor.

The Montgomery County resident said she’s getting into the race because she is worried her newborn daughter won’t have the same opportunities she had.

Vignarajah, who also worked as an adviser at the State Department, said she was encouraged to run after making several speeches about her work in Washington that were well-received.

“There was a lot of enthusiasm for my message and my perspective on what we...

John W. Bereska, a retired Baltimore County public school educator who was principal of Hereford High School for more than a decade, died Friday of prostate cancer at his Cockeysville home.

He was 66.

“John was a good friend. We went on a State Department tour of Japan, and in three weeks, I really got to know him quite well. He was a good ambassador for the United States and American education,” said Robert Y. Dubel, who headed Baltimore County public schools for 16 years before retiring in 1992.

“John was a really sensitive and kind person, and I was delighted when he became a principal at Hereford, where he did a great job,” Dr. Dubel said. “He was a great supporter...

column2: U.S. Department of State
column3:
How much of the United States federal budget goes to foreign aid? When the Kaiser Family Foundation asked that question in a 2015 poll, nearly a fifth of people couldn’t even venture to guess. Of those who answered, most said between 5 and 51 percent, and 10 percent of those thought we give away half of our nearly $3.8 trillion federal budget to other nations.

In reality, foreign assistance makes up less than 1 percent of the U.S. budget.

column3:
The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) became law in 1990.

“The ADA is a civil rights law that prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in all areas of public life, including jobs, schools, transportation and all public and private places that are open to the general public. The purpose of the law is to make sure that people with disabilities have the same rights and opportunities as everyone else,” explains the introduction on the website https://adata.org.

It stands to reason that the federal government should have set an example with its facilities by seeing that they all became ADA compliant in the ensuing 27...

column2: U.S. Postal Service Articles, Photos, and Videos
column3:
Mail never stops moving at the Ellicott City post office. Letter carrier Dave Colbert began his shift last week on a windy, 21-degree morning inspecting his van before loading it with boxes and bins. The 58-year-old said he was “in for a cold one” and climbed into the driver’s seat, a holiday workload of 648 deliveries stacked behind him.

As one of Howard County’s larger post offices, the Ellicott City office handles between 150,000 and 200,000 pieces of mail every day, according to postmaster Howard Hines, and averages between 5,000 and 7,000 packages, also known as parcels – a number that triples over the holidays.

“This time of year, we have 15,000 to 18,000 parcels per...

column2: U.S. Postal Service Articles, Photos, and Videos
column3:
Caitec Corp., a pet supply and garden products company, is moving its headquarters from Baltimore City to Halethorpe.

The company outgrew its 40,000-square foot warehouse in the city's Morrell Park area, said Caitec President Terry Gao.

Caitec's distribution and offices will be based at a 110,000-square foot Hollins Ferry Road warehouse that had been rented seasonally by the Postal Service.

"Without this building, we cannot carry out our business plan," he said. Gao said he hopes to double sales of its branded products by 2020 but declined to elaborate.

He would not disclose revenues of the privately held company. Gao expects the move will be completed in...

column2: North Carolina State Wolfpack Articles, Photos, and Videos
column3:
North Carolina State earned another game with a former conference rival. The Wolfpack's Kiara Leslie gets a reunion with her old Maryland teammates.

When fourth-seeded N.C. State (25-8) faces the fifth-seeded Terrapins (26-7) today in the second round of the women's NCAA Tournament , there certainly won't be many secrets.

Yet Wolfpack coach Wes Moore tried to defuse the suggestion that Leslie might hold the key to stopping the Terps.

"Heck, she doesn't remember the stuff we're running," Moore quipped Saturday. "So how could she remember what she ran two years ago?"

The winner advances to...

Maryland women’s basketball coach Brenda Frese opened her postgame news conference Friday afternoon with a joke about former president Barack Obama, who picked No. 12 seed Princeton to take down the fifth-seeded Terrapins in a bracket he posted online. Obama’s niece Leslie Robinson plays for the Tigers.

“First of all, I don’t know what it is about former president Obama always picking against us,” Frese said with a smile. “We’re neighbors. We allowed him to use our arena for speeches — but we’ll take it! It’s been good luck for us.”

Frese and her Terps were in a joking mood after they took down Princeton with ease Friday, scoring a 77-57 win at Reynolds Coliseum to advance...

PASSING GAME

RAVENS: Joe Flacco hasn't put up huge numbers the past two weeks, completing 34 of 51 attempts for 412 yards and two touchdowns, but he has gone two straight games without an interception for the first time all season. He's on pace to set career highs in completion percentage, passing yards and touchdown passes. Torrey Smith has 14 catches for 236 yards and two touchdowns over the past three games, after making just 18 receptions for 308 yards and three scores over his first eight.
