At the same time, this week’s binding UN resolution also calls for domestic anti-terror policies to be revamped to staunch the flow of foreign fighters to the front lines of jihadist-triggered conflicts.

On the military front, the U.S. is primarily interested in putting together a regional coalition of majority Sunni-Arab nations — Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain — that will get more directly involved in fighting the Sunni extremists that dominate IS.

For its part, Canada has already sent 69 military advisers to northern Iraq, to reinforce Kurdish fighters acting as a bulwark against further IS incursions. Canada is also aiding with the transport of ammunition, weapons and humanitarian assistance. But Prime Minister Stephen Harper said Canada has been called upon by the U.S. to do more.

Canada ought to be an active partner in the fight, but Harper also should make good on his promise to hold a full parliamentary debate on Canada’s involvement. And any involvement must respect Canada’s weak combat capacity; under the governing Conservatives, the military has stayed largely intact in terms of the number of personnel, but cuts to equipment maintenance and upgrading have largely degraded Canada’s potential effectiveness.

New Democratic Party leader Thomas Mulcair is correct that there is a significant threat of mission creep in any new offensive. And while he is also right that Canadians are not enthusiastic about military involvement, he should not underestimate the importance of forcefully confronting IS.

IS may be an ideological abomination. But it is highly disciplined, well-trained, well-equipped — and it is also increasingly wealthy due to black-market crude-oil sales. It is a serious threat to regional and global security.

That said, there can no hope of a pure military victory, at least one in the traditional sense, against such a non-traditional, non-state actor.

However, military action will be useful, as it has been in recent days, with bombings designed to destroy captured oil-production facilities that were bringing IS millions of dollars a day in underground crude-oil revenues.

The fight against IS is an ideological war, more than a munitions war. It is the latest chapter in an unfolding civil war in the Middle East over the future of Islam. In this respect, Muslim nation states have a selfish interest in seeing IS destroyed. But given the Sunni roots of IS, it will ultimately be up to the Sunni nations to step up and do more to combat this group that even al-Qaida has disowned and regards as a mad menace.

It is estimated some 130 Canadians are waging jihad under the IS banner. But Canada isn’t alone. Other countries are also seeing citizens going abroad to join IS and other jihadist groups. Canada needs to step amplify efforts to identify and stop those ready to join the battle, exercise vigilance over fighters who return home, and hold to account any Canadians involved in atrocities perpetrated by IS.

Military action should be continued against IS, but with the more realistic strategic goal of destabilizing it while political alliances with moderate Muslims in the Middle East can be transformed into a newer and more powerful ideological force.

The perverted world view espoused by IS cannot be allowed to proliferate unchecked.

column2: Editorial: Parental-leave time cut would be a false economy
column3:
The news that Quebec is considering cuts to parental-leave benefits hardly comes as a surprise, given the government’s oft-repeated mantra that it will leave no stone unturned in its quest for cost savings.

But the suggestion that paid leave could be scaled back to nine or 10 months, down from the current 50 weeks, is something that should be approached with caution. Such a move might actually prove counterproductive, both by upping the cost of operating the publicly subsidized daycare system and making it more difficult for parents to return to work as they seek a scarce spot for a young baby.

Parental-insurance plans generally are a worthy public investment that promote a range of family-friendly health, social, developmental and economic goals. A one-year leave to give mom and/or dad time at home to nurture their new baby is the gold standard.

The Quebec Parental Insurance Plan is, however, extremely generous compared to the benefits in the rest of Canada, which are administered by the federal government. Quebec moms are exclusively entitled to 18 weeks of benefits, during which time fathers also get five weeks of paid leave, something they do not get elsewhere in Canada. The remaining 32 weeks can be split between both parents. Quebec pays 70 per cent of salary for half the leave and 55 per cent for the remainder (or 70 per cent and 55 per cent of $69,000, for those whose annual salary is higher). Quebec also offers the option of higher benefits — 75 per cent — allocated over a shorter period of time. And there is a program for adoptive parents. In the rest of Canada, parents can collect 55 per cent of their salary (or of $48,600, if their salary is higher than that amount) for 50 weeks.

The current made-in-Quebec system was introduced by the Liberals in 2006 — and came after a fight all the way to the Supreme Court of Canada over Quebec’s right to establish its own program.

Last year, the QPIP paid out $1.87 billion in benefits, and Quebec recorded 88,600 births.

Should Quebec’s program be scaled back? As with every program under the microscope, it’s hard to justify why it should escape scrutiny entirely.

But the idea of reducing the time period of benefits should be immediately scrapped for the unnecessary burden it would put on both families and the public purse. Parents returning to work after a leave already know daycare places for children under 18 months of age are harder to find, given that not every daycare has a “pouponnière.” If they manage to find a spot in the private sector, the fees can be higher for infants until they can graduate to a room for toddlers older than 18 months, due to lower employee-to-child ratios required, exacting standards for the rooms where babies are cared for and other factors. In cases where a parent does find a subsidized space, the cost to the public purse is higher: the subsidy for each child under 18 months is $61.86 versus $39.08 for an older child.

Cutting off parental benefits earlier would mean the government is going to have to foot the bill for a greater number of younger children at a higher cost. And in other cases, it will simply force families to pay for the higher costs themselves — wherever they manage to find daycare.

If, in the end, some cutbacks to parental benefits must be made, let those be in the form of cuts to benefits, not the time period covered. Forcing parents back into the workforce prematurely would not only have social drawbacks, it would be a false economy for the government, and would penalize parents twice.

column2: Parked in a plum role
column3:
Opportunity has knocked at last. Veteran actor/director Joel Miller is about to play a long-desired role, Shakespeare’s Falstaff.

Miller will be doing the role outdoors, in Repercussion Theatre’s Harry the King: The Famous Victories of Henry V, which opens on July 8 in Westmount Park.

“The more I get involved with it, the more I love it,” Miller said via cellphone from the Côte-St-Luc park where rehearsals were held this week. “I was aware that it wasn’t going to be a walk in the park — although it is indeed a walk in the park. I just discovered some muscles I never knew I had.”

Park Shakespeare, which entails location changes every couple of days as well as discreetly swatting mosquitoes mid-speech, tends to be a rite of passage for recent graduates, rather than late-career artists.

But Miller, who taught at the National Theatre School for almost 20 years and admits to being in his early 70s, is having a blast. Asked about his approach to Falstaff, Miller replied, “The whimsical part of myself wants to say that I drink a lot of booze.”

Falstaff is one of Shakespeare’s most beloved characters. He’s a sodden, overweight, blowhard of a knight who becomes a companion to the wayward young Prince Hal (who becomes the heroic King Henry V). Playing Falstaff is an honour eagerly sought by mature actors, almost on a par with portraying King Lear. (The late, great William Hutt did both, plus Prospero, during his last years at the Stratford Festival.)

Harry the King is an adaptation by Repercussion Theatre artistic director Paul Hopkins and Concordia professor Karen Oberer — with help from McGill Shakespeare expert Paul Yachnin — that combines three Shakespeare plays: Henry IV, Part One, Henry IV Part Two, and Henry V, along with a dash of Richard II.

Miller is happy to acknowledge that he’s a tad slim for Falstaff. Padding will be added to create a suitable girth. He sees Falstaff as a “Lord of Misrule,” a person appointed by the court in medieval times to preside over the Feast of Fools, “when the nobility became servants to the commoners for one day.”

Besides being a boozer with a big appetite, Falstaff is a “parallel father figure to Prince Hal,” Miller said. “Because Hal’s father Henry IV has always been very critical of Hal and doesn’t like him hanging out with Falstaff and his gang. Through mockery and raillery, Falstaff is teaching Hal. He’s a total anarchist.”

Even Queen Elizabeth I was smitten with the old rogue, to the point that she asked Shakespeare to write Falstaff into a third play (he appears in Henry IV Parts One and Two, but not in Henry V). Thus he ended up in Merry Wives of Windsor. Many years later, Giuseppe Verdi wrote him an opera.

Hopkins said it’s the first time that Repercussion Theatre has tackled Shakespeare’s history plays. The 100th anniversary of the First World War seemed a good time to do them. “In Henry V, there’s a lot of battles and it’s often brought up when it comes to war,” he said, citing the Sir Laurence Olivier film Henry V, which was a vital part of Britain’s effort to rally the troops during the Second World War.

Harry the King, however, is an amalgam. “I’ve extracted the storyline of Hal, which spans four plays,” Hopkins explained. “He’s introduced at the very end of Richard II and then he becomes a character in Henry IV Part One, Henry IV Part Two and Henry V.”

column2: Just for Laughs: Mike Birbiglia is happy to lose the plot
column3:
MONTREAL — There is little mystery about the titles of Mike Birbiglia’s one-man shows. Audiences knew exactly what was in store for them with monologues like Sleepwalk With Me, What I Should Have Said Was Nothing and My Girlfriend’s Boyfriend.

Birbiglia’s latest play to be launched at Just for Laughs, Thank God for Jokes, is pretty self-explanatory as well. And judging by audience reaction to his previous pieces, it’s a good bet that Thank God for Jokes will eventually hit Broadway and perhaps spawn another film.

Birbiglia has a masterful monologist’s touch. He is able to dig deep into his past, come up with embarrassingly personal tales of woe and transform them into highly humorous, occasionally poignant entertainment for the masses. Ever honest, Birbiglia calls this process “monetizing my pain.”

But Thank God for Jokes is somewhat of a departure for the comedian, who presents the show July 23 to 26 at the Gesù — and as Birbiglia asks in a phone interview: “Could there be a better place for me to thank God than at a church?” Probably not.

“My other shows were so focused on me telling a singular story, but I really wanted to go back to what brought me into this in the first place, to what made me love comedy.

“It was the jokes of Bill Cosby, Steven Wright and Mitch Hedberg that touched me and had me laughing my head off. So I decided that I wanted to put together the funniest show I could and not think about narrative. To show the role comedy has played in my life and in all our lives.”

But don’t go expecting Birbiglia to recite his top 100 one-liners. Instead, he will be telling 10 stories over the course of his show.

Birbiglia will also seek to demonstrate how comedy can be profound and bring people together but can also alienate. “Jokes can give and take. They have a double-edged nature.”

Unlike that of most of his fellow American comedians, Birbiglia’s humour is not punchline-driven. It’s more nuanced. Much like that of such Brit wits as Monty Python, or that of some Québécois raconteurs.

“I’ve never been to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, but friends have been telling me for years to go, that my stuff would fit in nicely there, that performers there are doing similar things to what I do,” Birbiglia says.

“Americans don’t always understand that kind of humour — much the same way they don’t understand soccer.” Pause, followed by an unusual segue: “I don’t have any soccer jokes in this play, but I did play a lot of soccer growing up. I was actually an excellent goalkeeper and I was, surprisingly, quite aggressive.”

But Birbiglia lost his aggressiveness when confronting an opposing forward for a loose ball. “I slid into him and the ball, and he kicked my head as though it were the ball. And I decided never to play goalkeeper again.”

One gets the feeling that Birbiglia has now found another embarrassingly personal moment to monetize. “I like to think that guy played a role in kicking my head into comedy,” he cracks.

column2: Editorial: Let’s just leave the Constitution alone for now
column3:
Premier Philippe Couillard gave Quebecers a scare over the weekend, when comments he made during a speech Saturday marking the 200th anniversary of the birth of Sir George-Étienne Cartier, a Quebec Father of Confederation, were interpreted to mean he wants a new round of constitutional talks.

News reports suggesting the premier is vying to get Quebec’s signature on the Constitution by 2017, Canada’s 150th birthday, were doused the next day by Couillard himself, who told reporters to look more closely at the text of his speech. The key sentence in the speech read: “À l’aube du 150e anniversaire du Canada, les Québécois souhaitent que le pacte qui lui a donné naissance soit réaffirmé.”

True, there’s a certain ambiguity there, but Couillard was right to say Sunday that his priority is the economy, not the Constitution, and that he simply meant to say Quebec’s ties with the rest of Canada need to be “reaffirmed” as 2017 approaches.

The clarification is most certainly welcome, given Canada’s difficult constitutional history over the past generation. What’s more, Couillard wasn’t elected with any mandate to enter into constitutional talks. The absence of Quebec’s signature on the 1982 Constitution isn’t a good thing, but polls show Quebecers generally like the Constitution, and it applies to Quebec nonetheless. In fact, the Constitution, as passed in 1982, hasn’t prevented the Quebec legislature from taking measures to preserve and promote French.

Couillard won a surprising majority-government upset in the April 7 election, but no one should take that, or the simultaneous collapse of the Parti Québécois, as a sign of renewed federalist fervour in Quebec.

The fact of the matter is that Quebecers are largely divided over Quebec’s place in Canada. One-third would like to separate from Canada, one-third would like to see Quebec sign the Constitution and one-third are generally happy with the ambiguous middle position. Those proportions have shifted somewhat in the past generation, but not by much. Against this backdrop, no Quebec premier should try to change the constitutional status quo, one way or another. The federal Clarity Act, quite rightly, insists on a clear majority in favour of sovereignty, in any referendum question, for it to reflect the clear will of the people. Similarly, no Quebec premier should push for Quebec’s signature on the Constitution without there first being a strong indication over time that this is what a clear majority of Quebecers want. To act otherwise would be to invite political confrontation, social unrest and economic uncertainty.

For the moment, Quebecers as a whole are not demonstrably unhappy with the current constitutional configuration. In the end, it’s very difficult to lead people in a direction where they don’t want to go. There may well come a day when public opinion will crystallize in favour this or that, and remain constant for a decade or so. Until then, Quebec politicians should just put the whole constitutional debate on ice, as François Legault’s Coalition Avenir Québec has formally done.

Canada doesn’t always work very well in theory, but it works well for Quebecers in practice. By all means, let’s hear some speeches reaffirming Quebec’s ties with Canada as 2017 approaches, but let’s devote our political energies to moving forward on the economy, environmental issues, health care and other more pressing issues.

column2: Editorial: Unfinished business at the Charbonneau hearings
column3:
Antonio Accurso, the Quebec construction magnate who went to the Supreme Court to fight a subpoena to appear before the Charbonneau Commission, dropped a string of bombshells Friday on his third day of testimony at the inquiry.

Most shocking was his claim that he paid $250,000 to former Montreal police chief Jacques Duchesneau, to help Duchesneau with his campaign debts after his failed Montreal mayoral bid in 1998, in exchange for unspecified future favours.

Accurso’s allegation — vociferously denied later Friday by Duchesneau — rattled the very foundation on which the commission had been struck. It had been a 2011 report by Duchesneau, as head of Quebec’s anti-collusion squad, that was a key impetus to the formation of the Charbonneau Commission. His report drew links between the awarding of provincial transport contracts and illicit political financing. And Duchesneau was the commission’s first witness in 2012, claiming that 70 per cent of all contributions to political parties in Quebec in recent years have been illegal.

Justice France Charbonneau asked Accurso point-blank if he was out for revenge. When she demanded to know if he had a copy of this cheque, he fired back that all of his documents have been seized by police — and he didn’t remember which company it had been issued from.

Of course, authorities will now need to review these documents for supporting evidence. In the meantime, Accurso’s allegation shouldn’t be allowed to overshadow the many hours of testimony from many others witnesses since the commission began. From the very beginning of the hearings, some witnesses have provided self-serving testimony, and the reputations of many people have been affected as a result, perhaps in some cases unjustly. But as a whole, however imperfect, the commission has done good work trying to illuminate the public’s understanding of corrupt practices in political financing and public tendering.

Time is running out for the commission; it is due to move on now to hear briefs from major players in Quebec society on how to improve tendering and related questions. But Accurso’s testimony this week pretty much obliges the commission to break with the script and call new witnesses, and perhaps recall some who have testified before.

For one, former premier Jean Charest needs to be summoned. So, too, should former Quebec Liberal fundraiser Marc Bibeau. Bibeau has figured in the testimony of many witnesses, but until Accurso took the stand this week, Charest had only been mentioned peripherally.

True, that photograph of Charest with Accurso that made the news this week dates from 2001, before Charest became premier in 2003, but it has an exceedingly chummy quality to it that raises legitimate questions about the nature of their relationship, and that of the political class and construction industry more generally. As well, former Parti Québécois premier Pauline Marois should also be required to testify, as should her husband Claude Blanchet, to answer allegations about an unspecified “deal” alluded to by union leaders in wiretap testimony heard earlier by the commission.

The Gomery inquiry into the federal Liberal sponsorship scandal managed to call former prime ministers Jean Chrétien and Paul Martin to testify. Similarly, Charbonneau should not be shy to require former Quebec premiers to appear.

column2: Editorial: STM executive pay hikes send a bad signal
column3:
In a move clearly out of step with fiscal and political realities in Quebec, the Société de transport de Montréal awarded substantial pay raises in 2013 to the transit commission’s 12 executives.

From the 4.52-per-cent increase to bring the salary of François Chamberland, executive director of technical services, to $188,692, to the 6.53-per-cent raise to push the pay of Luc Tremblay, executive director of finance, to $225,162, the hikes to executives averaged 5.31 per cent.

News of these raises, well in excess of the inflation rate, comes at a time the STM is slashing $65 million from its operating budget, cost-cutting that has meant reduced service on some bus routes, fewer staff at métro ticket booths, dirtier transit stations — and, not surprisingly, lower customer satisfaction.

Executive compensation in the public sector is often an easy target for criticism; there must be a recognition that pay has to be competitive to attract top people to important public positions and retain them. However in this case, the base rates already earned by these executives are reasonable, and increases exceeding inflation are hard to justify. The salary hikes are substantially more than the modest 2.3-per-cent increase in weekly earnings that Canadians saw in February 2014 from a year earlier.

The 2013 annual report, which was made public last month and which disclosed the pay hikes, also showed that customer satisfaction dropped in 2013. Last year, The Gazette obtained the salary figures for a longer list of STM managers and found that the salaries of a dozen top managers had jumped by 10 per cent in 2012.

That executives are being rewarded so handsomely while customer satisfaction is declining and service to the public is being cut is unacceptable. News of the increases is also politically unfortunate, coming as it does at a time when Mayor Denis Coderre is looking for take-backs from municipal workers on pension reform. It will undermine the city’s case in the pension dispute.

The excessively large raises to STM executives is a reminder of disquieting trends in the private sector, where executive compensation — generally much higher than in the public sector, pensions aside — is creeping back up to unprecedented levels, after cooling in 2008 and 2009 in the wake of the global economic meltdown.

Realities in the public sector, though, are quite different; the public sector is struggling through a slow but steady fiscal deterioration. At the provincial level, Quebec is proposing new austerity measures to help offset a persistent structural deficit. Municipalities will also be looking at new austerity measures when 2015 budgets are tabled late this fall.

Under the circumstances, the pay hikes to STM executives in 2013 sent the wrong message to employees, to passengers and to Quebecers at large. It is to be hoped that the new STM board chairman, Philippe Schnobb, appointed by Coderre last fall, will be able to oversee greater budgetary discipline going forward.

column2: Editorial: With this budget, Quebec starts putting its house in order
column3:
MONTREAL — Finance Minister Carlos Leitão’s first budget reads like a business plan for reviving Quebec’s moribund economy, with tax cuts for small enterprises, infrastructure investment, a relaunch of the Liberals’ Plan Nord, planned equity stakes in natural resource companies, a maritime strategy to position the province as a shipping and shipbuilding hub and a vow to create 250,000 jobs in five years.

“Quebec is open for business,” Leitão, a world-renowned economist, declared, sounding as much like a chief executive officer as a finance minister.

Quebecers may have been expecting dreaded austerity measures after all the talk of Quebec’s dire financial situation during the April 7 election campaign and since, but the new government certainly has not taken an axe to front-line services. At least not yet.

Instead, it appears that revving Quebec’s economic engine will be the first move on the long road to putting the province’s precarious finances back on track, with the government betting on economic growth of 1.8 per cent in 2014 and two per cent in 2015 after a weak 2013.

But make no mistake: painful measures to come are foreshadowed in this budget, which will hold government spending increases to 1.8 per cent this year — and just 0.7 per cent next year. That very low number on the horizon is the Rubicon Quebec will have to cross.

Any deep cuts to Quebec’s generous social services — to tame a projected deficit of $2.35 billion in 2014-15 and a return to a balanced budget promised for 2015-16 — will be deferred until after a review of the necessity, efficiency, delivery and financing of every government program, as well as a separate scrutinizing of the tax system that funds them all.

This seems prudent and realistic, given the tight timeline — just five weeks — between Premier Philippe Couillard’s Liberal government taking office and the presentation of this first budget Wednesday.

The kind of reform this administration has promised will take time to implement — not because the situation isn’t urgent, but because structural overhaul of this magnitude requires thorough examination and careful consideration. The commissions set up for this — to review programs and evaluate taxation — are to ensure proper reflection takes place.

Nevertheless, hitting the brakes on government spending inevitably will have an impact on services like health care and education. Growth in health spending will be capped at three per cent this year, or $33 billion, and 2.7 per cent next year. That will hurt, given it rose 5.8 per cent last year. There is a hiring freeze in the civil service and publicly funded agencies. Parental fees for subsidized daycare will be indexed, so the daily cost will rise to $7.30 from $7 by October. Taxes on cigarettes and alcohol will rise, but they will fund a modest tax credit to help seniors afford sports and leisure activities.

Infrastructure spending has been scaled back to $11.5 billion this year from the $15 billion the Liberals promised during the campaign. But Leitão said this was necessary to limit borrowing costs after the discovery that the deficit for 2013-14 is actually $3.1 billion — $600 million higher than predicted.

The budget lays the groundwork for more drastic measures that must be taken soon. Treasury Board Chair Martin Coiteux also tabled spending estimates, a much more sobering document, and talked about needing “courage” to re-evaluate every program Quebec offers to regain control of public finances.

These are formidable challenges. Quebecers are aware of this, with about 70 per cent telling a pollster in the aftermath of the election that the government needs to clean up its financial house. And they must remember this as the services dearest to them come under review.

The path immediately ahead is indeed bleak. But onward Quebec must press if it is to have a bright future.

column2: Magnotta consulted a psychiatrist mere weeks before killing, court hears
column3:
Journalists wait outside a courtroom at the Montreal courthouse, Monday, September 29, 2014, during the start of the murder trial for Luka Magnotta. Phil Carpenter/The Gazette

Members of the media wait outside the Montreal courthouse, Monday, September 29, 2014, for Luka Magnotta, who was to arrive for the start of his first degree murder trial. The trial is expected to last about two months. Phil Carpenter/The Gazette

People wait to be admitted to the afternoon session of Luka Magnotta’s first-degree murder trial at the Montreal courthouse Monday, September 29, 2014. Magnotta is accused of killing Lin Jun. Magnotta’s first-degree murder trial got underway at the Montreal courthouse. John Kenney/The Gazette

Line-up outside the courtroom at the Montreal courthouse, Monday, September 29, 2014, for the start of the murder trial for Luka Magnotta. Phil Carpenter/The Gazette

Lin Duran, the father of murder victim Lin Jun during a break at the Montreal courthouse, Monday, September 29, 2014, during the start of the murder trial for Luka Magnotta. Phil Carpenter/The Gazette

Caroline Simoneau, who was a crime scene photographer where remains of Lin Jun were found, at the Montreal courthouse Monday, September 29, 2014 waits to be summoned for her testimony in the afternoon session of the trial of Luka Magnotta who is accused of killing Lin Jun. Magnotta’s first-degree murder trial got underway at the Montreal courthouse. Simoneau is the first witness of the trial. John Kenney/The Gazette

Crown prosecutor Louis Bouthillier at the Montreal courthouse Monday, September 29, 2014 where the first-degree murder trial of Luka Magnotta got underway. John Kenney/The Gazette

Lin Jun's father, right, leaves a courtroom during a break at the Montreal courthouse, Monday, Sept. 29, 2014, during the start of the murder trial for Luka Magnotta. Phil Carpenter/The Gazette

Crown prosecutor Louis Bouthillier (right) walks past media at the end of the first day of the first-degree murder trial of Luka Magnotta in Montreal on Sept. 29, 2014 John Kenney/The Gazette

Just weeks before Lin Jun was killed, the man accused of his murder walked into a Montreal hospital and had a one-hour assessment by a psychiatrist.



“Had it been longer, we probably wouldn’t be here today,” Luka Magnotta’s defence lawyer told the jury on the opening day of the 32-year-old’s first-degree murder trial.



Luc Leclair told the eight-woman, six-man jury that his client admits to the five counts against him, including the killing of Concordia University student Lin Jun, but will set out to show that his mental state prevented him from fully grasping what he was doing.



Crown prosecutor Louis Bouthillier, on the other hand, told the jury that the evidence they will hear over the next three or four weeks will show that the murder was planned up to six months in advance and that it was deliberate. He said an email a British reporter received makes it clear that Magnotta had planned to kill a human being and make a movie of it.



“You will see the so-called murder video,” Bouthillier told jurors. “Evidence will show it was posted by Magnotta on a website.”



He also made the shocking revelation that in the first 53 seconds of a video, shot the week before, another man can be seen bonded to Magnotta’s bed.



“The video shows Lin Jun in the same position,” Bouthillier said.



That video will be shown during the third week of the trial and Bouthillier told jurors they would be forewarned, given the upsetting and gruesome nature of the material.



Before the lawyers spoke, the five charges were read aloud by the court clerk: first-degree murder, causing an indignity to a human body, producing and distributing obscene material, sending obscene material via Canada Post and harassing Prime Minister Stephen Harper and other MPs. After each count, Magnotta said clearly “not guilty.” As he spoke, the father of the victim, Lin Diran, stared at him intently but showed no emotion.



Given the length and difficult subject matter of the trial, there are 14 jurors, instead of the usual 12. All will hear the evidence, but only 12, chosen randomly by drawing numbers, will actually deliberate and decide Magnotta’s fate. The two alternates will take the place of anyone who leaves partway through the trial, which is expected to last six to eight weeks.



In his opening statement, Bouthillier also said that surveillance cameras at Magnotta’s Côte-des-Neiges apartment show Lin entering the building with Magnotta in late May 2012. He was killed and dismembered and the jury will see photos of the body parts, Bouthillier warned. Parts of the body were mailed to Prime Minister Stephen Harper and the Liberal Party of Canada in Ottawa, while others were shipped to schools in Vancouver.



The head was discovered in Angrignon Park, Bouthillier said.



Leclair said he hopes to call Magnotta’s father, Donald Newman, who has been diagnosed with schizophrenia, to tell the court what his son’s life was like growing up. Magnotta, who changed his name from Eric Newman, has a sister, Melissa, and a brother, Conrad, the defence revealed.



“We may hear from his family, or not,” Leclair said. “I’m keeping my fingers crossed.”



He said that in March, 2012, just months before the murder, Magnotta went to a Montreal hospital and was referred to a psychiatrist whom he saw in April, 2012. Leclair said he will be presenting Magnotta’s medical reports, including those from Peterborough, Ont., and North York General Hospital, to prove his defence of not criminally responsible.



He said his client claims someone named “Manny” told him a year before the killing to commit the acts with which he is charged.



The first witness called to testified Monday showed photos of body parts that were found stashed in garbage bags and a suitcase behind and beside Magnotta’s Décarie Blvd. apartment in the Côte-des-Neiges area.



Caroline Simoneau, a crime scene technician for the Montreal Police, said she arrived on the scene at about 12:15 on May 29, 2012. They found a human torso tucked snugly inside a suitcase, that was covered in flies and emitted a strong odour, she said. A dead black dog with white paws was tripled bagged in black garbage bags.



Police also found a leg in one bag and two arms and a leg in another, Simoneau said, describing each photo as it was projected on large screens in the courtroom. The limbs were missing the hands and feet. She showed photos of two knives, a screwdriver, a grinder, hammer, blue latex gloves and several pieces of clothing. Police also retrieved a bloody mattress cover and a soaked towel that oozed red liquid she said.



There was red liquid seeping from many of the garbage bags, Simoneau told court. In all, police searched 31 garbage bags. They found pink tissue paper, a gift bag and a Canada Post cardboard box.



The trial continues Tuesday.



smontgomery@montrealgazette.com

Twitter: MontgomerySue

column2: Five jurors chosen for Magnotta trial
column3:
Potential jurors are instructed by a special constable while they line up at the Montreal Courthouse as jury selection begins in the Luka Magnotta murder trial in Montreal, Monday, September 8, 2014. Graham Hughes/THE CANADIAN PRESS

If so, the trial will probably begin on Monday.

The first two men who appeared before Superior Court Justice Guy Cournoyer Tuesday were chosen as the triers, who will sit in court throughout the jury selection and determine which candidates fit the bill. Once accepted by the triers, both the crown and defence have the opportunity to overrule their decision and reject a candidate.

As the candidates filed into court one at a time, Magnotta sat in the prisoner’s box, his arms folded across his chest and he appeared to doze off at times. A few times he conferred with his lawyer, Luc Leclair, on a jury candidate.

Each candidate was asked a series of questions by Leclair including whether they had seen the “so-called murder video on the Internet, in which you see Magnotta allegedly committing the murder of which he is accused.” Leclair asked whether they could set their opinions aside during the trial and if they wanted to be on the jury. They were also asked if they could handle seeing “graphic and potentially upsetting” evidence.

If francophone, they were asked the questions in English; if anglophone, they were asked in French. All were asked whether they read newspapers, magazines or books or whether they watched television or listened to the radio in their second language.

Out of the 22 candidates who were called before the judge Tuesday, five were selected. Among the three women, there is an auto parts analyst, an assistant manager at a telecommunications firm, and an insurance broker. Among the men is a website programmer.

“It’s the first time since becoming a Canadian citizen that I feel like a citizen,” the man, who is black, told the court.

The other man works as a maintenance man and cleaner. When asked why he wanted to be on the jury, he replied, “The judge said it is a good life experience so if he said it, it must be true.”

“Thank you,” replied Cournoyer. “You just made my day.”

Twelve people will be chosen to sit on the jury, plus two alternates, who will listen to all the evidence but not deliberate. Another two will be chosen as back-ups until the trial begins.

Magnotta, 32, faces five charges in connection with the May, 2012 death of Lin Jun, a Chinese national and 33-year-old Concordia University student. Magnotta was arrested in June 2012, and has been in detention ever since.

Jury selection continues Wednesday.



smontgomery@montrealgazette.com

column2: Live: Luka Magnotta jury selection, Day 4
column3: An artist’s view of Luka Magnotta on Monday, Sept. 8, 2014, the first day of jury selection in his first degree murder trial for the 2012 death and dismemberment of Lin Jun. Atalante

column2: Luka Magnotta murder trial jury gains five more members
column3:
The final five jury members faced with the arduous task of judging accused murderer Luka Magnotta were chosen Thursday, and will spend the next couple of months with seven others picked earlier this week.

An additional four people — two who will be back-ups until the trial begins and two who will listen to all the evidence but not deliberate — will likely be chosen Friday.

If so, the trial will get underway Monday in room 5.01 of the Montreal courthouse.

So far, about 85 people — randomly chosen from the electoral list — have been called before Superior Court Justice Guy Cournouyer, although a handful have failed to appear.

Those present have had to answer several questions posed by defence lawyer Luc Leclair in order to determine their impartiality and fluency in French and English.

Magnotta faces five charges in connection with the May 2012 death of Lin Jun, a 33-year-old Chinese national and Concordia University student.

A translator, CEGEP professor, call-centre employee, retired financial planner and a woman who works in the bursary department at McGill University were added to the jury Thursday, but several candidates were rejected based on their pre-conceived ideas of the case.

“I don’t understand why there’s a trial for this,” said one man who works as a web designer. “There’s video proof he’s guilty so this is a waste of time.”

Another man said he didn’t want to be on the jury because he thought Magnotta was guilty.

“I’m too scared to disappoint members of my family and co-workers if he’s found not guilty,” he told the court.

Jury selection will continue Friday.

smontgomery@montrealgazette.com

Twitter: MontgomerySue

column2: Two more jurors added for Magnotta murder trial
column3:
Nine more people still need to be chosen.

On Wednesday, a woman who does public relations for a firm was chosen after she told the court she believed everyone has the right to a fair trial. A university professor who teaches hospitality management was also chosen. He said he wanted to be on the jury because he saw it as his civic duty, like voting or paying taxes.

The first 12 people chosen will hear all the evidence throughout the trial, expected to last six to eight weeks. They will then deliberate in order to reach a unanimous verdict. Another two will hear all the evidence, but not deliberate. And the last two will serve as back-ups only until the trial starts, which could be as early as Monday.

Throughout the selection process so far, Magnotta has sat in the prisoner’s box, often with his eyes closed and sometimes sipping water. At times, he confers with his lawyer, Luc Leclair, about whether a candidate should be rejected as a juror.

The 32-year-old faces five charges, including first-degree murder, in connection with the May 2012 death of Lin Jun. Jun was a Chinese national who studied at Concordia University. Magnotta was arrested and charged in June 2012.

Two of the 24 candidates called to appear Wednesday didn’t show up, while others didn’t appear to be sufficiently bilingual. The trial will be held in English, but some witnesses will testify in French and some reports will be written in French.

A woman rejected Wednesday said she didn’t have an opinion on Magnotta or the case and wanted to hear the facts.

“I would like to know the five Ws,” she told the court. “Like how, when, why and where.”

An artist who makes miniature replica firearms and has a tendency to faint was also rejected.

Two people were released from duty by Superior Court Justice Guy Cournoyer Wednesday — a man who had a doctor’s note regarding his mental health and a military reservist who is being sent to Valcartier this weekend.

The selection process continues Thursday.



smontgomery@montrealgazette.com

Twitter: MontgomerySue

column2: Jury selection in Magnotta trial set to begin Monday
column3:
Luka Magnotta is taken by police from a military plane to a waiting van in Mirabel, Que., on June 18, 2012. THE CANADIAN PRESS HO/THE CANADIAN PRESS

MONTREAL — First a foot, neatly packaged and labelled, was delivered by Canada Post to Conservative Party headquarters. Then a hand and foot — badly decomposed by the time they made their way across the country — were delivered to two Vancouver schools.

For about a week, the news headlines were filled with increasingly gruesome details, as the mystery of the body parts unfolded. Another hand discovered. The head. The torso.

Interpol was alerted, sparking an international manhunt.

On June 4, 2012, Ontario-born Luka Magnotta was arrested in an Internet café in Berlin.

On Monday, jury selection for what is sure to be one of the most closely watched trials since perhaps that of killer Paul Bernardo is to get underway at the Montreal courthouse.

With both the Crown and defence weighing in, 12 members of the public will be chosen to determine the fate of the 31-year-old accused as they sit through six to eight weeks of disturbing evidence.

Magnotta is charged with the first-degree murder of 33-year-old Lin Jun, a Chinese national who was studying engineering and computer science at Concordia University. He is also charged with committing an indignity to a body, publishing obscene material, criminally harassing Prime Minister Stephen Harper and other Members of Parliament, and mailing indecent and obscene material.

Like all trials, this one will be open to the public. But the Quebec Superior Court room in which it is to be held has fewer than two dozen seats, so an overflow room will be available in which people can watch on a screen.

It will be up to Superior Court Justice Guy Cournoyer to decide how to manage the expected large numbers of journalists and onlookers.

column2: No publication ban in Magnotta murder trial: judge
column3:
MONTREAL — A Quebec Superior Court judge ruled Monday that there will be no publication ban on evidence presented at the upcoming murder trial of Luka Magnotta.



Lawyers in the case were in court Monday to argue various motions by the defence.



A temporary publication ban on the motions prevents the media from reporting their contents until Justice Guy Cournoyer rules on them. The hearings will continue on Tuesday.



Magnotta is charged with first-degree murder in the May 25, 2012 death of Lin Jun, a 33-year-old Chinese national who was studying engineering at Concordia University.



Magnotta, 31, sat in the prisoner’s box Monday, listening to the procedure. His hair was shaved close to his head and he appeared much heavier than when he was arrested two years ago.



His trial is set to begin Sept. 8. Besides the first-degree murder charge, he is also accused of committing an indignity to a body, publishing obscene material, criminally harassing Prime Minister Stephen Harper and other MPs, and mailing indecent and obscene material.



smontgomery@montrealgazette.com

Twitter: MontgomerySue

column2: Luka Magnotta case: Montreal police cannot view research video, judge rules
column3: MONTREAL — A Quebec judge has refused to allow Montreal police to view a taped interview with accused killer Luka Magnotta about his work as an escort, saying the university researchers who conducted the sex worker study have a right to keep Magnotta’s answers confidential. Five years before he was charged with killing and dismembering Chinese student Lin Jun in 2012, Magnotta participated in a study by two University of Ottawa criminologists about sex workers.

column2: Alouettes knock the stuffing out of Roughriders
column3:
MONTREAL — There was no way the Alouettes were going to lose on the day devoted to Anthony Calvillo.

And how ironic that on the day the organization retired the legendary quarterback’s number, the Als looked like the powerhouse team that dominated the Canadian Football League when Calvillo was in his prime.

Montreal won its third consecutive game Monday afternoon at Molson Stadium, defeating the Saskatchewan Roughriders 40-9 before a season-high crowd of 23,069. During halftime, a 24-minute ceremony was conducted in which Calvillo became the 10th player in franchise history to have his number retired. Former teammates Tracy Ham and Mike Pringle were among those who addressed Calvillo. The franchise also paid tribute to Calvillo with a red and white stripe, accompanied by his number, on the 13-yard lines at both ends of the field.

The Als improved their record to 6-8, moving into a three-way tie for first place in the East Division with the Hamilton Tiger-Cats and Toronto Argonauts. In the process, Jonathan Crompton improved his record to 5-1 as the team’s starting quarterback.

The defending Grey Cup champions, meanwhile, lost for the fourth time in five games since Darian Durant, their starting pivot, suffered an injury. Saskatchewan’s record now is 9-6.

The Riders actually scored first, taking advantage of a Duron Carter fumble in the first quarter that was recovered by Tristan Jackson at the Montreal 35.

That eventually led to an 11-yard touchdown pass from Tino Sunseri to Anthony Allen, who was wide open in the flat, at 11:19. But the Riders would never lead again.

The momentum of the game changed when Sunseri was hit by linebacker Chip Cox in the second quarter. Cox, the league’s outstanding defensive player in 2013, forced a fumble that was recovered by John Bowman at the Saskatchewan 25.

Three plays later, third-string quarterback Tanner Marsh scored on a one-yard run at 5:02. The play came after the Riders were called for pass interference.

Montreal took a 14-7 lead more than 10 minutes into the quarter. Crompton passed to Carter over the middle, and the wide-receiver outraced Saskatchewan defenders into the end zone. Carter extended himself on the play, making a nice reception.

Newcomer Chris Rainey, making his Montreal debut, returned the second-half kickoff 52 yards. The Als then went 67 yards in six plays, culminating in a 25-yard touchdown pass to Carter, his second of the game, at 2:54.

Carter outwrestled Rod Williams for the ball on the play, giving the Als a commanding 21-7 cushion.

After Chris Milo struck the crossbar on a 47-yard field goal attempt, Crompton passed 26 yards to Tyrell Sutton, replacing injured tailback Brandon Whitaker. That eventually led to the first of four Sean Whyte field goals, a 25-yarder, at 9:47.

On the Riders’ next possession, Allen fumbled the exchange with Sunseri. The ball was recovered by linebacker Winston Venable at the Saskatchewan 30-yard line.

Two plays later, Crompton connected with Brandon London, who was between two defenders, for a touchdown at 10:38, increasing Montreal’s lead to 31-7.

Whyte concluded the quarter with a 42-yard field goal at 14:23.

Montreal outscored the visitors 20-0 in the period.

Whyte conceded a safety four minutes into the fourth quarter before kicking a 25-yard field goal at 11:20. He added a 29-yarder at 13:45.

Crompton left the game in the fourth quarter, replaced by Alex Brink. Crompton unofficially completed 12 of 25 passes for 225 yards along with three touchdowns.

The Als meet the Argonauts on Saturday afternoon at the Rogers Centre.

hzurkowsky@montrealgazette.com

Twitter: HerbZurkowsky1

column2: Alouettes to rely on Sutton against Roughriders
column3:
As much as every professional athlete wants to play, he’ll claim opportunity shouldn’t come at the expense of another who has been injured. Otherwise, he comes across as being selfish, and not a team player.

Tyrell Sutton has always felt a connection to Brandon Whitaker since his arrival in Montreal last season. Two men chasing the same job, which is perhaps why Sutton has felt a symbiotic relationship with the Alouettes’ starting tailback.

And so, it’s with mixed emotions that Sutton has taken his promotion to starter after the Als placed Whitaker on the six-game injured list late Friday afternoon. He broke two bones in his foot last Wednesday during an off-field workout. With five games remaining in the regular season, and the Als in no way guaranteed a playoff berth, Whitaker’s season might, in fact, be over.

“It’s very unfortunate. Anyone can tell you he (Whitaker) is one of my best friends. He’s like a brother of mine,” Sutton said Sunday, during an interview in the team’s Olympic Stadium dressing room. “I didn’t want to do this without him. I still don’t, but the game stops for nobody.

“Nobody wants to be a backup, but you play the role that you have. I’m not saying I was fine with it, but I was fine with it. There’s nothing wrong with Whit. There’s no reason for me to say I should be starting over Whit.”

But beginning Monday afternoon at Molson Stadium (1 p.m., TSN, RDS, TSN Radio-690) against the Saskatchewan Roughriders, that’s the role Sutton has been cast into. And he’ll be backed up by former Pittsburgh Steeler Chris Rainey, although he arrived only this week and had been on the practice roster.

Whitaker was second in the Canadian Football League in rushing yards, behind Calgary’s Jon Cornish, but has a history of injury problems. He tore his anterior cruciate ligament in 2012, and finished last season on the nine-game injured list after dislocating a shoulder and pulling his hamstring.

Sutton started the final three games, along with the East Division semifinal against Hamilton. He exceeded 100 yards in both games against the Tiger-Cats and completed the season with an impressive 6.2-yard average, gaining 342 yards on 55 carries.

“Everybody trusts Sutton. He can run. He can block. He knows the offence,” said offensive-tackle Jeff Perrett. “He’s a physical runner, straight downhill, and he’s not scared of contact. He’s not scared to be a blocker. He’s fast and has the whole package.”

At 5-foot-8 and 213 pounds, Sutton’s two inches shorter, but 13 pounds heavier than Whitaker. Sutton, who spent time in the NFL with Green Bay, Carolina and Seattle, started this season on the six-game injured list, having suffered a hamstring problem at training camp. The Als introduced a two-back system two months ago, at Saskatchewan. Sutton was dressed for Montreal’s last game, at Ottawa, but failed to play a down because of a rib injury.

Sutton, much like Mike Pringle –– who will attend a halftime ceremony Monday during which former quarterback Anthony Calvillo will have his number retired –– will gain his yards running over and through tacklers. He’s an aggressive ball-carrier compared to the elusive and shifty Whitaker.

“I don’t care. You hit me, you’re going to feel some kind of force behind it,” Sutton said. “We’re both quick, fast and very intelligent.”

Rainey, meanwhile, is a 5-foot-8, 190-pound back who gained nearly 2,500 yards at the University of Florida while scoring 13 touchdowns. He also proved competent catching the ball out of the backfield and is a versatile player who can return kicks, if necessary. He was the Steelers’ fifth-round draft pick in 2012 and was a first-team all-SEC all-star as a senior.

Despite his limited time with the Als, Rainey claimed he has been able to learn the entire offensive playbook.

“All you got to do is go to YouTube,” he said, laughing. “I’m not bragging, but I’ve got all my work on there. I’m still that kind of player –– a playmaker than can score from any place.

“I hope (the organization) sees something in me and I hope to show them.”

Rainey’s activation can be considered surprising, given his limited time in Montreal. The Als, arguably, might have selected Brandon Rutley, who returned to the practice roster Sept. 23 –– where he had spent most of the season before being released on Aug. 11. Rutley dressed for a July game at Vancouver.

“He (Rainey) brings a different dimension that, I think, will complement Tyrell as we move forward,” head coach Tom Higgins explained. “He has been impressive and looks quick.

“Right now, it made the most sense to put the possibility of a home-run hitter and see what he can do. He showed us enough.”

With Toronto’s last-minute comeback victory against Hamilton on Friday, the Als must defeat the defending Grey Cup champions to keep pace with both teams. Under that scenario, all three would sit at 6-8 with four games remaining. Three of those four Montreal games come against the Argonauts and Ticats.

“You can’t look at what everyone else is doing. Take care of our own business and we’re in,” Perrett said. “All the clichés are true in this case. As long as we keep winning and play like we have been, we’ll be fine.

“This is the situation we put ourselves in. We have to keep winning. Maybe it makes us play more desperate, which is a good thing. We have zero room for errors and mistakes.”

The Riders, meanwhile, might be 9-5, but are without their starting quarterback, Darian Durant. And they’ve lost three of four games since he underwent surgery in early September to repair a torn tendon in his right elbow. He’s eligible to return from the six-game injured list on Oct. 24.

Tino Sunseri is expected to start at quarterback.

Saskatchewan also will be missing left-guard Brendon LaBatte with an upper-body injury. LaBatte was the league’s outstanding lineman last year.

Notes: Tracy Ham, the quarterback whom Calvillo replaced, also is scheduled to attend the jersey retirement ceremony. To accommodate the proceedings, the halftime break’s expected to last 24 minutes, longer than normal. … LaBatte will be replaced by Dan Clark. … Als linebacker Kyries Hebert will miss his second consecutive game with a hamstring injury.

hzurkowsky@montrealgazette.com

Twitter: HerbZurkowsky1

column2: The Snap: Alouettes Notebook, Sept. 21, 2014
column3:
This was originally posted to The Snap blog.

MONTREAL – Much has been made of Chad Johnson’s contribution – or lack of such – with the Alouettes this season.

The former NFL standout wide-receiver, who spent most of his career with the Cincinnati Bengals, returned to pro football this season, following his release from the Miami Dolphins in 2012. But Johnson has had little impact with Montreal, held to seven catches for 151 yards. He has scored one touchdown.

None of this should be surprising. The Als utilize Johnson at strong-side wide-receiver – the longest throw on the field for the quarterback – and have made little, if any effort, to move him around. In the one game he was scheduled to play slotback, at home against Edmonton, he suffered a concussion on the second play.

General manager Jim Popp, the man responsible for signing the 36-year-old, predictably has defended the move, suggesting it was never Johnson’s mandate to be the team’s saviour.

“When Jim Popp signed him,” Popp said, talking in the third-person, “it was to fit him into a very talented receiving corps – one on which S.J. Green and Duron Carter are the stars. I was trying (to find) another piece to the puzzle.”

Popp also knew he had an opening at receiver, since Jamel Richardson was coming off debilitating knee surgery and wouldn’t be ready for the start of training camp. Indeed, Richardson was released following camp and hasn’t resurfaced with another Canadian Football League club – yet to be medically cleared.

“If you look at the stats, you’d think he would have had more,” Popp said. “If you look at how many times he’s actually had a ball thrown to him, he wouldn’t have a lot more.

“We have a lot of weapons on offence; you can’t say we don’t.” . . .

In case you haven’t heard, veteran receiver Eric Deslauriers finds himself on the six-game injured list, having suffered a sprained medial collateral ligament in his left knee. He suffered a similar injury in 2009, combined with a torn hamstring, forcing him to miss the Als’ Grey Cup victory against Saskatchewan.

Deslauriers has never been used extensively since joining Montreal in 2007. This season, he has 15 catches for 121 yards, but has yet to score a touchdown.

Potentially complicating matters is the fact Deslauriers is a potential free agent next February. He’s 33.

“This is an injury I came off before. I know how to handle it,” Deslauriers said earlier this week. “I jogged today and it felt good. I hope to be on the field faster than I think.

“You never want to be injured and I pride myself on being healthy. I haven’t missed a practice in five years. I was hoping to keep that going. Unfortunately, that wasn’t the case.”

Deslauriers never has played with a brace since suffering his 2009 injury. He said he will when he returns this season – provided he returns. . . .

You’ve probably heard by now non-import Calgary running-back Jon Cornish won’t face the Als Sunday afternoon at Molson Stadium.

Cornish, the league’s reigning outstanding player and top Canadian, was concussed by Montreal linebacker Kyries Hebert on June 28, when the teams opened the regular season. The Stampeders said he’s resting some nagging injuries that have no correlation to his earlier head problems.

Hebert was fined by the CFL for the hit, having led with his head. He continues to maintain it wasn’t intentional. While he’s sorry Cornish missed a number of games, Hebert won’t apologize for the way he plays.

“I can’t apologize for how hard I hit a player. The fact he got injured on the play, it really looked bad,” Hebert said on Saturday. “It was a football play. It’s my job to get him on the ground. I did. Regretfully, there was contact with the head, which you never want.”

Hebert has suffered a concussion himself, so knows brain injuries are a serious matter.

“My intent wasn’t to injure,” Hebert said. . . .

News you need: As montrealgazette.com has previously reported, former Als slotback Ben Cahoon reiterated he and Popp had discussions last winter about joining Montreal as an assistant coach. Cahoon confirmed the scenario this weekend, when he returned to be inducted into the Canadian Football Hall of Fame.

Popp was under the assumption he would remain the Als’ head coach. The idea was Popp would hire an offensive co-ordinator and an offensive position would be found for Cahoon. The team instead, of course, hired Tom Higgins as its head coach.

Having said that, there was no guarantee Cahoon, who has already been through the coaching regime at Brigham Young University, his alma mater, would have accepted. He’s the father of four young girls and has a job back home, near Salt Lake City, in the medical supplies field. His coaching experience at BYU soured him, to an extent, on coaching. . . .

Although he compiled 254 regular-season victories as a head coach – the most in CFL history – Wally Buono, another Hall inductee, insists Don Matthews, not he, is the best coach the league has seen.

“I don’t measure it by wins,” Buono said. “Don did it a certain way, his way. I did it with two teams. He did it with five. He set the standard for great coaching. The fact I coached a year longer than him gave me a few more wins.”

Buono remains involved in the game, now serving as the GM of the British Columbia Lions. . . .

And finally, Als scratches against Calgary are Kenny Stafford and Dominique Ellis.

column2: Als’ defence will carry team vs. Stamps, Cox vows
column3:
It was a defensive collapse of monumental proportions — not as great as Toronto squandering a 29-3 second-quarter lead against Calgary — but staggering nonetheless.

The Alouettes were leading Edmonton 16-12 early in the fourth quarter before the Eskimos erupted for three successive touchdowns in slightly less than 11 minutes.

It appeared to be a case of the Als’ defence, on the field for just over 37½ minutes, succumbing to attrition and breaking down. Nonetheless, a defiant Chip Cox vowed on Thursday history won’t be repeated this Sunday, against the Stampeders, at Molson Stadium.

“Do you think it’s going to happen again this week? Give us 40 minutes and I bet you it won’t happen again this week,” the strong-side linebacker, the Canadian Football League’s outstanding defensive player in 2013, stated following practice at Stade Hébert.

“We won’t let that happen again,” Cox continued. “Because we won’t. I can say that. This defence won’t let that happen again. We’re going to stand up. We’re going to put the team on our back. We’re going to take responsibility for everything.”

It won’t be easy, of course. The Stampeders (10-1) are the CFL’s best team and haven’t lost on the road this season. Even missing starting quarterback Bo Levi Mitchell and defensive-lineman Charleston Hughes, Calgary figures to be a formidable challenge. Drew Tate, who was the Stamps’ former starter, replaces the injured Mitchell.

“I don’t anticipate them changing how they play defensive or offensively,” Als head coach Tom Higgins said. “History has proven with that organization it doesn’t matter who’s playing. They seem to be able to be very productive.”

Productivity isn’t a word associated with the Als for the better part of two seasons. Montreal finished third in the East Division last year, at 8-10, and will be hard-pressed to match that mark as the team sits at 3-8. Indeed, even making the playoffs might be challenging, although the Als, Hamilton and Toronto all have three wins.

Losing might be part of football, but for veteran Als players, it remains a novelty.

“It has been tough, even last year,” offensive-tackle Josh Bourke said. “I’m not saying we can’t be great at some portion of the season, but we’re still trying to find our way — especially offensively. We have one decent game, then we struggle a little bit.

“We haven’t consistently been putting it together most of the season. Until we do, we’re just going to be an average to below-average offence.”

From breaking in an inexperienced offensive coordinator, Ryan Dinwiddie, to the shuffling of quarterbacks, little has worked for Montreal. And the numbers don’t lie. The Als have scored more points than only expansion Ottawa, more touchdowns than only the Redblacks. Montreal is last in the league in offence, averaging 267.5 yards per game. And the Als are ahead of only Ottawa in first downs.

Brandon Whitaker might be second in the CFL in rushing, with 605 yards, but Duron Carter potentially will be the Als’ only 1,000-yard receiver.

“We have vets everywhere on offence, slightly at quarterback. I don’t have excuses for you,” said slotback S.J. Green. “We just have to make the plays. Why aren’t we? Execution, lack of detail, attention to details, just not being locked in on the play at the time. I’m not saying guys aren’t focused, but obviously they’re not focused enough if they’re not making the play.”

The majority of Als players believe they’re still capable of escaping the abyss — Cox merely stating he hopes so — because they believe in each other and haven’t relinquished hope, because playing in a weak division leads to endless possibilities.

Of course, what else are they supposed to say?

“All we can go off is what we have in our locker room, the game plan and the trust we have in each other,” Green said. “Outside sources really don’t matter to us. Whether you guys (in the media) believe we can turn it around or not, we really don’t care.

“All we have is us, and we know that.”

Sunday’s game coincides with the Canadian Football Hall of Fame induction ceremony. Three former Als — slotback Ben Cahoon, offensive-tackle Uzooma Okeke and linebacker/punter Wally Buono, now the B.C. Lions’ general manager — are among this year’s entrants, with festivities beginning Friday night. Next month, during a game against Saskatchewan, quarterback Anthony Calvillo will have see number retired.

Cahoon, Okeke and Calvillo were part of great Montreal teams not so long ago. Teams that won, had glory and dominated. It was a tradition. It was the Als’ way. But that mystique has disappeared in the span of two years.

“I’m sure they’d be pissed off. They would see the product we put on the field every week and they’d be ashamed to wear an Alouettes jersey. I would be, too,” Green admitted. “I hope we can make them proud, put some wins together and make a playoff push.”

hzurkowsky@montrealgazette.com

Twitter: HerbZurkowsky1

Rookie Jeff Finley can laugh about it now, but he got pummelled last week against Edmonton, suffering a concussion. To learn more, go to montrealgazette.com/thesnap

column2: Alouettes prevail against injury-riddled Stampeders
column3:
So what if the Alouettes were meeting a depleted team, ravaged by injuries. In a season where wins have been few and far between, Montreal must take its victories where it can — in any shape or form.

The Als won for the third time in four games Sunday afternoon at Molson Stadium, defeating the Calgary Stampeders, 31-15, before 19,892 spectators. The Stamps were missing quarterback Bo Levi Mitchell, running-back Jon Cornish, leading receiver Marquay McDaniel and defensive-lineman Charleston Hughes.

Montreal improved to 4-8, keeping pace in the East Division with the Hamilton Tiger-Cats and Toronto Argonauts, both of whom defeated West Division teams this weekend. The Ticats are in first place, with a 4-7 record, while both the Argos and Als have identical marks — although Toronto has defeated Montreal once this season.

Calgary saw its six-game unbeaten streak come to an end, although the Stamps still hold the Canadian Football League’s best record of 10-2.

The game coincided with the Canadian Football Hall of Fame’s annual induction ceremony — former Als Ben Cahoon, Uzooma Okeke and Wally Buono among this year’s recipients.

Following a scoreless opening quarter, the Als went on a 10-play, 78-yard drive, capped by Tanner Marsh’s one-yard run at 1:06. Earlier in the drive, Jonathan Crompton completed a 27-yard pass to S.J. Green. The other significant play was a 22-yard completion to Duron Carter, moving the ball to the Calgary three-yard line.

Sean Whyte’s 50-yard punt single at 5:24 increased Montreal’s lead to 8-0. Stamps’ punter Rob Maver got that back with an 85-yard punt single at 6:58.

But the Als then went on a methodical seven-play, 75-yard drive to take a two-touchdown lead.

Crompton connected with James Rodgers for a 19-yard gain on the drive. Two plays later, coincidentally following two runs by Tyrell Sutton — ignored last week at Edmonton — Crompton hooked up with Rodgers for an 18-yard touchdown pass at 10:20. Rodgers broke a tackle on the play.

But the visitors went on a 12-play, 67-yard drive before halftime. Drew Tate, who was replacing Mitchell, gained 15 yards on the drive and capped the possession with a one-yard run, off play-action, for the touchdown at 14:37, sending the teams to their dressing rooms with the Als nursing a 15-8 lead.

Last week, Calgary overcame a 29-3 first-half deficit against Toronto. And it appeared history might be repeated when the Stamps scored on their opening possession of the third quarter, requiring only five plays to go 54 yards.

The significant play was a 39-yard pass to Maurice Price, who beat Billy Parker on the play, moving the ball to the Montreal six-yard line.

Tate then scored on a quarterback draw at 3:17, tying the score.

But the Als retained their composure under first-year starter Crompton.

Whyte’s 18-yard field goal late in the quarter capped an impressive drive — albeit one Montreal couldn’t complete — giving the home team an 18-15 lead.

A 19-yard punt return by Rodgers to begin the fourth quarter gave the Als good field position at the Calgary 45. Five plays later, and following a 20-yard run by Brandon Whitaker, Crompton passed 10 yards to Carter for a touchdown at 3:21.

Carter beat cornerback Quincy Butler on the play.

Montreal had a 10-point lead but wasn’t finished, Whyte’s 34-yard field goal midway through the fourth quarter proving to be a much-needed insurance score. Whyte added a 27-yarder at 12:18.

Both Sutton and defensive-tackle Michael Klassen sustained injuries for the Als. Klassen was taken off the field on a Gator, having suffered an injury to his left knee, it appeared.

The Als’ next game is this Friday night, at Ottawa.

hzurkowsky@montrealgazette.com

Twitter: herbZurkowsky1

column2: Zurkowsky: ‘It’s a win, we’ll take it’
column3:
Might this be the opportune occasion to remind everyone the Calgary Stampeders on Sunday were missing their starting quarterback, Bo Levi Mitchell, who has thrown for more than 2,500 yards and 17 touchdowns … a guy who, quite simply, just wins baby?

How about the fact they were also without tailback Jon Cornish? All he did last season was capture the Canadian Football League’s outstanding player award while also being named the top Canadian.

Marquay McDaniel? Calgary’s leading receiver. Charleston Hughes? The team leader in quarterback sacks.

This also might be a good time to remind readers of this space nothing upsets a professional athlete more than the suggestion his squad just beat an inferior team.

“I couldn’t care less who they play. Obviously, everyone has injuries,” said Josh Bourke, the Alouettes’ hulking offensive-tackle. “Cornish played a pretty damned good game last week. I don’t know what his situation was … nagging injuries? That’s what they’re saying. We’re not really concerned. They have two other running backs that are both professionals that are capable. Did they miss him? I’m sure they did.

“And Drew Tate’s got plenty of experience in this league. He’s had quite a bit of success. I don’t see a huge drop-off at the quarterback position.

“It’s a win –– and we’ll take it.”

Indeed. While the Als’ 31-15 victory was impressive, it must be kept in perspective. The Stampeders have depth, but Calgary didn’t field its strongest team. Tate was this team’s starter at one point, before sustaining injuries. But he’s the backup now, and clearly displayed why he has been cast in a supporting role.

He completed only 50 per cent of his passes, good on 15 of 30 attempts for a modest 152 yards. And he was intercepted once. Many of his throws almost looked like knuckleballs, his receivers unable to dig them out of the dirt. Calgary had the ball barely more than 23 minutes, generating only 15 first downs and 267 yards’ net offence.

Nonetheless, after leading his team to touchdowns late in the second quarter and another to begin the third period, Tate and the Stampeders were tied 15-15 with Montreal. The Als’ defence didn’t allow a point through the game’s final 26:43.

That was impressive, especially following the unit’s meltdown at Edmonton in their last game, the Eskimos scoring three consecutive touchdowns in the fourth quarter, erasing Montreal’s 16-12 lead.

“It was a statement. We know we didn’t perform in the fourth and we wanted to come out and do all we could not to blow it again,” said defensive-tackle Alan-Michael Cash, who recovered a pair of fourth-quarter fumbles.

In the days leading up to the game, linebacker Chip Cox told The Gazette the defence would carry the team this week –– even if the unit spent 40 minutes on the field. There wasn’t going to be another meltdown.

There could have been, when the score was tied.

“I think (last week’s performance) had a lot to do with it,” Cox said on Sunday. “We were in the same position last week and we blew it as a defence. We blew it. We’ve yet to finish a game, strong, while we were up.”

The Als have now, outscoring the visitors 13-0 in the final period. That fourth-quarter play was a regular occurrence, especially at home, when Anthony Calvillo was directing the huddle in the good old days, which now seem like a distant memory.

“There’s multiple signs that, all of a sudden, we’re getting where we want to be. I’ll take that (fourth quarter) as a sign,” said head coach Tom Higgins, showing some rare emotion when the game ended, pumping his fists in the air. “There’s no quit in the athletes. They have a lot of pride. It’s a challenge when you make so many changes. We’re going in a direction we feel is positive.

“The advantage you have, when you’re on the sideline and with the group, you know when there’s panic. There was no panic. They kept playing and made things happen. It’s easier to take when you know how the athletes are responding. You can let your mind wander if you want. But it’s easy to stay in the moment.”

The Als have now reached the two-thirds mark of this marathon with a 4-8 record. They’ve finally climbed above .500 at home, now at 4-3, but have yet to win on the road –– so plenty of issues remain.

But this team responded and met its challenge. Montreal took the field knowing both Toronto and Hamilton had won earlier this weekend. The Als knew they required a victory to keep pace, although they sit third in the East Division despite all three teams having won four times.

The Als have six games remaining –– two at Ottawa against an expansion team that pretty well loses every game but remains competitive; two against Toronto, one home and away; a home game against Saskatchewan, which has lost starting quarterback Darian Durant, and the season finale at Hamilton, a match that potentially looms large.

If you’re looking for signs in the tea leaves, the Tiger-Cats still have a game in hand while the Argos, who have played their last four on the road, still have five games remaining at the Rogers Centre with only six to play.

“I think all of the players would have known we wanted to stay on par with Toronto and Hamilton,” Higgins said.

hzurkowsky@montrealgazette.com

Twitter: HerbZurkowsky1

column2: Jazz festival: Five notable shows Tuesday, July 1, 2014
column3:
A quick look at five noteworthy shows Tuesday at the Montreal International Jazz Festival:

Brad Mehldau (7 p.m., Maison symphonique, $57 to $68.50). A jazz fest regular, the acclaimed pianist makes his Maison symphonique debut at this year’s event with a solo performance.

Tony Bennett (7:30 p.m., Salle Wilfrid-Pelletier of Place des Arts, $112.50 to $146.50). The legendary — and indefatigable — crooner, 87, will be joined on a few songs by his daughter, Antonia.

Marcus Miller (8 p.m., Théâtre Maisonneuve of Place des Arts, $50 to $57). The multiple-Grammy Award-winning multi-instrumentalist from Brooklyn is best known for his virtuoso bass work.

Burning Spear and Sly & Robbie (8:30 p.m., Metropolis, $53.55). A true double-bill featuring two of the most pre-eminent reggae acts of the past few decades, the legendary singer and the genre’s finest rhythm section, respectively.

Kenny Garrett Quintet (9:30 p.m., Théâtre Jean-Duceppe of Place des Arts, $52). The Detroit saxophonist, formerly of one of Miles Davis’s bands, is considered one of the finest players of his instrument in contemporary jazz.

For tickets and more information, visit montrealjazzfest.com. All prices include taxes.

column2: What to see at the jazz fest Wednesday
column3:
MONTREAL – A quick look at five noteworthy shows Wednesday at the Montreal International Jazz Festival, which wraps up July 6:

Matt Andersen and the Mellotones (7 p.m., Club Soda, 1225 St-Laurent Blvd., $36). The award-winning New Brunswick native showcases his new album, Weightless, featuring impassioned vocals complemented by sunny folk/blues guitar.

Zappa Plays Zappa (8:30 p.m., Metropolis, 59 Ste-Catherine St. E., $40 to $68.55). Few musicians can hope to accurately re-create Frank Zappa’s mind-frying compositions, but son Dweezil has the exceptional genes, talent and bandmates required to keep his father’s legacy alive.

The London Souls (9 and 11 p.m., Loto-Québec Stage, de Montigny and Clark Sts., free). The New Yorkers marry a love of vintage British rock with classic pop hooks, and come armed with a fiery live rep.

Randy Weston and Billy Harper (9:30 p.m., Cinquième Salle of Place des Arts, $52). Weston, whose piano style bears the influence of Thelonious Monk, and sharp-toned saxophonist Harper, who has played with Art Blakey’s Jazz Messengers and Max Roach, team up in support of their album The Roots of the Blues.

Of Montreal (11 p.m., Club Soda, $37). Kevin Barnes and his genre-straddling Athens, Ga., psychedelic polymaths return to their spiritual home.

For tickets and more information, visit montrealjazzfest.com. All prices include taxes. For more jazz fest coverage, please join us at montrealgazette.com/mtlfest and add your own photos and tweets by using the hashtag #mtlfest

column2: The Revenge of Dr. Porter?
column3: Arthur Porter, the former head of the McGill University Health Centre who is facing extradition to Canada to face fraud, breach of trust and money laundering charges, has been held in a Panamanian jail for more than a year. During that time he says he’s been treating himself for stage four lung cancer, tear gassed and injured in a prison riot and, every now and then, proclaimed his innocence and vilified his accusers via his ongoing blog Illegal in LaJoya, a reference to the name of the infamous jail where he is being incarcerated. But now it seems that Dr. Porter has also found the time to write what ostensibly is a memoir but what might also be perceived a list of allegations against those who were associated with him in happier days. Entitled “The Man Behind the Bow Tie”, the work purports to detail Porter’s relations with, among others, Prime Minister Stephen Harper and Quebec premier Philippe Couillard. Is this a work of history? Of fiction? Is it revenge? The Gazette’s Aaron Derfel has been reporting on the triumphs and travails of Porter’s career and read his latest work. We asked him what he made of Porter’s version of events. Click on the audio player below to hear what he had to say. And remember, you can listen to all of our podcasts at montrealgazette.com/montreal@themoment on iTunes and follow us on Facebook

column2: The Story So Far: Dr. Porter dishes dirt; city hall probe was political - union
