To share memories, please visit vermeulenfuneralhome.com.

Clark R. Curtis

Clark R. Curtis, 65, of Bad Axe, passed away on Tuesday, March 25, 2014, at McLaren Regional Medical Center in Bay City .

He was born on June 14, 1948, in Stockbridge, son of Glenn and Therma (Hayhoe) Curtis. He married Mary Gajewski on May 31,1980, in the Bad Axe Free Methodist Church.

He was a teacher for 34 years in the Ubly School District, where he also coached the girls basketball team. He was a committee member of the Bad Axe Downtown Development Authority, and enjoyed hunting and woodworking .

He is survived by his wife, Mary Curtis of Bad Axe; daughter Tammy Cushard of Jackson; four sons, Kevin Curtis of Zephyrhills, Fla., Scott (Julie) Curtis of South Bend, Ind., Brian (Pam) Curtis of Auburn Hills, Chad (Amanda) Raftery of St. Louis, Mich.; mother, Therma Curtis of Stockbridge; nine grandchildren, Tori Cushard of Ann Arbor, Heather Cushard of Jackson, Amanda Cushard of Jackson, Avery Curtis of South Bend, Ind., Michael Curtis of South Bend, Ind., William Mills-Curtis of Auburn Hills, Madison Raftery, McKenzie Raftery and Cameron Raftery all of St. Louis, Mich.

He was predeceased by his father, Glenn Curtis.

Services will be at 11 a.m. on Monday, March 31, 2014 at the Kaufman Funeral Home in Bad Axe. Burial will be in Colfax Cemetery.

Visitation is from 1 to 8 p.m. on Sunday and from 10 a.m. until the time of service on Monday at the Kaufman Funeral Home.

Memorials may be offered to the Ubly girl’s basketball fund .

Ernest (Ernie) Goretski

Ernest (Ernie) Goretski, 81, passed away Wednesday March 26, 2014, at Huron Medical Center in Bad Axe after a battle with cancer.

He was born on March 20, 1933, to the late Allen and Viola (Murawski) Goretski.

He celebrated 58 years of marriage on November 12, 2013 with his wife, Grace (Lasceski), whom he married in St. Mary’s Catholic Church in Dwight Township.

Ernie farmed his entire life with his wife and son David. He loved his animals, enjoyed going to auction sales, watching WWF Wrestling and playing with his grandson Jonathan. He was a member of Kinde Seniors Club and was a director of Farmers Mutual Fire Insurance Company.

He is survived by his wife Grace; son, David; and grandson, Jonathan Goretski; as well as David’s fiancé, Christine McDaniels and her daughters, Alexandra and Jessica. Also surviving are two brothers; Clarence (Josephine) Goretski of Bad Axe and Ronald Goretski of Kinde; one sister-in-law, Bernice (Mark) Osentoski of Kinde; and brother in law, Jerry(Sue) Lasceski of Fairgrove.

He was preceded in death by sisters; Bernice Goretski and Florence Lasceski; brothers-in-law, Leonard Goretski, Bernard Lasceski and John Lasceski; sister-in-law Barbara Lasceski; in-laws; John and Anna Lasceski,

Funeral Mass will be at 11 a.m. on Saturday, March 29, at St. Michael’s Catholic Church of the Annunciation of the Lord Parish, in Port Austin, with Father Craig Carolan officiating. Burial will be in the church cemetery

Visitation will be from 6-8 p.m. Thursday and from 1-8 p.m. Friday at Knoblock Funeral Home in Kinde, and from 9 a.m. Saturday until leaving for the church at 10:30 a.m. at the funeral home. There will be parish vigil at 7 p.m. on Friday evening.

Dorothy Marie Hylko (nee Watchowski)

Dorothy Marie Hylko (nee Watchowski), 84, a longtime resident of Warren, died on Sunday, March 23, 2014.

She was born in Dwight Township in Huron County, on May 8, 1929. She was the daughter of the late Anthony and Frances (Ornowski) Watchowski. Dorothty was united in marriage to William Hylko at St. Mary’s Catholic Church, Dwight Township, on May 7, 1949.

She was a homemaker, and enjoyed gardening, fishing, and spending time with her family.

She was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother and is survived by her children Diane (Robert) Sinagra, Denise (Dennis) Rocco, and Dennis (Michele); grandchildren Kristina (John), Katherine, Karen and her fiancé Michael, Anthony and his fiancé Kristen, Nicole; step-grandson Matthew; and several grand-dogs. She is also survived by her twin sister, Virginia Deman.

In addition to her parents, she was predeceased by her loving husband of 63 years, William Hylko; as well as four brothers and four sisters.

A special thanks to the staff at KALB AFC Home II and Henry Ford Hospice for their loving care and support during Dorothy’s illness.

The funeral mass will be at 10 a.m. Monday at St. Mary’s, Our Lady Queen of Families (formerly St. Clements) 25320 Van Dyke Ave, Centerline, 48015.

Visitation will be from 3 to 8 p.m. on Sunday, with prayers at 6:30 p.m., at Resurrection Funeral Home 40800 Hayes, Clinton Township, 48038.

Visit online at www.resurrectionfuneralhome.com.

Caroline Elsie (Schelke) Williams

Caroline Elsie (Schelke) Williams, 86, of Rapson, passed away peacefully on Monday, March 24, 2014.

She was born on March 11, 1928, in Bloomfield Township, daughter of the late William and Olga (Pleiness) Schelke.

She married Alvin Williams on Sept. 9, 1950, in the former Bloomfield Lutheran Church.

She was a longtime Rapson farmer and a member of Our Savior Lutheran Church in Bad Axe.

She enjoyed crocheting, quilting, sewing, baking, reading, reupholstering furniture, and spending time with family.

She is survived by two children, Allan (Jan) Williams of Utica and Shari (David) Luttenberger of Utica; a sister, Mildred Pawlitz of Port Hope; four sisters-in-law, Florence Schelke of Harbor Beach, Mildred Steciak of Bad Axe, Eleanor Bambach of Bad Axe and Irene (Arnold) Stirrett of Sterling Heights; six grandchildren, Erica (Jerry) Heinecke of Thorp, Wis., Melanie (Daniel) Bellinger of Houston, Texas, Adam (Elizabeth) Williams of Houston, Texas, Alyssa Williams of Toledo, Ohio, Heather Luttenberger of Utica and Sarah Luttenberger of Utica; four great-grandchildren, Malachi, Zachary, and Avelyn Heinecke of Thorp, Wis. and Lilah Williams of Houston, Texas.

She was preceded in death by her husband, Alvin Williams on July 3, 2003; and two brothers, Arnold Schelke and Harry Schelke.

Services will take place at 11 a.m. on Saturday, March 29, at Our Savior of Lutheran Church in Bad Axe. Officiating will be the Rev. Kenneth Lueke, pastor. Burial will be in Lakeview Cemetery in Port Hope.

Friends may call at from 2 to 8 p.m. on Friday the Kaufman Funeral Home in Bad Axe, or from 10 a.m. until the service time at 11 a.m. on Saturday at the church.

Memorials may be offered to the family memorial fund.

Michael “Mick” Lynn Yaroch

Michael “Mick” Lynn Yaroch, 60, resident of Sheridan Township, passed away Tuesday, March 26, 2014, at his home, with his family by his side, while under hospice.

He was born April 30, 1953 in Bad Axe to the late Frank and Gertrude (Rice) Yaroch.

Michael was united in marriage to Caroline Dorsch on Sept. 6, 1974. She preceded him in death on Jan. 20, 1994.

He was a member of Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Bad Axe. Michael graduated from Bad Axe High School and was employed at Wal-Mart in Bad Axe. He was a big Michigan and Detroit Tiger fan and loved all sports, buying lotto tickets and attending antique car shows. He liked to hunt deer, turkey and pheasant.

Michael is survived by his brother, Ron (Kathy) Yaroch of Bad Axe; two sisters, Pat Wells of Bad Axe and Judy Copeland of Bad Axe; a special nephew, Joe (Darlene) Yaroch and special godchild, Tiffany Jurgess; several nieces and nephews; special care givers, Steve and Betty Jurgess; special friend, Robert Keehn and many other friends.

He was preceded in death by a son, Michael Yaroch on March 4, 1994; sisters, Frances Wassin and Kathleen Kay Yaroch; nephew, Marvin Johnston; niece, Deborah Johnston and a brother in-law, William Wells.

Mass of Christian Burial will be at 11 a.m. on Monday, March 31, 2014 at Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Bad Axe with Fr. Robert Howe officiating. Burial will be in Sacred Heart Cemetery.

Visitation will take place Sunday from 2 - 9 p.m. with a scripture service at 7 p.m. at MacAlpine Funeral Home in Bad Axe and at 10 a.m. at the church until time of service Monday.

Memorials may be offered to the American Cancer Society or Muscular Dystrophy.

Condolences may be shared at www.macalpinefuneralhome.com.

column2: Plan to finance college after finishing draws interest
column3:
Plan to finance college after finishing draws interest

Sacramento -- A state lawmaker wants California to join a growing number of states that are examining a college financing system that flips the current model on its head.

Where colleges typically charge tuition and fees prior to enrollment, the new model instead would have students pay after they finish through fixed payroll deductions.

The "pay it forward, pay it back" model is catching the attention of educators, lawmakers and students nationally, with nearly a dozen states considering different variations. Assemblyman Reggie Jones-Sawyer, D-South Los Angeles, introduced a bill last week asking the state to study whether the model should be offered to some Californians.

The idea is that after college, students would contribute a portion of their earnings - from 1.5 percent to 4 percent - to an education trust for about 20 years. That trust would fund future generations of students.

"It's Social Security turned upside down," said John Burbank, executive director of the Economic Opportunity Institute, a Seattle-based liberal think tank that began researching and marketing the model as debt-free access to higher education. "Here you get your benefits right away, then contribute."

LATEST SFGATE VIDEOS Now Playing: Now Playing Still Standing Lea Suzuki

The wettest and driest places in the Bay Area Ted Andersen, Alix Martichoux, SFGATE

The Regulars: The Mushroom Hacker Nani Walker, Robin Simmonds and Lauren Schwartzman

Candy Land: How West Oakland's Ocho Candy Makes Its Organic Sweet Treats Sarah Fritsche

Bernal Heights hit-and-run San Francisco Chronicle

Woman's car plunges 300 feet off cliff near Pacifica California Highway Patrol

SF Brewing Co. Ghirardelli Square Virtual Tour San Francisco Chronicle

The story behind You're Going to Die, SF's death-related open mike San Francisco Chronicle

Protesting the death of Stephon Clark: ‘You murdered a Son’ New York Times

David Nayfeld making pasta San Francisco Chronicle

But the idea isn't without its critics. Some education policy experts warn that high-income graduates could wind up paying thousands more for their education than if tuition was paid up front. They also fear that taxpayers could be asked to cover initial startup costs or that schools would have a hard time seeking payroll deductions if former students moved out of state.

A coalition of education groups - including the American Association of State Colleges and Universities, the American Association of University Professors, and the American Federation of Teachers - have voiced strong criticism of the model, saying it further shifts the cost of higher education on students and families. They believe states should instead improve funding for public colleges and universities and increase need-based student aid.

"The Pay It Forward model puts a tiny Band-Aid on a gaping wound without doing anything to stop the cause of the bleeding," said Sara Goldrick-Rab, an associate professor of educational policy studies at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, who has studied the model and says more students are taking on debt due to rising college costs. "This policy sounds far better than it really is."

But supporters believe the model could open doors for students who otherwise would not consider college. That includes households where there is a cultural or familial aversion to taking on substantial debt, said Isaac Bowers of Equal Justice Works, a Washington, D.C., group of lawyers that represents underserved communities and causes.

"The opportunity to go and repay later is pretty innovative and may break down some of those barriers to access," Bowers said.

The cost of attending California's public universities and community colleges has doubled since 2007, although tuition and fees remain among the lowest in the country and graduates, on average, borrow less than students in most states.

Students at California's public and non-profit colleges rank 48th in student debt. Half of California's undergraduates finish with debt that averages $20,300, according to statistics in Gov. Jerry Brown's budget proposal for the 2014-15 fiscal year. Nationally, 70 percent of undergraduates finish with debt, which averages $29,400.

Proponents argue that the model does not have to replace current college financing models, but instead can be used as another option to students.

"We came up with this idea and it seems to have struck a nerve since there is a lot of interest," Burbank said. "Both Republicans and Democrats have children. They see these rising costs of tuition and are freaked out by it. This may have some mileage that is bipartisan."

Last month, Sen. Jeff Merkley, D-Oregon, introduced legislation in the U.S. Senate that would help states implement the program. Under Merkley's Pay It Forward College Affordability Act of 2013, students would still have the option of concurrently participating while taking out federal loans, receiving federal grants and other aid from public and private sources.

The Oregon Legislature unanimously passed a bill in July to create a study committee that will develop a pilot program for the pay-it-forward model, with lawmakers deciding in 2015 whether to implement the plan. Since then, officials in several other states have begun exploring whether they should be exploring the model, too.

In California, AB1456 calls on the state's public university and community college systems and Student Aid Commission to study the model to determine whether a pilot program should be created through future legislation.

AB1456 is scheduled to be heard in the California Assembly later this month or in early February.

column2: 'Redskins’ school mascots would be phased out under bill
column3:
'Redskins’ school mascots would be phased out under bill

Photo: Tony Avelar, Associated Press Image 1 of / 4 Caption Close Image 1 of 4 A group protests the Washington Redskins name across from Levi's Stadium before an NFL football game between the Redskins and the San Francisco 49ers in Santa Clara, Calif., Sunday, Nov. 23, 2014. (AP Photo/Tony Avelar) less A group protests the Washington Redskins name across from Levi's Stadium before an NFL football game between the Redskins and the San Francisco 49ers in Santa Clara, Calif., Sunday, Nov. 23, 2014. (AP ... more Photo: Tony Avelar, Associated Press Image 2 of 4 A group protests the Washington Redskins name across from Levi's Stadium before an NFL football game between the Redskins and the San Francisco 49ers in Santa Clara, Calif., Sunday, Nov. 23, 2014. (AP Photo/Tony Avelar) less A group protests the Washington Redskins name across from Levi's Stadium before an NFL football game between the Redskins and the San Francisco 49ers in Santa Clara, Calif., Sunday, Nov. 23, 2014. (AP ... more Photo: Tony Avelar, Associated Press Image 3 of 4 FILE - In this Aug. 28, 2009, file photo, the Washington Redskins logo is displayed at midfield before the start of a preseason NFL football game in Landover, Md. The team's nickname, which some consider a derogatory term for Native Americans, has faced a barrage of criticism. But a new Associated Press-GfK poll shows that nationally, “Redskins” still enjoys widespread support. (AP Photo/Nick Wass, File) less FILE - In this Aug. 28, 2009, file photo, the Washington Redskins logo is displayed at midfield before the start of a preseason NFL football game in Landover, Md. The team's nickname, which some consider a ... more Photo: Nick Wass, Associated Press Image 4 of 4 'Redskins’ school mascots would be phased out under bill 1 / 4 Back to Gallery

SACRAMENTO — A California lawmaker is attempting to force four high schools in the Golden State that use “Redskins” as their mascots to abandon the controversial name.

Assemblyman Luis Alejo, D-Watsonville, introduced AB30 this month, giving public schools until 2017 to phase out the use of the Redskins as mascots. It is the third time the Legislature will consider similar statewide bans on Indian-themed mascots since 2002.

Alejo’s bill would specifically affect four holdout schools that are the remaining campuses in the state using the mascot. Those schools are Gustine High School in Merced County, Calaveras High School in Calaveras County, Chowchilla Union High School in Madera County and Tulare Union High School in Tulare County.

Sarah Koligian, superintendent of the Tulare Joint Union High School District, and other school leaders say their communities take great pride in their Redskins mascot.

LATEST SFGATE VIDEOS Now Playing: Now Playing Still Standing Lea Suzuki

The wettest and driest places in the Bay Area Ted Andersen, Alix Martichoux, SFGATE

The Regulars: The Mushroom Hacker Nani Walker, Robin Simmonds and Lauren Schwartzman

Candy Land: How West Oakland's Ocho Candy Makes Its Organic Sweet Treats Sarah Fritsche

Bernal Heights hit-and-run San Francisco Chronicle

Woman's car plunges 300 feet off cliff near Pacifica California Highway Patrol

SF Brewing Co. Ghirardelli Square Virtual Tour San Francisco Chronicle

The story behind You're Going to Die, SF's death-related open mike San Francisco Chronicle

Protesting the death of Stephon Clark: ‘You murdered a Son’ New York Times

David Nayfeld making pasta San Francisco Chronicle

“Tulare Union Redskins are part of a long and proud tradition dating back to 1890,” Koligian said. “Our school has worked closely with our local Indian tribes to include them in the discussion regarding how the Tulare Union Redskin depicts both pride and respect.”

Other schools have dropped Redskins as a mascot amid increasing protests from those who say the term is offensive. The issue resurfaced this season in the NFL, which saw protesters gather outside games played by the Washington, D.C., team to lobby for it to change its mascot. The Assembly passed a resolution by Alejo in August urging the team to make a change.

Alejo said “singling out the Native American community” for the mockery and taunts that mascots are often subjected to is discriminatory.

In 2002, American Indians began pushing legislation in California to ban the use of mascots like Redskins, Chiefs, Comanches, Indians and Braves after years of taking their protests to individual school boards to appeal for changes.

That bill by Jackie Goldberg, a then-Assemblywoman from Los Angeles, failed in the Legislature in 2002. Goldberg narrowed the bill to only ban the use of Redskins, which the Legislature passed in 2004. However, then-Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger vetoed that bill, saying “decisions regarding athletic team names, nicknames or mascots should be retained at the local level.”

“This is long overdue,” Alejo said. “The bill gives a reasonable amount of time to prepare and phase out their mascots.”

Under the AB30, all public schools would be prohibited from using the term Redskins as a school or athletic team mascot beginning Jan. 1, 2017, unless a tribe within the boundaries of the school has authorized the use of the name.

To save on the cost of changing the mascot, schools would be allowed to continue to use uniforms and other materials with the Redskins mascot if the item was purchased before the bill became effective. New purchases would bear the new mascot, however. The state may be obligated to pay for some of the costs associated with new school and athletic supplies.

“It’s a small thing we can do in California that is part of a national movement to phase out the use of racial slurs as mascots,” Alejo said.

Melody Gutierrez is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. E-mail: mgutierrez@sfchronicle.com Twitter: @MelodyGutierrez

column2: SIUE professor named to Ferguson Commission
column3:
SIUE professor named to Ferguson Commission

FERGUSON — Missouri Governor Jay Nixon has named 16 members to the Ferguson Commission Tuesday, including SIUE Professor of Public Administration T.R. Carr Jr.

“The members of the Ferguson Commission are tough, they are smart, they are empowered and they are independent,” Nixon said in a release. “Their most important work will not be what is written on sheets of paper or on a website. Their most important work will be the changes we see in our institutions and our work places, in our communities and in our interactions with one another. Change of this magnitude is hard; but maintaining the status quo is simply not acceptable.”

According to Carr’s biography on the SIUE website, he is a professor and program director at the Department of Public Administration and Policy Analysis at SIUE. He is also a Senior Research Fellow with the Institute of Urban Research at SIUE. He has an MPA and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Oklahoma. He recently completed the “Vision 2020”, a federally-funded Department of Labor project through the Madison County Workforce Investment Board in cooperation with the Mid American Workforce Investment Board.

In the St. Louis area, Carr has served as mayor of Hazelwood, MO for three terms from April 2000 to May 2009. He served as president of the St. Louis County Municipal League, Secretary-Treasurer of the Metro Mayors of Greater St. Louis and served on the East-West Gateway Council of Governments Board of Directors.

LATEST SFGATE VIDEOS Now Playing: Now Playing Still Standing Lea Suzuki

The wettest and driest places in the Bay Area Ted Andersen, Alix Martichoux, SFGATE

The Regulars: The Mushroom Hacker Nani Walker, Robin Simmonds and Lauren Schwartzman

Candy Land: How West Oakland's Ocho Candy Makes Its Organic Sweet Treats Sarah Fritsche

Bernal Heights hit-and-run San Francisco Chronicle

Woman's car plunges 300 feet off cliff near Pacifica California Highway Patrol

SF Brewing Co. Ghirardelli Square Virtual Tour San Francisco Chronicle

The story behind You're Going to Die, SF's death-related open mike San Francisco Chronicle

Protesting the death of Stephon Clark: ‘You murdered a Son’ New York Times

David Nayfeld making pasta San Francisco Chronicle

Because of his service to the St. Louis region, he has received the Buzz Westfall Award for Excellence in Leadership from the St. Louis County Municipal League as well.

“My goal is to build bridges, build relationships, help advance Ferguson, North County and the St. Louis region,” Carr said to St. Louis Positive Change, the official site for the Ferguson Commission. “Our challenge is to build trust between the public, law enforcement and local government. I believe my background and skills will contribute to the effectiveness of the Ferguson Commission. I live in North County, served as mayor of Hazelwood for nine years, am a graduate of McCluer High School and a professor of public policy at SIUE. The issues that emerged in Ferguson require thoughtful deliberation with a range of voices on the commission. It is important to effectively communicate with the law enforcement community as strategies are developed for this region. I can help serve as a bridge in the area.”

The Ferguson Commission will be responsible for issuing a report with policy recommendations in the areas of: citizen-law enforcement interaction and relations, racial and ethnic relations, municipal government organization and the municipal court system, and disparities in areas including education, economic opportunity, housing, transportation, health care, child care, business ownership, family and community stability.

Nixon has given the commission until Sept. 15, 2015, to issue its reports, but said that he would welcome any interim recommendations for positive steps that can be taken prior to the completion of its final report. The commission has been given $100,000 from the Missouri Development Finance Board for operating costs, research and other expenses. Funding is also coming from private sources. The commission will operate from space provided by Washington University.

Besides Carr, the commission has selected 15 other individuals from the list of more than 300 applicants and nominations. They are:

Rev. Starsky Wilson, CEO of the Deconess Foundation

Rich McClure, former president and COO of Unigroup

Rev. Traci Blackmon, pastor of Christ the King United Church of Christ.

Dan Isom II, director of the Missouri Department of Public Safety

Scott Negwer, president of Negwer Materials in Ferguson

Bethany Johnson-Javois, CEO of the St. Louis Integrated Health Network

Gabriel E. Gore, attorney and partner at the law firm of Dowd Bennett, LLC

Brittany Packnett, executive director of Teach for America

Rose Windmiller, assistant vice chancellor for government & community relations at Washington University

Rasheen Aldridge, Jr., community organizer and director of Young Activists United

Grayling Tobias, superintendent of the Hazelwood School District

Becky James-Hatter, president and CEO of Big Brothers Big Sisters of Eastern Missouri

Felicia Pulliam, director of development for FOCUS St. Louis and Ferguson resident.

Kevin Ahlbrand, detective sergeant with the St. Louis Metropolitan Police Department and president of the Missouri State Fraternal Order of Police.

Patrick Sly, executive vice-president at Emerson

“These 16 men and women bring to the table a rich diversity of life experience and points of view-business owners and not-for-profit leaders; teachers and lawyers; police officers and activists; pastors and public servants,” Nixon said in a release. “But while they are clearly a diverse group, they are united by their shared passion to promote understanding, to hasten healing, to ensure equal opportunities in education and employment and to safeguard the civil rights of all our citizens.”

column2: Tough climb pays off on Mount St. Helena
column3:
Tough climb pays off on Mount St. Helena

Image 1 of / 1 Caption Close Image 1 of 1 Tough climb pays off on Mount St. Helena 1 / 1 Back to Gallery

What you'll see: On crystal-clear days in early spring, the view from the top of 4,343-foot Mount St. Helena can make life seem complete. On the best days, you can see the snow glisten white on the Sierra Crest 150 miles to the east. Closer to home, Mount Tamalpais and Mount Diablo rise to the south in the Bay Area. Lake Berryessa is below to the east, and the Napa Valley plunges to the south. Several times in the spring, I've seen the clear outline of Lassen Peak to the northeast.

Location: 7 miles north of Calistoga, at the border of northern Napa, eastern Sonoma and southern Lake counties.

LATEST SFGATE VIDEOS Now Playing: Now Playing Still Standing Lea Suzuki

The wettest and driest places in the Bay Area Ted Andersen, Alix Martichoux, SFGATE

The Regulars: The Mushroom Hacker Nani Walker, Robin Simmonds and Lauren Schwartzman

Candy Land: How West Oakland's Ocho Candy Makes Its Organic Sweet Treats Sarah Fritsche

Bernal Heights hit-and-run San Francisco Chronicle

Woman's car plunges 300 feet off cliff near Pacifica California Highway Patrol

SF Brewing Co. Ghirardelli Square Virtual Tour San Francisco Chronicle

The story behind You're Going to Die, SF's death-related open mike San Francisco Chronicle

Protesting the death of Stephon Clark: ‘You murdered a Son’ New York Times

David Nayfeld making pasta San Francisco Chronicle

The hike: 10.2-mile round trip, with a 2,068-foot elevation gain on the way up. The route emerges from oak woodlands on a dirt service road. The climb is steady with two steep spots. Four miles in, continue straight at a junction to the North Peak (a left takes you to the 4,003-foot South Peak).

Trail time: Strong hikers will make the summit in about 2 1/2 to 3 hours, with the last half hour strenuous, and then return downhill in about 1 1/2 to 2 hours.

On-the-spot note: In spring, bring a windbreaker for the often-chilly breezes out of the north at the top and a change of shirts for the one you will likely soak with sweat during the climb, especially if you carry a pack.

Dogs, mountain bikes: No dogs are permitted, per state parks policy. Mountain bikes are allowed, but it's a very challenging ride.

History lesson: The mountain is in Robert Louis Stevenson State Park, so named because this is where Stevenson, the author of "Treasure Island," spent his summer honeymoon in 1880, in a cabin long since gone. The cabin site is off a spur (hikers only), 1.5 miles in, marked along the trail to the top.

Cost: Parking, access are free.

Map/brochure: PDF at www.parks.ca.gov.

How to get there: From the Golden Gate Bridge, drive north on Highway 101 for 48 miles to Santa Rosa and the exit signed for Highway 12 east. Take that exit and go 2.7 miles (signed turns) to Highway 12. Turn right on Highway 12 east and drive 2.4 miles to Calistoga Road. Turn left and drive 7.1 miles (becomes Petrified Forest Road) and then continue 4.4 miles to Highway 128/Foothill Boulevard. Turn left and go 0.8 of a mile to Tubbs Lane (this route bypasses Calistoga to the north, missing city traffic). Turn right on Tubbs and drive 1.3 miles to Highway 29. Turn left on 29 and drive 7.2 miles (climbs, becomes twisty) to signed trailhead parking on the left.

Distance: 25 miles from Santa Rosa, 50 miles from Vallejo, 70 miles from Concord, 73 miles from Berkeley, 82 miles from San Francisco, 98 miles from Burlingame.

Contacts: Robert Louis Stevenson State Park, c/o Bothe-Napa Valley State Park, (707) 942-4575; www.parks.ca.gov; Calistoga info, (866) 306-5588, www.visitcalistoga.com.

- Tom Stienstra

column2: John Muir National Historic Site: Where explorer settled down
column3:
John Muir National Historic Site: Where explorer settled down

When conservationist John Muir returned from the wild in 1890, he and his wife settled in Martinez, on his father-in-law's 2,600-acre fruit ranch. Today, you can visit his home and see his "scribble den," 9 acres of the orchard and the historic Martinez Adobe home.

If you want more exercise, take a 2.4-mile hike and climb nearby Mount Wanda, where Muir tramped with his two daughters.

The John Muir National Historic Site is open 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Wednesday through Sunday. It is closed on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. There is no admission fee. For more information, call (925) 228-8860 or go to www.nps.gov/jomu.

LATEST SFGATE VIDEOS Now Playing: Now Playing Still Standing Lea Suzuki

The wettest and driest places in the Bay Area Ted Andersen, Alix Martichoux, SFGATE

The Regulars: The Mushroom Hacker Nani Walker, Robin Simmonds and Lauren Schwartzman

Candy Land: How West Oakland's Ocho Candy Makes Its Organic Sweet Treats Sarah Fritsche

Bernal Heights hit-and-run San Francisco Chronicle

Woman's car plunges 300 feet off cliff near Pacifica California Highway Patrol

SF Brewing Co. Ghirardelli Square Virtual Tour San Francisco Chronicle

The story behind You're Going to Die, SF's death-related open mike San Francisco Chronicle

Protesting the death of Stephon Clark: ‘You murdered a Son’ New York Times

David Nayfeld making pasta San Francisco Chronicle

Visitor center and grounds

Start at the Visitor Center at 4202 Alhambra Ave. Here you will find a helpful ranger, books and T-shirts for sale, clean restrooms and, best of all, a fascinating 20-minute movie about John Muir's life. If you are planning to climb Mount Wanda, ask the ranger for a trail map. Exit the back of the visitor center to begin a tour of the park grounds.

Wander through the extensive orchard of grapevines and apple, pear, apricot, orange and lemon trees. (You are free to take home fallen fruit.) You can also take a self-guided cell phone tour of the grounds. Tables and benches are there for picnicking.

The Strentzel-Muir House

Take the path uphill to the Strentzel-Muir House. Although John Muir often hiked in the rugged wilderness, the home where he lived was huge and luxurious. Given to him and his wife by his in-laws, Dr. John and Louisiana Strentzel, who had lived in it previously, the Italianate Victorian home is 10,000 square feet and has 17 rooms with 12-foot ceilings. Knowledgeable docents are available to show you around.

The Martinez Adobe

Another "must-visit" structure on the grounds is the Martinez Adobe. Don Vicente Martinez was the son of the comandante of the San Francisco Presidio and built this adobe house around 1849. The house passed into the hands of Muir's father-in-law. Later, Muir's daughter Wanda and her husband lived there, and Muir often visited to have dinner and play with his grandchildren.

Today, the adobe features exhibits about the Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail. You can learn about de Anza's 1775-1776 journey when he led more than 200 men, women, and children from Sonora, Mexico, to Monterey.

Mount Wanda

Although the trailhead through this 326-acre parcel is only about a quarter mile from the visitor center, you cannot safely walk from one to the other as there is no sidewalk on Alhambra Avenue. Parking for Mount Wanda is at the Caltrans Park and Ride lot next to Franklin Canyon Road. There is also a bus stop here.

During the spring, wildflowers abound. From the summit at 640 feet, you can enjoy sweeping views of Martinez, the Carquinez Strait and Mount Diablo. Pick up the trail (actually a fire road) on Franklin Canyon Road. Past the information kiosk, the road ascends for about a half-mile through bay, oak and buckeyes. Then, split off on the Nature Trail, which is more level and wooded, with benches for resting and a stream trickling along below.

When the Nature Trail ends, turn left back on the fire trail. Then, to get to the summit (more mound than mountain), quickly turn right on another fire road and then left on a path to the top with its 360-degree views. Return to the main fire road and back to the trailhead.

If you go

John Muir National Historic Site: Public transportation: Take the County Connection 98X from the Walnut Creek BART Station or the County Connection 16 from the Concord BART Station. Both buses stop in front of the John Muir Visitor Center. By car from S.F.: Cross the Bay Bridge and continue on Interstate 80 eastbound to Highway 4 eastbound. Exit at Alhambra Avenue, then turn left at the bottom of the ramp. Cross beneath the highway, and the park will be on your left.

column2: Controller candidates insist they're not politicians
column3:
Controller candidates insist they're not politicians Yee, Swearengin tout budgetary, executive expertise







window._taboola = window._taboola || []; _taboola.push({ mode: 'thumbnails-c', container: 'taboola-interstitial-gallery-thumbnails-4', placement: 'Interstitial Gallery Thumbnails 4', target_type: 'mix' }); _taboola.push({flush: true});



Photo: Jason Henry, Special To The Chronicle Image 1 of / 4 Caption Close Image 1 of 4 Democrat Betty Yee says her experience as a member of the state Board of Equalization will serve her well as controller. Democrat Betty Yee says her experience as a member of the state Board of Equalization will serve her well as controller. Photo: Jason Henry, Special To The Chronicle Image 2 of 4 Candidate for state controller, Ashley Swearengin Candidate for state controller, Ashley Swearengin Photo: Ashley Swearengin Campaign, For State Controller 2014 Image 3 of 4 John Chiang was a voice for fiscal prudence and honest budgeting during the tough years. John Chiang was a voice for fiscal prudence and honest budgeting during the tough years. Photo: Dylan Entelis / The Chronicle Image 4 of 4 Controller candidates insist they're not politicians 1 / 4 Back to Gallery

One of November's hottest ballot battles matches two women who swear they're not politicians.

Democrat Betty Yee of Alameda and Republican Ashley Swearengin, mayor of Fresno, both say their race to replace termed-out Democrat John Chiang as state controller is less about partisan labels and more about who can best serve as watchdog over California's precariously balanced economy.

"I'm a wonk, not a politician," the 56-year-old Yee protested before appearing at a San Francisco event for Emily's List, a group that supports Democratic women who favor abortion rights.

At a talk before the Sacramento Press Club, Swearengin, 42, also eased away from her party roots, declining to endorse Neel Kashkari, the Republican candidate for governor, and noting that she has never held a partisan office.

"I think voters are looking for an independent view," she said.

LATEST SFGATE VIDEOS Now Playing: Now Playing Woman hit by Sacramento sheriff's deputy vehicle during Stephon Clark protest Guy Danilowitz

Still Standing Lea Suzuki

The wettest and driest places in the Bay Area Ted Andersen, Alix Martichoux, SFGATE

The Regulars: The Mushroom Hacker Nani Walker, Robin Simmonds and Lauren Schwartzman

Candy Land: How West Oakland's Ocho Candy Makes Its Organic Sweet Treats Sarah Fritsche

Bernal Heights hit-and-run San Francisco Chronicle

Woman's car plunges 300 feet off cliff near Pacifica California Highway Patrol

SF Brewing Co. Ghirardelli Square Virtual Tour San Francisco Chronicle

The story behind You're Going to Die, SF's death-related open mike San Francisco Chronicle

Protesting the death of Stephon Clark: ‘You murdered a Son’ New York Times

Yet neither Yee nor Swearengin is a political rookie.

Political experience

Yee, who grew up in San Francisco and graduated from Lowell High School and UC Berkeley, was a top budget deputy in the state Department of Finance under Democratic Gov. Gray Davis, served as chief aide to Democrat Carole Migden when Migden was on the state Board of Equalization, and then was elected to two terms of her own on the board.

In the June primary for controller, Yee edged Democratic Assemblyman John Pérez of Los Angeles, who as Assembly speaker was one of the most partisan politicians in California, for the second and last spot on the November ballot.

Swearengin, who finished on top in the primary, was raised in Arkansas before graduating from a Fresno high school and California State University Fresno. After working for the university as community and economic development director, she served as chairwoman for the California Partnership for the San Joaquin Valley, a group established by Republican Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, before being elected as Fresno's mayor in 2008. She was re-elected four years later.

Each woman argues that her experience best prepares her for a job that's been described as California's bookkeeper, the person who writes the checks and audits the accounts for the state.

"It's not a sexy job," Yee said. "California is a big, complex state, and state finance is a complex system. But that's the expertise I bring."

Her time dipping deep into the details of the state budget, along with her years on the Board of Equalization, which runs California's tax system, gives her insight into the details of how the state's finances work, Yee said.

"You need credentials to be the state's fiscal watchdog," she said. "You have to be able to call out before something catastrophic happens."

That's especially important in this time of term limits, when legislators aren't in Sacramento long enough to develop that type of expertise, Yee said.

"I don't see the controller's job as a political office, but obviously politics has its place," Yee said. "I believe the controller's job is to hold the Legislature accountable to the people ... and be independent enough to call them out."

Fresno's travails

Swearengin says her efforts to steer Fresno through financial hardships brought on by the housing crunch and the recession, along with her willingness to make the tough choices needed to keep the city solvent, show what she can bring to the controller's office.

The city, with an annual budget of $1 billion, was on the verge of bankruptcy when general-fund revenue plunged 16 percent from 2008 to 2010, she said. But by cutting the budget, eliminating some services, establishing public-private partnerships and taking other measures, Swearengin said, she helped the city return to solvency.

"I'm the right person for this job," she said. "I'll bring to the office direct experience in an executive position, where I was the one person accountable for a 3,200-person workforce and the one person who would take the rap for what happens, good or bad."

As the person checking the state's books, Swearengin would not only point out potential problems but also find ways that legislators and the state could deal with them, now and down the road, she said.

"I'm not a person who likes to criticize and walk away," Swearengin said. Instead, the controller "needs to make suggestions and fix the problem."

Being a Republican working with a Legislature that will be overwhelmingly Democratic is an asset, not a problem, she added.

The controller's job "requires independence, free from the political party in control in Sacramento," Swearengin said. "If something can work, even if it's politically controversial, I'll support it."

GOP's hope

Although the candidates downplay the politics of the controller's race, that doesn't mean it's not there. Republicans, for example, see Swearengin as their best chance to grab a statewide office, something they've had difficulty doing in recent years.

Aside from Schwarzenegger, Steve Poizner, who spent one term as insurance commissioner, has been the only Republican elected statewide since 2003.

In an invitation to a Piedmont fundraiser in August, Duf Sundheim, former chair of the California Republican Party, described Swearengin as a future star of the party and a candidate who has "a real chance to win."

Partisan cash

Both Yee and Swearengin drained their campaign treasuries to get through the primary, but both have been raising money since, with much of the cash coming from the usual partisan sources - unions, women's organizations and education groups for Yee, and deep-pocketed individual donors for Swearengin.

And while the controller's office might not seem like a major political plum, it has been an important step up for a number of politicians.

Republican Tom Kuchel and Democrat Alan Cranston each served as controller before moving up to the U.S. Senate, and Davis, a former controller, was elected governor.

column2: Salesforce, others back Clintons' job-training initiative
column3:
Salesforce, others back Clintons' job-training initiative





window._taboola = window._taboola || []; _taboola.push({ mode: 'thumbnails-c', container: 'taboola-interstitial-gallery-thumbnails-3', placement: 'Interstitial Gallery Thumbnails 3', target_type: 'mix' }); _taboola.push({flush: true});

Photo: Paul J. Richards, AFP/Getty Images Image 1 of / 3 Caption Close Image 1 of 3 Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will be emphasizing youth unemployment issues through her family's Clinton Global Initiative. Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will be emphasizing youth unemployment issues through her family's Clinton Global Initiative. Photo: Paul J. Richards, AFP/Getty Images Image 2 of 3 Salesforce.com founder Marc Benioff, who has rallied tech firms to fight poverty, has given to Clinton's campaigns but says this program is not political. Salesforce.com founder Marc Benioff, who has rallied tech firms to fight poverty, has given to Clinton's campaigns but says this program is not political. Photo: Patrick T. Fallon, Bloomberg Image 3 of 3 Salesforce, others back Clintons' job-training initiative 1 / 3 Back to Gallery

In its latest philanthropic move, Salesforce.com's foundation will spend $6 million nationally over the next three years on job training for underemployed young adults.

The program was announced Tuesday in Denver as part of a Clinton Global Initiative effort to expand job opportunities for the nearly 6 million people between the ages of 16 and 24 who are out of work and not in school.

Salesforce will expand its existing partnerships with Genesys Works and Year Up - two nonprofits geared to providing job training for low-income young people. The San Francisco company's philanthropic arm will also create 400 unpaid internships and 150 post-internship jobs for young people as part of the program.

LATEST SFGATE VIDEOS Now Playing: Now Playing Woman hit by Sacramento sheriff's deputy vehicle during Stephon Clark protest Guy Danilowitz

Still Standing Lea Suzuki

The wettest and driest places in the Bay Area Ted Andersen, Alix Martichoux, SFGATE

The Regulars: The Mushroom Hacker Nani Walker, Robin Simmonds and Lauren Schwartzman

Candy Land: How West Oakland's Ocho Candy Makes Its Organic Sweet Treats Sarah Fritsche

Bernal Heights hit-and-run San Francisco Chronicle

Woman's car plunges 300 feet off cliff near Pacifica California Highway Patrol

SF Brewing Co. Ghirardelli Square Virtual Tour San Francisco Chronicle

The story behind You're Going to Die, SF's death-related open mike San Francisco Chronicle

Protesting the death of Stephon Clark: ‘You murdered a Son’ New York Times

"What we want to do is give them access and exposure so they can fill the jobs that are out there," said Ebony Frelix, vice president of programs at the Salesforce.com Foundation.

Many young people of that age "have had a hard time accessing those jobs," said Jay Banfield, founding executive director at Year Up Bay Area. "This will really help."

Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton announced Salesforce's program expansion Tuesday during a meeting of the Clinton Global Initiative, which her family founded. The organization will focus on youth unemployment issues over the next year. Joining Salesforce in making similar commitments Tuesday were San Francisco clothing chain Gap, software security company Symantec of Mountain View, Corning, Ernst and Young, JPMorgan Chase & Co, Lifeway Foods, Marriott International, MDC Partners Inc. and Microsoft.

Clinton, who is contemplating a 2016 run for president, recently blasted the nation's increasing wealth inequality gap during a policy speech in May at the New America Foundation in Washington.

"The dream of upward mobility that made this country a model for the world feels further and further out of reach, and many Americans understandably feel frustrated, even angry," Clinton said.

Salesforce.com founder Marc Benioff, one of the nation's largest donors to Democratic candidates and interest groups, donated $25,000 in November to Ready for Hillary, an organization supportive of Clinton's presidential aspirations, according to the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics.

Salesforce officials say their involvement with the Clinton Global Initiative is not political in nature.

"We were supporting this before Secretary Clinton's involvement, and we will continue to support it," Frelix said.

Salesforce.com has about $4 billion in annual revenue, and Benioff has an estimated personal net worth of $3 billion, according to Forbes. Benioff, with his wife, Lynne, have made numerous philanthropic personal donations, including $200 million to UCSF Benioff Children's Hospitals.

Benioff - along with the nonprofit Tipping Point Community and Ron Conway, venture capitalist and head of the San Francisco Citizens Initiative for Tech and Innovation, rallied other tech companies this year to join forces in giving $10 million to Bay Area antipoverty causes.
