Robert Clifford, author of the study that came out Wednesday, said he wanted to learn more about how H1-B visas are used in New England because our region has the most highly educated immigrant population of any part of the country.

He said he wanted to explore the question: "What are the policies that could attract and retain these individuals?"

When outsourcers bring Indian immigrants to do information technology work in the United States, those immigrants rarely have a chance to stay for the rest of their careers, unless they find another employer willing to sponsor them before their six-year visa is finished.

These companies — Indian firms such as Wipro, Infosys, Tata as well as Cognizant and Deloitte — rarely sponsor green cards for the immigrants who work for them, Clifford said.

For instance, according to myvisajobs.com, Deloitte brought close to 1,800 workers on H1-Bs to America in 2014, but only sponsored 27 green cards.

He said another issue is that while they provide some services onsite, they send other work to India. In Cognizant's case, the majority of its technical staff work in India, and they do work for insurers both onsite and offshore on the same projects.

Still, Clifford said he cannot say that the concentration of visas among outsourcing firms is a problem with the program.

"There could be positive effects from the role of outsourcers," he said. "Instead of focusing capital on IT labor force, they may be better able to invest in the core line of business."

There is a 65,000 cap on the number of H1-B visas that can be issued every year, though there are two loopholes — 20,000 more applicants can receive the visas if they graduated from a master's program in the United States that year, and nonprofits are not subject to the cap.

Yale is the fourth-biggest sponsor of H1-Bs in New England, after Infosys, Wipro and Patni Americas, according to the report. On average, it requested 306 visas a year between 2010 and 2012.

Not all requests are filled, but Clifford said this was the best data available for local geographies.

Clifford said no one knows how many people are currently working in the U.S. on H1-B visas, because the data is kept by more than one agency and is not organized.

However, his study found that on average between 2010 and 2012, there were 1,358 requests for H1-B visas for computer professionals in metro Hartford, where there were 18,960 people working in the field — or about 7 percent of the industry.

That proportion of applications to workforce is lower than in Fairfield County, which is one of the top 10 urban areas in the country in intensity of H1-B demand.

His paper did not say which Hartford firms rely most heavily on these outsourcing companies, but the U.S. Department of Labor documented cases from The Hartford, Travelers, Cigna, Prudential and Mass Mutual in the last five years where local workers (including IBM contractors) lost their jobs because the work was sent to outsourcing companies in India.

Some critics of the program say that the younger, cheaper workers on H1-Bs are driving down wages for native IT professionals. Clifford said there isn't clear evidence that's happening.

Companies that apply for H1-B visas do not have to show that they tried to find a U.S. worker and couldn't.

Clifford said the program is often misunderstood, because he said, the political argument for raising the cap is often made that "we have a skill shortage."

He said policymakers should examine the program and think about what problem it's designed to solve. Is it a way to recruit the most talented scientists and technical minds to America? If so, maybe a point-based system would be more effective, as Canada uses.

Is it a way to help tech companies fill jobs? Clifford suggests then the cap should fluctuate by openings and unemployment rates.

column2: EPA Administrator Makes A Hartford Homecoming
column3:
HARTFORD — Gina McCarthy was one of the last people ever to walk into the Phoenix Auditorium on the fifth floor of the state Department of Energy and Environmental Protection offices here.

And McCarthy, the head of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency who lead Connecticut's environmental department from 2004 to 2009, wasn't about to waste it.

"Yo, yo, yo, yo," McCarthy said, laughing and striding into the room to applause from her former colleagues. "This is so cool to come home."

She stared out at the faces in the auditorium.

"I forget everybody's name" — the crowd laughed — "No, I'm just kidding."

Commissioner Rob Klee introduced and welcomed McCarthy, a "witty and inspirational presence," he said, before announcing that the crème, pink and green auditorium would be renamed the Gina McCarthy Auditorium to honor her long list of accomplishments in Connecticut as well as her work pushing the country through its first major attempt to beat back the effects of climate change.

"I was worried about what you were going to actually name it. I've been known to have some pointed statements and colorful language. I thought you might call it the 'wicked-cool auditorium,'" McCarthy said, her Boston accent in full force.

One employee said McCarthy would hold monthly meetings with managers in the auditorium, where she would sit on the stage, with her feet swinging off the ground, and take all sorts of questions.

McCarthy, 60, made other stops in Bridgeport and New Haven on her trip through the state Tuesday, stopping at a fuel cell park in Bridgeport and an aquaculture school in New Haven. In Hartford, she stressed how environmental protection and economic growth need to be seen as complimentary, rather than as opposing, forces.

The nation's economy would not be where it was today, she argued, if it did not take care of its environmental issues. "We just wouldn't be and we need to remind people of that," McCarthy said. "I can make that case to any human being that comes in front of me."

In June, the Environmental Protection Agency released a draft rule that calls for the state to cut emissions of greenhouse gases from existing power plants by nearly a third in the 15 years. While Connecticut and other New England states should make quick work of that target, the plan quickly gained opponents from those in areas where the power sector largely relies on coal and oil.

"The one thing that the EPA needs to be a little bit clearer about is what we do for a living and why it matters, because in the end all that remains is about public health and about the next generation," she said, "And you helped me focus that. You helped me stay energized. You taught me so much. I will forever be grateful."

McCarthy joked and took questions from her former employees.

Yes, her current chief of staff who also worked for her in Connecticut is doing well, although he works too much and eats too many candy bars. Yes, there's assigned seating at White House cabinet meetings. No, McCarthy is not in the line of presidential succession, which she said is a good thing.

"Washington is great. They are just as mission driven as you guys are. It's just not quite as fun," she said.

McCarthy has sensed a change in tone in the forums and visits about climate change she makes around the country. "There are big differences now," she said.

"You are feeling the impacts of climate. The science is very definitive, and we have solutions to offer. We no longer have to worry that once we admit it, we've got nowhere to go: We have technologies out there. And we can do this in a way that will continue the strong economic growth we have been seeing."

But there are many challenges too, she said.

"Our challenge is to convince people that what we are doing is following the direction of the energy transition in the United States, and that we have provided the flexibility for that to work in every state. … Climate resilience is going to be one of the toughest issues we deal with," she said.

The power sector, parts of which have been some of the most vocal opponents of the climate change plan, McCarthy said, are coming around and are being modernized by the push to cut greenhouse gases.

"They were a sector that was growing old fast, wasn't investing in itself, wasn't frankly doing anything and they got bypassed," she said. "They are now catching up because we are telling them to integrate the things that you want in the world for them to do. We want them to be efficient. We want them to be reliable. We want them as cheap as we can get them, and we want them to be sustainable, which means low carbon."

column2: General Electric CEO Immelt Made $11.3M In 2013
column3:
Jeffrey R. Immelt, chairman and chief executive of Fairfield-based General Electric Co., made $11.27 million in 2013, a steep decline from the $20.45 million he took home the prior year, a federal filing Thursday showed.

The drop in earnings for the year is mainly attributable to a decline in performance-based pay for 2013, which more than outweighed the company board of directors' approval of a higher cash bonus for Immelt and his first salary increase in almost a decade.

In addition to the higher earnings, the company awarded Immelt, 58, stock now valued at $7.78 million. The ultimate value of the stock will depend on how well the company's stock performs, and it will only be awarded after a vesting period if the company meets certain financial performance targets.

The compensation committee on GE's board of directors increased Immelt's base pay 6 percent to $3.47 million and upped his cash bonus by 11 percent to $5 million, and said his "pay reflects the [committee's] view of his outstanding leadership and, consistent with prior years, represents a balanced approach to compensation."

Immelt's last base salary increase was in April 2005.

The details were contained in the company's proxy statement filed with the U.S. Security and Exchange Commission on Thursday in advance of a shareholder meeting in late April, where votes will be held on the election of directors, the company's executive compensation packages, auditor approval and other proposals.

From Jan. 1 to Dec. 31 last year, the company's stock increased 37.1 percent to $28.03 a share. Revenue fell 0.5 percent for the year, while net income rose about 10 percent.

The Courant calculates compensation as the sum of salary, bonus, value exercised from stock options and vested stock awards, plus other forms of direct pay, such as incentive payments and personal use of corporate aircraft.

The company's proxy also listed compensation for other key company executives: Jeffrey S. Bornstein, chief financial officer, $11.32 million; Daniel C. Heintzelman, vice chairman, $8.77 million; John G. Rice, vice chairman, $10.88 million; Keith S. Sherin, vice chairman, $9.57 million; and Brackett B. Denniston III, general counsel and secretary, $6.0 million.

column2: Health Insurers Propose Rate Increases For 2015 Coverage
column3:
Insurance companies selling health plans next fall for coverage in 2015 are asking state regulators to approve prices that reflect medical-cost inflation, and, in some cases, federal mandates, and expensive drugs to treat Hepatitis C.

Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield in Connecticut and ConnectiCare are asking for increases. HealthyCT is asking for a price decrease.

Summaries of the proposed rate increases were posted this week on the Connecticut Insurance Department's website. Insurers were required to file 2015 rates by May 31 for review by the department, which could approve, modify or deny them. The insurance plans will be available next fall to customers who buy insurance either on, or off, a public exchange, Access Health CT, which was created by the Affordable Care Act, often called Obamacare.

One major theme in the rate requests is that all insurers expect a continued rise in "trend" — the rising cost in medical services and the increasing demand for those services.

Anthem, the state's largest health insurer, and ConnectiCare both say their higher prices also reflect taxes, fees and requirements of the Affordable Care Act. Additionally, Anthem said prices reflect expensive pharmaceuticals to treat Hepatitis C, including Sovaldi by Gilead Sciences Inc. Sovaldi was approved for use in December by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.

New this year, UnitedHealthcare will sell individual health plans on the exchange. Last year for 2014 coverage, UnitedHealthcare only sold small-group plans on the exchange.

Here is a summary of rate requests submitted this week:

— HealthyCT Inc., is asking for rate decrease averaging 8.9 percent on individual health plans sold on and off the exchange for coverage beginning Jan. 1. The lower rate would affect 7,248 policyholders. HealthyCT is too new to the market to have claims experience on which it can base its 2015 rates. It used the consulting firm Milliman to develop rates using various data sources and models. HealthyCT anticipates a 5.2 percent increase in the cost of medical services and demand for those services, but that will be offset by other adjustments that lower the rates. For example, HealthyCT is spreading the cost of administrative expenses and fees over a three-year period instead of one policy year.

— Anthem Health Plans, Inc., a part of Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut, is asking for a rate hike averaging 12.5 percent on individual health plans sold on and off the exchange. The new rates would affect 66,200 policyholders. Anthem attributed the rate hikes in part to federal mandates from the Affordable Care Act, such as "guaranteed issue," which is a requirement that insurers offer plans regardless of a person's health condition. Additionally, Anthem said its new rates reflect taxes and fees.

— ConnectiCare Benefits Inc. of Farmington is asking for a rate increase of 11.8 percent on individual health plans sold on the exchange. The increase would affect 27,500 policyholders. ConnectiCare expects a 10.7 percent increase resulting from medical costs and utilization of medical services. The company also expects a $14.68 per-customer, per-month charge related to fees associated with the Affordable Care Act. The fees include Patient Centered Outcomes Research Fee, Transitional Reinsurance Program, Health Insurer Fee and the Risk Adjustment Program. ConnectiCare based its rates on the claims experience of health plans it sold off the exchange in Connecticut because there isn't enough claim history for 2014 alone, the first year of the exchange.

— UnitedHealthcare is selling individual health plans for the first year on the exchange. The company based its prices on the claims experience of fellow UnitedHealth Group subsidiaries — Oxford Health Insurance and Oxford Health Plans, which sold small-group plans on the exchange. UnitedHealthcare expects that taxes and fees will account for about 7.3 percent of its rates.

column2: Local groups involved in rallies supporting Palestine
column3:
On June 12, three Israeli teenagers were kidnapped in Gush Etzion, in the West Bank, as they were hitchhiking to their homes. The Israel Defense Forces began a search for the three teens. In the early days of the investigation, Israel arrested approximately 250 Palestinians, including nearly all of the West Bank leaders of Hamas, the group which has governed the Gaza Strip after winning a majority of seats in the Palestinian Parliament in 2006. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu claimed that the teens had been kidnapped by Hamas, but the group and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas denied Hamas' involvement.

On June 30, search teams found the bodies of the three missing teens. Netanyahu vowed a tough response to the killings, kicking off the most recent uptick in the long-standing clash between Israel and Palestine.

As of Monday, July 21, the Gaza Health Ministry said that the death toll in Gaza has risen to 511 since the conflict began. The number of Palestinians seeking refuge with the United Nations continues to increase, growing to at least 85,000 people now living in 67 shelters, mostly at schools, according to the U.N. Relief and Works Agency. The United Nations also said a preliminary review in Gaza found that more than 72 percent of those killed were civilians, not militants, and include large numbers of women and children.

During the heaviest day of fighting to date, Sunday, July 20, more than 100 Palestinians were killed, along with 13 Israeli soldiers, after the beginning of a ground incursion into Gaza.

Peace activists around the world have responded to the violence. On March 19, a large group gathered in front of the Old State House in Hartford. Among the groups participating were the Israel/Palestine Peace, Education and Action Group of N.E. Connecticut, based in Storrs, and the Students for Justice in Palestine group out of Uconn. "From Monday, July 7, until Saturday, July 19, peace activists across Connecticut joined a global outcry to denounce the latest attack on Gaza, Palestine," said SJP spokesperson Adam Antar. Activists attempted to meet with U.S. senators Blumenthal and Murphy regarding cutting $3 billion of military aid to Israel. "Despite a disciplined series of demonstrations and outreach to our representatives, they refused to address the Palestinian plight," said Antar "While hundreds of civilian Palestinians are being murdered by American-made Israeli death machines, our same senators voted to give Israel more emergency aid," he continued. "At the same time that our senators are so staunchly supporting murder with $7 million a day of American tax money, schools are shutting down around the state. Thousands of people had their water cut in Detroit. Where are the priorities of our senators?"

There is a National March on the White House planned for Saturday, Aug. 2, at 1 p.m., to demand an end of aid to Israel and an end to the violence. SJP and other local groups hope to send representatives.

column2: Former Enfield K-9 Officer Appeals Town's Decision To Fire Him, Ninth Notice To Sue Filed
column3:
ENFIELD – Former K-9 officer Matthew Worden will appeal the town's decision to fire him, according to grievance documents Worden filed with the town on Oct. 8.

Patrol officer Jaime Yott, suspended for 60 days, has also filed a formal grievance regarding her suspension.

The town fired Worden and suspended Yott and another officer, Michael Emons, after an April 1 arrest resulted in allegations the officers used excessive force.

Worden and Yott argue in the grievance filings that they should be reinstated and compensated for any loss of wages.

Since the town denied Worden and Yott's requests, according to the town's human resource director Steven Bielenda, the appeals will go to the Department of Labor's State Board of Mediation and Arbitration.

Worden is named in a number of lawsuit notices filed with the town. The latest involves an incident on Christmas Day in 2012 when Worden and Yott responded to a home on a medical assistance call.

According to the notice, a family member of Tyler Damato's called police for assistance in having him transferred to a hospital for psychiatric evaluation.

Damato had been in a car accident a few months earlier and suffered a traumatic brain injury. Attorney A. Paul Spinella, who is representing the family, said police were told of Tyler's condition before they got to the house.

While waiting for an ambulance to arrive, Damato came out of the house and, Spinella said, "was suddenly assaulted by Officer Worden who tackled Damato from behind, slamming his head into the curb several times."

The notice, filed by Amie Olschafskie the adminstratix of Damato's estate, claims the injuries that Damato suffered from that incident helped lead to his death six weeks later. Damato died a few days after a second car accident in February 2013.

"But for the attack by Worden he would not have died a few months later," Spinella said. "In my mind it is just another in long continuing series of cruel acts. This one is more shocking because it was Christmas Day right in front of the whole neighborhood."

The Damato case is the ninth notice of intent to sue the town filed by Spinella alleging police brutality by Worden. No lawsuits have been filed yet.

column2: Judge Refuses To Release Suspect In Iran Documents Case
column3:
BRIDGEPORT — A federal judge Wednesday denied a motion to release a former Pratt & Whitney engineer facing trial on charges of trying to send sensitive documents to Iran regarding the U.S. military's latest tactical aircraft, the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter.

U.S. Magistrate Judge William I. Garfinkel concluded that the details of the case and the potential punishment for Mozaffar Khazaee, 59, render him too great a flight risk, even if he were to wear an electronic tracking bracelet and deposit $50,000 with the court's clerk.

Khazaee "has very good reason to leave the country," Garfinkel said. "In fact, it would almost be irrational for him not to attempt to leave, under the circumstances. … This is a case that the flight risk is way too high."

In January, authorities arrested Khazaee at Newark International Airport in New Jersey as he was boarding a flight to Frankfurt, Germany, where he planned to connect to a flight to Tehran, Iran, according to the U.S. attorney's office in Connecticut. He was found with $60,000 in his carry-on — money prosecutors have seized and the defense says was to pay for medical care for Khazaee's mother in Iran.

Prosecutors said Wednesday that Khazaee could face up to 30 years in jail for more serious crimes that the government has yet to charge him with.

Defense attorney Hubert Santos, in arguing for Khazaee's release before trail, said holding him at the Wyatt Detention Facility in Central Falls, R.I., makes it difficult for Santos to meet with him about the highly technical engineering manuals and documents found among items Khazaee was shipping to Iran. The solution he proposed was to have Khazaee stay in an apartment in Greater Hartford, with a tracking device, and post $50,000 bail.

Prosecutors have offered to move Khazaee from Rhode Island to detention facilities in Connecticut, including Hartford and Bridgeport, which would be closer to Santos' offices.

In addition to the decision on pre-trial release, the hearing Wednesday gave Santos the chance to raise an issue he sees surfacing when the trial begins next year. Are the documents that were found among Khazaee's belongings in December decades old manuals with little value in the present, as Santos says, or are they, as the government contends, extremely sensitive plans for some of the military's latest technologies?

"A lot of this material is 40 years old," Santos said.

Government prosecutors described Khazaee as an extreme flight risk, unlikely to be deterred by an electronic bracelet and bail. Assistant U.S. Attorney Krishna Patel said the government's fear would be that Khazaee cuts the bracelet and escapes to Canada. There, he could enter an Iranian embassy, get a new passport and leave for Iran.

In a memo opposing Khazaee's request for release until his trial is expected to start next year, prosecutors said that Khazaee had, years earlier, emailed documents about the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter to individuals at a university in Iran — in one case openly acknowledging the documents' inherent sensitivity.

The documents "are very controlled … and I am taking a big risk," Khazaee wrote in the 2008 emails, the government said.

Prosecutors said Wednesday Khazaee appeared as if he would not be returning from his trip to Tehran. Agents searched his Indianapolis apartment, finding nothing but a mattress and a lamp, Patel said. He spoke in emails about wrapping up his life in the United States and needing only to figure out how to send a vehicle to Iran.

The defense argued that if Khazaee was itching to leave for good, he would not have left $60,000 in U.S. bank accounts.

Santos said Khazaee was looking for employment at a university in Iran because he was laid off from Pratt & Whitney in August. If prospects were good for a job there, he might have stayed. Otherwise he would have returned. "He was not sure he wanted to stay in Iran," Santos said.

That, and visiting his sick mother, were reasons for his visit, Santos said. The documents made their way into his belongings because Khazaee would often work from home, he said.

column2: Middletown Board Delays Action On Officer's Disability Pension Request
column3:
MIDDLETOWN — The city's pension board has delayed action for a second time on a request from a fired former police officer to receive a disability retirement.

Former Officer Christopher Lavoie worked for the department for 16 years before he was terminated in February after the city said he violated the terms of a "last chance" agreement he signed in 2013.

He has said he filed a request for a disability pension because of on-duty back injuries he sustained over several years.

After a contentious debate Thursday that followed a lengthy executive session, the pension board voted to have Lavoie obtain an additional independent medical evaluation to determine whether he is permanently disabled.

That vote came after an initial vote to grant the disability pension resulted in a 3-3 tie.

Board members, including Mayor Daniel Drew who is on the pension board, argued over whether or not one of the two evaluations Lavoie provided had been tainted when the city provided the doctor with disciplinary records.

"The city should have sent medical records instead of personnel records," said Christine Bourne, one of the three who voted in favor of granting the pension. "The city got involved where it shouldn't have gotten involved."

Drew, who fired Lavoie in February, said the case is "unprecedented" and said he does not think the medical evaluations show that Lavoie is permanently disabled.

"I think we have some board members who are doctor-shopping on behalf of the applicant, and I think that's inappropriate," Drew said.

Lavoie's attorney, Andrew Houlding, argued that when the city sent disciplinary records, it supplied information that was irrelevant to a medical evaluation and that the personnel records could make a fair assessment impossible.

Councilwoman Sandra Russo-Driska, one of two council representatives on the pension board, said the board should be responsible for choosing the doctor who will perform the additional evaluation.

"Clearly the city can't handle it," Russo-Driska said. "You don't send disciplinary records for a medical evaluation."

Lavoie was one of four officers who filed complaints against Police Chief William McKenna last year accusing the chief of seeking prescription pain killers from police officers. A law firm hired by the city said in its investigation report that there was not enough evidence to support the claims of the officers.

Michael McAuliffe, the attorney who represents the city in a separate case concerning Lavoie's workers compensation, said no formal hearing has been scheduled to resolve the compensation claim.

"The issue is whether he is disabled to a point where he is entitled to workers compensation benefits," McAuliffe said.

He said it is unusual for a retirement request to be considered before a compensation claim is resolved. Officials have also said Lavoie's case is unusual because the pension board does not typically consider requests from employees who have been terminated.

The board in November approved a disability pension for Gino Pulvirenti, another officer who had been fired. The board determined in that case that Pulvirenti suffered an on-duty knee injury that left him unable to continue as a police officer, and found that the injury predated his termination.

The city fired Pulvirenti after he was videotaped working at his auto repair business while out on temporary disability leave. He is still fighting the termination and the workers compensation case is also pending.

column2: Lembo: State's Pharmacy Benefits Expenses Could Have Been More
column3:
The cost of providing pharmacy benefits to state workers, retirees and their families increased from fiscal 2013 to fiscal 2014, but state Comptroller Kevin Lembo said in a statement Friday it could have been worse.

The state spent $345 million to provide pharmacy benefits to Connecticut workers and their beneficiaries during fiscal 2014, which ended June 30. That's up from $341 million the previous year.

However, Lembo said his office negotiated a better contract with Caremark for fiscal years 2014 to 2016 and saved about $50 million annually as a result. In other words, the pharmacy benefits would have cost $395 million for fiscal 2014 under the previous contract, according to Lembo's office.

"These savings — totaling approximately $50 million — directly resulted from aggressive renegotiation of our state contract," Lembo said in a statement. "Strong and smart contract negotiations, backed up by innovative benefit designs that focus on preventive care and chronic care management, continue to bend the health-care cost trend in the right direction."

Caremark, a division of CVS Health of Woonsocket, R.I., also had the previous state contract for pharmacy benefits. The state's medical coverage contract is with both Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield in Connecticut and Oxford, a division of UnitedHealthcare. The state contracts with Cigna Corp. for dental coverage.

The state had about 210,000 people on its medical-coverage plans as of March, which includes employee dependents and retirees.

column2: Frustrating Job Search? This Lawmaker Can Relate
column3:
WATERBURY — State Rep. Larry Butler didn't intend to bare his soul when he got up to speak at the Platform to Employment graduation in October.

But his voice filled with emotion as he told the job seekers he knows how hard it is to tell your spouse: "I've put in four or five hours today. Still, nothing."

He said he knows how it feels to get to the third interview but still be passed over for the job.

Butler, like the people he spoke to, has been unable to find a job after a long search. He's been looking for more than three years.

His last job was with DST Output, a communications and IT outsourcing company, where he designed class-action checks, college savings plan statements and more. He worked there for more than six years before being laid off in March 2011.

"I just felt compelled to speak to them in that matter," he said later, reflecting on the speech he gave. He wanted them to know "somebody in a policy-making decision capacity understands what you're going through."

The DST job was a position he found after 10 months of searching, after losing his job as a consultant with Howard Systems International, a job he had for about 10 years, and the best-paying job of his career.

Butler knows mainframe computers and the computer languages that manage them. He worked in IT at Travelers and Cigna before becoming a consultant.

Butler was just re-elected to his fifth term in the Connecticut General Assembly, a part-time job that pays $32,000.

Although the state legislature has funded several programs designed to spur hiring of the long-term unemployed — including $3 million for Platform to Employment — Butler said he's never shared his struggles on the floor of the House.

"I support those initiatives, certainly," said Butler, a Democrat. "I don't want to be defined by this. It's not really who I am."

Butler said he doesn't think the demands on his time during the session are keeping him from getting hired. He said as a committee chairman, he can schedule meetings around his work. In the past, he used half-days of vacation during the session without any trouble.

"There are many people out there that have very similar skills to me," Butler said, and the number of jobs maintaining large mainframe systems in Connecticut has shrunk with globalization.

"A vast amount of our jobs in our area are being sent overseas," he said.

In fact, Butler said, one of the last job interviews he had was for a contract job to package work to send offshore. He laughed bitterly.

Butler, 60, said he thinks his age is working against him, even though when he's filling out online applications, he says he's willing to work for a salary in the $50,000s, about $20,000 less than his best wage, two jobs ago.

He worries about what pricing his skills so low says to employers. Do they think he's a bargain? Or that he must not be that good? He said he didn't really consider getting retrained in a more modern segment of information technology. He said he worried if he spent $10,000 on a Java or C++ course, he still wouldn't find a job.

And, he said, "I spent a good portion of my retirement money just surviving." Tens of thousands of dollars, he said.

After so many unsuccessful attempts at getting computer jobs, Butler has lowered his sights, applying for a cashier's job at CVS, Walgreens, Cumberland Farms and for a warehouse job at Sears.

In all, he estimates he's applied to more than 550 positions.

"It wasn't like I thought any other employment was beneath me," he said, but still he wasn't successful.

"A Cumberland Farms, they won't hire me," Butler said, because they know as soon as he finds a better job, he'll leave. He said the owner of one store told him that directly.

Butler's children are grown, and his wife works, but her job as a career counselor at Waterbury Adult Education was definitely the smaller paycheck in the household.

He said he's been blessed, because before he was laid off, they had been making extra payments to their mortgage. They were able to pay off the loan during the first year of his unemployment, when he was still getting unemployment checks.

"If I hadn't had accelerated payments to my mortgage prior to that, I would've lost my house," he said.

Butler said he thinks he could work his network to get a state job that would pay $40,000 or $50,000. But to do that, he'd have to resign his seat, which he's not willing to do.

"I know there are a lot of people out there that would like to apply their skills," he said, just as he would. "Over 20 years of knowledge, experience goes to waste."

Butler is considering trying to get a spot in Platform to Employment. About four of 10 of the most recent round of graduates have found work in the past two months. But whether that happens or not, he said with conviction: "Larry Butler will have a job in 2015."

column2: Genomics Research Lab Planned For Branford
column3:
The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai is opening a satellite Genetic Testing Lab in Branford, in space formerly occupied by 454 Life Sciences.

The managing director of Mt. Sinai Testing Lab-Connecticut was vice president of research and development at 454, and the director of laboratory operations was the director of the sequencing center at 454.

The Icahn Institute for Genomics and Multiscale Biology announced the move in September, and Gov. Dannel P. Malloy toured the facility Thursday and talked about the government incentives offered to the medical school.

The Department of Economic and Community Development gave it a $9.5 million subsidized loan and, if the institute meets hiring projections and reaches a staff or 142 people over the next five years, $7.25 million of the loan will be forgiven.

454 Life Sciences, the DNA sequencing machine company that had occupied the space, employed about 200 people in 2007, when it was bought by Roche for $155 million. Roche announced a year ago that it would close and lay off 100 employees.

Glenn Farrell, a spokesman for the Icahn genomics institute, said Mt. Sinai has been working for months to renovate the former 454 space and has shipped equipment there. The facility has hired 10 people, and is recruiting for about 10 more, including entry-level technicians, early career technicians, a quality assurance professional, managers and an accessioning specialist. He said it should open in December.

Currently, the Genetic Testing Lab in New York employs about 100 people. The largest part of its work is doing genetic screening for couples planning to have a child. The lab also does more comprehensive screening for patients whose illness is a mystery and cancer target-specific gene testing.

The Institute had 340 employees at the end of last year in New York, including 188 staff, 87 professors and 65 post-doctorate researchers. It has been aggressively expanding in all those areas, and in its 2013 annual report, boasted of recruiting a Yale University professor. Mt. Sinai's medical school is ranked in the top 20 nationally, and its genetics specialty is ranked 15th.

In New York, it is exploring genetic markers in cancer, autism, schizophrenia, colitis and Crohn's disease, congenital heart disease and Alzheimer's.

It outgrew its testing lab space in New York, and Farrell said New York City is a difficult place to find affordable space where you can expand quickly.

Mt. Sinai looked on Long Island, in New Jersey and in Stamford before choosing Branford.

This spot was appealing for a number of reasons: the building had previously contained lab space, there's space for more expansion if needed, and, with Yale nearby, there's "local biomedical expertise." The new lab will occupy 16,500 square feet.

And, of course, the state money. "DECD was fantastic, the support they gave us was truly phenomenal," Farrell said.

He declined to say how much Mt. Sinai spent on the new lab except to say it's tens of millions of dollars.

The Malloy administration said the subsidy is part of the state's strategic economic development plan to target the bioscience industry.

"The addition of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai facility in the state is another big win in our long range plan to strengthen and expand our bioscience sector," said DECD Commissioner Catherine Smith. "We are creating a critical mass of industry leaders in the state — great organizations like Yale, UConn Health, Jackson Labs and now, Mount Sinai. The interplay between these important and growing industry players will help create a robust ecosystem that will help drive Connecticut's economy for decades to come."

The director of the Institute said Mt. Sinai hopes to collaborate with UConn Health, Jackson Laboratory in Farmington, and Yale.

column2: Middle-Class Earnings Continue To Stagnate In CT, Census Figures Show
column3:
VERNON — The middle class in Connecticut and the country was clobbered in 2009 and 2010 — and while those wounds haven't gotten deeper, they haven't healed yet, either.

Much of the pain is hidden. As Pete Pusztai said Wednesday afternoon, "You drive around South Windsor, people are driving nice cars, everybody has a nice phone."

So, the South Windsor resident said, the bad economy is like a low-level headache that lasts for days, so long that it starts to seem normal.

"I think people are numb to it, and I think people are just doing what they can to get by."

However, annual U.S. Census surveys — the largest questionnaire in the country — bring the struggles of the middle class into focus.

The typical Connecticut household — right in the center of the income distribution — earned about $67,000 last year, about $5,000 less annually than in 2009, according to Census figures released Thursday.

And while New London County is the only place where median incomes fell from 2012 to 2013, that doesn't mean the rest of the state is bouncing back.

The median income is below where it was in 2009 in Fairfield, Hartford, New Haven, New London and Tolland counties, and, the data show, in Tolland, it continued to fall in 2011 and 2012 before finally stabilizing last year.

Why does the median income fall? It can be that one spouse loses a job and finds a new one, but the new one pays far less or is only part time. One 55-year-old Vernon man, too embarrassed to tell his story in full, admitted that the job he started in July pays 60 percent less than his previous supervisory job he lost in February.

Pusztai said he knew four people who lost their jobs during the Great Recession. Two, in their 60s, never worked again, though they had not planned to retire so young. He said the other two, one who was a computer programmer, and one who worked at an insurance company, went from well-paying, full-time jobs to 20- to 30-hour-a-week low wage jobs, one in home health care, one in a restaurant.

It can also be that employees keep their jobs, but overtime evaporates.

Eryn Gilligan of Stafford said that's what happened to one of her relatives who's a machinist. He used to get overtime all the time, she said. "It made a difference in his income."

Gilligan, a single mother of three teenagers, has worked for the state for 31 years. She hasn't seen a big cut in pay like some, but inflation is slowly eating away at her standard of living. She just had her first raise in three years, and that 3 percent raise immediately went toward a higher contribution to her pension, she said.

She said she feels the economy is not improving: "Prices continue to rise, and it's just hard to make ends meet."

Connecticut is no different from most of the country in this regard. The last time the middle class received raises that outpaced inflation was in the late 1990s.

Oscar Santiago of Hartford remembered those years fondly. Santiago, who was shopping at Kmart in Vernon with his 1-year-old son in the shopping cart, used to wash cars back then, and earned $125 a day. Now, he said, he earns $68 a day working in a warehouse. He started the job six months ago, moving from another warehouse job that paid the same minimum wage, but was a temp job.

"Bill Clinton was the best president," he said in Spanish.

While the median income drops because of what happens in the middle class, the ranks of the working poor are swelling, too. In Vernon, the proportion of children that qualify for free or reduced-price lunch have swelled from 23.9 percent at the end of the 2005-06 school year to 41.7 percent at the end of the most recent school year.

To qualify for a reduced-price public school lunch, a family of four must earn no more than $44,123.

The median household income can also fall because people can't get into the workforce after having staying home with a child, or can't land a first job.

Gilligan said her younger two daughters, 17 and 16, decided not to play sports this fall so they could have time to work, but neither has been able to find a job.

Gilligan's friend Kim Post, also of Stafford, was listening in the Kmart aisle as Gilligan talked about how the recession affected her family. "We have grown adults that are doing the jobs now the teenagers used to do," Post said.

column2: Connecticut Growers Tending Marijuana Crops, Preparing For Sales Starting In September
column3:
For months, Advanced Grow Labs LLC — one of Connecticut's four medical marijuana growing companies — slogged through the process of competing for a state license, securing local zoning approvals, and outfitting a building to state regulations that are as a tough as those at any pharmaceutical manufacturer.

Now, managing partner David Lipton knows his West Haven company is getting close: He planted his first marijuana seeds almost three weeks ago.

"I did my own tray, the D.L. tray," Lipton said last week. "My tray is looking pretty good; they're about 3 or 4 inches high now. Finally, we're not just buying stuff, we're dealing with something that grows."

Nearly two years after the state legalized it, the first medical marijuana is expected to go on sale next month. About 2,000 residents with qualifying chronic illnesses have registered with the state and with one of Connecticut's six dispensaries.

The four medical marijuana manufacturers are at varying stages of growing pot. It remains unclear which company will be the first to market, turning the raw plant into medicine that is smoked, used in a vaporizer, eaten or rubbed on.

Connecticut's six licensed dispensaries have fielded calls from potential clients for months, and at least one has passed the final state inspection and is consulting with clients to map out treatment plans with pharmacists on its staff.

In South Windsor, Prime Wellness of Connecticut last week met with as many as 50 people suffering with some of the 11 illnesses covered under the law.

"There are patients that are really, really in need, and so they have been waiting for two years," said Tom Nicholas, chief executive of the Prime Wellness dispensary. "We're almost at the end of the tunnel, but not quite."

The passage of the law in Connecticut did not come without controversy. Opponents raised concerns that once the medicinal marijuana left the dispensary, it could get into hands of those for whom it wasn't intended.

Pro-medical marijuana groups now say they are thrilled that pot will soon be available for the sick. But they also are worried that the state's stringent regulations — including on that requires every batch of processed marijuana be tested for purity — will drive up costs and make it unaffordable for some, at least at first.

As exciting as it is watching his tray of plants grow, Lipton said he doesn't have much time to relax.

AGL's manufacturing plant on Frontage Road is still under construction, with the plants growing only in a small, state-approved test area. He knows he won't be the first supplier to dispensaries but he wants to have his marijuana in all six. He's coming up against three competitors: Connecticut Pharmaceutical Solutions LLC in Portland, Curaleaf LLC in Simsbury and Theraplant LLC in Watertown.

"Until we are out there selling and bringing in revenues," Lipton said, "we're not out of the woods."

Prices To Be Determined

When the state legislature legalized medical marijuana in 2012, it ended a wide-ranging sale ban in Connecticut that dated back more than 80 years.

Regulations written by the state Department of Consumer Protection allow a broad array of products — including what can be smoked; tinctures, creams, and oils; and baked goods, such as brownies, bars and cookies. Marijuana-infused beverages and candy are not permitted under the regulations.

Before a patient can register with the state, a doctor must certify that he or she has a qualifying chronic condition with symptoms that could be eased by marijuana The doctor also certifies how much marijuana the patient is allowed a month, with a maximum of 2.5 ounces. Then a plan of treatment is worked out with the pharmacist in a consultation at the dispensary.

What isn't yet known is how much the medical marijuana will cost users, with growers saying it is still too early to predict their pricing to the retail dispensaries. The costs are all out-of-pocket to the patient because medical marijuana is not covered by insurance.

"It really depends on the market and the regulations," said Chris Walsh, editor of Marijuana Business Daily, based in Rhode Island. "Connecticut is probably going to be higher. It costs a lot more to get started there than in other states."

In Maine, the wholesale cost for a gram of medical marijuana ranges from $6.50 to $8.50 and rises to $12 to $13 when it is sold to patients, Walsh said.

The website priceofweed.com, which compiles user-reported entries anonymously for marijuana purchased on the street, gives a current range of $250 to $340 an ounce in Connecticut, depending on quality. Based on 28 grams in an ounce, that would be roughly $9 to $12 a gram.

"We expect once the program is fully operational and all producers and dispensary facilities are up and running, competition within the program will provide medical patients with better medicinal quality products and better pricing than the black market," said William M. Rubenstein, Connecticut's commissioner of consumer protection, which oversees the state's medical marijuana program.

Machinery, Security

The three manufacturers now growing marijuana — AGL, Curaleaf and Theraplant — declined requests by The Courant to visit the actual areas where plants are growing. The state must approve any outside visitors, but the growers make the ultimate decision on who they allow in.

Each company described similar components in the manufacturing process: flowering rooms with dozens of grow lights; a room with "mother" plants used for clippings and breeding new strains; harvesting and drying rooms; a room to store ground-up buds while batches are independently tested; extraction rooms; commercial kitchens; and packaging areas and storage vaults.

Each company has a research and development operation to develop new strains to treat the symptoms of illnesses that one day may qualify for medical marijuana treatment — and perhaps, one suggested, lead to cures for illnesses.

The start-up costs were considerable. Each raised $6 million to $10 million from private investors, including $2 million for a state-mandated escrow account intended to ensure companies got up-and-running quickly. Initially, the companies will have between 15 and 30 employees.

At Simsbury's Curaleaf, equipment cost about $2 million, a third of the $6 million raised to start production.

"Extraction equipment is extremely expensive," April Arrasate, Curaleaf's founder and chief operating officer, said. "We have an entire extraction department to isolate the desired compounds, and we reformulate them together in rations that make sense for qualifying conditions."

column2: Knights Pledge $500K For Iraq Christians
column3:
The Knights of Columbus have pledged $500,000 to aid persecuted Christians and other religious minorities in and around Iraq, the Roman Catholic lay organization announced Tuesday.

The organization, based in New Haven, also said it will match an additional $500,000 donated by the public to the K of C Christian Refugee Relief fund.

"The unprovoked and systematic persecution and violent elimination of Middle East Christians, as well as other minority groups, especially in Iraq, has created an enormous humanitarian crisis," said Supreme Knight Carl Anderson.

Donations can be made by visiting http://www.kofc.org/Iraq or by sending checks or money orders to: K of C Christian Refugee Relief, Knights of Columbus Charities, P.O. Box 1966, New Haven, CT 06509-1966. The organization said 100 percent of the donations will go toward humanitarian assistance.

Tens of thousands of Christians have fled to Irbil, the Kurdish capital now being protected by airstrikes authorized last week by President Obama. In Mosul, the center of a Christian community for centuries, Islamic State militants destroyed churches and confiscated homes of Christians.

The Knights donated a record $170 million to charity in 2013. The donations come in part from revenues generated by insurance sold by the Knights.

A report from the Los Angeles Times was included in this story.

column2: SCSU Forum to Mark 25th Anniversary of Fall of Berlin Wall
column3:
Nicholas Burns, who specialized in German affairs while serving in the U.S. State Department during the fall of the Berlin Wall, will be the keynote speaker at a Nov. 10 forum at Southern Connecticut State University to commemorate the 25th anniversary of that historic milestone.

The program, "Remembering the Fall of the Berlin Wall: 25 Years Later," is free and open to the public, and will run from Noon to 2 p.m. in the Michael J. Adanti Student Center, Grand Ballroom.

The wall's demolition on Nov. 9, 1989, marked one of the final moments of the Cold War. It had divided East and West Berlin for 28 years, as well as having been a tangible symbol of Soviet oppression of Eastern Europe.

Burns was involved in the discussions on Berlin and Germany before and during the time that the wall came down. In 1990, he was appointed by President George H.W. Bush to the National Security Council, a post he would hold until 1995, effectively bridging the administrations of Bush and President Clinton. He would later serve as undersecretary of state for political affairs under President George W. Bush, the third highest post in the State Department. Today, he is a professor at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.

Burns will discuss what the Bush Administration and the State Department were thinking during the lead-up to the fall, as well as how they addressed the situation before and after the wall came down.

A panel discussion will follow the keynote and is scheduled to include Troy Paddock, chairman of the SCSU History Department and an expert on German history; Kevin Buterbaugh, SCSU professor of political science and an international relations specialist; Stephen Breese, dean of the SCSU School of Arts & Sciences who lived in West Germany in 1989; and Eileen Kane, assistant professor of history at Connecticut College, where she specializes in modern Soviet/Russian history.

Video clips of major historical milestones pertaining to the fall will be shown. A question-and-answer period will follow the panel discussion.

The event Web page is: http://www.southernct.edu/special/berlinwall.html

For further information, contact forum coordinator Joe Musante at (203) 392-5073 or at musantej1@southernct.edu.

.

column2: First Selectwoman says Fusion Paperboard's closure is 'investment' decision by owners
column3:
The blow that struck the town of Sprague two weeks ago reads like the script of a Hollywood drama, except the events in this little town are all too real.

Workers at Fusion Paperboard in the Versailles section of Sprague were told on July 23 that they will be out of a job by September.

On July 24, Fusion Paperboard filed notice with the state Department of Labor that 145 jobs will be eliminated when the plant closes on Sept. 22. The town will also lose about $250,000 in annual tax revenue.

According to Sprague First Selectman Cathy Osten, the owners of Fusion Paperboard – an investment firm called OpenGate Capital – is closing the Sprague plant in order to boost profits for another company it owns, a Paperworks Industries plant in Wabash, Indiana.

OpenGate Capital purchased Fusion – formerly known as Cascades – in 2011.

Since then, management has made millions of dollars of capital improvements and has formed a close and cooperative working relationship with the town of Sprague. That's why the closure is such a shock, Osten said.

Osten, a Democrat in her seventh year as first selectman who also is a state senator representing Sprague, said she has enjoyed a positive relationship with Fusion's management for the last six years. "I was able to help resolve a tax appeal case" that resulted in a $124,000 tax rebate, Osten said.

The town also was able to reach an agreement to reduce permit fees for a roof construction project by $50,000.

The town also intervened on Fusion's behalf to keep utility costs down, Osten said.

Most recently, the town supported Fusion's application for a $2 million loan from the state Department of Economic and Community Development (DECD). According to an April press release, these funds were earmarked for repairs to the plant's machine that processes recycled paper and the turbine that generates power for its operation.

However, OpenGate sold the equipment to Paperworks, and by doing so, made it impossible for Fusion to continue to operate, Osten said. The owners' goal, Osten said, appears to be to remove Fusion's share of paperboard products from the marketplace in order to boost Paperworks' market share.

The $2 million DECD loan was supposed to help Fusion not only retain its full workforce, but create 20 new jobs by 2016. One of the stipulations of the loan is the recipient must continue to do business in Connecticut for at least 10 years. Fusion will now be required to begin repaying the loan immediately and will be assessed a penalty.

"It was heart-wrenching to walk into the plant after getting the news... both management and the workers were shell-shocked," Osten said.

Her response was to reach out for as much help as possible for the employees. "The first day, when I heard about it, I was at the plant within 10 minutes. Then I called the governor's office, Congressman Courtney, the Eastern Connecticut Workforce Investment Board... we all started brainstorming ways to provide options for the workers," Osten said.

She also contacted local agencies involved in attracting and retaining businesses, including the Norwich Community Development Corp., the Eastern Connecticut Chamber of Commerce and others who might help the workers who come from 31 towns, Osten said.

On July 25, a "Rapid Response" team from the Eastern Connecticut Workforce Investment Board was already at the plant, Osten said.

According to an update she received from the team's leader, John Beauregard, employees will receive counseling on searching for new jobs, but the agency is also working with Fusion management on a petition for funds for job training from the U.S. Department of Labor, known as Trade Adjustment Assistance.

The agency plans to ask help from the Eastern Advanced Manufacturing Alliance with placing Fusion employees with member companies. The update states, "This initiative was appreciated by Fusion and they are working on how to best represent the skillsets they possess in-house so would-be employers can match up."

In the meantime, Osten said she's already received several calls from potential buyers for the plant's real estate, and she is putting them in touch with the consultant hired by OpenGate to supervise the plant's "disbursement."

Commenting on the grievance filed last week by United Steelworkers Local 1840, which represents Fusion Paperboard employees, Osten said, "This is a normal part of the process in these cases, to protect the interests of the workers... such as what will happen to their health benefits, their retirement funds."

Calls to OpenGate Capital were not returned, and an email inviting response to comments in this story was not answered.

column2: Plainville High School Groups Rally to Help Those Less Fortunate
column3: This past month, the DECA and FBLA Clubs at Plainville High school partnered to adopt families to feed over the Thanksgiving holiday. Students in the DECA club collected donations of canned goods and the FBLA club collected money in the form of spare change. All of these donations were combined to create "Thanksgiving Baskets," each of which contained a 15lb turkey and all of the necessary "extras" for a complete traditional Thanksgiving meal. With the amount of donations that were collected at Plainville High School, the group was able to adopt and support seven families in the area - three from Plainville, three from Bristol and one family from Rocky Hill.

column2: What do we know about Ebola, and what are we doing about it?
column3:
Until Thomas Eric Duncan died in a Dallas hospital at 7:51 a.m. on Oct. 8, the Ebola virus was, for most Americans, a hideous disease that happened to people somewhere else. Duncan's death on U.S. soil made it personal. It punctuated earlier calls from President Barack Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry to unite the world's people against the virulent disease that has recently killed almost 4,000 people in West Africa.

According to Dr. Yaw A. Nsiah, a professor of biology at Eastern Connecticut State University who runs a NGO (non-governmental organization) clinic in Ghana, the best weapons against Ebola are prevention and control. Information is critical to both.

"Those people in Texas didn't follow the instructions," Nsiah said the Wednesday morning that Duncan, a 42-year-old Liberian succumbed to Ebola at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital. "He knew he was sick, he told them he was just back from West Africa, but nobody paid any attention to the information."

Calling the fact that Duncan was originally sent home from the hospital "unpardonable," Nsiah added that the protocol followed after his diagnosis was just as faulty. "First they left the people [his fiancée Louise Troh, her son and two nephews who he had shared an apartment with] in the apartment for three or four days before quarantining them..and they didn't think they needed to move these people into another area and decontaminate the apartment until 10 days later," he said.

Nsiah, a native of Ghana who has lived in the U.S. for the past 14 years, explained that West African countries like Sierra Leone have been through multiple civil wars and have a very elementary health system and no good way to handle the outbreak. "That is how these diseases spread," he said. "Here, we have one of the best health care systems in the world, although also one of the most expensive, so we can control it."

Gov. Dannel Malloy declared Ebola to be a "public health emergency" on Oct. 7, signing an order empowering Dept. of Public Health Commissioner Jewel Mullen to prepare the state's health services to deal with the virus should a case present itself here. He said that the state Dept. of Public Health has been closely monitoring the epidemic and "has sent regular Ebola-related updates and guidance to medical professionals, local health directors, hospitals and emergency medical service providers." Further, Malloy said that hospitals have been asked to complete a detailed checklist for Ebola preparedness.

"Literally, all hospitals in this country – including Connecticut – have to have at least an isolation unit and complete apartment within the hospital to have ready, because they never know when something like that is going to [happen]," said Nsiah.

Nsiah said the incubation period for Ebola is 2 to 21 days, with 8 to 10 days being the average. "If you are not showing symptoms, you are not contagious," he elaborated, adding that in order to contract the disease from someone who is infected, "there must be close physical contact with body fluids like saliva, blood - especially blood - urine or sweat." If a person who has been exposed to Ebola is monitored for 21 days and exhibits no measurable symptoms and is "still standing" at that point, they are out of the woods, said Nsiah.

Symptoms of the disease include fever higher than 101.5 degrees F, severe headache, muscle pain, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain and unexplained bleeding or bruising. The fact that most of these symptoms occur with forms of influenza can make it difficult to diagnose, said Nsiah.

"We have learned some lessons...in terms of what happened in Dallas," Obama told the nation last week. "We don't have a lot of margin for error. The procedures and protocols that are put in place must be followed."

According to USA Today, Duncan was being treated with what officials at Dallas Presbyterian described as an "investigational medicine" called brincidofovir, which has not been tested in humans and required special permission from the Food and Drug Administration.

Other experimental medicines that have been used against Ebola in this country include Zmapp, which contains man-made antibodies against Ebola and TKM-Ebola. Zmapp was administered to American health care workers Dr. Kent Brantly and Nancy Writebol, who were treated at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta and recovered. According to an AP report, the drug was made in small quantities and there are no more supplies of it at this time. Dr. Rick Sacra was released from Nebraska Medical Center after being treated with TKM-Ebola and two blood transfusions from another American aid worker who recovered from Ebola at an Atlanta hospital.

Drug companies in the U.S. and Europe have started gearing up, said Nsiah, but it takes time for a new drug delivery to occur. He also sees a potential vaccine being developed in the future.

In the meantime, caution and careful handling is what keeps the disease from spreading. Two Yale doctoral students who went to Liberia in order to help the Liberian Ministry of Health and Social Welfare monitor the disease have returned home and voluntarily sequestered themselves for three weeks, even though they are not exhibiting symptoms of the Ebola virus. In Texas, Troh and her family are quarantined and receiving daily blood tests and temperature monitoring. All people known to have had contact with Duncan have been interviewed and some of them have also been isolated for observation.

Probably the most difficult precaution had to do with Duncan's final arrangements. Because the body is still infectious post mortem, CDC guidelines require the body to be wrapped in a plastic shroud with all tubes and IV lines intact and then placed into two leak-proof zippered bags before being placed in an airtight casket and either buried or cremated, without embalming. The restrictions run counter to West African funeral rituals which traditionally involve family members handling the corpse, and that is one of the reasons that the disease spreads so rapidly in those communities. Dr. David Lakey, commissioner of the Texas Department of State Health Services, said that Duncan's family cooperated with all his recommendations and had agreed to cremation, which according to the CDC kills the virus so that Duncan's ashes can be returned to the family.

column2: Top 5 must-have hotel amenities
column3:
Having 24-hour service at the front desk seems like something every hotel should have, but you’d be surprised how many don’t. Spencer Platt/Getty Images

Restaurant at the Pan Pacific Vancouver hotel. An in-house restaurant at a hotel is a must if you want to trim your travel expenses.

Not every hotel has a pillow butler or tanning assistant on staff, but there are certain amenities travellers have come to expect with their accommodations.

Not every hotel has a pillow butler or tanning assistant on staff, but there are certain amenities travellers have come to expect with their accommodations.

Hotels.com recently surveyed 1,000 people to rank 33 different hotel amenities to determine which were the most important to guests.

The most desired amenities that made the top of the list are:

1. Complimentary breakfast

It’s nice to be a member of parliament who can afford $16 glasses of orange juice when you travel. But most travellers — especially those vacationing with families — look to save a bit of cash by seeking hotels that offer free breakfasts.

2. Restaurant

Not every hotel is surrounded with a choice of nearby dining establishments. Consider your average airport hotel or something that is on the outskirts of town. If you need to hire a taxi to go out for a meal, eating out becomes even more expensive. An in-house restaurant is a must. It also doesn’t hurt if the restaurant has an attached bar.

3. Internet and free Wi-Fi

A hotel room without Internet access is like having no bed. It is an amenity that guests expect so not having it can be a deal breaker for many. Mid-range and budget hotels often give free wireless access to their guests, but some higher-end places, especially those catering to business travellers with expense accounts, still charge for access.

4. Parking

Having a place to park your car, whether it be for free or at an affordable fee, is a godsend for travellers with their own vehicle. In some cities, you can end up spending more money parking your car off-site than you will for your hotel room.

5. 24-hour front desk service

When the toilet overflows at 3 a.m. or some other emergency arises outside of normal working hours, it’s reassuring to know there is hotel staff on hand. Having 24-hour service at the front desk seems like something every hotel should have, but you’d be surprised how many don’t.

column2: SportMedBC: Hamstring strains
column3:
A hamstring strain (pulled hamstring) is a tear of the muscle located in the back of your leg. With so much sprinting throughout a match and training, it’s easily one of the most common injuries in soccer.

A hamstring strain (pulled hamstring) is a tear of the muscle located in the back of your leg. With so much sprinting throughout a match and training, it’s easily one of the most common injuries in soccer.

The vulnerable time for hamstrings is prior to the foot striking the ground. At this stage, the muscles are maximally activated and are approaching their maximum length. A strain can also occur when pushing off to sprint, as the explosive movement recruits all the power of the hamstring muscles.

While sometimes this type of injury can happen to some of the fittest players in the game, an essential reminder is to always warm up correctly and completely.

The hamstring group comprises three muscles at the back of the thigh, which bend the knee and extend the hip.

Like groin injuries, hamstring strains are evaluated according to severity by grades. Grade 1 (mild) consists of minor tears within the muscle. Grade 2 (moderate) is a partial tear. Grade 3 (severe) is a complete rupture.

It’s important that this injury be managed conservatively, as a mismanaged hamstring pull can be one of those slow-healing, nagging injuries. The first couple of days post-injury are truly important. The PIER principle is helpful to control inflammation. Pressure: compress the area; Ice: 10-20 minutes every two hours for the first 48-72 hours; Elevation: encouraging blood flow away from the injured area; and Rest: resting from any activity that can cause any pain to the hamstring.

With this type of injury, the athlete should visit a therapist with experience in sports injuries to assist with an evaluation. This allows the injury concern to be treated properly, giving the player the best opportunity to return to play in a safe manner.

For more, visit facebook.com/sportmedsoccer and SportMedBC.com.

column2: Lyn Hall defeats Don Zurowski in Prince George with five incumbents, three newcomer elected
column3:
Lyn Hall will remain at the city of Prince George council table, but this time, he’ll be sitting in the mayor’s seat. According to unofficial results, Hall beat opponent Don Zurowski with a tally of 10,463 votes to Zurowski’s 8,850.

Lyn Hall will remain at the city of Prince George council table, but this time, he’ll be sitting in the mayor’s seat.

According to unofficial results, Hall beat opponent Don Zurowski with a tally of 10,463 votes to Zurowski’s 8,850.

Incumbent councillors Brian Skakun, Murry Krause, Garth Frizzell, Albert Koehler and Frank Everitt also held on to their seats.

Voters looked for a little more diversity around the table, also electing first-timers Jillian Merrick, Terri McConnachie and Susan Scott.

The city also spoke out against fluoride on election night.

On the referendum question about eliminating chemical fluoride to the drinking water, the No side took the night, with 10,171 votes cast to stop the practice. The Yes side garnered 8,764 votes.

column2: Led by fiery Squamish, Saturday’s municipal elections saw surge in turnout across the province
column3:
Squamish councillor-elect Peter Kent says he hopes to carry through on his promise to torch himself if voter turnout in the district increased. Peter Kent/Facebook

Voters in B.C. continued to turn up the heat on their participation in municipal elections but there’s nowhere the results were hotter Saturday than in Squamish. Preliminary and unofficial results from CivicInfoBC. the co-operative information service, had voter turnout around the province up to 33.3 per cent of eligible voters, although that didn’t include regional districts, the Islands Trust and school districts. The total represents a significant improvement from the 29.5 per cent turnout in 2011 and the 28.9 per cent in 2008.

Voters in B.C. continued to turn up the heat on their participation in municipal elections but there’s nowhere the results were hotter Saturday than in Squamish.

Preliminary and unofficial results from CivicInfoBC. the co-operative information service, had voter turnout around the province up to 33.3 per cent of eligible voters, although that didn’t include regional districts, the Islands Trust and school districts. The total represents a significant improvement from the 29.5 per cent turnout in 2011 and the 28.9 per cent in 2008.

The turnout in the Sea To Sky community of Squamish was well above that at 44.5 per cent, torching the 2011 turnout of 41.2.

Eyes are now on council candidate Peter Kent, who used to be a stunt double for action star Arnold Schwarzenegger; inspired by the youth-vote promotion appeal RockTheVote, Kent made a pledge in a YouTube video to torch himself if the community could beat that 2011 percentage.

Kent finished fifth among the six victorious Squamish councillors. But just because he’s got a new job doesn’t mean he’s going to back away from his promise.

“I have to speak to the district,” said Kent, 57, of getting permission for turning himself into a human torch.

He’s not at all concerned about the stunt.

“I’ve been a stunt man professionally for about 30 years,” he said. “I’ve done it a few times.”

He’s also lit other people on fire as part of his Peter Kent School of Hard Knocks stunt school.

“I’ve probably lit 120 students and never burned a one of them,” said Kent.

But as fiery as his fun may be, Kent is a lot hotter about the reaction it drew.

“It appealed to the youth demographic, the demographic that is so disenfranchised,” he said. “They have a demographic that generally doesn’t vote: ‘Well, what’s the point? Nothing will ever change, my voice will never be heard.’”

The challenge to vote, which he also made to other municipalities and councillors, “apparently worked,” said Kent.

Whether it was nice weather or local issues, turnout around B.C. was up enough to drive the provincial average higher.

Little Zeballos, a village of less that 200 inhabitants on north Vancouver Island, may have had the highest turnout at 87.25 per cent while the District of Stewart was at 83.2 per cent.

Fort St. John may have had the worst turnout at 15.2 per cent.

Election fever wasn’t really burning in Langley, either. Just 20.9 per cent of voters marked a ballot in Langley City, although the Township was at a more respectable 29.9 per cent.

But much of the attention around the province was drawn to B.C.’s biggest city, where the forecast was for a race between incumbent Vision Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson and challenger Kirk LaPointe of the Non-Partisan Association.

A chastened Robertson apologized to voters in the last week of the campaign for not paying enough attention to their concerns and he managed to hold off LaPointe by more than 10,000 votes. The incumbent scored a tally of 83,529 votes, beating out the political newcomer’s 73,443.

The mayoral duel attracted an estimated turnout of 44 per cent, far better than the goal of 40 per cent and significantly higher than the 35 per cent that bothered to cast a ballot in 2011 when Robertson cruised past NPA opponent Suzanne Anton.

Robertson was the top vote-getter, maybe because of his apology, or possibly his experience but undoubtedly due in part to the Vision party machinery that operates from year-to-year compared to the NPA’s hibernation between elections.

Like in 2011, the NPA council candidates got more total votes than Vision (475,210 compared to 462,384); this time out they got one more councillor elected than in 2011, running their representation to three.

But Vision was further chastened with Green Party incumbent Adriane Carr finishing first in the council vote with 74,077 — which was more votes than LaPointe attracted. Only Roberston managed more in any Vancouver race.

The three victorious NPA councillors finished second, third and fourth behind Carr, as incumbents George Affleck (68,419 votes) and Elizabeth Ball (67,195) were joined by former Vancouver Park Board commissioner Melissa De Genova (63,134).

The NPA also took control of the Park Board and increased their presence on the Vancouver School Board, although Green Party winner Janet Fraser holds the deciding vote there.

“I’m thrilled,” Carr said on Sunday. “I think people across the board valued my work on council, which was to listen to them and to work hard to try get their ideas into council decisions.

“When the Mayor made his apology three days prior to the election and said he could do things better, I think the voters were signalling where he needs to go by their resounding support of me,” she said.

Carr said she hopes to work collaboratively with her Green colleagues on Park Board and School Board.

Aflleck also said the elected NPA candidates will caucus together.

“I think the city wanted to punish the mayor and they punished him through council, not through mayor,” said Affleck,

Probably the biggest gain for the NPA was that Vision lost its so-called super majority on council of eight votes, which means Vision will need to win a vote from another party for financial approval of any decisions.

“We have more of a say in the financials,” said Affleck. “We will be able to get, I hope, the kind of details we want.”

Over the last three years, Affleck in particular was stymied in getting enough information about the financial workings of the city.

fluba@theprovince.com

twitter.com/frankluba

column2: Smyth: Is the B.C. legislature haunted? A lot of people sure think so
column3:
Victoria ghost researcher John Adams believes the B.C. legislature and the nearby Empress Hotel are both haunted by the ghost of Francis Rattenbury, the young English architect who designed both iconic buildings and was later murdered.

High tea served on Royal Doulton china at the stately Fairmont Empress hotel, built in 1908, is a major attraction for tourists.

Francis 'Frank' Mawson Rattenbury is one of British Columbia's most well-known architects and is responsible for many of the province's most famous landmarks, including the B.C. legislature. /PNG

The B.C. Legislative Building is shown in this 2013 file photo. Extra security measures were being taken Wednesday after a Canadian soldier at the Ottawa War Memorial was shot and killed by a gunman. Canadian Press files/THE CANADIAN PRESS

In B.C.’s most haunted city, it forms a kind of devil’s triangle of ghostly high jinks, where spirits and spectres gather as Halloween draws near.

VICTORIA — In B.C.’s most haunted city, it forms a kind of devil’s triangle of ghostly high jinks, where spirits and spectres gather as Halloween draws near.

Begin at the grand and gothic Empress Hotel, where startled guests spy strange apparitions ascending creaking staircases. Then take a walk down Government Street to the century-old James Bay Inn, where objects move and doors mysteriously open and shut for no apparent reason.

And then there’s the B.C. legislature itself, which has got to be the spookiest spot of all.

Not because it’s full of scary politicians. This place is full of ghosts. Just ask the frightened people who work there.

“Oh, yes, the building is haunted,” assures Craig James, the kindly clerk of the legislature, who invites me into his comfortable book-lined study, and proceeds to scare the wits out of me.

“Many of the staff around here have seen things and heard things — things they can’t explain.”

Like the committee clerk who was working alone in her office a few years back.

“She looked out her door, just down the corridor from the legislative chamber. All of a sudden she saw a figure in a black cloak floating along the hall. It went along the speaker’s corridor, past the entrance to the chamber, and then turned left into the library.

“She was terrified and phoned security. They came and checked it out, but there was nothing, nobody there. She was so scared she had to be escorted out of the building.

“The security people told her, ‘Don’t worry. It was probably just Rattenbury.’”

That would be Francis Rattenbury, the dashing young English architect who designed the parliament buildings, and the nearby Empress Hotel, too.
