Rattenbury became famous for his work in Canada, but he returned to England and died tragically — savagely murdered in 1935 by the young lover of his adulterous second wife.

“Rattenbury was egotistical and arrogant and full of himself,” said John Adams, a Victoria historian and researcher into the paranormal.

“But in England, he was completely unknown. That’s why his ghost returned to haunt the legislature and The Empress — to gratify his insatiable ego and cravings for attention.”

Adams conducts popular “ghost walks” for tourists (check ghostlywalks.com) and a few years ago a honeymooning couple told him they encountered Rattenbury at The Empress.

“They were talking in the lower lobby and the newlywed wife noticed a man in an old-fashioned suit peeking around a corner at them. Then, as they walked up a staircase, she looked over her shoulder and the man was suddenly at the bottom of the stairs.

“She whispered to her husband, ‘There he is again.’ Now they both looked back — and the figure instantly disappeared before their eyes.”

He heard another spine-tingling tale from one of the legislature’s Parliamentary Players, the troupe of young actors who portray costumed historical characters to the delight of tourists.

“One young man, playing the role of Rattenbury in full period costume, was waiting for his fellow performers in the upper rotunda. They arrived and said, ‘How did you get up here so quickly?’

“He said, ‘What are you talking about? I’ve been standing here waiting for you.’ They said, ‘No, you haven’t! We saw you downstairs and you came up in the elevator with us!’ They realized Rattenbury’s ghost must have been in the elevator with them.”

If you think these political poltergeists rattle the nerves of parliamentary employees, you’re absolutely right. That’s why many will escape a few blocks away to the friendly bar at the James Bay Inn, a favoured watering hole.

But just let bartender Eric Stofer pour you a drink and bend your ear, and you realize you haven’t escaped the spirit world at all.

“Emily Carr died in this hotel,” Stofer explains as he pulls a perfect pint. “And she never left.”

Carr, one of B.C.’s most famous, beloved and eccentric artists, haunts the hotel’s cozy pub, Stofer said. Her portrait hangs on the wall, near the exact spot where she’s believed to have died in 1945, when the hotel functioned as a private hospital.

“One night, after we had closed, I was here with just one other staff member, cleaning up and counting the cash,” Stofer said.

“The back door opened and then it closed. Then it happened again. We said, ‘Who’s there?’ No answer. Then the door opened and closed again, and I ran to see if someone was playing tricks.

“But there was no one there. Just a silent, empty parking lot and not a breath of wind — and a heavy door that would open and close by itself.”

Stofer is convinced: It was the ghost of Carr, playfully making her presence known.

“Another night, during the Stanley Cup playoffs, we had a large inflatable easy chair hanging over the bar. It was a raffle prize donated by Molson’s, and I personally tied it securely to a metal TV stand because I wanted to make sure no one tried to steal it.

“It was closing time, and one of the waitresses was standing right under the chair. She said something about Emily Carr. And literally a moment later, the chair fell to the floor right next to her.”

The inflatable chair was not heavy. If it had hit the waitress, she would not have been hurt. Another sign, Stofer believes, that Carr’s ghost is a friendly one.

“Did you know Emily Carr kept chairs suspended by ropes from the ceiling in her own home? If she wanted you to stay a while, she would lower down a chair. Well, that’s what happened right here, right when her name was spoken.”

I knock back the rest of my drink to calm my frayed nerves and head back to the legislature. As Halloween gets closer by every witching hour, the ghosts appear to get more mischievous.

They seem to like the library best.

“I was working up here alone one night,” librarian Iona Reid tells me. “Then one of the cleaning staff rushed up and said, ‘Were you just in the cataloguing department?’ I said, ‘No, I haven’t moved from my desk.’ He said he had heard footsteps and someone shuffling papers — but there was no one there.

“Other people have heard similar stories. Some people get the chills and don’t want to go into the stacks. A few others have seen things.”

Things real. Or things imagined. Decide for yourself. But in British Columbia’s cryptic capital, many believe there is more than political hot air swirling through the halls of the people’s haunted house.

msmyth@theprovince.com

twitter.com/MikeSmythNews

column2: Smyth: Provincial government making fools of B.C. tax slaves
column3:
Linda Reid is shown with lion cubs during a visit to South Africa in 2013.

In a photo from Linda Reid’s Twitter account, the MLA’s husband Sheldon pets a giraffe during a visit to South Africa.

Linda Reid became Speaker just nine months ago and promised to open up the legislature’s secretive system of MLA spending and privilege. CHAD HIPOLITO/THE CANADIAN PRESS

Running this B.C. government costs a lot of money. That money has to come from somewhere. And that somewhere is you and your wallet, write Province columnist Michael Smyth. The April Fool’s Day increases — including today’s nine-per-cent hydro-rate hike and four-per-cent ferry-fare increase — are bound to inflict significant hurt on anyone whose income hasn’t increased at a similar rate. That’s most of us. And the government can’t ignore it. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick

If you’re feeling acute pain in your wallet from Tuesday’s hikes in B.C. Hydro rates and ferry fares — not to mention recent Insurance Corporation of B.C. and Medical Services Plan increases — try to look at it from the government’s point of view.

If you’re feeling acute pain in your wallet from Tuesday’s hikes in B.C. Hydro rates and ferry fares — not to mention recent Insurance Corporation of B.C. and Medical Services Plan increases — try to look at it from the government’s point of view.

Where do you think the money comes from to send MLAs and their spouses to Africa so they can tickle giraffes and pet lion cubs?

Where do you think they get the cash to funnel into Downtown Eastside “charities” run by people who eat at Gotham Steakhouse, ride in limos and vacation at Disneyland?

Where are they supposed to get the big bucks for bonuses and double-dip pensions to reward executives running government monopolies?

Do you think it all grows on trees? Do you think they find it in loose change under sofa cushions in the legislature’s new MLA TV lounge with the $733 snack rack to hold their free muffins?

Running this B.C. government costs a lot of money. That money has to come from somewhere. And that somewhere is you and your wallet.

The April Fool’s Day increases — including today’s nine-per-cent hydro-rate hike and four-per-cent ferry-fare increase — are bound to inflict significant hurt on anyone whose income hasn’t increased at a similar rate. That’s most of us. And the government can’t ignore it.

“There is an impact when rates go up,” Energy Minister Bill Bennett acknowledged Monday. “I don’t want to say anything that would minimize the impact on people.”

But he also says B.C. Hydro needs money to build new dams and repair old ones. B.C. Ferries needs money to subsidize money-losing ferry routes.

ICBC must pay out higher injury claims and MSP faces increased demand for health care from an aging population of baby boomers.

Yes, the demands for more money are everywhere. But the government’s siphoning of your bank account would be easier to accept if they led by example, eliminated waste and told the whole truth about where your money goes.

For example: Not all the loot you fork over to hydro and ICBC pays for new dams or car-accident claims. Billions will be transferred directly to government in the form of “dividends” and “excess optional capital” — also known as “stealth taxes.”

At the ferries, top managers continue to bank performance-driven “salary hold-backs” — the government’s new name for “bonuses.”

But why you need to pay bonuses to managers of a government monopoly is beyond me (especially when they don’t pay any bonuses at all to ferry executives in neighbouring Washington state).

At the Health Ministry, they’re jacking up MSP premiums at the same time that they’re pumping millions into barely accountable organizations like the Portland Hotel Society, where audits revealed lavish personal spending, but no government appetite to dig deeper into the scandal.

And at the legislature itself, MLAs from both major parties have been forced to pay back money to taxpayers for dubious personal spending, including that giraffe-cuddling trip to Africa.

So crack open that wallet and dig a little deeper, tax slaves. They couldn’t have picked a more appropriate day to make us all feel a little more foolish.

msmyth@theprovince.com

twitter.com/mikesmythnews

column2: Parents take school board to court over transgender policy
column3:
Three Vancouver parents are taking the Vancouver School Board to court in a bid to quash a controversial policy that provided more support for transgender students. Xiaofeng Huang, Yuen Ching Li and Shaohui Liu have filed a petition in B.C. Supreme Court claiming the school board policy, adopted June 16 in front of a deeply divided audience, violates the School Act and the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

Three Vancouver parents are taking the Vancouver School Board to court in a bid to quash a controversial policy that provided more support for transgender students. Xiaofeng Huang, Yuen Ching Li and Shaohui Liu have filed a petition in B.C. Supreme Court claiming the school board policy, adopted June 16 in front of a deeply divided audience, violates the School Act and the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

It said the policy, which allows transgender students to use washrooms and locker-rooms that correspond to their gender identities, violates students’ rights to privacy and encroaches on parental rights over their children.

"Some students are uncomfortable with sharing very personal information or private spaces with members of the opposite sex and deeply care about their privacy when using the washroom or change room," said the petition, filed Oct. 31.

"The board never proposed how to accommodate the wishes of students who are uncomfortable with sharing the same washroom and change room with members of the opposite sex."

The policy also allows transgender students to be addressed by the name that corresponds with their gender identity.

In sex-segregated activities such as physical education, it gives them the choice to join the gender group they identify with.

It also calls for gender-neutral, single- stall washrooms in schools.

The petition argued the board has no authority under the School Act to make its decision, which it also called unconstitutional.

It also said the policy granted school officials "unfettered discretion" to withhold from parents information on their child’s gender identity and expression.

The three petitioners all have children, ranging in age from six to 17, who attend Vancouver School Board schools.

The petition is also supported by more than 180 affidavits from likeminded parents.

School board chairwoman Patti Bacchus told The Province that the policy updated a 10-year-old policy that had already been updated in practice.

"We made revisions to a 10-yearold policy," said Bacchus of the 2004 school board policy seeking to support LGBTQ students.

"What is now in policy now is in fact what was in practice."

column2: Condo Smarts: Right insurance is key in a condo
column3:
Dear Tony: Our strata council has been struggling with an issue in our building that involves insurance claims in a strata lot.

Dear Tony: Our strata council has been struggling with an issue in our building that involves insurance claims in a strata lot.

Our property manager tells us that if a claim happens in a strata lot, it is the owner’s responsibility and expense, and if it happens on the common property, the strata is responsible, but both the strata insurance company and the owner’s insurance company cannot agree on a current claim.

A pipe has broken in the ceiling between two strata lots, causing about $17,000 damage to the strata lot below. Our water deductible is $10,000, but the damage is only to the strata lot below and the insurer says it is the responsibility of the strata owner, but the owner’s insurance company has advised that this is an insurable loss on the strata corporation’s insurance.

We need some help to answer this question so we can get moving on the repairs.

— Karen, North Vancouver

Dear Karen: There are a few simple rules to follow that help in understanding the obligations of insurance and claims in a strata.

The first issue everyone needs to clarify is to define what was damaged. If the damages occurred to the original assets and fixtures, and the amount is equal to and greater than the deductible, then the claim will be covered under the strata policy.

It is also important to understand that strata lot owners are named insureds on the policy by virtue of the Strata Property Act (SPA) and as a result can directly file a claim with the strata insurance provider without the consent of the strata corporation.

Whether or not there is a claim is a decision that will be determined by the adjuster’s assessment of the value of damages.

In Karen’s strata, if the claim is for the strata common assets and fixtures and it exceeds the value of the deductible rate, then it is a claim on the strata corporation insurance.

The second issue to assess is what caused the claim. Now we know what is being covered and under what policy, it is important to identify the cause of a claim and whether it was the responsibility of the owner or the strata corporation.

The pipe identified in Karen’s strata is common property as defined under the act, and is therefore the responsibility of the strata corporation to maintain and repair, and the strata corporation will not be able to recover the $10,000 deductible from either owner. However, if the water loss was caused by the failure of a toilet tank or leaking dishwasher, failed washing machine or bathtub, the owner may likely have been responsible for the maintenance and repair of those fixtures and the strata council would have been able to seek an action to recover the $10,000 deductible from the owner who was responsible for or caused the claim.

An underlying principle of the SPA is that owners are responsible to maintain and repair their strata lots to the extent that the repairs are not damages caused by an insurable claim, a critical issue that is missed by many strata owners.

If, in Karen’s situation, the damage was caused by the neighbour overflowing the tub, and the damage amount was below $10,000 with no claim, Karen would be required to go to her own insurance provider to file claim for the restoration to her strata lot or pay it directly herself. There would be far fewer disputes over insurance claims if owners would simply invest in proper insurance coverage for their condos as there would be much less need to sue the neighbour who caused an underinsured claim because you as an owner failed to buy insurance.

Tony Gioventu is executive director of the Condominium Home Owners’ Association. Email tony@choa.bc.ca

column2: Blood of Pope John Paul II feared stolen by Satanists
column3:
A religious reliquary containing blood from the late Pope John Paul II has been stolen from a remote mountain church in Italy, with speculation that a Satanic group could be behind the theft.

A religious reliquary containing blood from the late Pope John Paul II has been stolen from a remote mountain church in Italy, with speculation that a Satanic group could be behind the theft.

Police were searching for any trace of the receptacle, which was stolen in the Abruzzo region at the weekend. “It’s possible that there could be Satanic sects behind the theft,” said Giovanni Panunzio, the national coordinator of an anti-occult group. “This time of year is important in the Satanic calendar and culminates in the Satanic ‘new year’ on Feb 1.”

The Vatican is preparing to canonise John Paul II on April 27.

column2: New chairs bring fast-lap fantasy
column3:
Over the summer construction crews have been busy on Whistler Blackcomb. Two new chairs have now been open just over a month: The Crystal Ridge Express and the Harmony 6 Express.

Over the summer construction crews have been busy on Whistler Blackcomb.

Two new chairs have now been open just over a month: The Crystal Ridge Express and the Harmony 6 Express. Both have greatly enhanced terrain access and speed up the laps. The new Harmony six-pack is a luxury couch, increasing uploads from 2,400 riders per hour to 3,600.

The old Harmony Express was dismantled, carted over to Blackcomb, and rechristened as the new Crystal. This much-needed Express takes a direct line through the zone, making for fast rips of the infamous powder glades and taking the pressure off Excelerator chair for riders lapping Blackcomb Glacier.

With several feet of new snow falling on Whistler Blackcomb over the past week, checking out the powder action below these new chairs is a must.

column2: Like no place else
column3:
Sports like mountain climbing, mountain biking, kayaking, skiing and fishing are big in the region, but golf may stll be the number one draw. Michael McCarthySports like mountain climbing, mountain biking, kayaking, skiing and fishing are big in the region, but golf may still be the No. 1 draw.

Kayaking is just one of the many exciting adventure sports for which the Comox region on Vancouver Island is becoming deservedly known. Michael McCarthy/For the Province

The amazement begins the moment the Harbour Air plane takes off from Coal Harbour in downtown Vancouver. The view is terrific and immediately gets better crossing Georgia Straight to Vancouver Island.

The amazement begins the moment the Harbour Air plane takes off from Coal Harbour in downtown Vancouver. The view is terrific and immediately gets better crossing Georgia Straight to Vancouver Island. Touching down in the marina at Comox Harbour in less than an hour, the dazzled visitor gazes up at the Comox glacier looming over a bright green valley criss-crossed with hundreds of farms and dozens of streams and begins to wonder. So, is this the Promised Land?

My assignment was to review the annual Shellfish Festival, which meant tasting Fanny Bay oysters and devouring fresh barbecued salmon and grilled scallops on a stick. As onerous as that task sounds, I was more interested in wandering around the valley and wondering what it would be like to live there. The rumour was that the Comox Valley represents the ultimate in penturbian living. So I went for a ramble.

About 25 years ago, Jack Lessinger, a retired University of Washington professor, invented the term “penturbia.” This promised land, he wrote, lay in the future. It would be found beyond the normal commuting range of big cities, well beyond suburbia. It would be replete with farms, forests, lakes, and rivers. Living in penturbia, he predicted, would be a relaxed and healthy lifestyle with walking, cycling, kayaking, fishing, and golfing.

My first destination was the Saturday farmers market. The Comox Valley stretches over 25 kilometres wide, a gentle sloping coastal plain criss-crossed with a web of fresh mountain streams and protected by a ridge of mountains capped by the Comox glacier and Mt. Washington, a mighty peak that blocks much of the rain and snow. A mild coastal winter, a long growing season and more sunshine hours than virtually any other region in the country allows for the valley’s tremendous agricultural output.

Comox is derived from the original aboriginal word K’omoks, meaning “plentiful, rich or wealthy.” The rich soil means the farmers’ market boasts farm fresh greens, cheese, meats and sweets produced on many of the 400 farms scattered throughout the valley. On this Saturday morning it was packed. Several vendors informed me that famed film producer James Cameron has just bought property in the valley. Several new wineries had just opened. Things were booming.

Penturbian regions in B.C. can be measured by how many hours it takes to reach from the Lower Mainland. Anything under a four-hour drive, properties can fetch a big city-like million-dollar price tag. The Comox Valley, however, now boasts direct flights from Vancouver’s downtown harbour, and in summer jets from YVR land at the new airport at the former Canadian Forces Base. WestJet also flies direct from Comox to Mexico in the winter.

Courtenay, a 10-minute drive from Comox, is actually the bustling centre of the valley. A walk through its busy downtown core turned up Thai restaurants, yoga studios, youth hostels, art galleries and adventure sports stores. Mountain biking, kayaking and skiing seemed to be the big draws. Comox might be where all the retirees live, but younger people and families looking to buy an affordable home or start a small business head for Courtenay. The Puntledge River runs right through the heart of town, so you can rent a kayak at lunch and go for a paddle. It was a sunny summer’s day on my visit, and every park in town was filled with kids playing soccer or having a picnic.

The Shellfish Festival at historic Filberg Park was rocking, with country star Sue Medley on the stage.

Big name chefs from Vancouver like Nathan Fong held cooking demonstrations, with the focus on shellfish harvested straight from local waters. Dozens of other music, arts and culture and sports festivals crowd the annual valley calendar. Winter brings swarms of skiers to Mt. Washington. There’s even half a dozen high-end restaurants in the valley to enjoy. Who knew?

Looks like the old professor was right. The promised land finally exists. The folks who live there are keeping it a secret for themselves, but now the rest of us know where to find it. Darn, there goes the neighbourhood.

column2: St. Patrick gets the party March 17, but there are many saints to honour
column3:
DUBLIN: St. Patrick may have banished snakes and brought Christianity to Ireland, but perhaps his greatest feat was one of sheer endurance. After all, there were hundreds of other future saints roaming Ireland at the time, but Patrick is the one who gets the party.

DUBLIN – St. Patrick may have banished snakes and brought Christianity to Ireland, but perhaps his greatest feat was one of sheer endurance. After all, there were hundreds of other future saints roaming Ireland at the time, but Patrick is the one who gets the party.

On March 17, Guinness will flow from Malin to Moscow, the Chicago River will run green and parades will be held worldwide to celebrate the fifth-century preacher and patron saint of Ireland.

“St. Patrick’s legacy is pretty impressive,” says historian Brian Lacey, “especially considering he wasn’t even Irish.”

Patrick was British, captured at the age of 16 by a band of raiders and brought as a slave to Ireland. For six years he tended sheep on a remote mountain in County Antrim and wrestled with visions from God. After escaping, he went on to become a bishop who travelled throughout Ireland building churches, baptizing converts and performing countless miracles along the way.

In recent years there have been calls to rein in the revelry and reclaim the religious aspects of the national holiday. Some are even attempting to boost the name recognition of other saints (early Irish records list as many as 1,700) and bring their stories to the attention of the world.

There are hundreds of holy wells, sacred round towers and monastic remains all over Ireland and it seems every town and village boasts its own special miracle maker.

GLENDALOUGH, COUNTY WICKLOW: ST. KEVIN

At Glendalough (valley of two lakes) in County Wicklow, visitors can wander through the remains of a monastic settlement that for 500 years was one of Ireland’s greatest centres of learning. Founded by Kevin in the sixth century, the soaring round tower, churches and gravestones, as well as “St. Kevin’s Bed” — a man-made cave carved into the rock high over one of the lakes — creates a strikingly evocative scene and almost mystical sense of the past.

Tour guides offer tales of how Kevin cast a monster into the upper lake, rebuked an ardent woman suitor (one unlikely legend has him hurling her from his cave into the depths below) and once, while fasting, allowed a blackbird to build a nest on his outstretched hand. The story goes that he kept his arm outstretched until the chicks hatched.

There are endless such yarns woven around the saints. At the time Ireland was dubbed “the Island of Saints and Scholars” and monastic settlements had to compete for pilgrims and patrons — causing in-house scribes to pen ever more dramatic tales of saintly powers.

KILDARE, COUNTY KILDARE: ST. BRIGID

Brigid, for example, is said to have turned water into ale, diverted rivers from their courses and conjured up extra bacon for unexpected guests. When she decided to build a monastery in Kildare in the fifth century, she needed land from a local chieftain. He grudgingly agreed to give her as much as her cloak would cover. Miraculously, the cloak kept spreading for as many acres as she wanted.

Today, a round tower and cathedral mark the spot in Kildare where Brigid’s abbey once stood. On the outskirts of the town is a tranquil park with an ancient well, said to have healing powers, next to a tall bronze statue of the saint wearing a cross and holding a flame.

CLONMACNOISE, COUNTY OFFALY: ST. CIARAN

In neighbouring County Offaly, visitors can explore the magnificent remains of the sixth-century monastic site founded by Ciaran in Clonmacnoise. It includes the ruins of a cathedral, two round towers, three Celtic crosses and the largest collection of early Christian gravestones in Western Europe.

Ciaran’s path to sainthood was launched as a young man, when he supposedly restored life to a dead horse — just one example of his way with animals. Legend has it that a fox carried his psalter (psalm book) and a stag held his books on its antlers while he studied.

After performing the usual round of miracles, Ciaran decided to build a monastery at Clonmacnoise, smitten, he said, by the beauty of the lush green plains and sweeping views of the river Shannon. First though, he had to settle a boundary dispute with a neighbour who offered him land as far as he could throw his cap. After uttering a prayer, a gust of wind swept Ciaran’s hat across the fields. To this day, a sudden squall in the midlands is sometimes called “Ciaran’s wind.” The neighbour was eventually made a saint as well — St. Manchan.

ARDMORE, COUNTY WATERFORD: ST. DECLAN

Farther south, at the picturesque seaside village of Ardmore, visitors can learn about St. Declan and how he crossed the sea on a huge flagstone which ran aground on a local beach. High on a hill above the village are the spectacular remains of his fifth-century settlement, including an ancient church decorated with intricate stone carvings, one of the tallest round towers in Ireland, and the remains of an oratory where Declan is buried.

The saint still has a cult following in County Waterford, which he christianized before St. Patrick. The waters of St. Declan’s well are said to possess healing powers, especially for aching joints and backs. And every year pilgrims flock to Ardmore to celebrate his feast day on July 24 and throw a weeklong party in his name.

ST. PATRICK AND MANY MORE

There are hundreds of other saints and saintly shrines. At Fenit harbour in County Kerry in southwest Ireland, a large bronze statue depicts St. Brendan, the sixth-century navigator who set off on an epic voyage across the Atlantic in a wooden boat covered with ox hides. Brendan is said to have landed in Newfoundland, and to this day his followers claim the saint was the first to discover America.

Relics of saints also abound. The preserved head of St. Oliver Plunkett — who was hanged, drawn and quartered in Britain in 1681 for his Catholic faith — is housed in an elaborate shrine at St. Peter’s Church in Drogheda, a port town north of Dublin.

For centuries St. Laurence O’Toole’s 900-year-old heart was on display at Christ Church Cathedral in Dublin until, shockingly, it was stolen in 2012 and has not been recovered.

And, though he wasn’t Irish, St. Valentine’s third-century remains also ended up in Dublin, preserved in an elaborate reliquary at the Carmelite church on Whitefriar Street.

Still, Patrick remains the star. This year Dublin will host a four-day extravaganza including beer fests, ceilis (Irish folk dancing), street performances and a lavish parade in honour of “La Fheile Padraig” (St. Patrick’s feast day). Downpatrick in Northern Ireland, where the saint is reputedly buried (and which has a huge visitor centre dedicated to all things Patrick) is throwing a nine-day program of events.

All this for a man who famously described himself as “a sinner, the most unlearned of men, the lowliest of all the faithful, utterly worthless in the eyes of many.”

___

If You Go…

GLENDALOUGH, COUNTY WICKLOW (ST. KEVIN): http://www.glendalough.ie/. Visitor centre open daily. Adults, 3 euros; seniors and groups, 2 euros; children/students, 1 euro; families, 8 euros. Guided tours of St. Kevin’s monastic site available.

CLONMACNOISE, COUNTY OFFALY (ST. CIARAN): http://www.offalytourism.com/businessdirectory or http://www.heritageireland.ie/en/ . Monastic heritage centre offers 30-minute video and tours. Open daily.

ARDMORE, COUNTY WATERFORD (ST. DECLAN): http://irelandsholywells.blogspot.com/2011/08/saint-declans-well-ardmore.html

KILDARE, COUNTY KILDARE (ST. BRIGID) http://www.kildare.ie/kildareheritage/?page_id=65 . Check with tourist office on walking tours to St. Brigid’s Cathedral and directions to St. Brigid’s well on town outskirts near the Black Abbey.

DOWNPATRICK, COUNTY DOWN (ST. PATRICK): http://www.saintpatrickcentre.com/ . Saint Patrick Centre, open Monday-Saturday (Sunday afternoons in summer only). Adults, 5.50 British pounds; children, 3 pounds; family, 13 pounds.

column2: Savouring sights of Kinsale
column3:
Kinsale, located on Ireland’s southern coast, is known as the gourmet capital of the country. But there’s much more to it than that, as writer Liisa Atva discovered. — Getty filesKinsale Marc C. Johnson/Getty Images/iStockphoto

Stranded Boats in Kinsale Harbour Ireland.thinkstock.comBoats are stranded in the mud at low tide in the Kinsale Harbour. — thinkstock.com files Kate_Butterfield/Getty Images/iStockphoto

Houses and shops serve as a complementary backdrop to the ocean harbour in Kinsale, a small town on the southern coast of Ireland.Kinsale Harbour. Liisa Atva

"We broke up and I got the house," I quipped when friends asked why, suddenly, I was going to Ireland. It wasn't actually his house, and became mine only for a few weeks.

“We broke up and I got the house,” I quipped when friends asked why, suddenly, I was going to Ireland.

It wasn’t actually his house, and became mine only for a few weeks.

We’d talked about going to Europe in April, and his friends had offered the use of their house in Kinsale, a town of 4,900 on the southern coast.

When the trip together evaporated along with the relationship, I asked: “Would they still lend me the house?” Although I didn’t know them well, they graciously agreed.

Tom, the taxi driver whom my hostess had arranged, met me at the airport in Cork. After 20 kilometres of pleasant country roads and conversation we were almost there.

“We can take the scenic route to the house,” offered Tom. “It’s a fixed rate from the airport anyway, so there’s no extra charge for the view.”

At the next intersection we emerged from a copse of black alder onto a cliff overlooking Kinsale; a pretty little harbour full of sailboats, narrow, winding streets of shops, and crayon-coloured houses on the hills above.

The house, Clara’s Cottage, was a three-storey Victorian on a hill so steep that Tom parked the car at the end of the road and lugged my suitcase the half-block to the door.

Next door lived the lead singer of a well-known 1970s rock band — who will remain nameless in order to prevent Kinsale from being overrun by paparazzi. Despite slowing down every time I passed his door, I never managed to bump into him.

The sights

To orient myself, I took Dermot Ryan’s heritage walk.

“Did you know that there is a Kinsale in Canada?” said Ryan.

“A town of 200 in Ontario.”

With the rest of the group gathered, he continued: “The history of Kinsale is the history of Ireland. The battle of Kinsale in 1601 is said to be the turning point in Irish history. Even though the Irish enlisted Spain as an ally against England, they were defeated on Christmas Eve, the beginning of the end of the old Gaelic way of life in Ireland with the loss of power of the chieftains and clans.”

Ryan pointed out the Kinsale Regional Museum and suggested it was worth a visit. Small and unassuming, if I hadn’t been determined to take in everything, I might have given it a pass.

When my friend and I visited, local historian Paul Slaney greeted us at the door. Noticing the “No Photos” sign I asked, “Is that to protect the artifacts from being damaged by the flash?”

“It’s for the insurance. You could be scouts working for an international smuggling gang and the next thing you know Tom Cruise will come down from the ceiling,” he said.

In 1915, when the museum was still a courthouse, the inquest into the sinking of the RMS Lusitania was held there. On its way from New York to Liverpool, the Lusitania was torpedoed by a German submarine 13 miles south of Kinsale. The ship sank in 17 minutes and more than 1,200 drowned. The incident brought the United States into the First World War and launched many conspiracy theories, including that the English allowed the ship to be sacrificed to that end.

As we were leaving, Slaney said — somewhat sadly — “It’s just a small regional museum and we don’t really get the young people.” That’s a shame. The museum had an old-fashioned charm, and with Slaney to entertain us, Kinsale’s history came alive.

Kinsale also has not one fort, but two — Charles and James Forts. I visited the larger Charles Fort, built in the 1670s by the British, and said to be one of the best-preserved 17th-century star-shaped forts in Europe.

The shape is difficult to discern from within, and the fort was a bit crumbly, but the setting, four kilometres from the centre of town, is serene. The best view of both forts is from the water, and the one-hour harbour tour offered by Kinsale Harbour Cruises sails by both.

The food

Known as the gourmet capital of Ireland, Kinsale has more restaurants than one would expect for a town its size. The Taste the Wild Atlantic Way Street Food Festival, held in early April, was on. I grazed my way through the stalls offering appetizer-sized servings focusing on Irish cuisine — halibut chowder, fish cakes, seaweed scones, and sticky toffee pudding. I saved the black pudding, a local delicacy made from pork blood and oatmeal, for next time.

The following day, I was invited to be a judge at the 4th All Ireland Chowder Cook Off Competition. When I told some of the entrants that I was an international judge from Canada, they seemed excited to meet me. Along with the two hundred other judges, I tasted as many types of chowder as I could.

Most days, The Poet’s Corner, a café and book exchange on Main Street, became my second home: Old-fashioned armchairs, walls lined with books, cheese toasties, carrot, cumin, coconut soup, sticky hot chocolate, Simone, the friendly proprietor, and most importantly, free Wi-Fi.

The credit card machines at the Kinsale restaurants that I visited didn’t have a tip option on them. “It wouldn’t be Irish to ask for a tip even if it’s on the machine,” explained one server. However, in the larger Irish cities credit card tipping had been discovered.

The pubs

No trip to an Irish town would be complete without visiting a local pub, and I had the opportunity to acquaint myself with a few.

A short walk from the centre of town was the Spaniard Bar, the second oldest pub in Ireland — more than 400 years old. It looked as if it had been untouched since the Spanish Armada: a warren of tiny rooms with low timbered ceilings, walls and floors of stone, and a peat fire smouldering in the corner.

At the Spaniard for the Saturday evening “trad session,” the pub was shoulder to shoulder with people of all ages. The physical closeness, the warmth of the room, and the heart-touching melodies, swept me in and I was no longer a stranger.

At Monday night’s trad session in Dalton’s pub, the band of musicians grew with the addition of an accordionist, hand drummer, a man playing spoons, and three young lady flutists. When they sang in Gaelic, the soft melodic, almost mournful cadence was a language I’d not heard before.

At the White House, another pub in the centre of town, we were treated to a group of young people playing a mix of folk, pop and trad.

At closing time, when the musicians started playing the Irish National Anthem, everyone stood up and sang.

“Is this something special because it’s Good Friday tomorrow?” I asked another friendly local. “No, every day at closing time,” she said.

When I returned to Canada, an acquaintance asked: “What did you find to do in one small town for two weeks?”

Everything! I walked every street, visited every attraction, took in every event, and savoured every moment.

column2: Shell Busey: Renovations can boost efficiency
column3:
Many homes in the 40-to-50-year range are being renovated on the outside, giving their street face a much more up-to-date look.

Many homes in the 40-to-50-year range are being renovated on the outside, giving their “street face” a much more up-to-date look.

New and existing homebuyers like to freshen up exteriors to both change the look and to upgrade energy efficiency — both of which create future value for the residence.

The most common upgrades include roofing, windows, siding and doors (both the garage and the entrance). This pretty much covers the exposure to the street, often referred to as curb or street appeal. Over the past few years, there have been grant programs enticing homeowners to add these upgrades to their homes.

Changes such as exterior siding, windows, doors and roofing will completely change the way your home will perform before these energy-efficiency upgrades. Let me explain.

Roofing: When you remove a cedar or duroid (asphalt) roof and apply plywood sheathing or oriented strand board (OSB), the application of your new roof would likely include a stick-down membrane under the actual roofing material. This tightens the air cavity and will require the installation of extra venting by the roofing contractor.

Replacing windows and doors: Installing new windows and doors with proper weatherstripping provides more energy efficiency and tightens up the envelope of the home. This adds another requirement for additional controlled exhaust ventilation, such as bathroom, laundry room and kitchen exhaust.

Siding: Replacing siding and adding extra rigid foam insulation on the outside walls acts as a thermal bridging protection. This insulation stops the cold outside air coming directly in contact with the wall studs, transferring cold air to the inside of the home. The additional comfort to the home again adds more reason to control potential moisture buildup inside the home, requiring the extra exhaust fans as mentioned above.

The point I want to stress is that, before you begin any home improvement, it’s important to check with a professional to know what is required.

It’s just that easy if you do it right!

For further home-improvement information or to send Shell an email, go to AskShell.com and join Shell’s HouseSmart Club.

column2: Aug. 13, 2013: Taxes on fuel raise cost at B.C. pumps to top of North American heap
column3:
Will you fill up your car's tank at a Lower Mainland gas station today? If so, you'll pay more than anyone else in North America.

This story originally appeared in The Province on Tuesday, Aug. 13, 2013.

Will you fill up your car’s tank at a Lower Mainland gas station today? If so, you’ll pay more than anyone else in North America.

According to statistics released on gasbuddy.com last week, B.C. is home to the 10 most expensive places to buy gas on the continent. Delta topped the list at $1.44 per litre, with Surrey, Vancouver, Coquitlam and Burnaby only fractions of a cent away.

Surprised? You shouldn’t be, experts say, because B.C. has some of the highest gas taxes in North America.

"It’s primarily taxes. Canada has a lot higher gas taxes than the U.S., and that’s why gas prices are much higher," said Jason Toews, co-founder of gasbuddy.com. "The Vancouver area is especially expensive with their gas tax."

According to Jordan Bateman, the B.C. director for the Canadian Taxpayers Federation, Lower Mainland gas taxes add up to about 49 cents per litre. The biggest pieces of that number go to a 17-cent TransLink tax, a 10-cent federal tax, and GST, which is slapped on top of everything else.

"Honestly, gas taxes in the Lower Mainland are just so unbelievably high," Bateman said.

Gasbuddy.com’s statistics, compiled last Thursday, were pulled from gas prices in nearly 5,600 cities. According to Toews, the 24-hour snapshot is an accurate reflection of the bigger picture.

"It definitely is. We’ve been doing this since 2000, and B.C. is always up there," he said.

In fact, there are a handful of small towns in B.C. that have even higher gas prices than Delta; Fort Nelson came in at $156.9/litre on Monday. However, gasbuddy.com considered only communities with five or more gas stations.

The temporary closure of an Alberta oil refinery jacked up prices, according to an industry insider.

"Part of the refinery had some maintenance issues and they ended up being a bigger deal than they thought," said Keith Schaefer, the editor of the Oil and Gas Investments Bulletin. "When you have reduced supply, that means higher prices."

The 50-day closure of the refinery, owned by Syncrude Canada Ltd., eliminated about 125,000 barrels of oil from the market, Schaefer said.

"I talked to them Tuesday last week … it’s almost ready to reopen," Schaefer said. "Then I would expect gas prices to come down here fairly quickly."

Many Lower Mainland drivers who are fed up with paying chart-topping prices have begun looking south for cheaper fuel. Trips across the border just to fill up on gas have become more popular, Bateman said.

"It’s just common sense," he said. "It needs to be made worthwhile for them financially, and when you cross the border you’re saving $20 at the pump immediately."

The news of Delta’s chart-topping gas prices was met with little surprise on Monday.

"I’m not shocked at all. It’s so high, so expensive," said Naz Grewal, 18, as she pumped $20 worth of gas into her van at a Delta Esso station. The price: $143.9/litre. "I’m just getting enough to make it home."

For Wendy Wilson, 63, of Surrey, filling up the tank got so pricey that she decided to buy a fuel-efficient Smart Car last year.

"That’ll be good for three weeks now," Wilson said after paying $46 at the pump. "I only drive my bigger car when I have things to move."

HIGHS AND LOWS

The top 10 most expensive cities in North America to fill up, according to gasbuddy.com, as of Aug. 13, 2013:

1. Delta: $1.44

2. Surrey: $1.44

3. Pitt Meadows: $1.43

4. North Vancouver: $1.43

5. Maple Ridge: $1.42

6. Burnaby: $1.42

7. Vancouver: $1.42

8. New Westminster: $1.42

9. Richmond: $1.42

10. Coquitlam: $1.41

The 10 cheapest places in B.C. to fill up your vehicle:

1. Mission: $1.32

2. Courtenay: $1.33

3. Ladysmith: $1.34

4. Kelowna: $1.34

5. Winfield: $1.34

6. Westbank: $1.34

7. Oliver: $1.34

8. Duncan: $1.34

9. Dawson Creek: $1.34

10. Penticton: $1.35

column2: B.C. Liberal insiders charged with Elections Act violations stemming from 'ethnic outreach' scandal
column3:
Brian Bonney, former director of communications in the Ministry of Multiculturalism. /PNG

Part of the Province's front page on Feb. 28, 2013, when the story of the Liberals' ethnic outreach scandal broke. Files/The Province

A former communications director in the Liberal government and an employee of the B.C. Liberal party have been charged with Elections Act violations stemming from an RCMP investigation launched in the wake of the so-called “ethnic outreach” scandal.

A former communications director in the Liberal government and an employee of the B.C. Liberal party have been charged with Elections Act violations stemming from an RCMP investigation launched in the wake of the so-called “ethnic outreach” scandal.

The justice ministry announced Monday that charges against Brian Bonney and Mark Robertson were approved by independent special prosecutor David Butcher, who was put on the case in August 2013.

Bonney, then-communications director in the ministry for multiculturalism, and Robertson, the Liberal party’s director of field operations, are alleged to have made an illegal political contribution between Feb. 22 and April 19, 2012 during the Port-Moody-Coquitlam provincial byelection, said a statement by the Criminal Justice Branch.

The two men face two counts of making/accepting political contributions and one count of an offence in relation to election expenses.

According to court documents, Bonney and Robertson are alleged to have paid a woman named Sepideh Sarrafpour to work on the campaign of Liberal candidate Dennis Marsden without disclosing the payment to Terry Hawes, Marsden’s financial agent, in contravention of the Election Act.

By doing so, the pair are also alleged to have incurred an election expense unauthorized by the Election Act.

A numbered company, 0750837 B.C. Ltd. dba Mainland Communications, is also named in the charge. Bonney and Robertson are directors.

Robertson remains employed by the Liberal party, which issued a brief statement Monday.

It said it became aware in November 2013 of a $2,240 expenditure that was “misreported” during the 2012 byelection and filed an amendment accepted by Elections B.C. to “reallocate the expenditure” in December.

“The B.C. Liberal Party takes its financial reporting obligations seriously,” said the statement, pointing out that amendments are allowed under the act and are a common practice used by all parties.

The Criminal Justice Branch said the investigation remains ongoing, with a final report expected early next year.

Neither Butcher or the Criminal Justice Branch were able to comment further “as there is now an active prosecution before the court,” said the Criminal Justice Branch in a statement.

Former NDP leader Adrian Dix wrote a letter to RCMP in August 2013 raising concerns about information uncovered as a result of an internal government review of a controversial Liberals strategy of earning political “quick wins” by pandering to ethnic communities.

After the ethnic outreach scandal broke in the spring of 2013, several party staffers resigned and Premier Christy Clark launched a review into the strategy headed by deputy minister John Dyble.

Buried among thousands of pages of documents related to Dyble’s report that were dumped by the government on its open information website was an email chain that suggested the Liberals offered some kind of inducement to silence a former employee, later identified as Sarrafpour.

At the time, Sarrafpour said she never accepted any kind of offer and stressed she never did anything wrong while working for the Liberals.

colivier@theprovince.com

twitter.com/cassidyolivier

chchan@theprovince.com

twitter.com/cherylchan

column2: Born of tough times, the Empty Stocking Fund continues so long as stockings need filling
column3:
1918 was a brutal year. The First World War had come to an end, the Spanish flu pandemic had spread across the globe to B.C. and workers here had organized the Vancouver General Strike in protest of a labour activist’s murder.

1918 was a brutal year.

The First World War had come to an end, the Spanish flu pandemic had spread across the globe to B.C. and workers here had organized the Vancouver General Strike in protest of a labour activist’s murder.

The Daily Province newsroom was tasked with covering some pretty grim stories, and something needed to be done to lift spirits before the year was out.

On Dec. 5, 1918, the paper announced The Province Santa Claus Fund, a Christmas fundraiser to help struggling British Columbians over the holiday season.

In a particularly gloomy message to readers, with no byline but signed “The Province Santa Claus,” its author lamented Christmas being “the time of goodwill and cheer” — but only for some people.

“Have you ever seen children — eager, trusting children — in the cold grey dawn of Christmas morning with an empty stocking in their hands,” The Province Santa Claus wrote.

“An empty stocking! Childhood knows no greater grief than this. Santa Claus has forgotten them.”

The Daily Province asked readers for a “surge of unselfish giving” to help raise $6,000 (about $82,000 today) destined for “the poor,” “the widowed and fatherless” and “the brave who have been maimed in the Great Cause.”

It’s been 96 years since that Dickensian message prompted readers to donate $3,000 — it was a bad year, after all — but it was the start of something big.

Fifty years ago, the paper’s name had shortened to The Province and the fundraiser was called The Empty Stocking Fund, but tough times continued.

“Poverty has a smell to it,” Province reporter Nikki Moir wrote Dec. 8, 1964. “It is damp and woody and acrid. It hangs like a pall over Vancouver’s slums. Yes, there ARE slums in Vancouver.”

Moir wrote again the next year about hundreds of families struggling with “feelings of fear and desperation” as the holidays approached.

“They are weary from worrying as to how they can have a Christmas for their children. Christmas trees at a dollar a foot aren’t for them, nor the lights that go on them, and gifts to go under them. Poor children get just as fanciful ideas as the rich when it comes to building up hopes for a toy car, a pair of skates.”

The fund ballooned to a record $30,212 (about $225,000 today) by the end of 1965.

Sadly, British Columbians continue to fall on tough times, but the generosity continues.

Last year, The Province Empty Stocking Fund raised more than $324,000 to warm the holidays for thousands.

The fund will continue with your support so long as empty stockings need filling.

neagland@theprovince.com

twitter.com/nickeagland

column2: She rode the SkyTrain 'for free' when she was 15, now ICBC is telling her — and 37,000 others — to pay up
column3:
A decade ago, as a girl of 15, Rayanne Tupman used to ride SkyTrain for free. She was caught almost a dozen times, and issued tickets, but she never paid them or told her parents.

A decade ago, as a girl of 15, Rayanne Tupman used to ride SkyTrain for free. She was caught almost a dozen times, and issued tickets, but she never paid them or told her parents.

This week, the now 25-year-old Maple Ridge mother of two was shocked to learn those fines had come due, thanks to a new crackdown at ICBC. Nearly 40,000 other B.C. residents could soon find themselves facing the same nasty surprise.

The Douglas College nursing student is upset that she must pay more than $2,000 in unpaid TransLink fines in order to upgrade her driver’s licence.

Have you had trouble with unpaid ICBC fines? Tell us your story at tabtips@theprovince.com

“They are taking the food out of the mouths of my children for something that occurred a decade ago, something that my parents were never informed of since I was a minor,” she said.

She argues TransLink should have sent a notice to her parents, because she was a minor and didn’t understand the repercussions.

“How is this justified that the government can bring old skeletons out of our closets from when we were kids?” Tupman said.

Upset as she is, Tupman admits she is responsible and says she will pay the fine. But she wants her experience to serve as a warning to other youths what could happen.

A 2012 legislative provision that came into force at ICBC Monday will now make it impossible for drivers like Tupman with pre-2012 unpaid fines to renew licences or vehicle registrations without paying their TransLink debts.

ICBC’s Adam Grossman said approximately 37,000 B.C. residents with some $5.7 million in outstanding tickets incurred between 2002 and 2012 would now find licences and registrations subject to a “refuse to issue” hold.

“The refuse to issue restriction is part of the legislation introduced by government in May 2012 to reduce fare evasion on the transit system and has been in place on new transit debt since Sept. 4, 2012,” Grossman explained. “We’ve now made the system changes required to support refuse to issue holds on older, provincial transit tickets.”

Grossman said ICBC would send out notices to affected drivers prior to their renewal date.

TransLink warns on its website that unpaid tickets can impede an individual’s ability to renew driver’s licences or vehicle insurance.

Overdue fines are sent to collections. Once a ticket is more that 180 days past due, the $173 fines increase by $40 to $213. Once a ticket is more than one year overdue, fines increase another $60 up to $273.

Fare infractions issued before Sept. 4, 2012, are considered provincial offences and are collected or disputed through ICBC.

TransLink spokeswoman Jiana Ling referred inquiries on this case to ICBC, as they were in charge of fine administration prior to 2012 and therefore have jurisdiction.

If fines remain unpaid after a year, ICBC refers them to collections. Between 2010 and 2012, ICBC collected $10 million in unpaid fines on 60,000 tickets, averaging 2,500 a month.

In September 2012, following the introduction of the South Coast B.C. Transportation Authority Act, TransLink gained responsibility for issuing fare-infraction tickets and collecting fines.

At that time, TransLink admitted it was losing $18 million a year in revenue to fare evaders.

In 2013, the first full year TransLink took over fine administration, the transit authority issued 25,400 tickets worth about $5.6 million. They managed to collect on 33 per cent of the tickets.

Fare evasion is expected to decline following the implementation of the $170-million Compass Card faregate program.

Passengers can pay fines in person, online or by mail. They can dispute a ticket, even if they have paid some or all of it. They must fill out a Notice of Dispute form on TransLink’s website and submit it within 14 days of the date the ticket was issued. Passengers unhappy with the outcome of dispute resolution can appeal the decision.

Learn more at translink.ca/fareinfraction.

NO PAY, NO LICENCE

ICBC can refuse to issue a licence if the following debts are owed:

■ Violation tickets issued under the Offence Act that are motor vehicle-related;

■ Criminal Code fines that are motor vehicle-related;

■ Intersection Safety Camera tickets;

■ Immediate Roadside Prohibition fees;

■ Motor vehicle court fines;

■ Liquor Control Act violations;

■ Family Maintenance Enforcement Program;

■ Golden Ears & Port Mann Bridge tolls;

■ Transit fines;

■ Various debts owed to ICBC.

eoconnor@theprovince.com

twitter.com/elaine_oconnor

column2: Legalized marijuana in Washington state could hurt B.C.'s multibillion-dollar pot economy
column3:
B.C’s massive pot industry is in for some tough times because of changes in U.S. marijuana policy and a shrinking market south of the border. The changes have raised questions about whether the B.C.’s economy will take a hit.

B.C’s massive pot industry is in for some tough times because of changes in U.S. marijuana policy and a shrinking market south of the border.

The changes have raised questions about whether B.C.’s economy will take a hit.

Washington state’s liquor board is expected to issue the first wave of retail marijuana store licences on July 7, with some of the 334 outlets set to open the next day. Pot growers for recreational marijuana already operate legally in Washington state. Colorado began allowing the sale of recreational pot on Jan. 1.

Marijuana sales haven’t started in Washington but the effects of the loosened drug laws are already being felt in B.C., said Simon Fraser University criminologist Neil Boyd.

“There’s not that export market any more, and taking that market out of the picture, your profitability is going to reduce,” said Boyd, adding there are indications the wholesale price of marijuana in B.C. has fallen to up to half of what it used to be.

Marijuana activist Dana Larsen estimates that pot prices in B.C. have dropped about 20 to 25 per cent retail and up to 30 per cent wholesale in recent years, with about half the decrease since 2011. Part of the drop was due to new laws in Washington and Colorado, but the fact that 22 U.S. states have legalized medical marijuana also plays a big role, he said.

Other factors include better technology, stricter U.S. border controls, and the exchange rate. Most experts predict the price of pot will only continue to go down.

“It’s a risky business to be in (for) the long term for profitability, especially when a marijuana high is cheaper than an alcohol high,” said Boyd. “I wouldn’t want to invest in the industry.”

It is difficult to get accurate data on an underground industry, but most agree the majority of B.C. bud is exported to the U.S. or Eastern Canada.

According to a 2004 study, B.C.’s marijuana industry is worth $4 billion to $7 billion annually. The RCMP believes about 50 to 80 per cent of marijuana grown locally — about $2 billion to 5 billion worth — is smuggled to the U.S., a figure that rivals the province’s agricultural or lumber exports.

Daniel Werb, a public health policy researcher with the University of B.C. who specializes in drug policy, believes the expansion of California’s medical marijuana program in recent years has played a larger role in the decrease in U.S. demand.

“Even if growers in (Washington and Colorado) were to replace all the B.C. bud being trafficked in those places, it would not make the same kind of dent (as California),” Werb said.

The question for law enforcement and health policy researchers right now is how the local cannabis industry will change or compensate for the smaller U.S. market.

“There are obvious pressures on the export of B.C. bud because of policy changes elsewhere,” said Werb, who is in the early stages of a study that will look at the impact of U.S. drug policy changes on B.C.’s lucrative industry.

“Are people who are in control of the market here going to shift to other industries? Are they going to shift to other drugs? What’s going to happen? That’s something we need to know.”

While figures on the underground marijuana economy are guesstimates at best, the illegal trade earns real dough that goes toward local goods and services and business, which may influence the provincial economy as a whole.

“If you compare the size of the (marijuana) revenues to B.C.’s GDP, it’s way up there,” said Werb. “The entire market has estimates that suggest it is comparable to the forestry sector or mining sector in B.C. In fact, estimates suggest it’s larger. We’re talking about billions in revenue.”

Marijuana activist Jodie Emery, whose husband Marc Emery is serving the last two weeks of a five-year jail term for selling marijuana seeds to the U.S. in the ’90s, believes B.C. will undoubtedly feel ripple effects, from “car dealerships to Rolex shops and house sales.”

The money may be illicit, she said, but it goes into the legitimate economy.

“People who grow pot and sell it, whether they’re mom-and-pop types or big-time gangsters, they spend their money in restaurants and stores and (on) clothing and cars.

“There’s a lot of money out there,” Emery said, pointing out it’s money that’s off-limits to law-abiding Canadians and benefits mostly “unsavoury characters.”

With Oregon and Alaska voting on the legalization of recreational marijuana in November, Emery thinks B.C.’s marijuana money woes will only get worse.

“We’re going to be squeezed through … overgrown on both sides. One day we will be importing pot from Washington State. I hope not.”

Not everyone is convinced the B.C. economy is going to feel an impact.

SFU economist Stephen Easton, who wrote a 2004 report on marijuana growth in B.C., said there will no “apocalyptic” repercussions for B.C. due to growers or dealers losing their purchasing power.

“They’d have to go get other jobs,” he said.

Very few people are full-time marijuana growers, unless they’re members of organized crime, said Easton: “Most people will also have other jobs and they’ll just have to change the balance of how much work they do.”

The B.C. finance ministry said it has not commented on the issue because marijuana is a federally regulated substance and its economic impact cannot be measured.

chchan@theprovince.com

twitter.com/cherylchan

column2: Review: Paul Walker memorable in gritty 'Brick Mansions'
column3:
Adrenalin runs high in the entertaining, action-heavy remake of the 2004 French film "District B13." Starring the late Paul Walker in one of his last roles, "Brick Mansions" packs gunfights, car chases, acrobatic stunts and humour into one stylized package.

Adrenalin runs high in the entertaining, action-heavy remake of the 2004 French film "District B13." Starring the late Paul Walker in one of his last roles, "Brick Mansions" packs gunfights, car chases, acrobatic stunts and humour into one stylized package.

In the urban ghetto of Detroit, which has been surrounded by a containment wall, narcotics officer Damien (Walker) goes undercover and teams with ex-con Lino (David Belle) to infiltrate a crew of criminals and defuse a confiscated bomb.

Originally set for a February release, the film comes five months after Walker’s death in a car accident and it was a bit unsettling to see him running around in the future. But his love for action roles comes through clearly in this movie. From the detailed fight scenes to the subtle humour, Walker was in his element. He’s as gutsy and charming as ever.

Wu-Tang Clan rapper RZA plays crime lord Tremaine. As the ring leader of the slums, RZA looks the part. But rarely do you believe a word he says when he attempts to be threatening. There’s too much hesitation and not enough conviction. Later, Tremaine reveals redeeming qualities, which RZA embodies with more believability.

There’s an element of camp to this movie as well, which allows those who aren’t the best actors — Walker included — to prompt a few laughs.

"Brick Mansions" was directed by newbie Camille Delamarre and written by Luc Besson, who also wrote "District B13." Like the original, "Mansions" is set in the near future, although there’s really nothing in the film that shows us we’re a few years ahead other than the "2018" that is flashed on the screen.

The many fight sequences were choreographed using a technique called Parkour, which was created by Belle, also a star in the original film. Parkour incorporates vaulting, flipping, swinging, rolling, etc., to move through various obstacles in a scene. The action is frozen for a split second during many of these moves and extreme close-ups put us right in the action.

At times the Parkour technique requires the ability to suspend disbelief, especially when a character is jumping from one rooftop to another, climbing brick walls or overpowering as many as four men at once.

Focused on finding Tremaine, who he believes killed his father, Damien’s motivation is rooted in revenge. Lino’s subplot revolves around his ex-girlfriend, Lola. Tremaine has dragged her into the slums, which she had worked hard to escape. But she’s no damsel in distress.

Lola can fight and handle a gun — all while showing off quite a bit of leg in a waitress outfit that looks like a truncated schoolgirl uniform. At one point, Lola and the main dame in Tremaine’s clique, Rayzah (Ayisha Issa), who sports a tiny leather ensemble, duke it out. Though it’s a clichéd fantasy come to life, it’s still a hot scene.

At the heart of the film is the social commentary focusing on a community divided. Within Brick Mansions, there is no school, hospital or police station, and those who live there are mostly minorities. It’s made clear that the government could care less about the Brick folks, as they’re said to contribute nothing to society.

This is not a film that will shift anyone’s moral compass. But it’s worth it to see Walker in the last film he was able to complete.

"Brick Mansions," a Relativity Media release, is rated PG-13 by the Motion Picture Association of America for "frenetic gunplay, violence and action throughout, language, sexual menace and drug material." Running time: 89 minutes. Two stars out of four.

column2: U.S. report points to impact of global warming on forests and coasts of Washington, Oregon, Idaho
column3:
Global warming is already altering forest landscapes in the U.S. Northwest, increasing wildfire risks and threatening coastal communities, according to a new federal scientific report released Tuesday.

SEATTLE — Global warming is already altering forest landscapes in the U.S. Northwest, increasing wildfire risks and threatening coastal communities, according to a new federal scientific report released Tuesday.

The National Climate Assessment provides a detailed look at the regional and state-level effects of climate change. It lists key concerns for Washington, Idaho and Oregon:

WATER RELATED CHALLENGES

Regional warming has been linked to changes in the amount and the timing of snowmelt, which provides a bulk of the region’s water supply, the report says.

Declining snowpack and changes in the snowmelt timing are already happening and will continue, reducing the supply of water for farming, communities and fish.

Without changes, annual hydropower production is much more likely to decrease than to increase in the Columbia River basin; such hydropower changes could cost millions of dollars a year.

COASTAL VULNERABILITY

Rising sea level, erosion and ocean acidification pose a major threat to infrastructure, ecosystems and economic activity, the report says.

As sea levels continue to rise, more than 140,000 acres of coastal lands in Washington and Oregon that lie within 3.3 feet in elevation of high tide will be inundated more frequently.

The rising acidity of the ocean also threatens oysters and other marine food web, such as Pacific salmon, while increasing coastal water temperatures and changing conditions may alter how well certain marine species survive.

IMPACTS ON FOREST

Climate change will alter Northwest forests by increasing wildfire risk and insect and tree disease outbreaks, and by forcing long-term shifts in forest types and species, the report says.

Those impacts are already causing widespread tree die-offs and are certain to cause more forest die-offs by 2040.

Though wildfires are natural events in the Northwest, warmer and drier conditions have helped boost the number and extent of wildfires in U.S. Western forests since 1970s, and that trend is expected to continue.

Higher temperatures and outbreaks of mountain pine beetles, for example, area increasing pine tree die-offs in drier forests.

column2: B.C. flushes away revenue with cheap water prices for fracking
column3:
For gas companies doing hydraulic fracturing, or "fracking," near Dawson Creek, the city charges $4,500 per million litres of water. For the same amount of water used for the same purpose, the provincial government charges up to $1.10.

This story originally ran in The Province on Nov. 1, 2013.

—

For gas companies doing hydraulic fracturing, or "fracking," near Dawson Creek, the city charges $4,500 per million litres of water. For the same amount of water used for the same purpose, the provincial government charges up to $1.10.

Dawson Creek’s director of infrastructure said that gas companies in the region have no problem paying the rate of $4.50 per thousand litres. He said the fee’s introduction a few years ago drew little concern from the corporations and did not decrease industrial operations in the area.

Meanwhile, the provincial government charges $1.10 per 1,000 cubic metres for water used in fracking. That works out to less than a penny per thousand litres, or less than 0.03 per cent of the rate charged by Dawson Creek.

The stark gap highlights the difficulty of pricing such an invaluable resource – and critics say it also suggests the province is forgoing substantial revenues.

Dawson Creek’s $4.50 charge includes a $1.90 levy specifically for industrial users, the vast majority of which are fracking operations, said Kevin Henderson, Dawson Creek’s director of infrastructure and sustainable development. "The $4.50 is a higher rate for industrial uses because council realized as well that it’s a precious resource," Henderson said.

With the B.C. government’s Water Sustainability Act proposal in its public consultation period until Nov. 15, critics are calling on government to raise water prices for industry.

Geoff Morrison, manager of B.C. operations for the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers said gas companies are paying close attention to the proposed Water Sustainability Act. "Competitiveness is important for us and fairness is important, and how we arrive at those two things is part of the discussion."

Morrison added that the disparity in water prices for fracking is not necessarily an "apples to apples" comparison because of complexities, including who bears the cost of infrastructure.

Ben Parfitt, who wrote about Dawson Creek’s water in a recent report called "Counting Every Drop," said Morrison’s point is valid, and that a straight comparison between rates is not simple.

"But I feel very comfortable saying that somewhere between the extremely low price (charged by the province) and the extremely high price (in Dawson Creek) is probably a figure that’s closer to the mark of what should be paid," said Parfitt.

dfumano@theprovince.com

twitter.com/fumano

column2: New regulations sought for electronic cigarettes in B.C. (with video)
column3:
B.C.’s top doctor is calling for electronic cigarettes and “vaping” to be regulated after an 11-year-old was able to buy one in a Tsawwassen corner store.

B.C.’s top doctor is calling for electronic cigarettes and “vaping” to be regulated after an 11-year-old was able to buy one in a Tsawwassen corner store.

But one anti-smoking activist said the relatively new products — which allow users to inhale vapour that’s been flavoured and in some cases infused with nicotine — are difficult to regulate because they exist in a grey zone.

The province’s chief medical officer, Dr. Perry Kendall, and others concede not enough evidence exists to determine whether puffing on the battery-operated inhaler without producing “smoke” is dangerous, but he said everyone should avoid it.

“Sucking up vapour that’s got ethylene glycol and other chemicals in it is properly not a good idea,” he said. “I can’t see why people would want to.”

“The bigger public health concern is that vaping — it’s a verb now — would become an acceptable social habit. Young children are vaping. It’s just a gateway to smoking.”

B.C. health officials are writing to schools to ban it from schoolyards and drafting a letter to urge Health Canada to regulate the devices.

“They should be restricted to people over 19 years,” said Kendall.

Joe Braico of Delta said his 11-year-old son called for him to check out an e-cigarette that vaporized a blueberry-flavoured substance the boy had bought from a local lottery store.

“He said, ‘Hey, Dad, look,’ and he’s trying to blow a smoke ring with this thing,” said Braico.

Braico returned to the store, the Tsawwassen Lottery Centre at Tsawwassen Town Centre Mall, and the woman who sold the $10 device to him assured him there was no nicotine in it and told him it was like candy.

She told him there was nothing illegal about selling to children.

“I don’t think it’s appropriate for an 11-year-old boy,” said Braico.

The staffer, who said her name was Nanshim and had limited English, told The Province she sold the e-cigarette.

“It’s not illegal,” she said, saying she sold it to “not many children. They are very curious. It’s just for fun.”

Braico said he discovered many of his son’s friends had the same device and said sales should be restricted, although he doesn’t oppose their sale to adults.

“My friends at work are using them to quit smoking and they’re loving them,” he said.

E-cigarettes with nicotine are marketed online as a way to quit smoking and Kendall conceded they may be less harmful than a traditional cigarette, which has 4,000 toxins, including 60 to 70 carcinogens.

But the nicotine version cannot legally be sold in Canada because it would then require approval by Health Canada, said spokesman Gary Holub. And neither can manufacturers claim any health benefits without Health Canada’s review and approval, he said.

Products without health claims or known toxic ingredients can be sold in Canada and “the onus is on the manufacturer that they do not pose a danger to human health or safety,” he said.

Health Canada in 2009 issued a product safety warning, “advising Canadians not to purchase or use electronic smoking products, as these products may pose health risks and have not been fully evaluated for safety, quality and efficacy by Health Canada.” Holub said the advisory still stands.

Veda Peters of the B.C. Lung Association said e-cigarette makers are careful not to make any claims for their products as a quit-smoking tool so that they won’t be subject to government review.

She said there isn’t enough research done on the devices to prove they’re harmful, but she worries that it would reverse the public health efforts to ensure children and others are getting the message that smoking kills.

“We would hate to see the hand-to-mouth action of a white stick becoming normal again,” she said.

Paul Bergen of the Electronic Cigarette Trade Association of Canada told the Delta Optimist that e-cigarettes are safe and designed as adult pleasures.

He also said retailers usually refuse sales to minors and called the Delta sale an anomaly.

Melodie Tilson of the Non-Smokers Rights Association in Ottawa said her group doesn’t insist on banning the devices and they may help people quit smoking, but she said the federal government needs to regulate them, especially so they aren’t sold to children.

She said it may be necessary to create a new law to do so if it can’t be done within the current regulatory framework.

“They’re in a regulatory grey zone,” she said.

Kendall said B.C. may be able to regulate them as a “health impediment,” as was done recently with trans fats.

slazaruk@theprovince.com

twitter.com/susanlazaruk

column2: New election rules: Social media strictly off-limits for candidates on voting day
column3:
Until polls close on Saturday night, Twitter, Facebook, Instagram and other social media outlets are off-limits for candidates and political organizations running in the municipal election.

Mayor Gregor Robertson says he’s disappointed with an Elections B.C. decision to prohibit candidates in the municipal election from using social media.

Until polls close on Saturday night, Twitter, Facebook, Instagram and other social media outlets are off-limits for candidates and political organizations running in the municipal election.

According to Elections B.C., the Local Elections Campaign Financing Act prohibits candidates and electoral organizations from using social media on general voting day, including tweeting about where to vote, sending private messages on Facebook and sending mass emails.

Sending out such messages would be considered advertising, and candidates cannot sponsor new advertising or alter their existing advertising on election day.

The mayor, who was in the West End Saturday to accompany his three kids to vote, said not being able to tweet or use other social media is “really disappointing” for Vision staff.

“It’s not a good thing,” he said. “I disagree that we should be banned from social media on election day. Hopefully we will see that overturned soon. I hope that it doesn’t suppress the young vote today.”

Elections B.C.’s decision to ban candidates and their organizations from using social media was made in May, but Robertson said he only received final confirmation of that decision in the last 48 hours.

“It’s a last-minute ruling that is surprising and disappointing,” he said. “I think this has an impact on young voters, who certainly use social media more than the older generation.”

The social media ban applies to any account that may have been used in relation to campaigning.

Elections B.C. says candidates could potentially use a personal social media account in a non-political way, as long as that account was set up before they were ever a candidate and it has never mentioned the candidacy.

For example, if someone wants to use a personal Twitter account that has never in any way been linked to or referenced their candidacy to share a video of a puppy and a kitten doing something adorable, that could be allowed.

Personal, one-on-one emails to family and friends are OK, if they are not election advertising that promotes themselves or opposes other candidates. Personal, one-on-one text messages to family and friends are also fine.

Individuals other than candidates, however, can use any social media to express their personal views on a non-commercial basis on general voting day, including promoting and opposing candidates or elector organizations.

Robertson said he was excited to see that it was a sunny day in Vancouver, and hoped that would boost voter turnout. “Hopefully we get a big turnout today, that’s the important thing, because we want as many people in Vancouver as possible to come out and vote.”

“I’m confident, I’m optimistic. I think we fought a really tough campaign and tried to be as positive as humanly possible,” said Robertson.

— With files from Tiffany Crawford, Postmedia News

jensaltman@theprovince.com

twitter.com/jensaltman

Do you think politicians should be allowed to connect with voters via social media on election day? Tell us what you think in the comment section below

column2: Smyth: B.C. finance minister should be more than just ‘disappointed’ about payments to public execs
column3:
Finance Minister Mike de Jong is officially “disappointed” at the latest news of under-the-table payments to public-sector executives in B.C. Hey Mike: You should be more than “disappointed.”

Finance Minister Mike de Jong is officially “disappointed” at the latest news of under-the-table payments to public-sector executives in B.C.

Hey Mike: You should be more than “disappointed.” You should be mad as hell.

It started with revelations of unreported payments to executives at Kwantlen Polytechnic University, where president Alan Davis and another executive received $50,000 “pre-employment contracts” not properly disclosed to government.

Now comes word of even more.
