The government says the Provincial Health Services Authority (PHSA) has been overpaying the CEO of the B.C. Cancer Agency through a lucrative contract that was not properly approved.

Dr. Max Coppes was hired in 2012 for $500,000 a year, even though the government’s maximum salary cap for the position was $400,000.

Now the government has ordered that the good doctor’s salary be surgically reduced by 10 per cent as a “symbolic” gesture.

This is ridiculous. It’s not Coppes’s fault he accepted what was offered to him. The real culprits here are the people who approved the contract.

The government says Coppes’s contract was “negotiated” by Lynda Cranston, the former CEO of the PHSA. Cranston resigned last year after approving 118 raises for other health-care managers in contravention of government policy. But if Cranston negotiated the contract, who approved it? The PHSA board of directors?

“No, the board did not approve the contract, though they were aware an offer had been made,” PHSA spokeswoman Theresa Kennedy told me Wednesday.

Kennedy said the board members — who are still in place — assumed the contract met provincial salary guidelines, but they didn’t know what the guidelines were. Oh, that’s just great! Then why have a board of directors at all?

Meanwhile, the CEO of the Royal B.C. Museum also bagged bonus bucks that the government says it didn’t know about.

Jack Lohman was given a “secondary contract” that included more than $50,000 in perks and bonuses. Again, the payouts were not properly reported and approved.

The government’s response? De Jong says the government is cutting the museum’s $11.8-million annual operating grant by $53,000 as punishment.

Lohman’s contract, meanwhile, is being stripped of three annual business-class upgrades for flights to London, one of the unreported perks he received.

Once again, they are penalizing the wrong guy. It’s not Lohman’s fault he accepted a contract in good faith. And cutting the museum’s operating grant just penalizes the museum and the people who visit it.

Where are the consequences for the people who approved the perks and payoffs?

The government says Lohman’s secondary contract was “signed” by John Williams, the former chairman of the museum board.

Isn’t it interesting — and convenient — that the government is pinning this stuff on two officials no longer with the public service?

Was the secondary contract approved by the museum board? A museum spokesperson could not answer the question Wednesday.

Don’t wait for any heads to roll on this one. That’s not the way this government operates. When your money goes down the drain, they want you to forget the whole thing as quickly as possible.

msmyth@theprovince.com

twitter.com/mikesmythnews

Statement from KPU President and Vice-Chancellor Dr. Alan Davis by The Province

column2: 'He is the anomaly': The unblemished legacy of Steve Nash
column3:
Late in the winter of 1990, I sat in the bleachers of the old gymnasium at Burnaby’s St. Thomas More Collegiate and watched, for the first time, a Grade 10 kid named Steve Nash playing at the B.C. junior basketball championships with his high school team from Victoria.

Late in the winter of 1990, I sat in the bleachers of the old gymnasium at Burnaby’s St. Thomas More Collegiate and watched, for the first time, a Grade 10 kid named Steve Nash playing at the B.C. junior basketball championships with his high school team from Victoria.

Last week, just nine months shy of a quarter-century later, I sit with filmmaker Michael Hamilton in his south Surrey home, getting a personal screening of his latest project, Nash: A Documentary Film.

It doesn’t take long before snippets from the now famously fuzzy highlight reel that a high school-aged Nash sent college recruiters fill the screen.

The images shake and wobble. The focus is far from pristine. Yet like early newsreel footage, it has not only endured, but become even more stirring with the passing of time.

“Where,” I ask Hamilton, “have the last 25 years gone?”

THE REAL STORY

If we drafted a blueprint of everything a professional athlete should be to his family, his team, his community and his world, Steve Nash would be that guy.

But how to best tell that story when the subject in question — one named by Time Magazine in 2006 as one of the 100 Most Influential People in the World — breaks so many of the stereotypes associated with the professional athlete?

“I guess, at the onset of the film, we were struggling a bit because in documentaries there is always some drama,” says Hamilton, the film’s producer, who began work on the movie in 2010 with co-director Corey Ogilvie.

“But that is something that we never had with Steve. He’s a pretty nice guy.

MORE: WATCH ‘THE FINISH LINE’ BONUS EPISODES

“Then the lightbulb went on for us. Why were we trying to find some kind of drama in a guy’s life, when there wasn’t any? He is the anomaly. He is the quintessential athlete who is doing it on his own terms.”

And thus over the course of the film, Nash grows from sketch to painting, its overall depth as a work eventually reflecting all of the shades and complexities of its subject: two-time NBA Most Valuable Player, filmmaker, father, humanitarian.

So much of the film’s strength, in fact, lies in the diversity of the interviews conducted by Hamilton — who met Nash years ago through mutual friends — and Ogilvie, because this isn’t just a basketball movie, and Nash isn’t just a basketball player.

“We don’t want people to think we have all of these celebrities in the film just to name-drop because all of them have a connection to Steve,” Hamilton says, laughing, alluding to the likes of actor Owen Wilson, director Ron Howard and even the most famous man in the world — the P.O.T.U.S.

FANS IN HIGH PLACES

Through the course of filming, Hamilton had learned that Marvin Nicholson, special assistant to U.S. president Barack Obama, was not only from Victoria, but also a graduate of St. Michaels University School, the same high school as Nash.

Nicholson agreed to be interviewed for the film, but then said to Hamilton: “You know what would be really cool? We might be able to get five minutes with the president, because he is a big fan of Steve’s.”

At various points over the next year, Hamilton figured it wasn’t going to happen. But in April of 2011, both he and Ogilvie found themselves at the White House.

MORE: KOBE BRYANT HAS HIGH PRAISE FOR NASH

“My heart is just pumping and Corey is miking up the president,” recalls Hamilton. “And then he says to us, ‘I just want you guys to know that this never happens.’ And it doesn’t. Never had a sitting president agreed to do an interview for something that isn’t related to politics or the State of the Union. But he did it for Steve and that is just a testament to Steve’s character and personality.”

Said Obama, in the film, of Nash: “People will look back at Steve as one of the greatest players of all time, and my suspicion is he’ll be in the Hall of Fame. But I think you’re measured not just by your skills and your wealth, but by your character. And by that standard, I think he’ll do very well.”

THE MYTH OF SISYPHUS

At one stage of the film, Nash is quoted as saying: “A lot of guys have been told since they were 13 or 14 years old that they were going to be in the NBA, whereas I was always told I would not be in the NBA.”

Placed amidst the images of a post-college, pre-NBA Nash, it’s a powerful image, and one which plays perfectly to the film’s recurring theme of an underdog who refused to quit.

Through self-narration, Nash is placed within the Myth of Sisyphus, the ancient Greek tale of a man condemned for eternity to roll a boulder to the top of a steep hill, only to have it come rolling back down just as he nears the peak.

“Corey is a big philosophy guy,” Hamilton says of Ogilvie, a former UBC Thunderbirds player.

“One day he and I were just sitting in a coffee shop and we were asking ourselves, ‘What is the narrative? What is our special thing?’ He came to me with this story and it’s amazing because it speaks exactly to Steve’s struggles.

“Every step of the way, Sisyphus is pushing this boulder up the hill. And there is something to be said for process. It’s a continual thing. And through the process, you get better and stronger, and in Steve’s career, that is what he has done.”

THE REAL STEVE NASH

Nash: A Documentary Film begins its journey within the pages of Nash’s family scrapbook, takes us through his early days with the Phoenix Suns, to his breakthrough years with the Dallas Mavericks, and later his triumphant return to the Suns. It concludes just as he leaves Phoenix for the start of a new chapter with the Los Angeles Lakers.

Along the way, no topic is taboo.

On a personal note, I have had the pleasure of interviewing Nash over the years on many stages.

On campus following practices at Santa Clara University; in his hotel room the night before the 1996 NBA draft; throughout his early days in the league, when our paths crossed in my capacity as The Province’s beat reporter covering the Vancouver Grizzlies; even in the back of a limo cruising through the streets of Philadelphia during his first all-star weekend in 2002.

The person I got to know is exactly the person portrayed in the film.

“Meeting all of these different people,” begins Hamilton, “from the people he grew up with to the President of the United States, they all say the same thing about the guy. They all took away a piece of Steve that was consistent across the board. And it was amazing to see that.”

Nash: A Documentary Film has completed a short theatrical run in Toronto, Vancouver and Victoria. It is now available across Canada on iTunes, and through both Shaw and Telus video-on-demand services. It is set to begin a U.S. release in advance of the 2014-15 NBA season.

htsumura@theprovince.com

column2: It’s location, location, location
column3:
The Village on False Creek features more than six acres of green space, playgrounds and parks for the urban family Gerry Kahrmann/PNG files Gerry Kahrmann/PROVINCE

It's the ultimate in urban living, a place with the water at your doorstep and the mountains in your sights, a place of tranquillity near a vibrant downtown core.

It’s the ultimate in urban living, a place with the water at your doorstep and the mountains in your sights, a place of tranquillity near a vibrant downtown core.

It’s a place where strolling the seawall, cycling the bike paths, kayaking on a sunny day or people-watching over lattes at the nearby market are within reach, and apt to make you wonder why you would live anywhere else.

We’ve started the house hunt for you; consider this trio of new home developments:

The Village on False Creek

With more than six acres of green space, playgrounds and parks, and just a stroll from the shops on Cambie and offerings on Granville Island, Aquilini Development’s The Village on False Creek is perfect for the urban family. There are just 29 homes left, including a number of two-bedroom-plus-flex spaces. The sales centre at 1693 Manitoba St. is open from noon to 5 p.m. every day but Friday, but don’t wait — it’s closing Nov. 30. For more information, call 604-733-2010 or visit thevillageonfalsecreek.com.

Lido

Those looking for an upscale condo that offers a full-time concierge, pool with heated cabanas and hotel-inspired interiors may want to look no further than Bosa Properties’ Lido. Located in Southeast False Creek, this 21-storey tower is steps from recreation, shops and restaurants. Visitors are welcome to visit 103 — 110 Switchmen St. daily from noon to 5 p.m. Call 604-872-2672 or visit bosaproperties.com.

Block 100

Enjoy the comforts of home at Onni Group’s Block 100. This three-building development consists of three blocks: Quebec, Centre and Main, and comprises condominiums and town houses and nearly 5,000 square feet of indoor and outdoor amenity space — from a fully equipped fitness studio to an urban agriculture solarium to rooftop decks. The sales centre at 1405 Main St. is welcoming visitors from noon to 6 p.m. every day except Friday. For more information, call 604-682-8801 or go to onni.com.

— The Province

column2: The wizard behind the Commodore’s curtain
column3:
Vancouver Sun file photo of Drew Burns, manager of the Commodore. Ran July 14, 1984 p. B2 with the caption: DREW BURNS: city's senior club owner. Glenn Baglo/Vancouver Sun [PNG Merlin Archive] Glenn Baglo/PNG

Aaron Chapman’s book about the Commodore, which first opened on Granville Street in 1930, will be published Nov. 1. Steve Bosch / PNG Steve Bosch/PNG

Drew Burns, who ran the Commodore Ballroom from 1969 to 1996, made Vancouver one of the best places in North America to see cutting edge rock music. Burns passed away a week ago at the age of 81. Steve Bosch/PNG Steve Bosch/PNG

Rock music brought Drew Burns a measure of fame and fortune but left his heart cold.

Rock music brought Drew Burns a measure of fame and fortune but left his heart cold. His own passions ran to opera, jazz and blues.

Burns, who ran Vancouver’s Commodore Ballroom from 1969 to 1996, was open to any music that drew a thirsty crowd. In the ’70s, ’80s and ’90s, his calculating open-mindedness made Vancouver one of the best places in North America to see cutting-edge rock music.

Burns, who died a week ago at 81, brought everyone from Captain Beefheart to David Bowie to The Clash to the Commodore.

“Drew wasn’t a fan of punk rock,” says Vancouver musician and writer Aaron Chapman. “But he was smart enough to realize that if kids liked it, he would do well selling drinks. He knew that all sorts of musical styles could work at the Commodore.”

Chapman learned of Burns’s death mere hours before his new book about the Commodore was to go to the printer. He had just enough time to make last-minute changes to reflect the passing of the man who discovered the ballroom’s soul as its longtime operator. The book, Live at the Commodore: The Story of Vancouver’s Historic Commodore Ballroom, is being published Nov. 1 by Arsenal Pulp Press.

The Commodore Cabaret, which opened on Granville Street in 1930, spent much of its first four decades catering to the jazz- and crooner-inflected tastes of the day. Patrons in gowns and tuxes danced to jazz big bands or swing combos, swigging from contraband liquor bottles hidden under tables.

But the Commodore was always waiting for Drew Burns. He was the visionary who saw what it could become — a showcase for the world’s leading pop musicians that also nurtured homegrown talent.

Burns, who had been running a Vancouver group for singles called the Fifth Day Club, leased the building in 1969, got a liquor licence and changed the name to the Commodore Ballroom.

At the start, he was a bit clueless.

“What am I going to do with this place?” he asked himself at night, standing alone in the silent ballroom, Chapman reports.

Burns spent the next 27 years answering that question. He rampaged through musical genres to book a vast and multi-faceted array of performers: James Brown, Muddy Waters, Kiss, Iggy Pop, The Police, Nirvana and U2, to name only a few.

“He sort of spoiled Vancouver,” Chapman says in an interview. “The city became the beginning or the end of many bands’ North American tours.

“Drew cross-pollinated local musicians with big acts from other places.”

Burns presented his first rock show at the Commodore in July 1971. It featured Detroit-based singer Mitch Ryder. Burns lost money on it because he had to pay a high guarantee to Ryder. Still, the event gave Burns a taste of the future.

Not every show proved to be an artistic or commercial victory.

Of a New York Dolls show in 1974, The Province rock critic Jeani Read wrote: “The New York Dolls are two million dollars’ worth of hype, and two cents’ worth of talent. They have a song called Trash and that describes them perfectly.”

Other shows were aesthetic triumphs but hygienic catastrophes, Chapman writes. In 1981, a vodka-gulping Joe Cocker fled the stage to vomit in a backstage toilet, rinse his face and return to deliver a scorching performance.

In 1978, Patti Smith became the first punk performer to sell out the Commodore. She asked Bud Wandrei, who worked for concert promoter Perryscope, for towels to take a bath backstage.

The backstage tub hadn’t been used for a bath in 20 years. It had been regularly used for almost every vile purpose.

Wandrei awkwardly told Smith that she didn’t want to take a bath in there.

“Oh, it’s OK — I’ll rinse it out afterward,” Smith reportedly answered.

Burns was blessed with a high tolerance for risk that let him take a chance on acts that had yet to become well known.

“He had a gambler’s guts,” Chapman says. “Another person who wasn’t as open-minded might have passed on them.”

One of Burns’s great skills was knowing what he didn’t know, Chapman says. He sought advice from music journalists and young employees about the merits of different bands.

“If he was unsure, he would call and pick my brain,” says arts publicist Ellie O’Day, who was then working part-time in radio.

DOA singer-guitarist Joe Keithley says Burns accepted punk music at a time other club operators feared its sometimes abrasive practitioners.

“If you get 500 people in here and the bar’s active, I’m happy,” Keithley recalls Burns telling him. “Play whatever you want.”

Burns wasn’t about just maximizing the bottom line. He went out of his way to help struggling local bands by getting them gigs as opening acts or packaging multiple bands for a show.

“He would give breaks to all kinds of people,” says Zulu Records owner Grant McDonagh. “He was one of the handshake generation whose word is gold.”

Burns left the Commodore in 1996 following a quarrel with the building’s owners. But Live Nation Entertainment, the company that now leases the Commodore, has kept alive his vision of the venue as a haven for top-notch global and local musicians.

“Drew has been our mentor and has guided us through the years,” says Gord Knights, who became general manager when the Commodore reopened after its closure from 1996 to ’99. “Music in Vancouver wouldn’t be what it is today if it weren’t for Drew.

“Anybody that was touched by Drew found their lives changed for the better.”

In the years since Burns’s departure, Knights and his team have managed to build on Burns’s vision of the Commodore as a music hub. And they’ve done it at a time many young people are as inclined to go see a DJ as they are flesh-and-blood musicians, Chapman says.

Among the memorable Commodore performances during the past 15 years have been those given by the White Stripes, Coldplay, Tom Waits, The Black Keys, The Roots and Lady Gaga, Chapman says.

Vancouver band 54-50 has played the ballroom more than 50 times, holding the record for most appearances.

But the current operators have broadened the Commodore’s showbiz palette beyond music. Its talent buyers have booked comedy acts such as Adam Carolla and have embraced, so to speak, wrestling by erecting a ring in the middle of the dance floor.

In 2011, Billboard magazine ranked the Commodore as one of the 10 most influential concert venues in North America. It took its place alongside legendary halls such as the Fillmore in San Francisco, the Bowery Ballroom in New York, the 9:30 Club in Washington, D.C., and the Troubadour in West Hollywood.

“The Commodore is the oldest club on the list and the only Canadian club,” Chapman says.

The Commodore’s sprung floor, which has put a bounce beneath the feet of generations of dancers, has long been part of its enduring charm, Chapman says.

Burns’s innermost mojo may not always have been stirred by the music of the bands he booked but he genuinely cared about the human beings in those bands, those who knew him say. In a business that had its cutthroat side, Burns is said to have been a decent person.

“He was a completely straightforward, totally nice guy,” Keithley says. “There was no ‘I’m better than you.’ He was just welcoming.”

Chapman says Burns’s love for people generated a goodwill that helped the Commodore prosper.

“In those days, if someone else had taken over the Commodore without Drew’s openness, imagination and fun-loving spirit, I don’t think it would have survived. It would have been demolished and become another long-forgotten ballroom.”

The Commodore’s future is not to be taken for granted. Chapman quotes Live Nation Canada senior vice-president Erik Hoffman as saying the club, for which the operating costs are “astronomical,” has been at risk several times.

“It’s on prime real estate,” Hoffman says. “It doesn’t make good business sense on its own to run the ballroom.”

But the Commodore has symbiotic value as a musical nursery and dating service. For bands, it acts as a springboard to playing stadiums. It lets Live Nation form a connection with bands that go on to play those arenas.

“The successful shows we do at the arenas allow us to take chances on bands in smaller venues, to book new talent, so one feeds the other,” Hoffman says in Chapman’s book. “The Commodore is at the cornerstone of this process.”

BLONDIE TO B.B. KING TO THE CLASH

The Commodore Ballroom hit its stride in the late ’70s and early ’80s, mounting many of its best-loved shows.

But the single month of January 1979 is remembered as an early creative peak. January saw a string of remarkable performances scattered like pearls across its 31 days, says Aaron Chapman, author of Live at the Commodore.

New wave band Blondie kicked the month off with its Vancouver debut on Jan. 2. Four days later, New York punkers The Ramones returned for a sold-out show with local band D.O.A. as the opening act.

Vancouver fans of new wave music had just enough time to catch their breath before Devo made its Vancouver debut with two shows on Jan. 12. The band’s then controversial music stunned concertgoers.

Country singer Tanya Tucker played on Jan. 13, followed by venerated bluesman B.B. King on Jan. 16 and 17.

For some, the month’s highlight was the North American debut of British punk band The Clash. American rock ’n’ roller Bo Diddley was the opening act.

“As with the nights that Captain Beefheart, the New York Dolls, or Kiss played the Commodore, the Clash show is remembered as a you-had-to-be-there, unforgettable night in the ballroom’s history,” Chapman writes.

pluke@theprovince.com
