column2: Key John Furlong accuser withdraws sexual assault lawsuit against former VANOC boss
column3:
A woman who accused former Vancouver Olympic CEO John Furlong of sexual abuse during his time at a northern B.C. school has withdrawn her lawsuit saying the stress of the court case was proving too much. A B.C. Supreme Court judge granted Beverly Mary Abraham’s request for dismissal on Friday.

One of the women who accused former Vancouver Olympic CEO John Furlong of sexual abuse has withdrawn her lawsuit.

A B.C. Supreme Court judge granted Beverly Mary Abraham’s request for dismissal on Friday.

Just over four months ago, Abraham lost her brother and shortly after her cousin and her 16-year-old nephew both died. Then, a month ago, her 91-year-old mother broke her leg and Abraham said she felt like she couldn’t deal with the stress of the lawsuit.

She said after speaking with her husband and hereditary chief, “it was time to let it go.” She said she stands by her allegations but she is too tired and stressed out to continue.

“A lot of weight came off my shoulders. I felt a hundred times lighter instead of dragging all these problems around,” she said Tuesday morning from her home in Burns Lake. “I just want to give it up to God. I told the truth. That’s all that matters. It hurts me deeply inside when I think of all the people that supported me saying ‘way to go Bev.’ It seems to me I let them down, but I had to take care of myself too.”

The allegations surfaced following an article, published two years ago in the Georgia Straight and written by Laura Robinson, suggesting he physically and verbally abused First Nations students at Burns Lake while teaching at a Catholic school there in the late 1960s.

Furlong has stated that he is innocent and that the allegations against him are false and defamatory. He still faces suits from Grace Jessie West and an unidentified man, both of whom allege they were sexually assaulted by Furlong.

His lawyer, Claire Hunter, said in a statement that Furlong has always maintained that all three claims are false.

“The dismissal follows the RCMP’s conclusion following an investigation that, ‘Based on the facts uncovered, the allegations made by Beverly Abraham are not supported.’”

She said Furlong will not comment with respect to the two outstanding claims because they remain before the courts.

Furlong has said previously that the article had “devastating and pulverizing consequences” on him and his family, and that he wished only to take action against “the source of these lies.”

He dropped a lawsuit against the Georgia Straight but is continuing a defamation suit against Robinson. He alleges that Robinson has a “personal vendetta” against him.

Abraham said her case was dismissed by consent without costs to either party. In her claim, Abraham alleged Furlong sexually molested her 12 times when she was 11 years old and attending the school. She also alleged Furlong justified his touching by saying, “You’re my beautiful Indian girl and my protege,” and his “favourite of all the girls.”

Furlong still faces suits from Grace Jessie West and an unidentified man, both of whom allege they were sexually assaulted by Furlong.

None of the allegations has been proven in court.

— With files from Kelly Sinoski and Lori Culbert

column2: A year ago The Interview seemed like a good idea
column3:
They made a comedy about cancer (50/50) and scored a hit. Then they made a comedy about the apocalypse (This Is the End) and turned that into a hit as well. And as the now-shelved assassination comedy The interview was being filmed last year in B.C., everyone involved was thinking Seth Rogen and co-director Evan Goldberg had another hit on their hands.

They made a comedy about cancer (50/50) and scored a hit. Then they made a comedy about the apocalypse (This Is the End) and turned that into a hit as well.

And as the now-shelved assassination comedy The interview was being filmed last year in B.C., everyone involved was thinking Seth Rogen and co-director Evan Goldberg had another hit on their hands.

“I think the crew is laughing more on this than on anything we’ve ever done,” said Goldberg as they filmed in a Burnaby soundstage interior set meant to be North Korean leader Kim Jong Un’s mountain palace.

The movie, which stars Rogen and James Franco as two clueless journalists coerced into a plot to assassinate dictator Kim (actor Randall Park), was abruptly pulled from release this week and may never be seen at all after distributor Sony Pictures was crippled by a corporate cyber attack now linked to rogue dictatorship North Korea. Sony opted to cancel altogether the Dec. 25 release date after anonymous hackers subsequently threatened 9/11-style terrorist reprisals against theatres that showed the film.

Rogen and Franco cancelled all media and print interviews last week just before the movie was pulled. But all of that was in the future last year as Goldberg, Rogen and Franco filmed a bawdy script that mixed politics with penis jokes.

“We did have to get another person to write the script because we’re not smart about politics,” said Goldberg, who has been writing scripts with Rogen since their high school days together at Point Grey secondary.

A fictional story about the assassination of a real-life dictator seems like an odd choice for a comedy — call it Zero Dark Superbad.

But when Rogen and Goldberg pitched their idea, Sony Pictures gave them a free hand.

“After This Is the End, they’re back into saying these guys can pull off wild stuff, so let’s just let them do whatever,” Goldberg said, adding all Sony was worried about when they were making the movie was that Franco should not have a beard, as he did in This Is the End.

“In this one we kept Franco real handsome . . . we had a huge battle over his facial hair in This Is the End.”

In that 2013 hit, Rogen, James Franco and several of their friends played themselves at a party interrupted by the apocalypse.

As it turns out, Franco’s facial hair or the lack thereof was the least of anyone’s worries.

The Interview’s fictional story originally formed around the notion of killing Osama bin Laden.

“Seth came to work one day and was like, if Charlie Rose or someone got an interview with bin Laden, why wouldn’t they just kill him, they’d be saving a lot of people,” Goldberg said. “We thought that’d be a good movie, then we went, ahh we’re too stupid to write it. But then we’re like what if we didn’t write it? What if we found someone who was smarter, and dumbed it down on our own?”

They enlisted writer Dan Sterling (The Daily Show, The Office), who shifted the story to a North Korean setting.

While the Middle East stirs debate from all sides, Goldberg said, North Korea was more straightforward.

“It’s a pretty cut-and-dried situation, s—’s crazy over there and it’s not cool,” Goldberg said. “People all generally agree they should have more freedom there.”

In Sterling’s script, actor Park plays the North Korean leader as a Katy Perry-loving pop-culture fan, who invites tabloid TV interviewer Dave Skylark (Franco) and his producer (Rogen) to North Korea for an interview. The CIA gets wind of the meeting, and coerces the journalists into an assassination plot.

“Leading up to it we’ve been heavily researching, which is the first time I’ve ever said that,” Goldberg said.

“We tried to make this realistic — the uniforms the wallpaper, the murals in the movie. The way people’s hair is cut the attitude of the people . . . we’re not just like loosey goosey doing a new North Korea. We’ve got some professors to look at it and nobody told us it’s bulls—.”

North Korea had figured in movie comedy before, in 2004’s Team America: World Police, which mocked Kim’s father, the late Kim Jong Il. That movie made the news again last week when Vancouver’s Rio theatre and several U.S. independent theatres announced plans to screen it in place of The Interview. But distributor Paramount kiboshed that idea by refusing to make Team America: World Police available.

“It just got pulled,” said Rio programmer Rachel Fox. “We’re likely going to screen The Great Dictator at some point . . . unless Hitler has an objection.”

And the creative chill continues, with news that film producer New Regency has cancelled a March filming start for a North Korea-themed thriller called Pyongyang, which was to star Steve Carell.

gschaefer@theprovince.com

twitter.com/glenschaefer

FRANCO ON ROGEN: ‘THERE’S NO BOSS’

James Franco and Seth Rogen have been working together since 1999’s cult TV hit Freaks and Geeks, and as they filmed the now-shelved comedy The Interview in Vancouver last year, they were revelling in an unprecedented degree of creative control.“(The Interview) feels like all the other movies we’ve done, but with the added bonus of, the kids get to control, the kids are in the kitchen,” Franco said last year during a break in filming on a Burnaby soundstage. “There’s no boss, there’s no one overseeing anything anymore, so it feels very free and very creative. . . . We get to do exactly the movie that we want to do.”For his part, producer-director-star Rogen was still getting used to that free hand on set last year.“There’s a moment where I have to remind myself — we’re the ones who have to say whether or not it’s acceptable,” Rogen said. “We’re used to the idea that if it’s really bad, someone will say something. I always have to remind myself like, no, we’re the ones who have to say something.”Rogen was talking about the need to keep doing scenes until they were as strong as possible, but after The Interview sparked an international wave of cyber-crime against studio Sony Pictures, and threats of terrorism against theatres that showed the movie, he can likely expect more scrutiny on his next feature project.Franco and Rogen first met at the beginning of their careers, as castmates on Freaks and Geeks, a short-lived but critically acclaimed series about a group of high school misfits.“That was Seth’s first professional job as far as I know as an actor,” Franco said. Rogen was 17 when the show came out in 1999, and Franco was 21. “I was very fresh, I hadn’t done much.”Their careers have continued to intersect over subsequent years, as Franco went on to projects that included the three Spider-Man movies and his Oscar-nominated role in 127 Hours. Rogen, meanwhile, turned to writing for TV’s Undeclared and Da Ali G Show, with supporting roles including Undeclared and The 40-Year-Old Virgin, before his breakout starring role in 2007’s Knocked Up.Franco had a cameo in that latter film, and the two paired up to star in 2008’s pot comedy Pineapple Express, which Rogen also co-wrote and produced. They were together again in last year’s apocalyptic comedy This Is the End, Rogen’s directing debut.“What’s so impressive to me about what he does is that it’s a fully dimensional kind of creating,” Franco said. “He does all sides, and this directing thing is kind of the last step.”As with This Is the End, Rogen co-directed The Interview with his writing partner Evan Goldberg.“When they started This Is the End, it was perfect. They had done everything else, and now why not, why shouldn’t they direct?” Franco said, adding Rogen “learned so much . . . gradually just developing all the skills. Now he’s a fully rounded story teller and entertainer. He’s taken all the best ways of working from his earlier jobs.”Studio Sony insisted that This Is the End (in which Rogen, Franco and others played themselves at a party interrupted by the end of the world) film in New Orleans, and execs also worried about the movie’s oddball premise. When This Is the End was a better-than-expected audience hit, Rogen and Goldberg got more latitude for The Interview, including the OK to film in their hometown.

column2: Striking a balance between economy and environment
column3:
This week, we talk with Alan Chen, sales manager for Long Hoh Enterprises Canada. Long Hoh is a small Qualicum Beach lumber manufacturer serving a unique niche market in Japan.

In a series of conversations with workers and business operators, the Province and the non-profit society, Resource Works, explore the contributions that trade, industry, and natural resources make to the British Columbia economy. This week, we talk with Alan Chen, sales manager for Long Hoh Enterprises Canada. Long Hoh is a small Qualicum Beach lumber manufacturer serving a unique niche market in Japan.

Postmedia News: Long Hoh markets itself as a small manufacturer of forest products focusing on quality and sustainability. How did you get started?

Alan Chen: In the beginning, some immigrant families came here to try to continue their expertise in wood processing and making building components. They acquired land (at Qualicum Beach) and built from scratch. In 1997, the sawmill opened for business. They chose the location because of its proximity to the required resources, which are the logs.

People in B.C. take pride in their natural resources, and value their trees. With help of government and community we have a set of regulations and guidelines governing our practice. People are getting more and more cautious about where they are getting their wood. I believe the owners had great vision.

PM: Could you talk about the specialty products your clients require?

AC: Our core business is to supply temple components, especially to Japan. Shinto temples hold sacred objects, statues or artifacts passed down from generation to generation, and people can go worship or pray. The wood was once a living thing, so it’s easy for the spirits in these temples to accentuate each other.

Because Japan historically had an abundant lumber resource, it’s very natural that they chose wood as the material to build the temples. They try to build without any nails. Our job is to map out our logs and cut exactly what they want. We try not to make too much waste in doing so.

PM: I’m guessing that when you have an order to fill, you have to have it into a container and out of the yard (and then onto a ship) on a pretty tight set of deadlines?

AC: Once we cut the trees into lumber — and dry it — we bring in the container trucks, load the containers on-site. Then they’re transported over to the Vancouver area and loaded onto vessels.

Because we are a small company, we have learned to do everything ourselves. We have a great team that handles our logistics. We map out the time frame from the beginning of the cut to loading the containers and then set up a schedule for the trucking company as well as the shipping line.

PM: How long have you been with the company, and what are your duties?

AC: I joined Long Hoh in 2005 and I started as a quality control and inventory clerk. Now I’m in charge of about half of our sales. Whenever there is a training session opportunity, the company will provide me time and pay my tuition. I take all the courses I can and the company supports that.

PM: Does work keep you awake at night wondering about production and shipping schedules?

AC: I’m very fortunate that I have many skilled colleagues helping me. Our contract shows that our responsibility ends when our containers are loaded onto those vessels, but we do have moral obligations so we are only satisfied when our customers receive the wood with smiles on their faces.

PM: How do you like living at Qualicum Beach?

AC: In summer, tourists flock in to enjoy the forest, the beach, and the things that the little township and the vicinity have to offer. In the winter the cold and damp air stops all these activities — but it is only then the perfect time for nature to recuperate and get back on its feet.

I’m well aware that what we do has an effect on the beautiful landscape. Because our business is close to the resource we use, we can be closer to reaching the balance between reducing the environmental impacts and growing the local economy.

column2: Veteran manager Tom Bradley lays out the case against index-linked GIC's
column3:
As a general rule, investment expert Tom Bradley doesn’t like products that come with high fees, too much structuring, and where it’s not clear how much the investor will gain

Tom Bradley has been in the investment industry for more than 30 years: he has been a equity analyst, a portfolio manager, an executive (he was the chief executive at Phillips Hager & North, one of country’s oldest institutional money managers that was sold to the Royal Bank in 2008) and the founder of another money manager, Steadyhand Investment Funds.

And when he set up that manager he did it his way with a model based on no loads, low fees and external management. Bradley also writes a blog where talks about his investment philosophy and also what he doesn’t like. As a generalization he doesn’t like products that come with high fees, too much structuring, and where it’s not clear how much the investor will gain.

“We’ve built a firm around the way we want our own money managed. And we provide a level of service and reporting that makes sense to us. This means your experience with Steadyhand is likely to be a little, well, different than what you may be used to,” says a posting on its web site.

This week Bradley wrote a blog that has attracted considerable interest given that the material focused on the interests of investors and where they stand in the pecking order. (The short answer is not very high.)

The chances are that the Royal Bank, in particular, won’t take too kindly to what he wrote given that he referenced one of its products. But it’s not a difficult jump to take his comments and apply them to the product manufacturers in general.

Indeed Bradley seems to be invoking retail investors to ask two questions: “what’s in it for me? And what’s in it for the issuer or the agents.” After all it’s their money.

column2: Federal-provincial accord on LNG industry includes use of foreign workers
column3:
OTTAWA — B.C.’s natural resources sector, including the budding liquefied natural gas industry, was declared to be in Canada’s strategic interests Monday as part of a non-binding federal-provincial deal that includes a commitment to encourage the active use of the Temporary Foreign Worker program.

The accord was signed as Premier Christy Clark, bringing with her what she described as possibly the largest B.C. delegation to Ottawa in Canadian history, declared that the LNG sector could be a “nation-builder” at least as important as Alberta’s oil wealth.

But she said that the industry’s enormous LNG potential depends on access to skilled Canadian and, if necessary, foreign workers.

Without that workforce the industry could look for other opportunities, she warned.

“You cannot build an economy without people who are trained and ready to take those jobs,” she told a gathering of federal and B.C. politicians.

The memorandum of understanding says Canada’s resources industry “is a significant economic catalyst in rural and remote regions that is becoming increasingly important to British Columbia’s economy and strategically important to Canada’s economic future.”

The growing global demand for those resources, including LNG, “has created a highly competitive global environment, requiring Canada and British Columbia to move quickly and responsibly to ensure Canada’s energy industry is export-ready.”

The meeting, and an elaborate signing ceremony between B.C. and federal ministers, appeared designed to send a message to industry that the federal and B.C. governments will move aggressively to ensure that Canada’s training, educational, and especially immigration policies will help the LNG sector expand.

But both Clark and her federal cabinet colleagues stressed that the temporary workers won’t be allowed to take jobs away from qualified Canadians.

The TFW has been plagued by abuses, and the federal government has recently taken steps to toughen sanctions against employers who use it to abuse vulnerable foreign workers and drive down wages.

“Our commitment is this: British Columbians first, Canadians second, and then when we have maxed out every opportunity to put Canadians to work on these projects we will need to begin to look oversees for temporary workers,” she told reporters after speaking to a gathering of LNG industry executives, First Nations leaders, federal MPs and senior federal ministers and officials.

B.C. wants at least three LNG terminals in operation by 2020, and is anxious to quell industry concerns about potential wage inflation that hurt the industry in Australia.

B.C. Jobs Minister Shirley Bond said the industry executives who expressed that concern were impressed with the level of cooperation shown here Monday by both levels of government.

“What we’re trying to avoid is what happened in Australia” where wage inflation caused by a shortage of workers created “significant issues,” Bond told The Vancouver Sun.

“We’re hearing today (from industry attending the session) that this is the first time we’ve seen this kind of cooperation early in the process, where both senior levels of government understand this is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and we need to be working together.”

David Keane, an executive with BG Canada, one of the LNG proponents, and a member of Clark’s working group on labour-related LNG issues, said the industry doesn’t want to be faced with the kind of “overly restrictive immigration policies” that caused problems in Australia.

“I think the federal government is working with the provincial government so we can address those issues,” said Keane.

Bond said Victoria is enthusiastic about the federal government’s new “expressions of interest” immigration program, which takes effect next January.

That program will actively prioritize foreigners who have skills being sought by Canadian companies.

poneil@postmedia.com

Twitter.com/poneilinottawa

column2: Deal with B.C. won’t make it easier to import foreign workers: Ottawa
column3:
B.C. Premier Christy Clark speaks to reporters in the Foyer of the House of Commons on Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Monday, March 31, 2014. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick Sean Kilpatrick/THE CANADIAN PRESS

OTTAWA — The federal government is making it harder, not easier, for employers like B.C.’s natural gas industry to bring in temporary foreign workers, Employment Minister Jason Kenney said Tuesday.

Kenney was responding to New Democratic Party allegations that governments are using the excuse of a possible West Coast natural gas boom to bring in an even larger number of temporary workers who will drive down wages and cost Canadian jobs.

The NDP’s criticism was focused on the Ottawa-B.C. non-binding agreement struck Monday on resource development that includes a commitment that the federal government continue its controversial Temporary Foreign Workers program.

The Harper government has “made it more difficult to bring in temporary foreign workers,” Kenney said.

“I was absolutely clear yesterday with the B.C. liquefied natural gas industry that it must employ and train Canadians first, particularly young Canadians and aboriginal Canadians, and only look to the TFW program as a last and very limited resort.”

Premier Christy Clark brought executives from the liquefied natural gas industry to Ottawa Monday to discuss their need for skilled workers.

Both levels of government made clear that Canada’s education and training systems won’t be enough to produce all the skilled workers needed, meaning that both immigrants and temporary migrants will be needed to meet the LNG sector’s needs.

But the NDP argued in Parliament Tuesday that the non-binding agreement that includes clear support for the temporary worker program is a cover to allow industry to bypass Canadians in favour of foreigners with no legal right to stay permanently in Canada.

“Projects like B.C.’s natural gas development (should provide) a generation of quality, decent-paying jobs for British Columbians,” Jinny Sims, the MP for Newton-North Delta, said during question period.

“Why are Conservatives making it easier to bring in even more temporary foreign workers when there are plenty of Canadians who could do the job?”

She later said in an interview that the true objective of the program is to lower Canadian wages, even though the government had dropped a provision allowing employers in some circumstances to pay foreign workers 15 per cent less than Canadians.

Kenney said during question period that Sims is one of a number of MPs, including B.C. New Democrats Libby Davies, Nathan Cullen, Alex Atamanenko and Liberal leader Justin Trudeau, who have written supportive letters on behalf of constituents trying to bring in foreign workers.

“The hypocrisy from the NDP on this question is really bizarre,” Kenney said.

Sims said she recalls sending a letter to the government in connection with a constituent’s frustration in getting a visa for a worker who had legitimately obtained permission from the federal government.

But she said that move wasn’t an indication she supports the program.

Data was unavailable Tuesday to indicate whether the Harper government’s recent harder line on temporary workers, in the face of numerous controversies over employee abuse, has had an affect.

The government imposed a $275 application fee on employers, insists that only English and French can be required languages, and is planning to bring in tougher sanctions that include “significant” fines, though the government won’t yet say how large they could be.

Over the long term, however, temporary foreign workers have flowed into Canada at a record pace. While the intake was relatively flat in the 1990s, peaking at 164,972 such workers in 1999, the number started growing dramatically starting in 2004. And since the Conservatives took power in 2006 the figure has almost doubled — from 255,331 that year to a record 491,537 in 2012.

B.C., Alberta and Saskatchewan have had a disproportionately high number of temporary foreign workers, with Kenney saying the cause has been a geographic and industry-specific skills shortage in the West.

poneil@postmedia.com

Twitter.com/poneilinottawa

column2: Tim Hortons, McDonald’s face criticism over foreign worker program
column3:
McDonald’s Canada said Wednesday it will be putting its use of the temporary foreign worker program on hold while conducting an audit by a third party to ensure there have been violations or abuse of workers — foreign or Canadian. KAREN BLEIER/AFP/Getty Images

Tim Hortons has ended its relationship with a franchisee in Fernie and Blairmore, Alta. who was the target of an Employment Standards Branch investigation after a temporary foreign worker from the Philippines claimed he was denied overtime pay for years.

In an emailed statement, Tim Horton’s spokeswoman Olga Petrycki said the company has “terminated our relationship with the Blairmore, Alberta/Fernie B.C. franchisee for failing to comply with Employment Standards requirements, a matter Tim Hortons takes very seriously.”

She did not specify which employment rules the franchisee had breached.

B.C.’s Employment Standards Branch and the restaurant chain launched an investigation after Filipino Richard Pepito, a former employee, went public with accusations that the franchise owner gave him paycheques that included overtime, but then required Pepito to pay the owner the overtime back in cash.

He told The Sun last year he wasn’t alone in being denied overtime pay, and staff were led to believe that if they complained they would lose their status under the temporary foreign worker program and be sent back to live in poverty in their home country.

“I felt discriminated against, harassed and bullied,” said Pepito.

Tim Hortons has assumed corporate control of the two restaurants and no employee jobs have been affected, Petrycki said.

Scott Lunny, assistant director of the United Steelworkers union in Western Canada, said his union has filed a complaint with the B.C. Human Rights Tribunal against the Fernie Tim Hortons franchisee and the corporate entity. He said the action was filed in December after workers came to the union seeking help.

“It came to our attention locally in Fernie that temporary foreign workers from the Philippines were not being treated properly within the confines of our human rights legislation,” he said.

“There’s a number of allegations which we say are either violations of employment standards or human rights violations given the status of these workers. These workers aren’t being properly treated and are being discriminated against in terms of their pay and working conditions.”

Lunny said the union believes similar abuse of temporary foreign workers is going on across Canada. “(Employers) are using (the program) to mistreat very vulnerable workers in some instances. We’re seeing more and more examples of that on a daily basis.”

McDonald’s Canada has also been stung by recent criticism of its use of temporary foreign workers. Three of its Victoria franchises are at the centre of program abuse allegations involving Canadian employees alleging foreign workers were given priority work status and in some cases took their jobs.

McDonald’s senior vice-president of human resources Len Jillard said Wednesday it will be putting its use of the program on hold while conducting an audit by a third party to ensure there have been violations or abuse of workers — foreign or Canadian.

“The reason why we’re doing that is we want to communicate to everyone we’re taking this very seriously,” Jillard said. “We’re taking a pause. We’re making sure that we’ve got everything in order, which I’m convinced we have.”

Jillard said McDonald’s has already informed the federal government about its plans, including federal Employment Minister Jason Kenney.

“We’ve had a couple conversations directly with Minister Kenney in terms of the approach we’ve taken,” he said.

Jillard said McDonald’s is voluntarily suspending its use of federal Labour Market Opinion applications for all of its Canadian restaurants for the hiring of temporary foreign workers. The LMO process is designed to ensure there are no Canadian workers available before a company receives permission to hire foreign workers.

McDonald’s is in the process of taking full ownership of the three Victoria franchises from the Victoria operator who previously held an 80-per-cent share in the three outlets.

Shortly after the Victoria restaurants were singled out by the federal government for breaking the rules, B.C. Federation of Labour president Jim Sinclair called on the company to stop using the program and asked the government to eliminate the use of the temporary workers for entry-level jobs.

“If McDonald’s does not take action to achieve these solutions, the B.C. Federation of Labour will consider further actions, including but not limited to, calling for a boycott of McDonald’s,” read the letter Sinclair sent to McDonald’s CEO John Betts.

Four per cent of the more than 80,000 McDonald’s employees in Canada are temporary foreign workers, Jillard said.

With files Brian Morton and Peter O’Neil, Vancouver Sun

tcarman@vancouversun.com

Follow me: @TaraJCarman

column2: Interior renovations turned Victoria house into home
column3:
A new window seat with built-in drawers for mats and linens, adds to kitchen seating and garden gazing Times Colonist

Powder room. This is where it all began. The family was looking for a new mirror, then needed a vanity . the rest is renovation history. Times Colonist

The new Jason Good kitchen features cupboards to the ceiling, a focal point range, decorative hood, and microwave camouflaged in the dark-tone island. Times Colonist

The owners found their dining table on-line and the artwork above, of beach stones, was painted by Cameron Thurbide. Times Colonist

The island looks like a giant quartz-topped table from this side, thanks to huge hand-carved corner posts. The fridge, at right, fits like a glove into a wall, which was optically straightened with different depth cupboards made by Jason Good. Times Colonist

Jennifer and Shane Palmer’s house in the Victoria neighbourhood of Fairfield looks old in style, but was built just 14 years ago and has a modern interior. Times Colonist

VICTORIA — It started when the couple decided to replace a bathroom mirror, and then wanted a new vanity, too.

“Pretty soon the ball started rolling and we were renovating the bathroom, gutting the kitchen, laying down new wood flooring,” said Jennifer Palmer. She and her husband Shane moved here from Calgary five years ago and found a lovely neighbourhood in Fairfield and a perfect home. Well, almost perfect.

“We were looking for a good place to raise our kids who are nine and seven,” said Shane.

“Enjoying nature is a bit of an ordeal in Calgary. Just getting out of the city is a chore, but in a community like this, there are so many opportunities within a short walk or drive. You can enjoy nature so much more easily — just like that,” he said, snapping his fingers.

Jennifer spotted the house online and flew out from Calgary for a closer look. She loved what she saw: A home with a historic-looking exterior, but modern interior.

“We’d probably have preferred a heritage house and did put in an offer on one, which we didn’t get,” Jennifer said.

“But then we thought how older homes are very broken up inside, whereas this house is so open and spacious.”

Their former house in Calgary was 1,000 square feet, whereas this is just shy of 3,800, which they wanted so they could do more entertaining.

The Palmers love the 14-year-old home’s “fabulous flow and room layout,” but gagged slightly when they saw the kitchen, which was completely pink inside. “The counters were pink and all the whitewashed cabinets had a pink undertone,” Jennifer said.

They planned to renovate down the road but. …

“All I did was go shopping for a bathroom mirror,” Shane said, helplessly. “And then we thought about a new vanity, and then we decided to gut the bathroom, and then the kitchen. …

“Jen was in Calgary at the time and I sent pictures of vanities from Home Depot, Rona, Slegg. Then I had a bright idea of going to a cabinetmaker. That was my fatal mistake,” he said.

He walked into the workshop of Jason Good Custom Cabinets and saw the owner covered in sawdust. “I could see Jason was a hands-on guy and that sold me.”

The meticulous Jennifer sought seven other quotes, just to be sure. One estimator said he could install a new kitchen in two days, whereas Good said his would take two weeks, and they liked that.

A makeshift kitchen was set up in the basement and they camped there for four months, during which “the fire alarm went off every day.”

“I started calling my wife General Jen,” said Shane, noting the former teacher was a brilliant general contractor who didn’t pick any tradespeople without references and multiple interviews.

“Jason’s attention to detail is incredible,” said Jennifer, who is detail-oriented herself. “We are forever in the kitchen, so it made sense to spend money here. This is where we live, where the kids do their homework, it’s the hub of the house.”

The new island seats six instead of three, and the oven, which used to be inconveniently opposite the island, is now part of the Blue Star range. It has a cast-iron top and no electronics, just simple switches, so fewer things to go wrong. The new fridge and stove are 48 inches wide instead of 30.

The house previously had white carpet in the family room, office and living room — “not very practical for our young family and dog” — so S & I Hardwood Floors laid new oak flooring to match that in the kitchen, hallway and bathroom. The matte finish is forgiving and doesn’t show dog or kid prints.

“The challenge was to lace it in, and they did a great job over the course of a week, so there is not a trace of a joint,” said Shane, who is chief pilot for VIH Aviation. His company works everywhere from Pakistan and Peru, to Taiwan, Africa, Australia and Brazil, and he has worked around the world.

“We wanted a bit of a focal point above the stove and that snowballed, too,” joked Shane, but they are delighted with the craftsmanship and way Good hid the exhaust chimney through cupboards at left.

“Just look at these joints,” said Shane, proudly pointing above the range. “Doing this reno, we learned a lot about why something is attractive. It’s not just one thing. It’s all kinds of little details.”

The fridge fit was so tight it couldn’t slide into place until Good came and trimmed a quarter inch off the base, said Jennifer. It fits like a glove, and he built a window seat, too. “It was an afterthought but we are really pleased. For one thing there is less storage now, because of our bigger appliance, and these drawers hold a lot.”

Good’s kitchen designer, Claire Reimann, “gave us unbelievable customer service.”

“I talked to a lot of kitchen people and they always went along with my suggestions. But Claire was different. She’d say, have you thought about this, or that? We didn’t need ‘yes people.’ ”

Reimann said the kitchen was challenging because the fridge wall had an awkward U shape. “You can’t tell now, but it was really uneven. Jason camouflaged that with cabinets of different depths.

“He created furniture kicks at the bottom of the cabinets, custom profiles, so your toes can slide under,” and put a vacuum in the kick, as well as classic style corbels in the wide, custom range hood.

“He put a panel on the dishwasher so it’s hidden, put light valances under the cabinetry and took cabinets to the ceiling, whereas before there was a good gap for dust collection.

“The island has big square posts on the corners now, hand carved in cherry like the new bathroom vanity, and it’s stained rather than painted so it won’t show nicks,” Reimann said.

Thick countertops make the kitchen look more custom and the microwave is hidden in the dark wood island. “It used to be over the range — not a great focal point.”

Other features include glass doors, undermount sinks and a valance above the window, with recessed puck lights. “A nice touch in houses with tall ceilings so it doesn’t leave that high void.”

column2: Judge slams CIBC for firing Vancouver employee
column3:
Staff at CIBC were "cavalier, insensitive, and reckless" in the wrongful firing of a Vancouver employee her manager had once called one of the best in the country, according to a recent B.C. Supreme Court judgment.

Guiyun (Han) Ogden, a financial adviser for wealthy clients at the bank’s Imperial Service division, was fired in March 2011 after managers had issued her a pair of disciplinary letters that Justice Randall Wong dismissed as unwarranted in his decision, released Tuesday.

"They forged ahead with a termination for cause based on inaccurate and incomplete information despite knowing they had a heightened responsibility to get it right," wrote Wong in his decision, adding the firing killed Ogden’s chances of working as a licensed financial adviser anywhere.

A panel of managers and other CIBC staff decided unanimously to terminate Ogden after she made a decision in September 2010 that the company later claimed was made in contravention of its Code of Conduct.

Wong found two of the panel members — Ogden’s superiors, Paula Vanni and Rod Fossen — "were motivated to fire an unhappy employee before she quit," ensuring they would retain her client accounts — worth $233 million — after she was gone.

But Ogden’s unhappiness at the bank appeared to come after she began to receive the disciplinary warnings from her managers toward the end of her nearly seven years of impressive performance, according to trial evidence.

Ogden came to Canada from China in 2000 with little English, according to the decision. She entered Royal Roads University and graduated at the top of her class with a business degree. Soon after that she became a level two certified general accountant, then a certified financial planner.

CIBC hired the hard worker as a personal banker at its University of B.C. branch in 2004. She was promoted to her position as a financial adviser within two years.

In her first years in the new position, she built a large, loyal clientele, mostly comprising wealthy Chinese immigrants. According to a 2009 performance review, she was a brilliant employee.

"Congratulations Han on an absolutely spectacular year," wrote David Fawkes, her then general manager.

"Your commitment to your own excellence shines through in everything you do, from maintaining a well-balanced book of business to providing excellent client service that goes above and beyond what is expected for your role. Your results truly speak for themselves."

In 2010, Vanni called Ogden "an exceptional adviser" and an "annual achiever."

But in 2008 and 2010, Ogden had been issued warnings that Wong later dissected in his ruling and found lacking a reasonable basis.

One warning came from "document deficiencies" that the justice found either did not occur, were caused by confusing and changing policies, or were systemic procedural problems in the branch that Ogden was "singled out" for.

Another warning came after a pair of contraventions that resulted from the actions of other CIBC employees, Wong found.

Ogden was devastated by that warning, wrote Wong. She protested, told Vanni she was unhappy and thinking about quitting, and wanted to escalate the matter to a senior vice-president at the company. But in the end, Ogden decided to drop the issue.

The final incident that led to Ogden’s termination involved a pair of wire transfers structured to work around Chinese regulations that prohibited individuals from transferring more than $50,000 US out of the country annually. The issue was not the fact that Ogden used the work around — a practice CIBC supported, Wong wrote — but the unconventional way she did it.

In September 2010, Ogden received a panicked call in the middle of the night from a client. The client was trying to transfer $500,000 into the country for the deposit on a home, something she needed 10 separate Chinese and Canadian accounts to do. But she was short two Canadian accounts and the money needed to arrive the following day or the real estate deal would collapse. The client asked to transfer the money via two of Ogden’s own accounts. She agreed.

"This was not a case of ‘don’t do x’ and Ms. Ogden ‘did x’," wrote Wong about the transaction. "The rule she is alleged to have breached was far from clear, was open to interpretation, and was sometimes confusing in its application. This was also a transaction in which there was no actual conflict of interest, but only a potential conflict of interest."

Months later, the CIBC panel debated the incident and decided to fire her.

In his decision, Wong chastised CIBC staff for having lost or destroyed relevant documents, contrary to company policy, and noted that Vanni, Fossen and another employee had changed their stories during testimony.

Wong found CIBC liable for breach of contract, declared the firing was without cause, and ordered costs and damages to be determined at a later trial.

During the trial, Wong heard testimony from Ogden that her goal when she came to Canada was to become "the best financial adviser."

"I felt I did it. I became a top performer. I built a large portfolio. I was proud of myself," she said.

"All of a sudden everything was taken away from me. I loved being a financial adviser. I can’t do it anymore . . . I feel all my hard work was for nothing."

Read the full ruling here.

mattrobinson@vancouversun.com

Follow me: @mt_robinson

column2: Temporary foreign workers drive youth out of labour market, economics professor says
column3:
The federal government should put the brakes on the runaway growth of the Temporary Foreign Worker program, imposing yearly caps until a review determines whether its continued expansion is in the national interest, according to a Carleton University economics professor.

The number of workers admitted under the controversial program has more than doubled nationally over the last 10 years, increasing to 213,573 in 2012 from 102,932 in 2003, Citizenship and Immigration Canada figures show. In B.C., the rate of growth has been even faster, with the number of temporary workers hitting almost 50,000 in 2012, up from just over 20,000 in 2003.

The people who come in under the program range from seasonal agricultural workers to highly skilled IT professionals, but it is the fast-food industry’s use of such workers that has been under scrutiny in recent days after Ottawa announced it was investigating a McDonald’s franchisee in Victoria for allegedly abusing the program.

The Sun reported Wednesday on a Kelowna-area Dairy Queen employee who said she went from 30-plus hours a week to weeks at a time without a shift after temporary foreign workers arrived from the Philippines. The worker, Alisha Harris, is an 18-year-old Grade 12 student who was working to earn money for university tuition.

Alexandra Fortier, a spokeswoman for Employment Minister Jason Kenney, said Wednesday that the government’s assurances of protection for Canadian workers also apply to part-time employees.

The risk that temporary foreign workers will take employment opportunities away from young Canadians is not one that should be lightly dismissed, according to Christopher Worswick, an economics professor at Carleton.

“The kinds of jobs that are more and more likely to be filled by TFWs (such as less-skilled fast-food-industry jobs and hotel work) were traditionally first jobs for many young Canadians and/or supported them while they pursued post-secondary education,” he wrote in an October 2013 report on the economic implications of changes to the temporary foreign worker program. “If employers are able to bring in TFWs rather than raising wages to induce young Canadians to take these jobs or perhaps move to regions where such jobs exist, this could mean that young Canadians may face even greater difficulties in becoming established in the labour market and accumulating the skills they need to move into higher-skilled occupations.”

The reason employers choose to bring in foreigners rather than hire local youth is the “elephant in the room” in the debate around temporary foreign workers, Worswick said, and it has to do with work ethic. There are many low-income workers around the world who would welcome the chance to work in Canada if it meant a better life for their family. Given this motivation, they are likely to work harder and be less likely to complain about working standards than a similarly trained Canadian worker, according to Worswick.

Employers “may see an opportunity to gain extra profit by either advertising jobs at too low a wage (given the job requirements) or perhaps by being overly critical of Canadian applicants, so they could gain permission to hire a TFW who would be more productive.” Worswick called this “the greatest challenge regarding the Temporary Foreign Worker Program.”

Despite this, Worswick argues in favour of a limited, tightly regulated version of the program that focuses on situations in which firms need to hire highly skilled workers. Those who show an ability to support themselves for a given period of time should be able to apply for permanent residence, he added.

tcarman@vancouversun.com

With a file from Peter O’Neil, Vancouver Sun

column2: Vancouver mayoral candidates debate issues of race and discrimination
column3:
Vancouver’s mayoral candidates tangled over tough issues including discrimination and workforce inclusion in a Thursday afternoon debate in Chinatown.

A crowd of nearly 200, about two-thirds of whom were visible minorities — many Asian, came to SUCCESS, a multicultural service agency, to hear how candidates from COPE, NPA and Vision, and a trio of independents, would address issues of importance to them.

But as questions came in from audience and panel members, it soon became clear that issues of importance to many in the crowd were identical to those of concern to residents across the city — foremost among them, high levels of homelessness, overcrowding on key transit routes, expensive housing and concerns about job opportunities.

“There is no majority culture here in Vancouver anymore,” said incumbent Mayor Gregor Robertson, tapping into a theme that emerged as the debate progressed.

But even in a city with a strong multi-ethnic identity like Vancouver, issues specific to visible minorities remain. The first question posed to candidates was what they would do to address concerns that Chinese immigrants are being excluded from city jobs.

NPA candidate Kirk LaPointe was first to tackle the question, saying he had a history of working on diversity initiatives, noting that he created CTV’s first diversity initiative more than a decade ago. LaPointe said he wants a city that is equitable and fair.

LaPointe told members of the panel — journalists from foreign and English-language news services — that he would ensure information from the city would be translated and made available at the same time as the English version.

Beyond that, he said he would introduce new measures to achieve “the most inclusive and tolerant city that we can have.” LaPointe did not detail what those would be.

Robertson said the city has made “significant progress in being a more inclusive city.

“When we look at our checkered history on this there are lots of challenges and conflicts between races in Vancouver and a lot of that history, we are trying to reconcile now. We’re working hard to address and acknowledge that that history happened (and) learn from that,” he said.

COPE mayoral candidate Meena Wong said from what she’s seen, many immigrants coming to the city from different parts of the world cannot get fair treatment. She said she would push for a fair and transparent employment policy.

“I experienced discrimination at the workplace myself,” she said, adding it is essential to “know your rights.”

Rounding out the list of mayoral candidates who attended the event were independents Mike Hansen, Bob Kasting and Tim Ly.

Other questions the candidates faced included whether the city’s network of bike lanes should remain in place — all candidates but Hansen agreed they should, and most, like Wong and LaPointe, pointedly noted the network should expand, but only if residents want that.

LaPointe was asked about his defence of a proposal by Chevron to donate money to schools, something he has said was wrongly turned down by Vision school board chairwoman Patti Bacchus. He said that as an educator himself he is opposed to advertising in classrooms, but because the program had no strings attached, free money for school equipment had been turned down for ideological, not practical reasons.

Barbed comments were exchanged at times between LaPointe and Robertson, but neither candidate got the better of the other. If applause can be considered a measure of popularity, Robertson had the most fans in chairs Wednesday, many of whom asked him for photographs after the event.

Join us Nov. 4 as four candidates for mayor of Vancouver debate the most important issues facing the city in an evening presented by The Vancouver Sun in partnership with SFU Public Square. The event is free but space is limited and registration is required. Register at vancouversun.com/register

mrobinson@vancouversun.com

Click here to report a typo or visit vancouversun.com/typo.

Is there more to this story? We’d like to hear from you about this or any other stories you think we should know about. CLICK HERE or go to vancouversun.com/moretothestory

column2: FOI request exposes lack of transparency within Metro Vancouver's 21 city halls
column3:
Freedom-of-information requests from The Vancouver Sun to 21 Metro Vancouver municipalities are highlighting the arbitrariness and frequent lack of transparency at city halls in the region. One straightforward request for a complete list of the mayors’ email correspondence for July 2014 provided a perplexing and troubling array of municipal responses. Maggie Wong/Vancouver Sun

Delta demanded $2,598 for the release of one month of Mayor Lois Jackson’s emails. NICK PROCAYLO/PNG

Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson racked up the biggest cellphone bill in 2013 at $3,309.45 for 2013, which compares with Coquitlam Mayor Richard Stewart at $3,017 and Surrey Mayor Dianne Watts (pictured) at $2,811. Jenelle Schneider/Vancouver Sun

Burnaby demanded $2,677 for the release of one month of Mayor Derek Corrigan’s emails.

Pitt Meadows provided only two emails for Mayor Deb Walters, noting information had been exempted due to third-party privacy reasons. /Vancouver Sun

Only North Vancouver district failed to fully comply with the two requests, demanding a fee of $424.16 to provide the cellphone costs. Pictured is Mayor Richard Walton. Glenn Baglo/Vancouver Sun

Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson (pictured) racked up the biggest cellphone bill in 2013 at $3,309.45 for 2013, which compares with Coquitlam Mayor Richard Stewart at $3,017 and Surrey Mayor Dianne Watts at $2,811. Langley township Mayor Jack Froese incurred a bill of just $261. Jason Payne/PNG

Freedom-of-information requests from The Vancouver Sun to 21 Metro Vancouver municipalities are highlighting the arbitrariness and frequent lack of transparency at city halls in the region.

One straightforward request for a complete list of the mayors’ email correspondence for July 2014 provided a perplexing and troubling array of municipal responses.

At one extreme, Burnaby demanded $2,677 for Mayor Derek Corrigan’s emails for that month and Delta $2,598 for Mayor Lois Jackson’s emails.

At the other extreme, White Rock provided The Sun with electronic copies of Mayor Wayne Baldwin’s emails, while Langley City and Bowen Island each mailed a stack of photocopied emails — free of charge — from acting mayor Ted Schaffer and the late mayor Jack Adelaar, respectively.

Vincent Gogolek, executive director of the B.C. Freedom of Information and Privacy Association, said he is puzzled by the vast differences in fee estimates provided to The Sun.

“You have a nice representative sample of Lower Mainland municipalities. You’d think they’d be in the same ballpark. Not so much,” he said.

“I’m hard pressed to come up with any way you could come up with $2,600 in fees (Delta) for one person’s email for a month.”

Information was severed from the records under various sections of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act, notably due to unreasonable invasion of a third person’s personal privacy.

Whether the differences are reflective of the overall openness of the various municipalities is hard to say.

“It could be, or they’re just not doing a very good job,” said Gogolek, noting that high fees can represent a deterrent to the public pursuing their right to access information.

Burnaby records and information administrator Pierrette Hodnett wrote The Sun to say that the $2,677 fee included 43 hours of “onerous” staff time for disclosure preparation at $30 per hour plus 5,548 copies at 25 cents per page.

Delta’s municipal clerk, Robyn Anderson, explained that a release of the mayor’s 813 emails for July “would not be a matter in the public interest” and that due to the sensitive nature of some emails, preparing the records for disclosure must be undertaken by “exempt employees” in the clerk’s office.

Of the $2,598 fee, Delta wants to charge $1,936 just to locate the records.

“You’re just asking for one person’s email,” Gogolek commented in an interview. “It’s not like you have a lot of searching to do. There’s the email box and there’s the emails. It seems pretty straightforward. You or I could go to our email box and do that in what, two minutes? And I’m no technical wizard.”

New Westminster charged nothing but provided just four emails for Mayor Wayne Wright.

Wright said he told his staff to provide everything to The Sun and that was simply all the emails for July. “You got everything I had,” he insisted. “Well, when you’re doing the job, what are you going to do? (The electorate) seem to be pretty happy.”

Upon further scrutiny, Jacque Killawee, the city’s records and information administrator, said that the “majority of email received during this time were personal in nature and do not fall under the scope of the Act.” Gogolek strongly disagreed with that determination.

Even more incredulously, Langley Township deputy clerk Wendy Bauer said “staff conducted a search of our email server” and identified only two emails sent or received by Mayor Jack Froese during that period and that the third parties are being asked if they object to disclosure.

Pitt Meadows also provided only two emails for Mayor Deb Walters, noting information had been exempted due to third-party privacy reasons.

Other municipalities are still in the process of responding to The Sun’s request sent Aug. 25.

The Sun posed two other requests to all 21 municipalities to judge the speed and openness of their responses: copies of the mayors’ travel receipts for January-June 2014, and a list of the five largest cellphone bills incurred by municipal staff plus the mayor in 2013.

Municipalities had little trouble complying with those requests, with some, such as Vancouver, already posting elected officials’ general expenses online.

Only North Vancouver district failed to fully comply with the two requests, demanding a fee of $424.16 to provide the cellphone costs — more even than the fee estimate for Mayor Richard Walton’s email for July.

To which Gogolek offered: “Did you tell him you just wanted the bill and that you didn’t want to buy the phones?”

The district’s manager of municipal services, James Gordon, explained that “many district staff pay a monthly fee to use their cellphone for personal use as well as business” and that to find the five largest bills, finance staff would have to “pull all bills (12 months’ worth) for all staff, ascertain and deduct the personal use charges and then total the bills.”

A request for Mayor Walton’s cellphone bill is ongoing.

Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson racked up the biggest cell bill in 2013 at $3,309.45 for 2013, which compares with Coquitlam Mayor Richard Stewart at $3,017 and Surrey Mayor Dianne Watts at $2,811. Langley township Mayor Jack Froese incurred a bill of just $261.

Among senior bureaucrats: Dave Semple, Richmond’s general manager of community services, $2,927; Vancouver chief of staff Michael Magee, $2,129; West Vancouver festivals and events manager Christie Rosta, $2,082; and Surrey fire chief Len Garis, $1,912.

When it came to redacting — the process of deleting sensitive passages in documents that are exempt from release under the Act — Bowen Island distinguished itself by doing the clumsiest job of all. Someone obviously went over the exempt portions by hand with a black felt pen. The job is so substandard that one can easily read the passages meant to be redacted; in some cases, only parts of the words or emails are poorly blanked out.

Software programs are available that leave blank spaces in the copy. However, some public bodies still use heavy black ink to disguise passages.

Bowen Island’s acting mayor Andrew Stone said he will raise the issue, noting the municipality has only a handful of staff and that FOI requests are “probably done off the side of someone’s desk.”

He added: “If you could read through the marker strikes, then there’s a problem.”

What may seem comical can have serious repercussions, said Gogolek, noting there can be good reasons for keeping information from the public.

“There is an issue there,” he said. “If you were asking for the names of police undercover officers and who they are working with … and if they’re just highlighted through, then there’s a real problem. That’s dangerous. You have to be professional about it.”

If you can’t view the below graphic, click here to see how your municipality responded: https://www.scribd.com/doc/245851665/How-did-your-municipality-respond

How did your municipality respond?

Would you like to participate in our civic election exit poll? The Vancouver Sun is partnering with pollster Insights West on a confidential survey of Metro Vancouver voters after they cast ballots on Saturday, Nov. 15. The Sun will use the poll results to examine which issues mattered most to voters, and how certain elections were won and lost. Please sign up here to receive an email invitation on Nov. 15 to the online poll. Then read The Vancouver Sun on Monday, Nov. 17, for the results.

With files from Chad Skelton
