column2: Surrey Six trial: Defence lawyer argues for manslaughter conviction at worst
column3:
Jonathan Bacon (left) appears in Abbotsford court in 2008 to face drug and weaons charges. He was accompanied by fellow gang member Matt Johnston. Rick Collins/PNG Files

Shell casings from suite 1505 where the Surrey Six murders took place. Handout/RCMP

Kevin LeClair, right, a close friend of Jamie Bacon, was gunned down in a targeted shooting at a Langley shopping centre in 2009. /Vancouver Sun

Accused killer Jamie Bacon has a reputation for ordering others to do jobs he doesn't want to including drug deals, assaults and murder, B.C. Supreme Court was told Friday. Handout/Vancouver Sun files

Crown lawyer Mark Levitz and his team leaving court after Day 3 of the Surrey Six trial at the Supreme Court in Vancouver on October 2, 2013. Levitz closed the prosecution's case Tuesday after 73 witnesses, 80 days of testimony and 241 exhibits filed. Mark van Manen/PNG

Cody Haevischer is one of three men going to trial for murder on Monday in the Surrey Six case. Handout/Vancouver Sun

METRO VANCOUVER — A lawyer for accused Surrey Six killer Matt Johnston said that even if he was in the apartment where six men were shot to death on Oct. 19, 2007, he should only be convicted of manslaughter.

Mike Tammen said in his closing submissions Friday that there is no evidence Johnston was part of any plan to murder rival drug trafficker Corey Lal.

"At its highest, the Crown’s case gets to establishing to the requisite standard that Matthew Johnston was part of a plan to rob or jack Corey Lal, but certainly not to kill him," Tammen said. "At most, Johnston knew of a plan afoot to commit what would clearly be a home-invasion-style robbery."

Tammen said drugs and cash were taken from the apartment where Lal, his brother Michael, associates Ryan Bartolomeo and Eddie Narong, and bystanders Chris Mohan and Ed Schellenberg were killed execution-style.

Tammen said even if Justice Catherine Wedge decides Johnston was inside suite 1505 with co-accused Cody Haevischer and a man dubbed Person X, there’s "a very obvious reasonable doubt that he possessed knowledge that one of the others was going to commit murder."

"If the court finds that Johnston was present in 1505 at the time of the killings . . . then the appropriate result is that he should be convicted on counts one through six on manslaughter," Tammen said.

He said even Johnston’s own admissions on a wiretap suggest he didn’t know the whole story about what happened and may not have been inside the suite when the shooting started.

Johnston was taped saying to another Red Scorpion who was working for police that "I wasn’t inside, man."

At another point, Johnston says that just one of the murder weapons was left in the apartment, when in fact both guns were found there.

"That’s powerful evidence that Johnston wasn’t in the apartment when the shootings occurred. He had left," Tammen said.

After Tammen concluded his final arguments, Crown prosecutor Mark Levitz countered the defence submissions made over four and a half days this week.

Levitz rejected a suggestion by Haevischer’s lawyer that key Crown witnesses lied when they claimed final details of the murder plot were still being worked out two hours before it happened.

Levitz said the defence argued that it made no sense that experienced gangsters would "be in such disarray."

"Essentially what’s pointed out here is that the plot was engineered by a group of complete incompetents, or the witnesses are not telling the truth," Levitz said.

"In my respectful submission, the proof is in the pudding. Based on all the evidence, they went to kill one person and ended up killing six."

The Crown is expected to finish its submissions Monday, marking the end of the trial.

kbolan@vancouversun.com

read my blog: vancouversun.com/therealscoop

follow me: twitter.com/kbolan

column2: Pete McMartin: The terrible and miraculous war of Tadek and Barbara Pinkowski
column3:
I received an email recently from Liz Cochran of Vancouver about her parents, Tadek and Barbara Pinkowski. The email, three thousand words in length, was about their experiences during the Second World War. While Remembrance Day has come and gone, their intertwined stories were at once so terrible and so miraculous I thought they deserved repeating here.

Their story began in Poland.

“My father, Tadek, about to start college, was acutely aware of the rumblings of war. As a 19-year-old youth, he was part of an aircraft observation group in the small town of Olkusz.

“In Warsaw, my future mother Barbara … was hearing news of Polish troops on horseback, fighting first the Germans and then the Russians. These distant rumours became horribly real when she returned from a country holiday to behold her beautiful city of Warsaw in ruins.”

Poland fell to the invading German and Russian armies. Barbara, only 15, joined the Polish underground army, distributing newsletters created from secret radio broadcasts.

Tadek and his father left home to join up with what was left of the Polish defence forces. The nights were turning cold: they slept in barns. On Sept. 24, their unit was fired on. They returned fire, but then — “a white flag appeared and a voice proclaimed that ‘the Soviet Red Army was coming as a friend!’ ”

It was a trap. The Soviets took the Poles prisoner, then shot every fifth man, including Tadek’s father. “Sobbing, my father, tried desperately to staunch the blood while a priest moved him aside to administer last rites.”

The Soviets pressed Tadek and the remaining prisoners into slave labour hauling garbage, but Tadek escaped by mingling with locals scavenging for old clothes. Later, he would find out most of his fellow prisoners had been shot.

Back in Warsaw, Barbara watched the war decimate her family and home — an uncle in a prisoner of war camp, two young cousins tortured and shot by the Nazis. Her grandmother had been feeding a Jewish family — “they appeared one day with yellow stars on their sleeves, a grim foreshadowing.” The horrors of the Warsaw ghetto were just beginning: she heard stories of mass suicides, of “women jumping from roofs with babies in their arms.” Barbara took a first aid course and was sworn in as a soldier in the Home Army.

Meanwhile, Tadek tried to make his way back home. He was captured by the Germans this time, but escaped again and joined the Polish underground. But in January 1940 he was captured by the Soviets again, beaten, and sent to a gulag in Naryan Mar, on the Russian coast of the Arctic Ocean. “Prisoners were dying by the dozen of pellagra yet my father survived, his diet augmented by seeds of wild rose and rowan berries.”

Tadek befriended a young Polish doctor imprisoned in the camp and they formed an impromptu medical team, once helping deliver the baby of the camp commander’s wife. They were paid in vodka, “which came in very useful as an anesthetic when they later operated on a prisoner with appendicitis.” Others were not so lucky. Pellagra took its toll. “My father vividly remembers these young boys, so terrified, looking up at him as they died in his arms.”

When the Nazis invaded Russia in 1941, the Polish prisoners, now allowed to fight against the Germans, were freed and sent to southern Russia for military training. They arrived to a macabre sight — “box cars filled with frozen German soldiers, their bodies tightly pressed in a vertical position.”

After military training in Russia, he made his way through Iran, Iraq and Pakistan, then shipped out to England on the Empress of Canada, an ocean liner doing duty as a troop ship. En route, on March 13, 1943, it was torpedoed and sunk off the coast of Africa. Tadek spent three days in a crowded life raft before being rescued by a British ship. Finally, reaching England, he joined the Royal Air Force’s 315 Polish Fighter Squadron and began flying sorties over Germany.

On Aug. 1, 1944, Warsaw rose up against the German occupiers. It was a disaster: The promised help from Soviet forces never came. Barbara was 18, the leader of a patrol of field nurses. “The trips back and forth with the wounded were nightmarish, pulling heavy stretchers through narrow alleys, often not knowing if their human cargo was unconscious or dead.”

Warsaw held out for two months. Barbara was arrested and sent to a concentration camp for women in northern Germany. There, she contracted scarlet fever but survived. On April 12, 1945, the camp was liberated by a Polish armoured division. Offered the chance to go to England if she joined the Air Force, she enlisted and shipped out.

“And here,” Liz wrote, “fate took a hand.”

Tadek, on leave, was asked by a friend in his squadron to stop and see five friends of his sister who had recently been released from a German concentration camp and relocated to England. Barbara was one of the five. Tadek spent the rest of his leave with her. They married in 1946.

When Tadek was offered a job with a Canadian company, they emigrated and settled in Quebec. Their marriage lasted 62 years. Tadek died in 2008.

Barbara now lives in a care home in Quebec.

She celebrated her 90th birthday Tuesday, on Nov. 11.

pmcmartin@vancouversun.com

column2: Vancouver indulgence: Fairmont Pacific Rim's Presidential Suite
column3:
The Fairmont Pacific Rim's Presidential Suite, the Best Hotel Suite in all of Vancouver is located on the 22nd floor of the downtown luxury hotel. The 2,230 sq.-ft, one-bedroom suite features stunning panoramic views of Coal Harbour and Stanley Park to the west, the North Shore mountains to the north and Burrard Inlet and the Ironworkers Bridge to the east. Fairmont Pacific Rim/Fairmont Hotels

The tub in the Presidential Suite at the Fairmont Pacific Rim Hotel in Vancouver. Fairmont Pacific Rim/Fairmont Hotels

The tub in the Presidential Suite at the Fairmont Pacific Rim Hotel in Vancouver. Fairmont Pacific Rim/Fairmont Hotels

The Best (fill in noun here) is always a tricky proposition, as claims of superiority always smack of subjectivity.

Be it ice cream. sportscars, watches or films, personal tastes and preferences dictate what constitutes the best in each of our minds.

That said, on some topics there is little wiggle room when ascribing the bold adjective ‘Best.’ Which brings us to today’s topic, the Fairmont Pacific Rim‘s Presidential Suite, the Best Hotel Suite in all of Vancouver.

Located on the 22nd floor of the downtown luxury hotel, the 2,230 sq.-ft, one-bedroom suite features stunning panoramic views of Coal Harbour and Stanley Park to the west, the North Shore mountains to the north and Burrard Inlet and the Ironworkers Bridge to the east. The grass-roofed Vancouver Convention Centre is below, and a high-powered telescope in the living-room provides no shortage of viewing options through the floor-to-ceiling windows.

The decor is contemporary, in keeping with the other 376 guest rooms in the Pacific Rim, and like those other rooms is tastefully modern with a high level of rich finish.

Spacious is a word that comes to mind when you enter the suite, with the large living room furnished with low-slung couches and chairs and a large glass coffee table. The book shelves surrounding the large flat screen TV are filled with hardcover books, and various sculptures and painting add to the room’s special ambience.

In one corner of the living room is a desk with a commanding view of the North Shore mountains.

Beside the living room is a large dining room with a beautiful table that seats 10, and just off this room is the Butler’s Pantry, a very modern kitchen with a wellstocked fridge and wine cellar, an oven, and dishes and cutlery.

Don’t worry though, you won’t have to cook if you don’t want to. There is a separate entrance into the Butler’s Pantry that provides Fairmont chefs and serving staff access to prepare and serve catered meals.

Past the dining room is the large bedroom, featuring a king-sized bed with those famed Fairmont pillows and duvets. Again, views are provided through floor-to-ceiling windows, which also allow natural light to fill the room. A massive walk-in closet provides all the room you’ll need for luggage and clothes to be out of sight.

Then there’s the bathroom. Make that two bathrooms, as the bedroom’s ensuite has two full oversized marble spa matching bathrooms, a him and a her proposition if you like. They are identical in layout except one has a deep, jetted soaker tub with incredible views; the other a large marble shower with huge rainfall shower head.

A separate bathroom off the dining room means guests won’t be traipsing through your bedroom, though you’d be remiss in not giving complete tours to all who enter the suite. The dual marble bathrooms are simply incredible.

Rounding out the suites features are a large private outdoor patio with table for four – ideal for breakfast – and a double sofa bed. And if that’s not enough room for your entourage, two connecting guest rooms can be accessed, bringing the total square-footage to 3,200.

Guest of this suite also receive Fairmont Gold services, which include private check-in, concierge and butler services and access to the Gold lounge on the 20th floor, itself a stylish space with stunning views of downtown, Stanley Park and the mountains. Daily breakfast

in the lounge is complimentary, as are evening canapes.

It doesn’t hurt that the suite is in, arguably, the best luxury hotel in Vancouver, a West Coast city bursting at the seams with high-end accommodation.

At $7,500 a night, the only downside of the Presidential Suite is that you’d be reluctant to not spend every minute of your stay in the room, though catching some live music in the lobby lounge and going for a swim in the palm tree-lined heated outdoor pool might coax you out for a little while at least.

What’s most amazing perhaps is that the Presidential Suite is not the most expensive suite in the Pacific Rim. That honour goes to the Owner’s Suite, a 2,250 sq.-ft two-storey salon inspired by a Balinese villa. Features in the so-called ‘Rock Star Suite’ include an eight-foot Swarovski crystal chandelier, a hand-carved soaker tub and a private gazebo with meditation pond and fire pit.

Rock Star is a fitting moniker for the Owner’s Suite, as its location overlooking the pool and just a few floors off Cordova Street appeals to the extrovert who craves being seen living the lush life. It truly is like staying in a goldfish bowl, figuratively and literally.

So why isn’t it the ‘Best,’ you ask? "They’re so different," says Pacific Rim public relations manager Kaylyn Storey. "The Presidential Suite is up on the 22nd floor and gets all the views that the hotel offers. That’s what makes that suite – it’s all about the view."

Storey says the average length of stay in the Presidential Suite is two days, "and it is booked more often than not."

Put it on your bucket list — and pack your camera.

amccredie@vancouversun.com

column2: Deadline for SVA entries looms larger
column3:
The clock says 2:18 a.m.

The blue light from the screen makes the eyes look gaunt.

The candy wrappers litter the chair in a perfect circle.

Coffee cups are stacked like pyramids.

These are the signs of a looming deadline.

Students from across the province are locked in mortal combat with time itself as the minutes and hours tick away forcing them ever closer to the deadline.

That deadline is 11:59:59 p.m. next Thursday, April 17, before student hit the final “return” thus completing their entry into the Vancouver Sun/CBC student video awards.

This is a dance with time students have done over the last two years, submitting some amazing pieces of work that they have laboured over during the last few months.

There are thousands of dollars in prizes by Vancouver Film School up for grabs.

Glory awaits those who have stayed true to their vision.

Everything you need to know about the contest can be found here: vancouversun.com/studentvideos.

But be quick. Time is running out.

column2: Surrey Six: Innocuous start to day that ended in slaughter (with video)
column3:
METRO VANCOUVER — That terrible day seven years ago began when Eileen Mohan received a call from her office at 7 a.m. saying she was needed at work.

She had planned to take Friday, Oct. 19, 2007 off so she could be home when a gas fitter came to service the fireplace in the penthouse apartment she shared with her husband Sunil and son Christopher, 22.

They had lived on the top floor of Surrey’s Balmoral Tower for less than a month, having moved from a 14th-floor unit they rented before it was sold.

She woke her son up to tell him that plans had changed and she would need him to stay home and wait for the person servicing the fireplace.

“We sat down at the dining table and had breakfast together. Eggs and toast, and he made pancakes for himself. That was his favourite. We spoke. Honestly, I didn’t know that would be my last time speaking to my son,” Mohan recalled.

“We hugged and kissed goodbye, and I walked out of the house not knowing that that day would turn out to be such a disastrous day.”

===

VIEW MORE PHOTOS HERE, or if you’re using a mobile device, tap the story image and swipe.

===

B.C. Supreme Court Justice Catherine Wedge will hand down her verdict Thursday in the trial of accused Surrey Six killers Matt Johnston and Cody Haevischer.

Each is charged with conspiracy to commit murder and first-degree murder in the deaths of drug dealers Corey and Michael Lal, Eddie Narong and Ryan Bartolomeo, as well as bystanders Ed Schellenberg and Chris Mohan.

Jamie Bacon will be tried on murder and conspiracy charges in a separate trial.

According to Crown evidence at the Surrey Six trial, suite 1505 across the hall from the Mohans’ was a stash house for Corey Lal and Eddie Narong.

The 22-year-old high school pals had been successful on the streets of Surrey and beyond, selling cocaine and heroin through their dial-a-dope lines.

Neither lived in the penthouse apartment, but they cooked crack, stored drugs and cash, and met there with others involved in the street-level drug trade.

Mohan still laments that she had no idea what was going on next door.

“I literally did not know that my neighbours were drug dealers. Had I known, I would have moved my family in a heartbeat. But no one told us what was happening on the 15th floor.”

Corey Lal obviously had no idea what would happen that fateful day, either.

He had been warned by his Red Scorpion gang rivals that he was selling drugs on their turf. He had even been roughed up by the other gangsters at a meeting inside a Surrey McDonald’s a few weeks before. One Scorpion had taken Lal’s 9-mm Glock handgun. Lal had been ordered to pay a $100,000 “tax” for operating in their territory, or else.

Lal didn’t pay.

About 9:15 that morning, Red Scorpion Jamie Bacon and a man who can only be called Person Y due to a publication ban arrived at a Port Coquitlam gym as undercover police officers watched.

Y later testified that Johnston arrived a bit later at the World Gym, along with Person X, another Red Scorpion whose identity is shielded by court order.

Y said the final details of a nefarious plan to kill Corey Lal were discussed inside the gym before he and Bacon left at 9:54, again captured by police surveillance.

Over the next three hours, there was a flurry of calls between Red Scorpion gangsters and their associates.

In the early afternoon, Johnston joined other Red Scorpions at the Seoul House Korean restaurant on 104th Avenue in Surrey.

He had already picked up an electronic key fob that would give the killers access to the Balmoral Tower where Lal lived, the trial heard.

At the restaurant, Johnston met Red Scorpion founder Michael Le, both Person X and Y, and some friends of Le’s who were triad members.

Person X was given the Glock seized from Lal weeks before.

The gangsters left the restaurant separately. Le went to lease a new Maserati at Blue Star Motors in Vancouver.

Johnston and X headed over to the nearby Stanley apartment building, where Cody Haevischer lived on the 16th floor with his girlfriend.

Police doing an unrelated drug investigation captured them on video going into the building about 1:50 p.m.

The trial heard Johnston and X cleaned their guns with Windex and paper towels as Haevischer changed and popped in and out of the living room. All three men headed down to the parkade at 2:08 p.m. and left in a black BMW.

The Crown said an identical BMW arrived in the parkade of the Balmoral, less than three kilometres from the Stanley, just before 2:23 p.m.

The driver nearly ran over Helen Lee and her three-year-old son. Helen had been at her Bible study group inside the highrise.

Lee testified that she saw three men get out of the car and make their way to a gate leading to an elevator into the Balmoral.

“They covered their faces with their hoods and … had leather gloves on,” she said.

The key fob alleged to have been passed to Johnston earlier that day was used to enter the building gate at 2:23 p.m.

Inside suite 1505 were Corey Lal, his older brother Michael, and friend Ryan Bartolomeo. Michael and Ryan had been cooking crack in the kitchen while Corey did some paperwork at a glass desk in the living room.

Gas fitter Ed Schellenberg arrived to service the fireplace in the neighbouring suite. It was supposed to be his last apartment of the day.

Phone records show that Corey Lal called a friend at 2:27 p.m.

The call was cut off, as Lal was heard saying: “Oh f–k, the door. He sounded really worried when he said it,” the friend later told police.

That was when the killers arrived, prosecutors said.

Chris Mohan’s bad luck was his timing. He left for a basketball game as one of the gangsters was checking the hallway. He was dragged into suite 1505. Eddie Narong also arrived to the unfolding nightmare.

As the apartment was ransacked for cash and drugs, the six victims were forced to the floor with hoodies or jackets thrown over their heads.

Eddie Narong lay beside Ed Schellenberg, almost perfectly parallel, and Corey Lal was to Eddie’s right.

On the other side of a leather loveseat, closest to the door, was Chris Mohan. To his left was Michael Lal and on the other side of Lal was Ryan Bartolomeo.

They were confined like that for several minutes, the trial heard. And then each was shot in the head and back, execution-style.

Nineteen shots were fired — 17 of them hit the victims. The two murder weapons — the Glock and an Ultrastar handgun — were left inside the suite. Their magazines had been emptied.

Police were later told the victims had begged for their lives.

“They saw our faces. We had no choice,” Johnston was said to have told his gang leader afterwards.

Three men in hoodies were seen leaving the Balmoral parkade in the black BMW at about 2:45 p.m. by another woman in the Bible study group.

Police still staked out at the Stanley saw the BMW linked to Haevischer arriving there just before 3 p.m. The men in hoodies were again captured on video.

Police were soon on the scene of the biggest gangland massacre in B.C. history.

And the Mohans and Schellenbergs, as well as three other Lower Mainland families, were soon to get the most devastating news of their lives.

===

column2: Federal environmental screening lacks clarity, clear rules: study
column3:
OTTAWA — The Harper government isn’t providing adequate information to the public or industry on how it determines what major projects get an environmental review.

That conclusion is in a report by federal Environment Commissioner Julie Gelfand, who looked at how the government has handled project screenings since sweeping 2012 legislation changed the way projects are assessed.

Since that period, 37 projects have been subjected to federal assessment by federal agencies, including 17 in B.C.

That’s a far cry from the more than 4,000 that were assessed in 2010 before Ottawa, as Green party leader Elizabeth May put it, took a sledgehammer to the environmental review process.

The federal government now focuses only on reviewing major projects. The 37 proposals that faced federal scrutiny since 2012 include Kinder Morgan’s Alberta-B.C. oilsands pipeline expansion, the Point Roberts Terminal 2 project, and a number of liquefied natural gas and mining projects across B.C.

Gelfand said the Canadian Environmental Assessment Agency has been “unclear” in its rationale for deciding which projects get screened, and details of its decision-making process aren’t made public.

“As the intent of the new legislation is to focus on projects that have the greatest potential for significant adverse environmental effects, it is important for the agency to have a clear, transparent basis for identifying those projects,” she wrote.

Among other criticisms in the report, which was tabled in the House of Commons on Tuesday:

• The report also said the agency and the National Energy Board, another federal body that conducts environmental reviews, have inconsistent rules on who can participate. The Environmental Assessment Agency “must hear” from those with “relevant information or expertise,” while the NEB “may hear” from potential witnesses who could be considered experts or have important information to share.

• The federal government doesn’t explain how it determines what weight it gives to public input at hearings.

• The 2012 reforms says the government must consider “adverse environmental effects,” yet Ottawa doesn’t define adverse.

• Despite a 2012 commitment to engage with First Nations, the Environmental Assessment Agency hasn’t put together a “systematic” approach to Aboriginal engagement. That criticism echoes a government-commissioned report by Vancouver lawyer Doug Eyford which said Ottawa hasn’t adequately met its court-mandated obligation to consult and accommodate First Nations on pipeline projects.

• The new 2012 legislative changes never provided federal review panels with guidance on how to define whether a potential intervener met the test of whether they were an “interested party.” As a result, the panel set up to assess the proposed New Prosperity gold-copper mine in B.C. came up with its own rules in a process that ultimately led to Ottawa rejecting the mine.

The Environmental Assessment Agency and the NEB both agreed with most of Gelfand’s criticisms and vowed to be more transparent, but the Green party’s May questioned that pledge given the Harper government’s reputation for secrecy.

“Stephen Harper is the least transparent prime minister in recent history,” she told The Vancouver Sun.

poneil@postmedia.com

Twitter.com/poneilinottawa

column2: Judge rules against staying Surrey Six charges over police misconduct allegations
column3:
A B.C. Supreme Court judge dismissed an application by Surrey Six killers Cody Haevischer and Matthew Johnston to stay their murder charges, but agreed their rights were violated by "egregious" police misconduct and prison conditions that were "harsh in the extreme."

Justice Catherine Wedge agreed with defence lawyers that the state misconduct in the case was "serious, prolonged and systemic." But she disagreed that it warranted staying all charges.

She said society’s greater interest is seeing the gang killers held to account for the "horrific" slaying of six men in a Surrey highrise on Oct. 19, 2007.

"The circumstances of the offences could not be more shocking. The murders were execution-style killings, carried out with deliberation while the six victims were defenceless," Wedge said.

"In light of the number of victims and the motivation underlying the murders, society’s interest in seeing justice done on the merits of this case is profound. Society’s interest weighs all the more heavily in the context of this case because the carnage was the result of gang members fighting for turf in the illicit drug trade."

Despite the Charter violations in the case, Wedge said: "I am satisfied that the price of staying these convictions could not be worth the gain to our justice system."

Both Haevischer and Johnston appeared at the Vancouver Law Courts via video monitor. A date for their sentencing will be fixed Thursday.

Wedge found both men guilty of six counts of first-degree murder on Oct. 2 for the murders of rival drug dealer Corey Lal, his brother Michael, associates Eddie Narong and Ryan Bartolomeo, as well as bystanders Chris Mohan and Ed Schellenberg.

She also found both Red Scorpion gangsters guilty of conspiracy to commit murder for plotting the hit on Corey Lal that spiralled into the deaths of six.

Neither man had been sentenced in the mass murder, pending the outcome of their application to stay the charges.

Mohan’s mother Eileen said she was relieved at Wednesday’s ruling and looking forward to sentencing.

"That kind of puts a lot of pressure off my shoulders and helps me to re-collect my thoughts and prepare myself for sentencing," she said. "I sat in court for almost 120 days now. And these convicted criminals can sit down and listen to me for half an hour. It’s my time to represent my son who’s not with me now."

Mohan said while Wedge found there was police misconduct and abuses of the killers’ rights, "my son’s life was way more precious than the mistreatment of these two criminals in prison."

"At some point, we have to come to a conclusion that if you are a criminal and you’ve led a criminal lifestyle, your rights do not supersede our rights," she added.

Crown prosecutor Mark Levitz earlier urged Wedge to dismiss the application, saying it would amount to the "stay of the century" if charges were dropped against two multiple murderers.

Defence lawyers Dagmar Dlab and Brock Martland had argued that the four RCMP officers now facing criminal charges behaved outrageously when they had sex parties and went to strip clubs with potential witnesses in the case.

And they argued that both their clients spent more than a year in segregation after their arrest, on the orders of police and in violation of their Charter rights.

Wedge said she accepted the allegations against the police as true for the purpose of the application. All four officers go to trial next September.

"The misconduct of the officers was unquestionably egregious. They engaged in exploitative sexual relationships with protected female witnesses, endangered their safety by revealing protected information about them to others, lied to their superiors, and manipulated overtime and expense claims to cover up their conduct," Wedge said. "The misconduct of these officers as alleged could constitute an abuse of process and conduct offensive to fair play and decency."

She noted that the RCMP dealt with the allegations when it learned of them, resulting in the charges being laid. None of the officers, nor the women involved, testified at the Surrey Six trial, she said.

Wedge accepted that both Haevischer and Johnston "suffered physically, emotionally and psychologically" during 14 months of segregation.

But the restrictions eased in June 2010 after a B.C. Supreme Court ruling condemned the jailers of their co-accused, Jamie Bacon, for holding him in similar conditions.

Wedge said that despite the Charter violations, a stay of proceedings would not serve society.

"The applicants chose to go to the Balmoral Tower, an apartment building which is home to hundreds of residents, and to settle their score with Mr. Lal on the doorstep of those residents. They were apparently undeterred by the prospect of imperilling anyone caught in the crossfire. The result was the murder of six persons," Wedge said.

"The surviving victims of these crimes are the families of the six men who were executed, and their interest in seeing convictions entered for these crimes is equally profound."

column2: Rick Hansen points to others as he’s named one of our Top-5 heroes
column3:
Rick Hansen in China during his world tour 25 years ago. Hansen was named one of British Columbia’s Top-5 heroes in poll results released this week. Handout. Denise Chong/PNG

Rick Hansen (left) during his world tour 25 years ago. Hansen was named one of British Columbia’s Top-5 heroes in poll results released this week. Handout. /Vancouver Sun

Rick Hansen, who inspired millions of people — and raised millions of dollars — with his Man in Motion tour was cited by British Columbians this week as one of their top-five heroes.

Hansen, who seemed surprised and delighted when he heard about the poll results, was quick to say no hero stands alone.

“I’m honoured that my name would stand among people that have made a difference. The work that I do is a reflection of hundreds and thousands of people that share my dream.”

He said his wheelchair journey around the globe would not have been possible without the dedicated team that travelled with him, encouraging him not to give up.

“It wasn’t the monumental earth-shattering cumulative impact of the journey, it was every moment along the way.”

The gruelling venture to raise funds and awareness took two years to complete, during which he often travelled a distance equivalent to two marathons in a day.

What kept Hansen going through the endless hours, the sleep deprivation and physical exhaustion, the robberies, the days and months when it seemed nobody was on board, the two years of slogging through ice, heat and storms?

“My team. That’s what kept me going. If I didn’t have my team with me — my wife Amanda, Don Alder, who was in the truck with me when we had the accident (that left Hansen a paraplegic at the age of 15), to support me, and when it looked like we wouldn’t have enough support, we had a home team that would be responding to help keep us going. That to me filled me with a sense of gratitude and inspiration.”

Hansen finds a parallel spirit in the character of British Columbians. “We need to help each other and that’s what we do. People have come to B.C. and have carved a life for themselves and made great sacrifices and taken great risks. We built our province together.”

Hansen knows the province well.

Although he was born in Port Alberni, his father worked for BC TEL, so the family travelled and lived in various B.C. communities including Fort St. John, Williams Lake and Abbotsford. He isn’t afraid to say he falls into the B.C.-first camp. “I’m a proud Canadian but I’m definitely born and raised in B.C. and proud of it. Because I’ve moved I’ve really seen a large part of the province as a resident and I’ve travelled almost every part along the way.”

Hansen is proud of how British Columbians have embraced inclusion. “I’ve talked to people from around the world who have come from around B.C. and across Canada and they see it as a progressive and accessible province.”

Hansen has heroes too. The first on his list is Stanley Strong who organized and played on Vancouver’s first wheelchair basketball team in 1950 after a car accident left him paralyzed.

Strong had been an athlete before his 1940 accident, and spent his life encouraging others. “He’s one of those obscure, great Canadians, a British Columbian who helped form the Paraplegic Association and wheelchair sports, a peer counsellor. He was injured in the early days when people with spinal cord injuries often wouldn’t survive. He refused to yield, kept a positive attitude and ended up not just living a good life but a great life, and helped young kids like me not give up.”

Strong was team manager of the Vancouver Cable Cars, the wheelchair basketball team Hansen led to five national championships. “He inspired me to recruit Terry Fox when he lost his leg to cancer,” said Hansen. “I just think of him as an incredible unsung hero.”

Hansen says his other hero, “great friend and inspiration” is Terry Fox. “I think the world of Terry, who he was as a human being, what he did to make a difference, what he sacrificed for others, what his legacy continues to be. He stands for facing your challenges, making a difference and serving others. We all have challenges in our life and we all have to face up to them and persevere and we all look for hope and inspiration in our lives if we want to make the best of our time here. Terry really does reflect British Columbian and Canadian values.

“If ever there was a person to reflect what B.C. stands for I couldn’t think two better people than these to stand for our values, one who is high profile and one who is obscure, and it also represents that you don’t have to be famous to make a difference.”Somehow it’s no surprise that when asked what single word he would use to describe B.C., Hansen answered quickly. “Hope.”

dryan@vancouversun.com

column2: Surrey Six: a timeline
column3:
Early Oct., 2007: Drug trafficker Corey Lal is roughed up by rivals from the Red Scorpion gang and told to pay them $100,000 in “tax” for selling cocaine and other drugs in their territory.

Oct. 18, 2007: Corey Lal, Eddie Narong and other associates forcibly take over a Surrey drug line run by Lal’s former partner Stephen Leone.

Oct. 19, 2007: Eddie Narong, Corey Lal, his brother Michael Lal, associate Ryan Bartolomeo and bystanders Ed Schellenberg and Chris Mohan are shot to death, execution-style, inside suite 1505 of Surrey’s Balmoral Tower.

Oct. 22, 2007: Police seized a BMW linked to accused Surrey Six killer Cody Haevischer at a Burnaby car detailing business where it had been dropped off.

Oct. 23, 2007: Homicide investigators search suite 1601 of the Stanley Apartments, 10082 148th Street in Surrey, where Cody Haevischer had been living with his girlfriend before the Surrey Six murders.

March 12, 2008: The Integrated Homicide Investigation Team ask for the public’s help in identifying a man with “significant” information about the murders and say police would protect the man from the killers.

May 31, 2008: The Vancouver Sun reveals for the first time that the Surrey Six suspects are linked to the Red Scorpion gang.

May 31, 2008: Police issue a public warning that anyone associating with the Red Scorpion Bacon brothers could be in danger because they have been targeted by rivals. Jamie and Jarrod Bacon are arrested on firearms charges.

Dec. 31, 2008: A Red Scorpion who can only be identified as Person X due to a publication ban suffers minor injuries in an attempt on his life in Abbotsford.

Jan. 20, 2009: Jamie Bacon is shot at as he drives his car through a busy Abbotsford intersection in the middle of the day. He is uninjured, but police later say the United Nations gang was hunting him at the time.

Feb. 2, 2009: Abbotsford Police hold an emergency public meeting about the gang war between the Red Scorpions and the United Nations gang, which had terrorized local residents.

Feb. 3, 2009: Raphael Baldini, a close friend of Corey Lal’s who once rented suite 1505 in the Balmoral Tower, is gunned down in the parking lot of a Surrey mall.

April 3, 2009: Person X enters a surprise guilty plea to second-degree murder charges for shooting to death Chris Mohan, Michael Lal and Ryan Bartolomeo in Surrey’s Balmoral Tower 18 months earlier.

April 3, 2009: Red Scorpions Cody Haevischer, Matt Johnston and Jamie Bacon are charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy in the Surrey Six slayings.

June 17, 2009: Red Scorpion gang founder Michael Le is arrested in the Philippines and deported to Canada, where he is charged with murder and conspiracy in the Surrey Six slayings.

Nov. 23, 2009: Sophon Sek is charged with manslaughter for allegedly helping the Surrey Six killers get access to the Balmoral Tower suite.

April 13, 2010: A Red Scorpion who can only be identified as Person Y pleads guilty to two unrelated murders and reveals he will be a Crown witness in the Surrey Six case.

Aug. 2, 2012: The Crown announces that Jamie Bacon will get a separate Surrey Six trial from his co-accused Cody Haevischer, Matt Johnston and Michael Le.

Sept. 30, 2013: The Surrey Six trial begins for Haevischer, Johnston and Le under tight security at the Vancouver Law Courts.

Nov. 28, 2013: Red Scorpion founder Michael Le enters a surprise mid-trial guilty plea to conspiracy to commit murder and agrees to testify against his former co-accused. The Crown drops the murder charge against him.

Dec. 2, 2013: Cody Haevischer’s former girlfriend, known as KM, begins her dramatic testimony implicating the accused killer in the Surrey Six murders.

March 10, 2014: Key Crown witness Person Y takes the stand and describes his life as a gangster and killer. He later implicates Matt Johnston in the Surrey Six murders.

April 8, 2014: Red Scorpion founder Michael Le begins his sensational testimony at the trial, saying both Cody Haevischer and Matt Johnston confessed to having roles in the murders.

May 20, 2014: Lead prosecutor Mark Levitz closes the Crown’s case after 73 witnesses and 80 days of testimony.

June 9, 2014: Defence lawyers Simon Buck, for Haevischer, and Michael Tammen, for Johnston, tell Judge Catherine Wedge they will not be calling witnesses on behalf of their clients.

July 2, 2014: Crown Mark Levitz begins the prosecution’s closing arguments in the murder trial.

July 7, 2014: Cody Haevischer’s defence team begins its closing arguments, calling the Crown’s evidence in the case “woefully inadequate.”

July 10, 2014: Matt Johnston’s lawyers begin their closing arguments, saying the only witnesses testifying about the murder plot are admitted violent gangsters and should not be believed.

July 14, 2014: B.C. Supreme Court Judge Catherine Wedge announces she will give her verdict in the Surrey Six case on Oct. 2, 2014.

Kim Bolan, Vancouver Sun

kbolan@vancouversun.com

column2: Surrey Six: Reform needed on mega-trials, former B.C. attorney general says (with video)
column3:
Former attorney general Wally Oppal says B.C.’s judicial system needs to be reformed to better manage major prosecutions so that they don’t take years to get to trial.

Oppal believes the public loses confidence in the system when people accused of crimes await trial for several years — particularly in so-called mega-trials like the Surrey Six murder case.

“When it takes so long to get disclosure, to bring people to trial and to eventually reach verdicts, it impacts on the credibility of the system,” Oppal told The Vancouver Sun in an interview.

“Our system needs to be reformed, particularly when it comes to timing. Should there be time limits from the time someone is charged to the time that that person goes to trial? Should there be time limits on cross-examination? Should there be time limits on arguments? These are matters that we have to look at. We go on endlessly in our trials.”

Oppal was B.C. attorney general when accused Surrey Six killers Cody Haevischer and Matthew Johnston were charged in April 2009 with the slaughter of drug dealers Eddie Narong, Ryan Bartolomeo, Corey Lal, his brother Michael and bystanders Ed Schellenberg and Chris Mohan, on Oct. 19, 2007.

Haevischer and Johnston will learn their fate today when B.C. Supreme Court Justice Catherine Wedge hands down her verdict in the historic gangland murder case. Both face six counts each of first-degree murder and one of conspiracy to kill.

If convicted on any of the murder counts, they would face an automatic life sentence with no possibility of parole for 25 years.

Haevischer and Johnston were suspected in the killings within days, according to evidence at their trial. But it took 18 months before charges were laid against them.

Also charged at the time was their purported Red Scorpion gang leader Jamie Bacon, who is going to trial next May — more than six years after his arrest. He faces one count of first-degree murder and one of conspiracy to commit murder in the death of Corey Lal.

Another gangster charged with manslaughter in the Surrey Six case doesn’t even have a trial date set yet, according to Neil MacKenzie of the B.C. attorney general’s criminal justice branch. Sophon Sek remains on bail, with a next appearance in Surrey provincial court set for Dec. 2, MacKenzie said.

The Surrey Six trial began under tight security at Vancouver Law Courts on Sept. 30, 2013 and ended in mid-July with closing arguments.

It was dramatic from the start, as lead prosecutor Mark Levitz laid out the Crown’s theory that Corey Lal, a 22-year-old drug dealer, was marked for death after he failed to pay a $100,000 tax to the Red Scorpion gang.

Levitz told Wedge that all the other victims were killed so there would be no witnesses.

The first to take the stand was retired Balmoral manager Norman Carothers. He wept as he described the horror of finding six bodies in suite 1505, where he had gone to search for Schellenberg, a gas fitter servicing the building’s fireplaces that day.

“Everybody is on the floor. There is blood. I don’t know what happened to them,” Carothers said, describing a frantic walkie-talkie conversation he had with his wife that day.

Gruesome police photos and videos of the six bodies lying in pools of their own blood inside suite 1505 were shown on television screens inside the courtroom.

Veteran police officers testified it was one of the worst crime scenes they had ever attended.

Several of the Crown’s 73 witnesses were former gangsters, drug dealers or their associates, which defence lawyers said destroyed the credibility of their evidence.

Two of those witnesses — Red Scorpion gang founder Michael Le and a gangster who can only be identified as Person Y — admitted to having roles in the plot to murder Corey Lal.

Le, who had been on the indictment with Haevischer and Johnston, dropped a bombshell two months into the trial when he pleaded guilty to conspiracy and became a Crown witness. The murder charge against him was dropped.

Le testified that the Red Scorpion gang, at the behest of Jamie Bacon, had conspired to kill Corey Lal and that the plan had spiralled out of control, resulting in the deaths of all six victims.

Le also said that Johnston and Haevischer each later confessed their involvement in the murders.

Johnston said on the day of the murders that all six victims were shot because “they saw our faces. We had no choice,” Le testified.

And he said Haevischer wrote on an eraser board a few days later that “six people got killed.”

Defence lawyers portrayed Le as a lying opportunist who got a great deal from the Crown despite his own violent history.

Another former Red Scorpion, Person Y, pleaded guilty to two unrelated murders and is serving a life sentence.

He testified that he had been willing to kill Lal for Bacon, but backed out when others were directed to accompany him on the hunt.

Y said he turned to police because he was sick of “the game” and wanted to do something good after a life of crime. He wore a recording device as Johnston made cryptic comments about the slaughter.

In closing arguments, Levitz said his team of prosecutors had “proved our case beyond a reasonable doubt against both accused on all seven counts.”

Defence lawyers said the Crown’s case was “woefully inadequate” and reliant on unsavory witnesses who should not be believed.

The Surrey Six murder investigation was one of B.C.’s largest and most complex.

RCMP Sgt. Rob Vermeulen said about 1,200 police officers and employees have worked on the case, with 35 still on the file full-time to support prosecutors.

“While the investigation began with a multiple homicide, it quickly expanded to a larger investigation of Lower Mainland gangs and organized crime. The investigation resulted in multiple charges and three convictions to date, including one subject convicted for two unrelated homicides.”

The Crown had nine lawyers and Johnston and Haevischer each had three lawyers. Le had six lawyers on his defence team before pleading guilty.

kbolan@vancouversun.com

column2: Surrey Six trial: Evidence suggests conspiracy to rob, not murder, defence lawyer says
column3:
Jonathan Bacon (left) appears in Abbotsford court in 2008 to face drug and weaons charges. He was accompanied by fellow gang member Matt Johnston. Rick Collins/PNG Files

Shell casings from suite 1505 where the Surrey Six murders took place. Handout/RCMP

Kevin LeClair, right, a close friend of Jamie Bacon, was gunned down in a targeted shooting at a Langley shopping centre in 2009. /Vancouver Sun

Abbotsford Police seized drugs, weapons and gang paraphernalia from the Aldergrove house of a Red Scorpion gangster Thursday night. Handout/Abbotsford Police Department

Accused killer Jamie Bacon has a reputation for ordering others to do jobs he doesn't want to including drug deals, assaults and murder, B.C. Supreme Court was told Friday. Handout/Vancouver Sun files

Crown lawyer Mark Levitz and his team leaving court after Day 3 of the Surrey Six trial at the Supreme Court in Vancouver on October 2, 2013. Levitz closed the prosecution's case Tuesday after 73 witnesses, 80 days of testimony and 241 exhibits filed. Mark van Manen/PNG

Cody Haevischer is one of three men going to trial for murder on Monday in the Surrey Six case. Handout/Vancouver Sun

METRO VANCOUVER — The evidence in the Surrey Six case suggests there was a conspiracy to rob target Corey Lal, but not one to murder the rival drug trafficker, a lawyer for accused killer Matt Johnston argued Thursday.

Mike Tammen said the only evidence of a murder plot came from former Red Scorpion founder Michael Le and an admitted killer dubbed Person Y.

Both Crown witnesses are untrustworthy and had a motive to lie, Tammen told B.C. Supreme Court Justice Catherine Wedge in his closing submissions.

"Each of them has a particular reason to implicate Matthew Johnston," he said.

Tammen said Le wanted to minimize his role in the murders after striking a deal with the Crown to plead guilty to the lesser charge of conspiracy.

Instead of admitting to his own central involvement, "he is plunking Matthew Johnston into the middle of this conspiracy," Tammen said.

And he said Y, who pleaded guilty to two unrelated murders and is serving a life sentence, admitted on the stand that he hated Johnston, though he never explained why.

Johnston and co-accused Cody Haevischer are charged with killing Lal, his brother Michael, associates Ryan Bartolomeo and Eddie Narong, as well as bystanders Ed Schellenberg and Chris Mohan on Oct. 19, 2007 in Surrey’s Balmoral Tower.

Both also charged with conspiracy to murder Lal on behalf of the Red Scorpion gang.

Tammen agreed with a Crown submission that the cell phones of victims were taken from suite 1505 before they were slaughtered.

"That is evidence that supports the theory that this was a robbery," he said.

Earlier Thursday, Tammen’s co-counsel Jonathan Desbarats argued that cell phone records disprove testimony from both Le and Y about meetings with Johnston both before and after the murders.

Desbarats took Wedge through records for Johnston, Le, Y and RS leader Jamie Bacon from October 2007.

Desbarats said the records show that meetings said to have taken place on Oct. 18 and Oct. 19 could not have happened as described by Le and Y.

Y testified that he met with Bacon, Johnston and a Red Scorpion member dubbed Person X outside a Surrey protein store on Oct. 18 to hammer out the details of the murder plot.

But Desbarats said the activity of the gang members cell phones on that date show that none of them were in Surrey at the same time.

He said even if you factored in the periods when they were not talking on their phones, police surveillance proved there was no opportunity for all four of them to have met in Surrey that day.

Desbarats also said cell phone records, which show the approximate location of the caller, also undermined Le’s claim that Johnston called him to a meeting at a Surrey Korean restaurant right before the murders. The records indicate that Le arrived in Surrey first.

And Desbarats said that a Burnaby meeting at which Le claimed Johnston confessed hours after the murder also would have been almost impossible given the location of the cell phones that afternoon.

Johnston’s team is continuing its closing submissions this afternoon.

kbolan@vancouversun.com

read my blog: vancouversun.com/therealscoop

column2: Or maybe not
column3:
ARTIST: Various artists

ALBUM: The Art of McCartney

(Arctic Poppy)

2½ stars out of 5

This two-disc Paul McCartney tribute is a decade-in-the-making labour of love by one man, producer Ralph Sall. So it would be churlish to throw cold water on it, right?

Sorry. Sall’s interest in chasing down marquee names, rather than marquee performances, makes this a gigantic missed opportunity.

Sall enlists McCartney’s current backup band to fill the same role on this 34-song effort (42 with the deluxe package). The result is musical consistency — consistently generic. He recruits primarily legacy artists whose best work is behind them, often decades behind. Billy Joel opens both discs with songs (Maybe I’m Amazed and Live and Let Die) that are beyond his range now. And, trust us, the world doesn’t need to hear Steve Miller sing Hey Jude or Alice Cooper do Eleanor Rigby.

To be sure, there are fun moments, like Bob Dylan croaking through Things We Said Today and Brian Wilson’s shimmering take on Wanderlust. The compositions are excellent, even if the performances don’t always rise to that level. But you knew that going in.

Bringing in some current and more diverse artists — maybe a Katy Perry or Pharrell — and letting them interpret the music freed from a band with its own preconceptions would have been infinitely more interesting. So would digging further into McCartney’s vast catalogue, including some work he’s done this century.

While musical adventurousness is risky, the rewards are greater. McCartney’s legacy deserved a more challenging environment.

column2: Prosecutor urges judge not to throw out murder charges in 'one of the biggest crimes of the century'
column3:
Prosecutor Mark Levitz called the Surrey Six slayings “one of the biggest crimes of the century” Monday as he urged a judge to dismiss a defence motion to throw out murder charges over alleged police misconduct in the case.

Levitz said the attempt by lawyers for convicted killers Cody Haevischer and Matt Johnston to get the charges against them stayed is grossly disproportionate to the misconduct alleged during the investigation.

“What my friends are asking for, essentially, is the stay of the century for one of the biggest crimes of the century, at least in this jurisdiction,” Levitz told B.C. Supreme Court Justice Catherine Wedge. “The conduct alleged is not the misconduct of the century.”

Levitz said that even if all the allegations made against police are accepted as true for the defence application, a stay of proceedings is not justified in a case where six people were executed.

Haevischer and Johnston were found guilty Oct. 2 of the 2007 murders of rival drug dealer Corey Lal, his brother Michael, associates Ryan Bartolomeo and Eddie Narong, and bystanders Chris Mohan and Ed Schellenberg.

Neither killer has been sentenced. Their lawyers are asking Wedge to order a full investigative hearing in December into the allegations of police misconduct.

Both killers have complained they were held in segregation for 14 months after their April 2009 arrest, in violation of their Charter rights.

And they say former officers on the case who allegedly had sex with potential witnesses shows “systemic” misconduct by police that warrants the stay.

Lawyers for Haevischer and Johnston said both gangsters would testify if Wedge allows a full hearing. The judge said she would rule on the defence application on Nov. 19.

Haevischer’s lawyer Dagmar Dlab said if her client is permitted to take the stand, “he would be giving details of his conditions of confinement and the impact on him — emotional, physical, all of that.”

Neither Haevischer, nor Johnston, members of the murderous Red Scorpion gang, took the stand in their own defence during the Surrey Six trial.

Dlab also told Wedge that she wants to call senior officers from the RCMP, as well as B.C. Corrections, about why the decision was made to hold Haevischer in segregation for more than a year.

And she said she wants former Mountie Dave Attew to testify about allegations of sexual misconduct that resulted in charges against him and three other Surrey Six investigators. Those officers are due to go to trial next September.

“We’d find out more about who knew what was going on. There would be a better indication of how widespread the knowledge was,” Dlab said.

Wedge suggested the defence lawyers are being vague about what evidence they would call if a full hearing were held and how it would assist her on deciding the abuse-of-process motion.

“Surely the court’s entitled to know the parameters of the evidence that you intend to call so that I can determine whether an evidentiary hearing will assist in determining the issues before me?” Wedge said. “I am not embarking on a hearing where the parameters are absolutely completely unknown and in a sense that’s what the applicants are asking me to do.”

kbolan@vancouversun.com

column2: Surrey Six murder trial: Key witness told by police that gang would kill him, court hears
column3:
The Balmoral parkade where three men exited on the afternoon of the Surrey Six murders in 2007. Handout/...

RCMP Cpl. Graeme Matthews leaves the courtroom after giving evidence in the Surrey Six murder trial in Vancouver October 15, 2013. He video-taped suite 1505 on Oct 20, 2007, after the six murders. Gerry Kahrmann/PNG

Eileen Mohan speaks to media outside BC Supreme Court in Vancouver, BC, September 30, 2013. Her son Chris Mohan was killed in a Surrey high rise. Three accused are facing trial. Arlen Redekop/PNG

A photo of Chris Mohan, 22, downloaded from Facebook as a tribute to him by friends. Mohan was one of two uninvolved bystanders killed in the Surrey Six case. /Vancouver Sun

Shell casings from suite 1505 where the Surrey Six murders took place. Handout/RCMP

An Ultra Star pistol jammed between a desk and wall at the Surrey Six crime scene. Handout/RCMP

Shell casings from suite 1505 where the Surrey Six murders took place. Handout/RCMP

Crown witness, Cpl. Lori Orstad, testified at the Surrey Six trial that she saw this VW Touareg while she was doing drug squad surveillance outside the Stanley on Oct. 19, 2007. ../Court exhibit

The black BMW that police say was used in the Surrey Six murders. Handout/RCMP

A Red Scorpion tattoo. The Crown contends that Cody Haevischer, Matthew Johnston and Michael Le were all members of the Red Scorpion gang when they plotted to kill rival drug trafficker Corey Lal on Oct. 19, 2007 and that the other victims - Michael Lal, Eddie Narong, Ryan Bartolomeo, Chris Mohan and Ed Schellenberg - were killed to eliminate witnesses. Handout/RCMP

Eileen Mohan speaks outside of B.C. Supreme Court in downtown Vancouver on November 28, 2013 following Michael Le pleading guilty to conspiracy to commit the murder of Corey Lal in 2007. Mohan's sun was an innocent bystander who got killed in the crossfire that left six people dead. Jenelle Schneider/PNG

Cody Haevischer is one of three men going to trial for murder on Monday in the Surrey Six case. Handout/Vancouver Sun

A police car outside the building where the Surrey Six Massacre took place. Ian Smith/Vancouver Sun files

A young drug dealer who lived in the Balmoral Tower in 2007 testified at the Surrey Six trial Tuesday about handing over his electronic key fob to accused killer Matt Johnston on the day of the murders. PNG files/...

METRO VANCOUVER — A key witness at the Surrey Six trial was told by police that the Red Scorpion gang would kill him if he didn’t cooperate in the murder case, B.C. Supreme Court heard Wednesday.

The witness, who can only be identified as DY due to a publication ban, agreed under cross-examination that police repeatedly warned him during a 2008 interview that his life was in danger from his former gang associates.

DY testified Tuesday that he gave his electronic key fob for the Balmoral Tower to accused killer Matt Johnston on the day of the murders.

DY also said that he wasn’t told why the gang needed the fob on Oct. 19, 2007, but cooperated as he sold crack and heroin for the Scorpions and hoped to become a full member some day.

But Johnston’s lawyer Mike Tammen suggested Wednesday that DY got his story from the police, who told the young dealer that Johnston was involved in the murders.

"They told you that Matt Johnston was one of the Surrey Six killers," Tammen said.

DY replied: "They did mention his name. I don’t remember what they said about the role he played."

Tammen went over a lengthy interview DY had with police after he was arrested in February 2008 in connection with the murders of drug dealer Corey Lal, his brother Michael, associates Eddie Narong and Ryan Bartolomeo and bystanders Chris Mohan and Ed Schellenberg.

Tammen said retired Mountie Don Adam, who was part of the interview team, "told you that Matt Johnston was the person to whom you gave your FOB."

DY said he couldn’t remember the specifics of what was said.

Tammen said "a theme" of police during DY’s interview was "that you were in danger of being killed by members of the Red Scorpions, correct."

DY agreed.

Tammen read from a transcript of the interview where Adam told DY that he was "a huge liability" and a "loose end" to the Red Scorpions.

"You are at that absolute crossroad right now, right?" Adam said. "Because you are, right now, either a guy who wanted those murders to occur or you are somebody who has gotten used. Only you can explain that."

Tammen noted that police told DY several times that he could go to prison for 25 years because his fob was used by the killers.

"Three guys came and they went up to 1505 where they murdered in cold blood six people," Tammen read from the transcript. "They butchered them. And DY, you by virtue of the laws of Canada assisted those people and are guilty of the murders as well as them, and DY you are going to be punished."

DY told Justice Catherine Wedge that it he agreed to cooperate after seeing videos of the families of the victims and not because of the threat of prison or fear of Red Scorpion reprisals.

He testified that he broke down and cried during the police interview after he saw the videos as well as photos of the crime scene.

During the 2008 interview, DY expressed concern for his family’s safety, but was reassured by the police that they would be looked after.

And he told investigators he "got tricked into giving the FOB to someone."

He also identified several Red Scorpion members to police by the pseudonyms they used, including Johnston, aka Josh, and Surrey Six co-accused Cody Haevischer, who he knew as Blake.

The trial continues.

kbolan@vancouversun.com

Read my blog: The Real Scoop

Follow me: @KBolan

column2: Victoria to Maui yacht race a high-pressure affair
column3:
String Theory rides out the doldrums on the way to Maui.

The crew of String Theory celebrate their second overall and first in Division 2 finish at the end of the 2014 VicMaui race.

Fifteen boats competed in the biannual Vic-Maui International Yacht race starting in early July, and the 2014 event saw it all.

From light winds to storms, from idle fishing in the doldrums to tricky navigation around the high pressure zones; it was all there. Great memories were made yet again and we all look forward to the 50th anniversary race in 2016.

The race started in Victoria and took the competitors across the Pacific to Lahaina, Maui; more than 4,000 kilometres away. Most boats took around 14 days to complete one of the world’s longest ocean races.

This year’s competition was very challenging, as the Pacific high that has traditionally developed by this time of the year was split into several high pressure zones.

While high pressure brings us sunny weather in Vancouver, sailors dread it as there is no wind in the centre of a high. The fleet soon split into two groups, one seeking a more westerly path between two distinct high pressure zones, the other staying closer east hoping for stronger winds closer to shore.

Both groups had to endure days of light winds making little progress to Maui, sails flapping idly under the scorching sun. The sailors worked to make some headway towards the elusive trade winds, the day only broken by the lonely flying fish and the odd tuna slicing through the water.

Rumour has it that some competitors passed the time fishing or going for a swim. After days of crawling across the Pacific, the fleet finally reached the trade winds. Competitors who decided on the more westerly route came out on top and enjoyed sailing in a solid breeze, while the other boats farther east had to wait a little longer to enjoy the fresh breeze.

This year’s Vic-Maui race saw its share of excitement. Early on, Anduril lost steering and had to hobble into San Francisco under emergency steering. Kinetic lost two steering cables but had a third in store that got them to Maui. Strong winds and sudden squalls shredded thousands of dollars worth of sails on different boats.

A final storm near the finish line tore through the fleet with brute force, bringing down the mast of Kahuna and ripping up the main sail on Turicum. Luckily, nobody was hurt and all boats made it safely into port. The sail lofts back in Vancouver are looking forward to the fleet’s return.

Long Board crossed the finish line at Kaanapali first and took the overall win. String Theory won their division and took second overall.

Volunteer and sponsors from Lahaina organized a welcome party for each boat and sailors’ families and friends. Mai Tais and champagne flowed freely no matter the time of day or night as the sailors crossed the finish line.

For more information on the race, visit vicmaui.org

The Vic-Maui race would not be complete without a few days of R-and-R on Maui. The island has every thing one can dream of: Turquoise water and sandy beaches for swimming and surfing, mountains to climb, seaside restaurants serving delicious fare, sublime snorkelling, sailing, paragliding, fishing and there is even a submarine.

One of my favourite beaches is Baby Beach, just outside of Lahaina. A reef breaks the waves, making it perfect for families with small children. If you want to give surfing a go, head to the beach just north of Lahaina for the perfect wave. The adventurous can rent a car and drive the road to Hana.

To escape the heat, you can get to the north end of Maui or even drive up Haleakala, one of the worlds’ largest dormant volcanoes.

For accommodation, I personally favour the hotels or small condo complexes in Lahaina over the large resorts of Kaanapali. You can walk everywhere in Lahaina: Down to Front Street for a dinner overlooking the ocean, having a swim or going surfing on the beach or picking up some fresh fruit from the local market.

As I am writing these lines I am sailing aboard String Theory about 500 miles north of Maui, returning the boat back to Vancouver together with her owners and a group of students.

Stay tuned for more stories from the high seas, fishing for Mahi Mahi and gorgeous sunset on the Pacific Ocean. In the meantime you can follow our progress here.

Aloha!

Christof Marti is the owner of Simply Sailing School in Vancouver (simplysailing.ca) and is a both director on the Board of BC Sailing and the Vancouver Rowing Club. Trained as an engineer and with an MBA in finance, Christof is also a qualified sailing instructor and a certified Yachtmaster. He will be filing reports from B.C.’s coastal waters over the season.

column2: Federal agency urged to expand assessment of Roberts Bank container project
column3:
Two endangered resident killer whales spyhop as a freighter passes through their critical habitat in Haro Strait, between Victoria and Washingtons San Juan Island. Photo credit: beamreach.org/marine bank beamreach.org/marine bank/Vancouver Sun

Aboriginal, conservation and community groups are demanding that a federal environmental review of the $2-billion Roberts Bank Terminal 2 container expansion project in South Delta include a range of marine issues that extend well beyond the project’s immediate footprint.

The concern is that Port Metro Vancouver is investigating only marine-related impacts — spills, ship collisions and effects such as noise pollution on endangered resident killer whales — within its navigational jurisdiction, a distance of only a few kilometres from the project site.

Vancouver lawyer Rosanne Kyle, representing the Pacheedaht First Nation of Port Renfrew on southern Vancouver Island, says in a submission to the Canadian Environmental Assessment Agency that container ships bound for Roberts Bank would pass through her client’s traditional territory.

Natives are concerned about risks of contamination and disturbance to the marine environment, especially alongside other projects such as the planned twinning of the Kinder Morgan pipeline, which has received far more publicity. She urged CEAA to adopt terms of reference that include the wider impact of shipping associated with the Roberts Bank project, especially as it relates to aboriginal rights and treaties.

BC Nature (the Federation of BC Naturalists) said in a separate submission that the project “will have a highly detrimental effect on the natural values of Roberts Bank, and puts at risk the ongoing viability of this critically important avian flyway. In addition, the ensuing large increase in shipping from the port through the Georgia Strait, Southern Gulf Islands and Strait of Juan de Fuca would severely threaten the integrity of these marine ecosystems.”

The planned new terminal at Roberts Bank would be located next to the existing Deltaport and Westshore Terminals and would provide an additional 2.4 million units of container capacity per year. In 2013, Port Metro Vancouver moved the equivalent of 2.8 million 20-foot container units.

“People don’t realize how big this is and the potential impacts,” said Roger Emsley of Against Port Expansion and a member of the port’s liaison committee.

Other concerns relate to increased rail and road traffic, noise and light pollution, and the habitat of juvenile salmon.

Emsley is arguing for an independent environmental assessment into the project, not one conducted by consultants hired by the port.

The port suggests the initial construction is worth about $500 million in wages. During full operation, it would directly employ 7,600 and contribute $1.2 billion to the gross domestic product.

The port estimates 260 vessels would visit the terminal annually, which translates into 520 transits through local waters.

The public comment period on the project’s draft terms of reference ended Sept. 22.

Debra Myles, panel manager for CEAA, noted in an email to port environmental manager Kyle Robertson dated Oct. 3, 2014: “Several submissions maintained that the federal environmental assessment should include the potential effects of container ship traffic activities which are not part of the project as defined for the environmental assessment.”

The port has not yet replied to the email.

Rhona Hunter, port director of infrastructure sustainability, explained in an interview that light emanating from the project and extending beyond the port’s jurisdiction to impact communities would fall within an environmental assessment. A spill from a container ship or a ship collision outside the port’s jurisdiction would not.

Likewise, while the port is considering the impact of the Roberts Bank expansion on endangered resident killer whales within its jurisdiction, it is also considering whether ship noise created within its jurisdiction must be studied because it can travel much farther underwater.

“That’s part of the assessment, to determine the range that noise travels,” said Hunter.

The port’s jurisdiction extends about 1.7 kilometres south of the project site and 11 kilometres west.

Port spokesman John Parker-Jervis noted that the new terminal would only handle containers, meaning the “risks and magnitude of a potential oil spill are limited to the bunker fuel that is onboard any vessels that would call on the new terminal.”

On Dec. 23, 1988, the Sause Brothers barge Nestucca released about 87,400 litres of bunker oil off Grays Harbor, Wash. The oil drifted northward with the currents, including up to the west coast of Vancouver Island as far as Cape Scott. The oil washed up on beaches, and up to 56,000 seabirds are thought to have died. Crab, shellfish and herring were affected along with native fishing practices.

The port’s environmental assessment should be concluded in early 2015.

Once the federal Minister of the Environment appoints a review panel, it will have 14 months to conduct its review, including public hearings, but not including time required by Port Metro Vancouver to gather information required for the environmental assessment.

Last June, CEAA announced the allocation of about $450,000 to 13 applicants — mostly aboriginal groups from Metro Vancouver and southern Vancouver Island — to support their participation in the environmental assessment of the proposed Roberts Bank Terminal 2.

If approved, the project would be completed in the mid-2020s.

When Port Metro Vancouver conducted its own review of a planned $15-million coal-loading facility at Fraser Surrey Docks, it studied the impacts of the project footprint but not the greater impacts associated with increased rail traffic. The project was approved in August despite widespread concerns involving human and environmental health, including by provincial health authorities.

Surrey individuals and organizations opposed to the coal facility have applied to the Federal Court of Canada for a judicial review of that decision.

lpynn@vancouversun.com

To watch a video related to the project, visit http://www.robertsbankterminal2.com/
