column2: Gas prices continue to slide in Metro Vancouver
column3:
LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 16: A man pumps gas at a 76 gas station on July 16, 2013 in Los Angeles, California. Higher gas prices have spurred a 0.5 percent rise in the consumer price index, the largest increase since February. /Montreal Gazette

The price for petrol dipped below a dollar a litre in Abbotsford this week as world gas prices continue to slump. The downshift from four figure gas prompted some residents to post pictures of pump prices that had fallen a low as 98.9 cents at that city’s Costco by late Friday, according to gasbuddy.com. Aaron Campbell/Twitter (@AaCamp81)

METRO VANCOVER – The cost of gas continues to drop in Metro Vancouver as world oil prices slump, with prices at some stations 25 cents a litre cheaper than this time last year.

The average price of gas in the region today is a little over 107.8 cents a litre, according to GasBuddy.com, a website that records gas prices from stations’ posted price. But in many areas of Vancouver the prices were less, as low as 105.9 cents. In Port Coquitlam on Friday, gas was posted at 103.9 cents.

That’s down significantly from just a week a go, when gas prices were on average around 112.4 cents a litre, and this time last year the average price in Metro Vancouver was 125.6 a litre.

Last week, the price for petrol dipped below a dollar a litre in Abbotsford. Residents posted pump prices as a low as 98.9 cents at that city’s Costco by late Friday.

Just six months ago, a litre of gas in Abbotsford was going for 142.8 cents. Gas has yet to reach the dollar mark in Vancouver, but at a little over 105 cents, it’s getting close.

A decade ago, gas in the city was going for 76 cents a litre.

Meantime, Statistics Canada said Friday a big drop in prices at the pump helped slow Canada’s annual inflation rate last month to 2.0 per cent.

Gasoline prices were 5.9 per cent lower than a year earlier amid a global slide in world oil prices, StatsCan said. The agency’s gasoline price index fell 7.5 per cent in November — the fifth consecutive monthly decrease.

ticrawford@vancouversun.com.

with files from Matthew Robinson and The Canadian Press

column2: ‘No-name’ NPA gears up for civic campaign
column3:
With just six months to go before the Nov. 15 civic election, there is little public sign that the Non-Partisan Association, once Vancouver’s dominant party, is ready to mount a campaign. No one has publicly stuck up their hand to run for mayor, and the only people confirmed running for office are the six incumbent councillors, park board commissioners and school trustees.

But the lack of activity doesn’t mean the NPA isn’t girding for a fight with incumbent Mayor Gregor Robertson and his Vision Vancouver party.

NPA president Peter Armstrong said his party has decided — like Vision Vancouver — to run partial slates for council, park board and school board. It has also narrowed its choice of mayoral candidates down to a handful and has spent months interviewing and checking the credentials of a number of candidates for the three offices. He said the party will likely announce its candidate list within weeks.

One person whose name won’t be on the mayoral list is developer and NPA vice-president Rob Macdonald, who confirmed Monday that he has — for the second time in as many elections — decided not to run for office. Former Liberal MLA and finance minister Colin Hansen also confirmed to The Sun several months ago that he had been asked by the NPA to run but decided to continue with his retirement.

Former Vancouver Sun managing editor Kirk LaPointe, now publisher at Self-Counsel Press, said Tuesday he’d been approached by the NPA. He said he had submitted information to the party but would not say whether he is interested in running for mayor or council.

“They asked if I would be interested in municipal politics,” LaPointe said. “I am keenly interested in the future of the city and I find that interesting. It is premature for me or anyone else to say I am a candidate at any level because there is a process underway and I am not in control of it. The party is in control of it.”

Macdonald said he had considered running for mayor but bowed out in part because he was concerned Vision Vancouver would make him “a lightning rod” for an attack campaign. Macdonald was the campaign finance chair for mayoral candidate Suzanne Anton in the last election campaign, when he donated more than $960,000 to the NPA — in part, he said, because he had been distracted from his fundraising goals because of the illness of a close friend. As a result, he made the donations personally to meet his pledge to assist Anton.

Macdonald said he has been told by several people that Vision Vancouver had plans to use his history — whatever that might mean — to attack the NPA.

“They’ve got a whole bunch of people in communications developing attack strategies … I don’t want to be the lightning rod for the party. It should really be about how to run the city and it shouldn’t be about Rob MacDonald. It is about who is best qualified to run the city,” he said. “I have met the candidates, and any one of them could do a way better job than the current mayor. So it doesn’t have to be Rob MacDonald. There are other qualified people.”

Armstrong would not confirm any names of those who put themselves forward for the NPA.

Coun. Elizabeth Ball, the chair of the NPA’s six-member caucus, said the party has been determined to find the right candidates and avoid the kind of costly election mistakes that have caused trouble in the past.

The NPA suffered through a nasty internal fight when it dumped Mayor Philip Owen in favour of Jennifer Clarke for the 2002 election, only to lose all but two seats on council. In 2008, the party split again when Mayor Sam Sullivan was dumped in favour of ex-councillor and businessman Peter Ladner, and the NPA was reduced to a single seat.

“It is the first time I have seen a process this tough,” she said of the NPA’s vetting system. ”They really are doing their homework so that there aren’t any surprises in the middle of the campaign. You don’t find out somebody has written something shocking. They are spending their time doing this. The truth is they are trying not to end up in any difficult situations, by getting really top people in those positions.”

Ball suggested the silence so far from the party is not unusual.

“It may be frustrating to outside people who want news right now, but all of us feel confident right now that the people who are going to be recommended are going to be top-notch people who have served the community in many ways,” she said, adding the party’s strategy is still to field enough candidates to form government.

“Oh, I think they are working very hard to get a team that can change the government. I think they really want to succeed in having a majority on council. I think that is absolutely the goal and that is why they are being so careful of who they are moving forward with,” she said.

jefflee@vancouversun.com

Twitter.com/sunciviclee

Blog: www.vancouversun.com/jefflee

column2: Delays, apparent lack of consultations delay action on Highway of Tears
column3:
Shawn MacMillen, brother of murder victim Colleen MacMillen, pauses for a moment during a news conference in Surrey, B.C., Tuesday, September 25, 2012. RCMP say they believe a deceased Oregon inmate is responsible for at least one of the murders along British Columbia's so-called Highway of Tears. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Jonathan Hayward

Highway 16 between Prince Rupert and Prince George, known as The Highway of Tears, where many women have vanished or been found murdered over a period of more than 40 years. Ian Smith/Vancouver Sun

VANCOUVER – A year and a half after a public inquiry called for urgent action to protect women along a stretch of highway in northern British Columbia known as the Highway of Tears, mayors and other leaders in the region say the province has yet to contact them about what needs to happen.

Internal briefing notes also indicate a team of bureaucrats assigned to hold consultations with communities along Highway 16, where women have been disappearing or turning up dead for decades, have put that work on hold for much of the past year.

What emerges is a picture of slow progress that appears to contradict the province’s claims that it has been busy holding a “tremendous number” of meetings about the issue with local governments.

A public inquiry into the Robert Pickton case also examined the phenomenon of murdered and missing women in the province’s north, in particular along the highway between Prince Rupert on the coast and Prince George, a nine-hour drive to the east.

At least 17 women, many of them aboriginal, have vanished or been murdered along Highway 16 and the adjacent Highways 97 and 5 since the 1970s. Most of the cases remain unsolved, though investigators don’t believe a single killer is responsible.

Much of the discussion about the Highway of Tears has focused on a lack of affordable transportation connecting isolated communities, which has led some women to resort to hitchhiking.

First Nations leaders released a report in 2006 recommending a shuttle bus along the highway.

Public inquiry commissioner Wally Oppal produced a report in December 2012 with more than 60 recommendations. Among them, Oppal endorsed the 2006 report and urged the province to “immediately” commit to developing an improved public transit system for the Highway of Tears, in consultation with local governments.

“I don’t know who they’ve been talking to, but they haven’t been talking to the mayor of Prince Rupert,” said Mayor Jack Mussallem, whose community of 13,500 people is located 750 kilometres northwest of Vancouver.

“I’m starting to get a little concerned about whether or not we’re going to see anything. … It’s not an issue that’s going to go away, and hopefully it’s somewhere on their priority list.”

Mayors or city staff in Terrace, Smithers, Vanderhoof, Houston, Fraser Lake and Telkwa said they, too, have not been directly contacted to formally discuss the Highway of Tears issue.

The tribal chief of the Carrier Sekani Tribal Council and the chair of the Regional District of Bulkley-Nechako also said they had not been approached by the province.

Documents obtained by The Canadian Press through a freedom-of-information request indicate there was some work done in early 2013.

Staff within the Transportation Ministry and assistant deputy ministers from three different ministries were assigned to the file.

They identified potential stakeholders and compiled a list of existing transportation options in the region. A status report from February 2013 indicates staff held an initial meeting with the North Central Local Government Association that month.

But by the summer, the work appears to have wound down, according to the documents.

The families of four women connected to the Pickton case filed the first in a series of lawsuits last May, prompting the province to warn that it’s work on Oppal’s recommendations would be constrained by the legal process. None of the lawsuits involved women whose deaths or disappearances were linked to the Highway of Tears.

A Transportation Ministry briefing note in July said staff had not planned any further consultations because of the lawsuits, and the ministry confirmed in a statement last week that consultations had been “put on hold so as not to compromise the legal process.”

The province settled the lawsuits in March.

Transportation Minister Todd Stone told the legislature in April that “there have been a tremendous number of discussions and meetings that have been held, particularly with local government officials, community organizations and other stakeholders throughout the corridor.”

When asked what meetings had actually taken place, the Transportation Ministry identified only two: the February 2013 meeting with the North Central Local Government Association and a meeting last November with the Omineca Beetle Action Coalition, a group of northern mayors and regional district chairs, to discuss “rural and northern transportation challenges.” Another meeting with the action coalition is set for May, the ministry said.

The ministry also noted BC Transit has been talking to northern communities about the possibility of expanding bus service.

Justice Minister Suzanne Anton declined an interview request. Instead, she issued a written statement repeating her previous comments that the issue is complex and that the government is committed to protecting vulnerable women.

A report released by the Justice Ministry last fall said staff had identified potential transportation options for the Highway of Tears and expected to begin consultations soon, though it provided no details.

Anton has insisted the highway is safer than it was 15 years ago and she noted there are several transportation options already in place, including local public transit, Greyhound bus service, rail service and a regional health bus that transports patients from rural communities to medical appointments.

Maurine Karagianis, the Opposition NDP critic for women’s issues, said the Liberal government has done nothing new to improve safety along Highway 16 since the public inquiry report. She also pointed out Greyhound dramatically cut its service last year, which means the situation is actually worse.

“It’s a mystery to me why the government hasn’t made more progress on this,” said Karagianis.

“All of the comments the minister (Anton) has made show how incredibly out of touch she and the government are.”

Terry Teegee, the tribal chief of the Carrier Sekani Tribal Council, said he’s disappointed, but not surprised, by the lack of progress on the issue.

“I think their lack of initiative just to look into the feasibility of this shows that it’s not a priority for them,” said Teegee, whose niece, Ramona Wilson, vanished in June 1994 and was found dead 10 months later.

Teegee disputed the government’s claim that the highway is safe.

“There are still woman going missing,” he said.

“This (proposed) shuttle service and other things that we are doing are to try to prevent this from happening.”

___

Follow @ByJamesKeller on Twitter

column2: BCSC hearing opens into allegations against The Falls financier
column3:
The British Columbia Securities Commission has opened a hearing into allegations that a promoter raising financing for Chilliwack’s The Falls Resort siphoned off money for his own use.

In its notice of hearing, commission staff alleges that Rodney Jack Wharram raised $9.35 million from investors through two companies between December 2006 and October 2010 that was supposed to be used to develop recreational property for the resort, but that only $3.6 million was forwarded to the developer.

Commission staff also allege that Wharram used $469,000 for his own purposes, including $130,000 to purchase his own home, a $240,000 loan to his wife and the purchase of a $24,000 diamond ring for his wife.

Owners of The Falls had ambitious plans to expand the resort with a $250-million winter club and considerable residential real estate, but ran into financial difficulties that saw the resort seek protection from creditors in 2011.

The commission alleges that when The Falls sought protection, Wharram sold his companies’ creditor claims against the development for $63,779, but spent $47,500 of the proceeds for personal expenses. Lastly, the commission alleges Wharram lied to its staff during a 2013 investigation.

During an interview in March 2013, Wharram told the commission he was no longer raising funds through his companies, but according to the notice of hearing, commission staff have evidence that he raised a further $450,000.

None of the allegations have been proven before the hearing panel.

Wharram, who is representing himself, said he will extensively cross-examine the BCSC’s lead investigator on the case, Liz Chan, and that questioning her investigation will be key to his defence, according to hearing transcripts.

The commission issued a temporary order last June barring Wharram and his related companies — The Falls Capital Corp., Deercrest Construction Fund Inc. and West Karma Ltd.— from selling the companies’ securities and prohibiting him from acting as the director of a company or engaging in investor relations before a hearing of the allegations.

The hearing opened Monday. Paige Leggat, counsel for the commission’s executive director, said she plans to call nine witnesses in the enforcement staff’s case.

depenner@vancouversun.com

Follow me: @DerrickPenner

column2: Mortgage holder shouldn't lose interest in Surrey marijuana grow-op property, judge rules
column3:
METRO VANCOUVER — A trust company that financed a Surrey house later used for a sophisticated marijuana grow operation did their due diligence before providing the mortgage, the B.C. Supreme Court has ruled.

Justice Brian Joyce said this week that the Maple Trust Company should not have to forfeit its interest in the house at 1173 – 160th Street to the government.

Federal Crown prosecutors had argued that Maple Trust should have checked into claims by Kien Tam Nguyen and his wife Nga Thuy Nguyen that they earned $95,000 a year as mushroom farmers before helping the couple buy the house.

Tax records found in the residence during an RCMP raid in 2003 showed the couple’s annual income was less than $10,500 at the time the mortgage was obtained.

The case has been before various courts for more than a decade.

The Nguyens were convicted of producing marijuana and received a conditional sentence of 18 months in March 2006. They were also ordered to forfeit their equity in the property.

They appealed to the Supreme Court of Canada and lost in 2009.

The Crown had also served Maple Trust with a notice of forfeiture of its interest in the house. The lender had provided a mortgage of $281,250.00, when the Nguyen’s bought the $375,000 house in late 2002.

Maple Trust fought back in B.C. Supreme Court, arguing that it shouldn’t have to hand over its interest in the property.

The case was heard over several days in the spring of 2012, with Joyce issuing his ruling Wednesday.

He accepted evidence from witnesses for Maple Trust who testified that the procedures used by the company for "non-income-qualified mortgage loans" like that obtained by the Nguyens were the same as those of other financial institutions at the time.

The Nguyens had claimed the husband was self-employed and had assets worth $344,000.00, including $140,000.00 on deposit with the Royal Bank. "

Maple Trust underwriter Sannie Fisher testified "that it was not Maple Trust’s policy to independently verify income, perform corporate searches or obtain criminal record checks with regard to borrowers."

"Ms. Fisher had not been cautioned in any way, in 2002, that marijuana grow-ops in residential properties were a significant problem in British Columbia," Joyce said.

He ruled "the steps taken by Maple Trust were reasonable in the circumstances, particularly when viewed from the perspective of a reasonable mortgage lender for the acquisition of residential property in 2002."

"I do not accept that Maple Trust should be denied relief from forfeiture because it failed to make independent inquiries of Mr. Nguyen’s amount and source of income," Joyce said.

kbolan@vancouversun.com

read my blog: vancouversun.com/therealscoop

follow me: twitter.com/kbolan

read the full ruling here: http://www.courts.gov.bc.ca/jdb-txt/SC/14/00/2014BCSC0055.htm

column2: Park board chairwoman Sharma to seek city council nomination
column3:
VANCOUVER – Vision Vancouver park board chairwoman Niki Sharma said Wednesday she will seek a nomination for city council.

Sharma, 34, a lawyer and new mother, was elected to her first term with the park board in 2011. She said she wants to move over to city council because she’s interested in citywide political issues.

Sharma is the second park board commissioner to indicate interest in running for council.

Melissa De Genova, one of two Non-Partisan Association commissioners, said she also plans to run for council following an NPA review of candidates.

The announcements come a day after the province said it will introduce changes to election rules to extend terms of office from three years to four.

Under Vision’s rules, Sharma will have to seek nomination in June for any positions left open after the party conducts a review vote of incumbents at its annual general meeting May 4.

Stepan Vdovine, Vision’s executive director, said incumbents wanting to move to a different level of office will not be given a leadership review in May and instead will have to submit to a separate nomination vote in June.

He said about two dozen people who have indicated they want to run for office under Vision will go through a vetting process before the June meeting.

The announcements come amid growing interest from people wanting to run in the November election.

Vision has not yet decided if it will run a full slate of candidates for council, park board and school board, Vdovine said. In the 2011 election Vision ran partial slates to help the Coalition of Progressive Electors, which shared some political views. However, in recent months, COPE has said it won’t split campaigns with Vision and intends to run its own full slates.

Natasha Westover, the NPA’s campaign director, said her party has received more than 100 expressions of interest from people wanting to run for office.

Sharma has received the backing of several Vision Vancouver councillors, including Geoff Meggs and Andrea Reimer, as well as school board chairwoman Patti Bacchus.

De Genova said that in recent weeks she has been encouraged by friends and voters to run for the NPA on council.

There are eight Vision council members, including Mayor Gregor Robertson. George Affleck and Elizabeth Ball have indicated they will likely seek re-election as NPA councillors. Adriane Carr, the Green party councillor, is also seeking re-election.

jefflee@vancouversun.com

Twitter.com/sunciviclee

Blog: www.vancouversun.com/jefflee

column2: Vaughn Palmer: Premier uses legislature appearance to toy with New Democrats
column3:
VICTORIA — For an entire question period one day this week, Premier Christy Clark took to the floor to answer for the B.C. Liberal side, and alternatively taunted and toyed with the New Democratic Party Opposition.

From the outset Wednesday, Clark saw where the New Democrats were headed with a line of questions about the government’s ethnic outreach scandal, and refused to play along.

“I think the members of the Opposition, rather than standing up here in this kind of theatrical farce — (should) just get the end of the book and let us know what’s going on.”

She reminded the NDP how the scandal had fared as a deciding issue in the last election: “These issues were talked about very extensively in this legislature, outside of it and then during the election campaign. Despite all of these issues having been raised, British Columbians said they wanted this government to serve them.”

She ridiculed: “I have to assume that the question bank for the Opposition’s research group is running a little bit low. Of course, if they don’t have any questions about the current workings of government, perhaps they could ask (MLA Andrew Weaver) of the Green party to get up. I know he’s always got something smart to say.”

She suggested alternatives: “I had thought that members might have some very vital questions about education, vital questions about what’s going on with Mount Polley, vital questions about what’s going on with the coroner’s inquest in Burns Lake for the Lake Babine mill. What about questions with respect to ferries? All of those are issues that we would be very, very happy to talk about in question period.”

She turned tables and asked questions herself: “Do they want a balanced budget, or do they want to stand by all those election promises that would have meant digging into taxpayers’ pockets for $2 billion more?”

She mock-sympathized: “We’ve all had losses in our lives and things that we regret and things that we wish we’d done differently. I take it that the members didn’t feel like they adequately canvassed all these issues a couple of years ago … so now they want to consume a question period talking about those things again.”

She just plain mocked: “They will have to change their name from the NDP to the Irrelevant Party one of these days soon.”

All this to thunderous desk-thumping and applause from her own troops, joined by Green MLA Weaver himself when Clark declared: “In this question period we have never seen a better and stronger argument for official party status for the Greens.”

All the while the New Democrats looked pretty downcast and afterwards mounted a defence-cum-excuse for what they had tried and mostly failed to accomplish.

The goal was to take advantage of one of the premier’s occasional appearances in the house to breathe second life into the scandal — Liberals scheming to use public resources to further the party’s partisan interests with various ethnic communities — that played out in the early months of 2013.

Not all of the questions were backdated, notwithstanding the premier’s taunts.

But the New Democrats choose to front-end-load their attack with concerns that were widely reported in 2013. “Blamelines in ethnic outreach debacle run straight to premier,” as the headline on one of my columns had it in the run-up to the election.

By the time Wednesday that Opposition MLAs had put aside the old news and zeroed in on the more recent developments — the laying of charges in September against two of those connected to the affair — they’d lost whatever initiative existed for them at the outset.

After 18 questions pitched by nine NDP MLAs, Opposition House Leader Mike Farnworth, batting cleanup as he often does, summed up the main point for his side about the multiple players in the scandal:

“They’re the premier’s people. They weren’t inherited. No one forced them upon this government. No one forced them upon this government. Two of those operatives and the company they own are facing charges for Election Act violations. According to the special prosecutor, there may be more to come.”

He spoke those words after the clock had run out, Speaker Linda Reid having exercised her discretion to briefly extend the usual 30 minutes set aside for question period.

Whether that extension was in the interest of the Opposition is open to debate. For by then, there was no moving the premier off her game.

“Well, I have to say I’m disappointed,” she scoffed in closing for her side. “After all of that run-up, a half-hour of question period asking the same question again and again, they finally get to the punchline, and it just wasn’t that good.”

No mercy, in other words. But the lack of respect is mutual and holds many risks for the Opposition in seeking to defeat the government next time.

The New Democrats don’t appear to have gotten over losing the last election to Clark, for they continue to discount her abilities as a communicator, a leader and a premier. Having underestimated both her abilities and her chances before the election, I understand how that can happen.

But unless the New Democrats start taking the premier more seriously than they have done to date, they risk more encounters where they don’t lay a glove on her.
